Amit Modi of a drug wholesaler company near PMCH said he was facing difficulties in supplying medicines to pharmacies. “The supply chain has been disrupted. Most of the staff members are staying at home. Supplying medicines without manpower is next to impossible. Besides, around 50-60% of the medical shops in the city are shut,” he said.Amit said people crowding Machuatoli and Govind Mitra Road most of the time is another reason for the disturbance in supply.Retail drugstores also apprehend shortage of medicines in the coming days. “Stocks of some medicines are over. People bought medicines in bulk till Tuesday. Now, we are selling medicines that are available at the shop,” said Vishal, an employee at a medical store in Danapur.Elderly people and people with underlying diseases, including diabetes, kidney and heart problems, said the shortage of medicines might aggravate their conditions. “I have an increased level of sugar and I get it tested every day at home. I also take five medicines everyday. Even though my son has stocked medicines for 30 days, I am scared about the consequences I might face in case I don’t get the medicines thereafter,” said Manorma Devi, a resident of Saguna Mor.

Title: Back from Mumbai, 19,000 people under home quarantine in Junnar
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Close to 19 ,000 people, mostly migrants who returned from Mumbai to their villages in Junnar taluka before the nationwide lockdown was imposed, have been put under home quarantine as a precautionary measure in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak.

Junnar tehsildar Hanumant Kolekar said the administration has formed 40 teams for regular health checks of these people. Most of them travelled by public transport and vehicles carrying vegetables from markets in Mumbai.

“The taluka has 184 villages, several hamlets, spread across hilly areas. The sources of livelihood are inadequate. Most of the people from Junnar work in big cities such as Mumbai and Pune. Our teams are visiting them every day,” he said.

At present, over 20,000 people are under home quarantine in rural Pune, said chief officer Ayush Prasad of the Pune zilla parishad . “Early detection of the virus-affected case, if any, is our first and foremost priority in the district. We have accordingly formulated our strategy. The Kerala government also managed to control the situation because of this tactic in their rural areas,” he said.

“Asha workers were working in tandem with the primary health centres across the district. We have specifically told them to inform those in charge of the health centre if they come across any person with symptoms such as cough, cold and fever. Our health centres are equipped with ambulances to shift patients, if needed,” Prasad said.

In Velhe taluka, all 106 people under home quarantine in 74 gram panchayats have tested negative. The administration also told those travelling from the city to villages to quarantine themselves as a precautionary measure.

Title: Villages in Pune prohibit entry of ‘outsiders’
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Many villages in Pune district have closed their entry points to keep ‘outsiders’ away in their bid to prevent Covid-19 spread.

The move follows Pune ZP’s recent circular to all gram panchayats, delegating powers to the sarpanch and executive body to take necessary measures to counter the situation at their level.

“Some gram panchayats have closed their villages for safety reasons. They are working in tandem with the respective police station and revenue officials,” ZP CEO Ayush Prasad said.

At some places, residents have even put up blockades to stop vehicles from entering their villages. “Most of the villagers have not taken the matter seriously or are unaware about the outbreak. So, we have blocked entry for outsiders. Our security personnel (villagers ) are allowing only for emergency works,” said Avinash Argade , Sarpanch of Kalus village in Khed tehsil.

“We have categorically told them not to restrict or ban entry to native person returning from cities like Pune and Mumbai. But for such people, home quarantine is mandatory, “ Prasad said.

The ZP has also told gram panchayats to create awareness about the virus. “We do not allow people to gather at the main square, which usually gets crowded” Sanjay Duandkar , a grampanchayat member of Shel Pimpalgaon village in Khed tehsil, said. Many villages have also cancelled their annual fairs. Even all social programmes are being conducted on low scale, said former Sarpanch Digambar Bhalchim of Malin village.

Title: Cops raid Somwar Peth godown, seize masks worth Rs 4.3 lakh
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police on Thursday raided a godown in Somwar Peth and arrested two men for illegally hoarding face masks worth Rs4.3 lakh.

The two men arrested are Bhupesh Omprakah Gupta (46)— a medicine-supplier and owner of the godown — and his employee, Rohan Ajay Shukla (26), both residents of Mundhwa Road.

At 3pm on Thursday, a team headed by deputy commissioner of police (crime) Bachchan Singh and senior inspector Arun Waykar — acting on reliable information — raided the godown, near Ladkat petrol pump at Narpatgiri Chowk, and seized 17,805 masks.

Police said as per the godown’s inventory, the stock of masks had been hoarded since March 21. According to police, Gupta wanted to create an artificial shortage in the market, where there is a high demand for masks in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, and sell them for a higher price than MRP.

“The masks are of different companies and meant for various purposes. The duo wanted to wait till there was a higher demand and sell the masks for an even higher price,” Waykar said.

Title: Pune: No requisition from state for army
Content: PUNE: The Southern Command on Friday issued a release stating that the Indian Army has not received any requisition for deployment and, as per inputs received from the state’s principal secretary (health), the arrangement was not envisaged at this stage. The Southern Command, however, assured the state government that it would extend full support to the civil administration to tackle the situation following the Covid-19 outbreak.

Title: Fields all ripe, but no labourer to cut crops in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The fields in Pune district are full of crops ready for harvest, but there’s no one to cut them as most farmhands have gone back to their native villages following the Covid-19 outbreak.

With hardly any worker available to reap the harvest, farmers fear that their produce will go to waste. Moreover, traders who collect the produce from the farmers have stopped coming after the lockdown came into force, fearing police action.

Sunita Daphal from Mulshi said that after cutting the rice crop, many farmers in Mulshi produce vegetables like tomato, cucumber and coriander till monsoon. “These crops are ready for harvest, but workers are not available to cut them. With three or four family members, it is not possible for us to cut and bring the produce to the city,” he said.

Hanumant Phuge from Nimgaon Indapur taluka said, “I produce vegetables and fruits. Everything will rot as there’s no one to cut the crops,” Phuge said.

He said that every day he cuts vegetables required for his family and goes home. “The government should do something about it,” Phuge said. At Aba Kale’s seven-acre farm in Solapur ’s Madha Taluka a crop of muskmelon is ready for harvest.

“It is not possible for me or my family members to cut the produce and sent it to the market,” he said.

Another farmer, Raju Pipare from Pimpalner near Indapur, said that all workers have gone back to their villages due to the coronavirus outbreak.

A grocery shopowner in Kothrud said that wholesalers have enough goods with them, but they cannot send them to retailers due to manpower shortage. “Wholesalers tell us to arrange a tempo and collect our orders. But is difficult to get tempos nowadays,” said a grocer.

Title: Sub-markets resume functioning at full capacity in Pune districts
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The city can expect more supply of vegetables as sub-markets in Moshi, Khadki and Uttamnagar have started functioning at full capacity, while the one at Manjari that was closed for two days will open on Saturday.

These markets supply vegetables and fruits to nearby retailers. The markets received less supply of vegetables for the past two days, while Manjari market remained closed.

The main wholesale market at Gultekdi had also been closed since March 25 after the traders and commission agents refused to work because of the novel coronavirus scare.

The officials of the Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) of Pune said markets will begin full-fledged unloading of vegetables and fruits by Saturday and added that steps were being taken to resume unloading and sale of vegetables at Gultekdi market from Sunday.

“The leafy vegetables are not fresh and those available are costly. We are left with no choice but to purchase potato, onions and tomato,” Megha Raje, a Shivajinagar resident, said.

A vegetable vendor from Aundh Road said supply on Friday had increased compared to the previous two days.

Vendors were also selling vegetables in tempos and handcarts in many areas of the city. “I purchased vegetables from Khadki market in the morning and will visit the residential areas nearby,” Kiran Dhakude , a tempo driver, said.

Meanwhile, officials from APMC said farmers will be able to bring their produce to Gultekdi market from Sunday. “We are expecting traders to resume transactions. If they do not, we plan to make adequate arrangements to unload vegetables sent by farmers and sell them to retailers,” an APMC official said.

The APMC on Friday said around 100 tempos carrying vegetables were unloaded at APMC despite the absence of traders. While traders in APMC Mumbai have resumed work, a similar decision is expected in Pune, a source from APMC said.

Title: Food apps’ employees get passes to make deliveries in Pune
Content:
It is a measure to enhance essential services to the maximum

PUNE: The city police on Friday started issuing passes to delivery personnel of various app-based food aggregators.

“For now, we are issuing a limited number of passes to each service provider based on a preliminary assessment of area-wise requirement,” joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve told TOI. Police have turned down requests for transferable passes to enforce social distancing.

The state government decided to allow reopening of eateries as part of its measures to ensure maximum essential services are made available to citizens so that they do not need to step out during the lockdown.

Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar was informed of the inconvenience people have been facing in trying to source cooked food during a meeting with officials on Friday. Pawar was told this was one of the main reasons why people stepped out.

Pawar asked hoteliers to provide delivery services at the gates of housing societies. He also instructed cooks and delivery personnel to take proper precautions and maintain hygiene.

Shisve said the Pune police were trying to ensure minimum inconvenience to the public. “We have been sensitizing policemen and public at more than 180 checkpoints since March 25,” he said.

Title: Delhi: Corporations may rope in retired employees if corona crisis deepens
Content: NEW DELHI: Amid growing concerns over rising novel coronavirus cases, the municipal bodies are planning to rope in retired public health officials to deal with any eventuality. Services of the officials who have prior experience of working during outbreaks of infectious diseases may come in handy if Covid-19 spreads further.At a corona preparedness review meeting held on Thursday, South Delhi Municipal Corporation SDMC ) commissioner Gyanesh Bharti directed all the deputy health officers of the four zones in south Delhi to prepare a list of the retired employees who are healthy.A senior public health official said that services of retired malaria inspectors, assistant malaria inspectors, senior malaria inspectors and other personnel have been utilised to control dengue in the past. “The civic bodies are discussing the idea of utilising services of retired corporation employees to deal with corona crisis on a contract basis. The retired people will supervise the work of domestic breeding checkers and nala beldars,” another official added.According to a official, SDMC has so far deployed 200 doctors, 750 nurses and over 1,000 domestic breeding checkers in various jobs, including contact tracing and sanitisation, to deal with the pandemic.“The staffers are busy sanitising parks, quarantined homes, offices and markets. We need people in supervisory roles to streamline the functioning of the field staff. Only retired people who are healthy will be engaged so that no one is put to risk,” the official said.The civic body has also started to train nala beldars for sodium hypochlorite sprinkling and disinfecting an area using knapsack pumps.The problem of shortage of staff in public health department across all three corporations is not new. The public health department of erstwhile unified MCD was expanded rapidly in 1978-79 when city faced a massive malaria crisis. But with large number of retirements of those recruits in last few years many of these posts are lying vacant. Some of the key posts like anti-malaria officers, senior malaria inspectors, malaria inspectors, assistant malaria inspectors and senior field workers witness over 50% vacancies.“These officers supervise the field staff, coordinate with RWAs and citizen groups, monitor the functioning of domestic breeding checkers, ensure fogging and fumigation, issue challans and prosecute violators. They basically ensure that the policy is implemented on ground,” said a public health official.

Title: Pvt sector ready, but all Covid-19 cases go to government hospitals
Content: Visakhapatnam: Even though the government has said both public and private hospitals can admit Covid-19 patients, as of now, in Visakhapatnam or in other districts of Andhra Pradesh, the suspects and Covid-19 positive cases are all being treated in government hospitals.A limited number of isolation and quarantine wards has been kept ready in major private hospitals as per the government order. Insurance coverage is also available for Covid-19 treatment at select private hospitals. Although patients prefer being admitted to private hospitals, but as of now, none of the private hospitals has neither treated nor been approached by people showing alleged symptoms of Covid-19.A spokesperson from a corporate hospital at Ramnagar said: “We have five isolation beds and at our Railway New Colony branch, 32 isolation beds have been kept ready. Ventilators, doctors and equipment are all available in case Covid-19 suspect cases or positive cases are admitted. But we do not have test labs. Our ambulances are ready to pick up patients, if required. However, the health authorities prefer to keep all Covid-19 cases or suspects under one roof at the Government Chest Hospital or IDH.”Concurring with this, Dr K Vijayalakshmi, in-charge DMHO, said: “Although private hospitals have been asked to brace for coronavirus-related emergency, their services are not required at the moment. This is because the suspects or patient admission is still low and manageable at IDH. Only when the government hospitals’ isolation beds are filled up, we will need the private ones to step in. Right now, we prefer to keep them all at one hospital. All 14-day quarantined persons, suspects or foreign returnees are kept at VIMS.”

Title: Mosques closed, clerics say offer namaz at home
Content:
The faithful offer namaz in a mosque in Varanasi on Friday

Varanasi: Following the appeal of clerics and health guidelines for social distancing, most people offered namaz at their homes on Friday. Almost all mosques in Varanasi, Jaunpur and other districts wore a deserted look. Only those who look after the mosque affairs were present there to offer namaz.

Though most of people followed appeals and instructions of offering Friday namaz at home, there were some who, without caring about social distancing, reached mosques. Around 6-7 people reached Laat Maszid in Saraiyya locality to offer namaz and despite of having a huge space, did not follow the norm of keeping a safe distance from each other.

Shahar-e-Mufti Maulana Abdul Batin Nomani had made an appeal to the community to not to go to the mosques for Friday namaz and offer namaz at their homes. In his appeal, he said that people should maintain social distancing in view of corona threat, hence they should offer namaz at home only.

Most mosques in Jaunpur including Atala Masjid were closed. Notices suggesting to offer namaz at home was also pasted at the mosques.

Meanwhile, in Gorakhpur Muslims offered Juma Namaz at home while only 5-7 people could be seen offering namaz at mosques. Meanwhile, Durga aarti was performed at Gorakhnath temple by chief priest Kamalnath in the presence of some Sanskrit Vidyalaya students chief Pujari, on the third day of Navratra on Friday.

“The temple used to witness a huge crowd for Durga aarti during Navratra but this year aarti was performed with only 5-7 Sanskrit Vidyalaya students due to threat of corona virus,” said Vinay Gautam, a staff of Gorakhnath temple.

Most of the prominent mosques followed norms for social distancing while offering namaz but some ignored the norm despite of huge space. Imam of Jama Masjid in Gorakhpur, Maulana Abdul Jalil Mazahiri, appealed people to remain at home during lockdown and said that Juma Nnamaz could be offered at home even with three people.

Following the appeal, Muslims offered namaz at home. “ We are facing pandemic and following the rules is very important to combat the virus. I offered namaz at home and prayed for the health of my countrymen. In my entire life I had never seen such a situation,” said 60-year-old Zakir Khan of Jafra Bazar area.

“Only 5-7 people including Imam and people related to management of mosque offered Juma namaz at mosques. In shariyat this is known as ‘Ehtiyati Tadbeer’,” he added.

Title: Colvale inmates ‘safer inside, than out in society’
Content:
Panaji: Colvale Central jail authorities on Friday had to face agitated jail inmates who are worried about getting infected from the novel coronavirus if they are left locked-up in their cells along with others. The inmates raised slogans demanding parole as is being done in prisons of other states.

Jail authorities quelled the commotion by explaining that the inmates were much safer inside their cells than outside, in society. “All precautions for their safety have been taken within the jail premises since response to Covid-19 became a reality,” said an inspector general of prison official.

The official said the commotion began in the morning when prisoners were let out between 9am to 1pm. As a precautionary measure, he said, “Prisoners are left out for longer duration from their cells since the last two weeks. They must have watched the news about the status in prisons of other states and demanded they be given parole,” he said. He did not rule out a possibility that the inmates may have been incited by some co-inmates.

“Since last few weeks we have stopped visitors to the jail. Patrolling staff has been reduced to half, to reduce density of persons on duty at a time,” the official said.

The Colvale prison currently has about 540 inmates, including under-trials and the jail has a capacity to accommodate 100 more.

“Unlike other prisons in the country, our prison is not over crowded,” the official said. Hand sanitisers have been provided to inmates and staff on duty while thermal guns are being used to keep track of body temperatures .

“Fifteen to twenty inmates are accommodated in one cell but since the outbreak of the disease, jail inmates have been instructed to maintain distance of one meter even when they are sleeping,” the jail official said.

New inmates or those who have returned from parole are kept in isolation. "With so many people living under one roof, it does increase the risk of infection but we are taking precautions. Two persons who returned from parole recently have been kept in isolation,” he said.

The jail has about ten isolation cells that are used to isolate any prisoner for 15 to 20 days who is a termed a trouble maker. Those cells are now being used to isolate prisoners who have come back to the facility. There is an in-house doctor to check prisoners. In addition, video conference and teleconferencing facility is offered to jail inmates. “We always had this facility but it was not used much. They can avail this benefit now,” the official said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Couple commits suicide
Content:
Representative image

RAJAHMUNDRY: A married couple committed suicide by setting themselves on fire with petrol in Rajahmundry on late night Thursday. The deceased couple has been identified as 40-year-old Satish and his 35-year-old wife Venkata Lakshmi.

Sources said that Satish and Lakshmi were married for 20 years and had no children. They were suffering from a number of chronic health issues and acute financial troubles.

Satish had reportedly taken a bank loan to purchase his auto-rickshaw and was steeped in debt. Unable to cope with the multitude of problems, they decided to set themselves on fire.

K Latha Madhuri , additional SP (law and order) of Rajahmundry (urban) district said the couple’s suicide note also said they were apprehensive of having contracted Covid-19.

Title: Ahmedabad: Police drones to keep watch on you
Content: AHMEDABAD: Many of us have got a WhatsApp message that says people feel like they are in Big Boss house during this period of lockdown announced by the government to fight coronavirus . Sola police of the city have made it a bit more real by deploying drone cameras to keep a watch on people's movements.Sola police have hired three cameras from private parties to keep a vigil on people's movements and restrict gathering of more than four persons. Police commissioner Ashish Bhatia has imposed section 144 of Criminal Procedure Code, which restricts assembly of more than four persons in the city."Cops of Sola police station are keeping a close watch over you with drone cameras. Please do not think that you can escape legal action if you are sitting in a garden or moving in an internal lane. If you are in the assembly of five people, then you will face action. If you are caught violating the law by our drone cameras, then you will be booked. Mind well, this drone cameras may fly over you any time." police said. This is an announcement being made by Sola police in Gota, Thaltej, Sola, some parts of SG Road and Chandlodia.Inspector JP Jadeja of Sola police said, "We will capture violators from their housing societies. We have started this exercise from today onwards and will continue it to restrict people's movements."Jadeja said this will help put psychological pressure on people. "If they know drone cameras can anytime catch them violating the law, they will themselves stop moving out of their homes to meet others,"

Title: Sealed border chokes edible oil flow in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The supply of edible oil to Maharashtra from neighbouring Karnataka has been hit with the border between the two states being sealed in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak and the ensuing nationwide lockdown.

Senior officials in the Maharashtra revenue department said the two state government were in talks to resume the supply at the earliest.

Maharashtra depends on the Virabha region and Karnataka for edible oil. Supply has been halted in Vidarbha because the drivers and workers were not reporting to work. Edible oil is also not reaching from Karnataka ever since the inter-state border has been sealed.

An official said panic buying by a section of the consumers aggravated the crisis and efforts were on to streamline the situation within two days.

“There’s s no need to panic and supply of all essential supplies, edible oil, vegetables and fruits, will be streamlined. It is just the initial teething problems after the lockdown was imposed. The process to send out essential supplies is on after thorough scrutiny,” the official said.

B V Mehta , executive director of the Solvent Extractors Association of India , told TOI that the ongoing crisis was due to the logistics issue. “I think the district administration is on the job and the supply will be shortly streamlined. People should not panic,” he said.

Mehta said Maharashtra procured coconut oil is procured from the southern part of the country and rice bran oil from northern India. As the nationwide lockdown was imposed, all inter-state borders were sealed.

“All states are now slowly sending out essentials. The country’s demand is about 230 lakh tonnes of edible oil and India produces around 75-80 lakh tonnes. The country imports about 150 lakh tonnes of edible oil to bridge the gap between demand and supply,” Mehta said.

There are a huge number of plants with a capacity from 50 tonnes per day to 1,000 tonnes per day producing different kinds of oil, depending upon the availability of seeds in an area. Major refineries are located near ports across the country.

“The current issue is that of logistics. Edible oil produced in the factories need to be moved first to the depots, then to wholesellers and finally to retailers. The Centre, states and local authorities are helping the industry resume production and maintain the supply chain. There is no restriction on inter-state movement of essential commodities. Once the logistics are in place, we do not fear any supply hassles,” Mehta said.

Title: No property tax or power tariff hike by Telangana government for now
Content: HYDERABAD: The state government has almost dropped its plans to hike power tariff and property tax in villages, towns and cities in the ensuing financial year until it tackles the coronavirus cases.Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is also likely to take a decision on rescheduling the last dates for tax payment soon. “The entire country is in a lockdown mode up to April 15. As on date, no one is sure about how long this lockdown will continue. During the lockdown, no activity of holding public hearings will be conducted. So, the power tariff hike, if at all allowed, will be only after July — that is based on the assumption that the coronavirus threat is over,” said highly-placed sources.Senior officials of discoms are meeting on March 30 to discuss whether the aggregate revenue requirement (ARR) submission to the Telangana State Electricity Regulatory Commission (TSERC) on March 31 should be delayed given the prevailing situation. Also, a decision would be taken whether to send the current meter readers to the doorsteps of the consumers for meter reading and raise bills or send bills to consumers based on their average bill payment in the last two to three month in view of the lockdown.“KCR should extend property tax due date from March 31 to May 31 and also provide relaxation for payment of electricity bills till May-end without any penalty,” Telangana Youth Congress spokesperson SP Kranthi Kumar said. He sent an email to the CM in this regard.The hike in power tariff would have allowed the discoms to raise an additional Rs 1,500 crore per annum. Last time the power tariff went up by 7% was in 2016 and this time it was proposed to seek a 10% hike.The southern and northern power distribution companies have to submit their ARRs, after which TSERC will decide how much tariff hike would be allowed after conducting a public hearing. The discoms are unlikely to submit ARRs by this month-end.As it is, collection of property tax in the current fiscal in gram panchayats and urban local bodies except GHMC has been hit due to the lockdown. Tax collections in the panchayats which were over Rs 330 crore in March 2018-19 stood at Rs 250 crore so far in the current fiscal.

Title: NMC begins disinfecting Khamla, nearby areas & main roads across city
Content:
Alongwith spraying, door-to-door containment drive of NMC has been widened to detect vulnerable patients

Nagpur: With five new Covid-19 positive patients detected on Friday, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) started spraying disinfectant in Khamla, adjacent areas, and also main roads across the city to control spread of the virus. Also, door-to-door containment drive has been widened to detect vulnerable patients.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe held a review meeting of all heads of departments and kicked-off spraying of disinfectant. He has instructed NMC’s fire department to provide fire tenders to spray disinfectant. The drive will be undertaken in association with officials of health department and ten zone offices.

Deputy commissioner Dr Pradeep Dasarwar told TOI, “NMC is spraying sodium hypochlorite, which is a chemical compound of sodium cation and a hypochlorite anion. In homes, we usually disinfect using phenyl. Similarly, NMC is spraying this chemical compound on streets. It will help control spread of Covid-19 and other viruses,” he said.

Chief fire officer Rajendra Uchake told TOI, “Eleven fire tenders have been pressed into action, of which six have capacity of 5,000 litres and five of 2,000 litres. They will work in all 10 zones. One each is from Civil Lines fire station, Ganjipeth, Cotton Market, Sugat Nagar, Lakadganj , Kalamna, Trimurti Nagar, Sakkardara, and two from Narendra Nagar fire station,” he said.

Fire department personnel started spraying disinfectant using hose pipes of the fire tenders right on the streets.

On Friday, TOI had reported similar spraying of disinfectant was launched in Wardha. Probably, Wardha was the first to launch it in Vidarbha.

NMC assistant commissioner of Laxmi Nagar Zone Raju Bhivgade said, “Khamla Road and other streets of Khamla and Pande Layout were covered on Friday night. Remaining areas will be covered from Saturday onwards,” he said.

Throughout the day on Friday, NMC sanitary workers sprayed disinfectant in interior lanes of Khamla manually. All lanes near the residence and shop of the positive patient were covered.

NMC zonal medical officer Dr Sunil Kamble said, “NMC’s door-to-door containment drive covered around 6,000 houses within 1km radius from the house of positive patient in Khamla. At the same time, we covered more than 11,500 houses in Bajaj Nagar, where the first three positive patients are residing and Swawlambi Nagar. We visited houses of the maids of Khamla positive family. We learnt she works in two more homes. We sent all of them to GMCH for testing,” he said.

Kamble added all suspected people in Khamla and nearby areas will be sent for testing. “We will expand survey to houses in 2km radius on Saturday, and 3km on Sunday,” he said.

The drive also continued in other zones of the city. Over 70,000 houses have been covered in the remaining nine zones.

NMC had claimed Khamla positive patient came to fore during its containment drive. When they learnt of his symptoms, the NMC team asked the person to visit Mayo Hospital on March 23. Accordingly, he and his family members went to Mayo Hospital on Wednesday.

NMC is probably the first in the state to launch door-to-door containment drive.

Title: Odisha: Promotion without exam for students of classes I to VIII
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: School and mass education minister Samir Ranjan Das on Friday said students of Classes I to VIII will be promoted to the next class without appearing for their annual examination amid the looming uncertainty over the novel coronavirus.

He said, “Students studying in Classes I to VIII in schools that come under our department will be promoted to the next class without appearing for the annual examination this year. Though we have not issued any notification in this regard, we are planning to do this in view of the difficult situation that has arisen out of Covid-19.”

Earlier, there was a system to auto-promote students from Classes I to VIII. For this academic session, the school and mass education department had decided to introduce the pass and fail system for students of Classes V and VIII. It had also conducted the half-yearly examination for the students of these classes.

“But this system can not be implemented this year. We have to postpone the pass-fail system for Classes V and VIII this time. The current situation has forced us to think of promoting the students of these classes without making them appear for an examination,” he added.

On March 13, chief minister Naveen Patnaik had announced to close schools and other educational institutions after the World Health Organisation declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic on March 11. Later, the school and mass education department had on March 16 postponed the examinations of all the classes starting from Class 1 to IX and Class XI as a preventive measure to contain the Covid-19 outbreak.

Sources said the schools in the state will reopen after the summer vacation is over in the third week of June. Last year, the government had shut the schools for summer vacation from April 18.

Title: No decision on transit trucks yet in Maharashtra
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: State transport minister Anil Parab on Friday said a decision on allowing the passage of trucks stranded on state borders was yet to be taken.

The announcement came two days after the state transport department’s claim of having adequate measures in place to help the stranded truck drivers in the wake of lockdown in the country. The department had said that food joints along the check-posts were being kept open for the benefit of these drivers.

“At present, no trucks transiting through the state or carrying non-essential items are being allowed to ply. Only trucks with essential commodities are allowed to pass,” Parab told TOI on Friday.

“Decisions pertaining to these issues are being taken in a phased manner. If we allow all trucks, the purpose of lockdown would be defeated,” he said, adding decision to open food joints for such stranded drivers was yet to be taken.

The president of Vahan Chalak Malak Pratinidhi Sanghatana, Baba Shinde, said, “If the transport authorities have said trucks would be allowed to ply, then where is the government resolution? At present, thousands of trucks carrying non-essential items are stranded across the state borders. No food joints have been opened for them. We have sent two letters to the minister of road transport and highways and are trying to speak with Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari .”

There are nine major check-posts across Maharashtra — Thane, Nashik, Dhule, Jalgaon, Nagpur, Kolhapur, Solapur and Sindhudurg.

Kulktran Singh Atwal, president of All India Motor Transport Congress , said, “Centre has allowed plying of trucks ferrying essential commodities but the order is yet to be communicated with many states. Several truck drivers deserted their vehicles and are walking to their hometowns. Thousands are stranded without any facilities.”

Title: Lack of workers to ferry essential goods a hurdle amid lockdown in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The state government and district administration are working around the clock to ensure uninterrupted supply of vegetables, fruits, oils, pulses, foodgrains, but their efforts are being stymied by an unavailability of workers .

With many workers having returned to their villages, the administration is trying to reach out to them and get them to come back to work so that the essential goods are supplied on time.

Nitin Pawar, state convener of Hamal Panchayat , said over 50,000 workers are employed in various sectors. “When the state went into lockdown, most of them returned to their villages. Now it is difficult them to return, but those who are available locally are now being pressed into service,” Pawar said.

Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram said they were working towards addressing this issue.

Pawar further said the government too needs to consider providing insurance cover for these workers.

“While the health workers are being covered, why not extend it to those delivering the essential services?” Pawar said, adding they have sent this demand to the government.

“Wages too should be given properly as there are many workers who have no food or shelter. There should be a health check-up of workers ferrying essential goods,” Subhash Lomte , general secretary of Maharashtra Rajya Hamal Mapadi Mahamandal , said.

A grocery shop in the city said it was looking to provide its own manpower to ensure loading and unloading goods at Gultekdi market.

Title: Pune police help stranded north-east students go back to hostel
Content:
A deserted stretch near Khadakwasla dam

PUNE: Three women students from the Northeast, studying in a city-based college, got help from the city police on Thursday in moving from Sangvi, where they were stranded for three days, to their college hostel in Bibvewadi.

Senior police inspector Arun Waykar told TOI that the students were stuck in a friend’s flat.

The students’ friend, who also hails from the North East, told TOI that they had booked flights to reach Meghalaya. The students are pursuing their postgraduate studies at a college in Bibvewadi.

Their flights were scheduled on March 25 but Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the nationwide lockdown on the March 24.

The students, between 24 and 25 years of age, decided to spend some time with other friends in Sangvi on March 24. Their flight was cancelled and at the same time the police order on a strict lockdown was implemented, he said.

In such a situation, the three students were stranded in the flat. They approached the police on a social networking site and requested them to shift them to their hostel. A police team shifted them and ordered them to stay in their hostel rooms.

Title: 378 with travel history quarantined in Jaunpur
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

VARANASI: A number of people who have returned from foreign countries, as well as from states like Maharastra and Kerala , have been put in home quarantine in Jaunpur district.

District magistrate Jaunpur Dinesh Kumar Singh , on Friday, said that so far 378 people, who have returned from foreign countries have been identified and put in home quarantine for 28 days. Besides, 6,629 persons returned from Maharashtra and 180 from Kerala have also been identified. The district administration is sending teams to their houses for examination and to instruct them for home quarantine.

The foreign returned people have been quarantined in 278 homes. All the persons have been examined by a team of doctors. Though none of them showed Covid-19 like symptoms, they have been asked to remain in home quarantine, said the DM adding that the officials have been asked to keep vigil on these people, and lodge FIR if they are found moving out of their home.

People who have returned from Maharashtra and Kerala are also being monitored, said the DM adding that they have been asked to remain indoors for 28 days to maintain social distancing. The doctors’ teams are visiting their places for health checkup.

So far, samples of 28 suspects were examined in the district out of whom only one was tested positive, said the DM. His health condition is improving, and the samples of his family members were tested negative.

Title: Leaked names bring grief for quarantined
Content: Panaji: Ever since the novel coronavirus became omnipresent, names of possible suspects and also those who had been asked to stay in home quarantine were being circulated on the social media.Apart from Covid-19 patients, some fictitious names too made it to the list on the Whatsapp groups. In few cases, even mugshots of suspects were circulated. Many of them were ostracised.Authorities denied of having any hand in leaking the names, but at least in two cases, they said they knew for certain that the information was leaked by the government staff.A resident of a coastal village said that after information about him and his wife in quarantine became public, his neighbours and villagers maintained distance with them.“My neighbours have stopped passing by my house though we have been tested negative,” he said.Epidemic Act which is in force allows the government to initiate action against those spreading rumours. It could not be confirmed if any action was taken against the rumour-mongers. Health minister Vishwajit Rane did not respond to a query by TOI on initiating action.Rajesh Pednekar who has been in quarantine, in a video message on Friday, said that fake news was spread about his family. They are all hale and hearty and has been under quarantine as a precautionary measure, he said.“I request people not to circulate fake news as it will send a wrong message. Some even may get into depression or it may lead to some other ailment,” Pednekar said in a video appeal.Last week, a letter by a health officer to the collectorate office went viral. The letter had names of travellers who needed to be put in quarantine and had been staying in the jurisdiction of the health officer.The officer had named those who his staff could track and those, they could not. Somebody had the letter posted on the Facebook.The officer said neither him nor any of his staff members had a hand in it. It was clear that some staffers, whether linked to his or Collectorate office, could be behind the leak.

Title: 100 ‘contacts’ of third Covid-19 patient
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The state government on Friday said the state might be heading towards stage 3 of Covid-19 (community transmission), a day after a man who has no travel history — either abroad or outside Odisha — and did not come in contact with any coronavirus patient tested positive for the virus.The health department has so far traced more than 100 people who came in ‘direct contact’ with the man in the past few days and immediately put them under quarantine.“We may be moving towards Phase 3 of the transmission (when the source of infection is not established). People must strictly abide by the lockdown norms and stay indoors,” Subroto Bagchi, state’s spokesperson for Covid-19, said on Friday.Bagchi said about 10 teams were working round the clock to trace people who might have come in contact with the man in the last few days. Government insiders said the figure could stand around 200.Health secretary Nikunja Bihari Dhal said, “The rapid response teams have already quarantined 100 people who have come in direct contact with the man. The swab samples of five persons who are his close contacts have been sent for testing.”Sources said staff members of a bank, where the man’s wife works, are among those asked to stay in self-isolation. This apart, an employee of the Vidhan Sabha dispensary, where the patient had initially gone for treatment with flu-like symptoms on March 16, has been asked to stay in home isolation. A doctor, paramedical staff and nurses of a private hospital have also been put under quarantine.The man was admitted to the private hospital for two days from March 23 before being shifted to the isolation facility in a government-run hospital on Thursday. The government also asked patients not to visit the private hospital where he had sought consultation, but allowed the treatment of patients who are already admitted there. “It will be difficult to shift patients from there because some of them are in the ICU,” a government official said.The government spokesperson said the 60-year-old man had travelled to Delhi and Rewari in Haryana between March 7 and 10 with his family. The man — third from Odisha to test positive for Covid19 had travelled on an Indigo flight from Delhi to Bhubaneswar with his wife and daughter on March 10.Earlier, a 31-year-old man with a travel history to Italy and a 20-year-old who had returned from the UK tested positive for the virus. The government authorities said their conditions are asymptomatic and stable.As many as 37 persons are in hospital isolation in the state for suspected symptoms. A government statement said samples of around 256 people were sent for the Covid-19 test. Of the total, the results of 67 are being awaited.

Title: Medical college dean, doctors among 100 quarantined
Content:
Ahmedabad: Over 100 people, including the dean, doctors, and health staff of a medical college and hospital — run by the Gujarat Medical and Education Research Society (GMERS) — have been quarantined after the dean’s wife tested positive for coronavirus, officials said on Friday.

The woman, 55, had tested positive on Thursday, they said. The medical college and hospital is run by the state government. “The dean’s wife works as a pathologist at some other hospital and may have got infected during her work,” deputy commissioner of Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation Om Prakash said. “There are two other possibilities. On March 15, some of her relatives from Mumbai had visited the family,” he said. “That could have led to the infection. We also learnt that her daughter-in-law had returned from Singapore and Thailand last month.”

She was hospitalised after her test reports confirmed her infection, Prakash added. However, her husband is healthy and has not shown any specific symptoms of coronavirus infection so far. “As a precautionary measure, we have also quarantined over 100 people, who had come in contact with the couple, including their relatives, doctors, and members of the college staff,” Prakash said.

Title: Gujarat government estimates Rs 4,000 crore hit on revenues
Content:
Representative Image

GANDHINAGAR: The lockdown for the Covid-19 pandemic may lead to a revenue loss of Rs 3,000-4,000 crore to the state, sources in the government said on Friday. Lower GST collection stemming from complete shutdown of manufacturing and service sectors, drastic reduction in income from electricity duties, and lack of real estate transactions will take their toll, sources said.

“Revenue collection under various heads increase in March due to the end of the financial year. But this time, GST collection is expected to drop sharply and the Centre’s share will also plummet. The shutdown in real estate and other sectors has stifled income from stamp duty and registration fees,” said a senior government official. He said the government is also staring at a drop in revenues generated from sales of motor vehicles, and electricity duty from from industries.

“Collectively, the loss of overall income of the state government may extend to Rs 3,000-4,000 crore,” he said.

The official said the possibility of reduction in grants-in-aid from the central government can’t be ruled out as the Union government will also be facing similar reduction in revenues. “Things will be clearer only after the lockdown is lifted and tallies made,” the official said.

Sources added that the impact of the lockdown may last for about two quarters after the lockdown period and state government revenues will continue to be hit for some time. “The state government may have to borrow more money to fund the state’s planned expenditure as budget allocation has already been announced. The government may also have to announce additional resource allocation after the lockdown is over,’’ said an official.

Title: Businesses, industrialists from Pune promise financial aid
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Industrialists and businessmen from the city have begun to support the administration and healthcare sector’s fight against Covid-19.

On Thursday evening, the Bajaj group pledged a support package of Rs100 crore to boost the fight against Covid-19, initially started as a crowdfunded effort by the Pune-based Mahratta Chambers of Commerce , Industries and Agriculture (MCCIA) a couple of days ago. “In Pune, we shall support upgrade of key healthcare infrastructure required to tackle Covid-19. These interventions will support communities in Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad and rural areas of Pune,” Bajaj Group said in a statement.

Industrialist and Force Motors’ chairman, Abhay Firodia, earmarked a sum of Rs 25 crore from his company’s fund to help upgrade healthcare facilities in hospitals in and around Pune.

Most of the resources, including that of the Bajaj Group, would be directed towards improving the intensive care unit facilities in identified hospitals, procurement of personal protective equipment like gloves and masks, enhancement of testing and setting up of isolation wards.

MCCIA, with the help of donations from some leading industrialists of the city, has facilitated the procurement of 27 ventilators. Some of the donors in Pune under the aegis of Pune platform include Abhay Firodia, Mukul Madhav Foundation, Pinnacle Social and Charitable Foundation, Entrepreneurs Organisation Pune , Weikfield, Desai Brothers, Anand Deshpande , Meher Pudumjee, Duroshox, Aqua Pharm, Advik Hi Tech, Polybond and Cybage.

Title: 4 hosps reserved for Covid-19 cases, others reel under more patient inflow
Content: Dehradun: With four state government medical colleges exclusively earmarked for the treatment of Covid-19 cases, the other hospitals in the state are facing issues due to the sudden increase in the number of patients at their facilities.A spot visit by TOI to city’s Gandhi Shatabdi Hospital on Friday revealed how patients and their relatives were crammed in small rooms at a time when social distancing is critical. In the women and infants’ ward of the hospital, around 30-35 people were present inside a 16x14 room with a capacity of six beds. While two pregnant women were lying on their respective beds, their kin were occupying the area near the bedside. Some were even sitting on the floor.Further, at a time when an infectious disease is rampant and cleanliness should be paramount, the sainitation in the wards left much to be desired. Also, there were no sanitisers available for patients and their attendants and the washrooms in the ward didn’t have soaps.When asked about this situation from hospital doctors, they expressed their helplessness saying that even after repeated requests and warnings, the kin of patients are not ready to leave the hospital. They added that the hospital got burdened after the women’s ward of Government Doon Medical College and Hospital was shifted here two days ago.“We have asked the kin of patients several times to leave the rooms and sit in the rest area on the ground floor but they hardly pay heed to our requests. They are risking the lives of their own kin. The work burden has increased for the hospital staff due to the influx of the patients,” Dr Praveen Pawar, acting in-charge of Gandhi Shatabdi Hospital, told TOI. The official added that the hospital’s request for additional staff is pending for approval with the state government.Other medical facilities are also facing a similar pressure due to increased patient inflow.

Title: Odisha: Prisoners being moved to jails with less occupancy
Content:
The Jharpada circle jail in Bhubaneswar

BHUBANESWAR: To decongest jails in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, the state government on Friday started shifting at least 856 convicts from different districts to prisons with low occupancy. The fresh move came a day after the government constituted a high-powered committee to facilitate early release of prisoners on parole and bail to decongest jails.

The 856 convicts, who were lodged in 18 jails at different places in the state, are being relocated to 17 less congested prisons. Though jails in Odisha are not overcrowded, the high-powered committee decided to shift the convicts to those prisons where the presence of inmates is less. Against the sanctioned capacity to accommodate 19,791 inmates, all 87 jails in Odisha currently house 18,112 prisoners, including 14,387 undertrial prisoners (UTPs) and 3,725 convicts. A few months ago, the state prisons directorate had proposed to the home department to close 18 jails due to low occupancy of inmates.

“We have started the process of shifting convicts from jails in Bhubaneswar, Choudwar , Berhampur, Bhadrak, Phulbani, Sambalpur, Sundargarh , Baliguda , Jajpur, Athagarh, Bhawanipatna, Dhenkanal and Angul where the capacity and existing strength of inmates are either same or a little less. We identified 17 jails in different districts where less number of inmates stay compared to the sanctioned capacity,” director general of police (prisons and correctional services) Santosh Kumar Upadhyay told TOI. Significantly, the three-member high-powered committee having chairman of Odisha state legal services authority, state home secretary and DGP (prisons and correctional services) as members has finalised modalities for release of convicts and UTPs. Sources said the committee has also asked under-trial review committees in all districts to hold weekly meetings and facilitate measures for release of prisoners.

“We gave special remission of two months to 126 convicts on Friday. That means they have been released from jails two months before the completion of their sentence,” Upadhyay said. Jail sources said different courts have granted bail to at least 60 prisoners on Wednesday.

Upadhyay said the committee laid emphasis on providing prompt healthcare facilities to sick prisoners. “We have supplied adequate hand sanitisers and masks to jails. State and district-level monitoring committees are being constituted for proper implementation of the decisions. Chief district medical officers have been requested to boost requisite healthcare facilities in jails and conduct awareness programmes among inmates,”Upadhyay said.

Title: Uttarakhand’s first corona positive patient recovers, discharged
Content:
Representative Image

DEHRADUN: A trainee forest service officer who was tested Covid-19 positive on March 15 has now recovered from the disease and was discharged from the hospital on Friday. The two other trainees, who were tested Covid-19 positive on March 17, have also tested negative and doctors say that they will also be discharged within two days if they test negative for Covid-19 again.

Dr NS Khatri, the nodal officer from Government Doon Medical College and Hospital (GDMCH) confirmed the development saying, “He has been sent to the Forest Research Institute (FRI) where he will be kept in isolation for some time but he is totally fine. The test reports of other two trainees have also come negative and they too would be discharged if they test Covid-19 negative again in the next 48 hours,” he added.

To recall, the IFS trainee, who was discharged , was the first coronavirus positive patient of Uttarakhand. Two of his colleagues, who had shared a room with him during their study trip abroad, were also reported Covid-19 positive on March 17.

Meanwhile, the health department on Friday launched an app to track coronavirus cases in the state. The app “Uttarakhand COVID-19 Tracking System” can be downloaded from Google Play Store. It has been designed by Siddhartha, a Class X student. He was helped by a team of Uttarakhand Science Education and Research Centre in developing the app.

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat launched the app saying, “The app will help the health department to track Covid-19 patients, analyse their geographical conditions, and help them accordingly.”

Meanwhile, on Friday, the health department received reports of 18 people and they all have tested negative for coronavirus.

Title: Most cases in city, least local transmission
Content: Ahmedabad:The city of Ahmedabad accounts for 34% of Covid-19 cases in Gujarat, 15 persons, 14 under treatment and one dead. But Ahmedabad, the most populous city in Gujarat, has one particular distinction, it has had the lowest local transmission (LT) cases so far.Compared to Gandhinagar and Rajkot, where LT cases make up 71% and 62% of the total, the city has only 13% LT cases, according to the state health and family welfare department statistics.The city also has the most diverse travel history of person found positive, 12 persons having travelled to six countries -- Finland, France, Saudi Arabia, UAE, UK and USA. The age distribution of patients shows that close to 50% are below 40 years of age. The only death recorded in the city was also the oldest patient, at 85 years old.Due to high number of patients, the number of persons under quarantine is also the highest in the state, at more than 4,000. “One factors for the high number of cases is of course the presence of the international airport. Area-wise, the cases are quite scattered. Thus, at the moment, we don’t see cluster transmission,” said a senior health department official.

Title: Birders to take up isolation as ‘Lockdown Bird Challenge’
Content:
Nagpur: With the country under Covid-19 lockdown , eBird, an online database of bird observations, has turned the compulsory quarantine into a positive contribution by organizing ‘Lockdown Birding Challenge’ by recording birds around homes.

The challenge begins from March 27 till the lockdown ends. Birders in the region are excited to be part of the event.

The count will be related to information about bird species sighted near homes, habitat and their behaviour. There may be several species that must not have been recorded before. Birders will record species by standing exactly 15 minutes at the same place in four slots every day.

At your home, from Friday until the lockdown ends, we need to look for birds in the time slots every day from 4am to 6am (optional), 6am to 9am, 4pm to 7pm and 7pm to 10pm (optional).

“The purpose of the pre-dawn and the night lists are to document early-rising birds and nocturnal species , respectively,” says Sarang Pimparkar, a city birdwatcher from Pannase Layout, who is excited about the event.

The complete lists with identity of birds have to be uploaded to the eBird platform (ebird.org/india). As with our other birding challenges, all those who manage to meet the target will be named on this website, and one among them will be chosen at random to receive a small gift in appreciation.

“The relative lack of noise is a good opportunity to try out some bird sound recordings using your smartphone. Alternatively, we will be able to record videos on our camera,” says Azra Taiyeb , who runs a school in Yavatmal and is into birding for past several years.

“We have sprawling residential premises with different tree species. Many birds are spotted on our premises and I maintain a diary about it. The lockdown challenge will help me upgrade my birding skills,” Taiyeb added.

“Due to road development, many trees have been cut in the last few months. I’m witnessing lot of bird activity at my place since then,” she said.

Ashwin Gharote, a birder from Sonegaon, said, “I will conduct the survey from my balcony. Due to the lockdown, people are not going for birding and this is the best way to record them. I will also record their calls.”

“If flocks of birds flying towards their roosting sites in the evening are seen, then this will be marked as ‘Flyover’. We also have to mention the direction of birds’ flight and those feeding on a flowering or fruiting tree nearby,” says Omkar Kekre, a birder from Ramdaspeth .

Kekre said, “Our house is old and has trees on the premises. This makes it a good habitat for house sparrows besides birds like robin and red vented bulbul. Many of our resident birds have already started their breeding activities.”

By gathering and storing bird sightings, eBird enables the gathering of baseline data on bird distribution and abundance, and disseminates this information for public and scientific use.

“Birders use eBird to upload and maintain their bird records. For each bird list, details of date and location are given, and ideally the ‘effort’ spent birding. Bird lists are useful to understand the distribution and seasonality of birds,” says bird expert Nitin Marathe.

Title: Kanpur: Showers lead to fall in mercury, more rain today
Content:
City witnessed heavy rainfall on Friday

KANPUR: In an unusual weather change, the city witnessed rainfall which also led to a fall in day temperature. The day temperature on Friday fell down by 9 degress from 34 degree Celsius recorded on Thursday.

The rain gauge recorded till 2:30 pm on Friday was 6 mm. Dense cloud cover continued to cover the city sky even after the rainfall had stopped.

According to weather experts, there are chances of rainfall on Saturday. This rain may prove harmful for the standing crops like wheat, said Met department.

Title: GHMC raids 36 pet shops, rescues trapped animals
Content:
Hyderabad: After rescuing six rabbits and eights birds that were found starving for food and water inside a locked pet shop in Narayanaguda on Wednesday, Enforcement Vigilance and Disaster Management (EVDM) wing of GHMC stepped up their efforts and conducted raids on 36 more pet shops on Friday. The EVDM teams started conducting raids on pet shops after animal lovers in the city raised concerns over owners of these shops leaving animals and birds inside after lockdown was imposed in the state.

Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao recognised EVDM and tweeted, “Fabulous job.” TNN

Title: 10 engineers to face heat for negligence of duty
Content:
VARANASI: Suspension of 10 engineers of four departments has been recommended for their alleged negligence in duty during the lockdown period in the district.

The borders of the district have been sealed at 14 points during the lockdown period to check the spread of corona virus. During the checking on Thursday, several engineers including MN Ansari and Ramchandra Yadav of Varanasi Development Authority (VDA), Sunil Kumar (first), Vinod Kumar Singh, Pratap Narayan Singh and Ajit Singh of PWD, Harendra Singh, Vinod Pandey and Rajendra Prasad Pal of rural engineering service and Avneesh Kumar of irrigation department were found absent from duty.

Taking a serious note of it, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma wrote a letter to the principal secretary recommending suspension and departmental action against the absentees.

Title: B’shahr man, who travelled from Amravati to Meerut, tests positive for Covid-19
Content:
Meerut: A 50-year-old man from Bulandshahr’s Khurja town tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday, according to reports of Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College laboratory. He is admitted to the quarantine ward of LLRM, Meerut, and will continue to be isolated here. According to sources, he had been living in Maharashtra’s Amravati for the past few years for work and had travelled to Meerut recently.

Meanwhile, Khurja sub-divisional magistrate Isha Priya and Khurja circle officer Gopal Singh visited his home to find out his travel history. “According to the initial information, we have got to know that the man in question was living in Amravati, Maharashtra for the past few years for work. He had returned a few days ago and went directly to Meerut to attend a family wedding. We have even extracted his call detail records and found that he did not come to Bulandshahr,” said Bulandshahr DM Ravindra Kumar.

Meerut chief medical officer Dr Raj Kumar said, “We will trace his travel history after talking to him on Saturday. Until then, all we know is that he lived around Shastri Nagar area in Meerut for a few days. We are yet to figure out who all he met. His travel history will be traced and quarantine measures will be taken according to the norms.”

District surveillance officer Dr Vishwas Chaudhary said, “Once we have clarity on his location, disinfectants will be spread in 1 km radius and people who came in his contact will be checked for symptoms. People with symptoms will also be quarantined.”

As soon as his report came, nurses and other paramedics in the quarantine ward of Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College left the ward and denied to work with the limited safety equipment. Now, the quarantine ward is totally dependent on the doctors posted there.

Title: Donation: MSU exempts ad hoc staffers
Content:
Vadodara: After confusion over the circular that it had issued seeking voluntary contribution from its staffers, M S University on Friday clarified that it does not want to burden those who cannot contribute to CM Relief Fund.

MSU on Thursday had issued a circular asking deans, principals, directors, coordinators, section heads among others to seek virtual consent from their staffers for donating one day salary in CM Relief Fund as a voluntary contribution to fight the battle against COVID-19.

The circular, however, had led to confusion as it had stated: “The names (department wise) of only those members of MSU family who do not want to contribute can be sent to director, computer centre with a copy to registrar and vice-chancellor by email only (sic).”

“If they are seeking voluntary contribution, why do they require names of those who don’t want to contribute?” questioned a temporary staffer.

Title: UP police to invoke provision of Disaster Management Act against organisers of religious gatherings
Content:
Meerut: In a bid to put a curb on religious gatherings, police in UP’s Meerut on Friday warned of invoking provisions of Disaster Management Act against those organising it, entailing a two-year prison term. The deterrent came ahead of Friday prayers and on the third day ‘Chaitra Navratri’.

Meerut’s superintendent of police (SP) Ajay Sahni said, “There are some notorious elements who are trying to deliberately violate the lockdown. There is a provision of punishment for up to two years in Disaster Management Act. If the lockdown norms are violated at any place of worship, action will be taken against cleric or priest concerned.”

The appeal is seen as another step to discourage devotees from attending Friday prayers and visiting temples during the ongoing ‘Chaitra Navratri’.

This week, three clerics in Bulandshahr and one if Meerut’s Sardhana area were booked for holding evening prayers in mosques. Several religious leaders have also come forward and appealed to the people to stay in homes and respect social distancing.

The appeals were recorded and shared widely on social media platforms. In most parts of the country, Friday prayers were not held, barring a few exceptions.

Most of the mosques in Meerut and other neighbouring districts like Muzaffarnagar, Bijnor, Baghpat, Hapur and Bulandshahr were shut and an appeal was posted at the main entrance requesting people to offer prayers at home.

However, in Shamli, an Imam was among three booked for lockdown violation after people gathered for namaz at a local mosques. More than 2,500 cases have been registered against people found violating lockdown in the state.

Title: UP roadways launches ‘emergency services’ to rescue stranded workers
Content:
Bijnor: Hundreds of government buses in Uttar Pradesh were on Friday pressed into action to bring home people stranded in the cities of their employment, mostly in Noida and Ghaziabad.

In the absence of public transport system, heart-wrenching visuals of families walking their way home are coming to the fore. Some of them are determined to walk over 100km to “save themselves from starvation” as they are out of job now.

On Friday morning, a fleet of 10 such government buses chugged off from Bijnor station for Ghaziabad to bring home scores of people stranded in the industrial city.

A similar exercise has begun in other districts of the state as well.

Assistant regional manager (ARM) of Bijnor roadways Vinod Kumar Maurya said, “Officers of Ghaziabad administration called up their Bijnor counterparts asking them to rescue workers of the district stranded there. We have sent ten roadways buses to Ghaziabad to bring them home. A similar arrangement has been put in place in other districts also. This emergency service was launched on Friday.”

Sunil Kumar, a labourer stranded in Ghaziabad, told over phone, “I worked in Delhi. The factory where I was employed was shut down due to the lockdown. That is why I want to travel to my village in Bijnor.”

Title: Two law grads highlight gaps in treatment norms
Content: Panaji: Two law graduates have written to the Chief Justice of the high court of Bombay highlighting the government’s inadequate medical preparedness to combat the Covid-19 outbreak.They have appealed for a standard treatment guideline along with vital information to be disseminated to the public over the isolation facilities and ventilators.“While the government has been effective in implementing the lockdown, it has completely failed in preparing itself on the health front,” Jay Mathew and Gauravvardhan A S Nadkarni stated in their letter.One of the main features of medical preparedness is forming a ‘Standard Treatment Guideline or Standard Protocol for Treatment’ which must be followed mandatorily, they said, adding that this was not only warranted for by the medical establishments but also the need of the hour.“There does not seem to be any formal standard prescribed for the doctors. The urgency of the same can be inferred from this unsettling scenario wherein two doctors had to be quarantined because of the inability in maintaining proper standard of care,” they said, adding that if the same is allowed to continue, then the safety of the isolated patients and doctors will be at stake.The letter also highlighted the lack of authorised testing facilities in the state. They have asked for certain information to be made available to the public by the government including physical preparedness and communication and readiness to include private hospitals and clinics for treatment and testing as is done in other states.

Title: Allahabad: Cops to regulate assembly of retailers on Leader Road
Content:
Retailers stock up on medicine consignments on Leader Road in Prayagraj on Friday

PRAYAGRAJ: After receiving intelligence reports that owners of medical stores are causing unnecessary crowding in wholesale medicine market on Leader Road, police authorities have roped in two additional teams to regulate assembly in the area.

These retailers have also been asked to follow norms like wearing mask, maintaining social distance and use sanitisers and gloves.

President of Allahabad Chemists & Druggist Association Anil Dubey said despite being asked to book their orders between 11am and 2pm and ensure deliveries from 3pm to 6pm, retailers were not following the appeal and reaching Leader road in groups for purchase of medicines .

“When the appeal was ignored by retailers, we shut our shops and refused to deliver drugs to them,” a wholesaler said.

Senior police and administrative officials interacted with office-bearers of the Allahabad Chemist & Druggist Association and decided to deploy additional mobile police pickets to regulate sale and purchase of medicines.

There are over 200 medicine shops dealing in wholesale business at Leader Road and retailers from various districts reach here to buy medicines.

Police have also advised traders dealing in wholesale to open shops alternatively to avoid rush and fix a proper time for delivery.

Harsh Mehrotra, a wholesale drug dealer at Leader road told TOI, “As additional police pickets are being deployed and police are strictly enforcing lockdown rules, those who have booked orders on phone or online are being asked to come to Leader Road to get deliveries.”

“We have also been making arrangements to dispatch orders to retailers,” he added. Meanwhile, retailers are also facing problems as people are asking for medicines for three months despite the fact that doctors have not prescribed for it.

Chemists said they were not in a position to provide medicines for months as they had limited stock.

Title: Kanpur: Traders indulging in illegal practices under admin lens
Content:
KANPUR: The district administration, on Friday, took action against traders who were indulging in black marketing of essential commodities in various parts of the city.

At Collectorganj, traders not only misbehaved with enforcement teams, but also snatched mobile phone of a team member. The team lodged a complaint with the Collectorganj police station against the traders.

According to Mala Singh , area rationing officer, a team of the enforcement wing had reached Collectorganj Mandi on the complaint of blackmarketing of sugar. The team asked the traders to show papers, but they refused to do so. The team directed them to sell the commoditiy on fixed rate on which the traders turned aggressive, saying that they would close down their shops and also misbehaved with the team and snatched away mobile of a member of the team. Interestingly, whole episode took place in the presence of two policemen. The area rationing officer later submitted a written complaint to Collectorganj police.

The Chakeri police, too, registered a cases against two traders of Vishambhar Market on the complaint of area rationing officer. The team reached the spot after which the two traders locked themselves inside their shop. The allegation agianst them of indulging in black-marketing was confirmed.

Similarly, Kalyanpur police lodged a complaint against three provisonal stores of the area for selling edible items on premium rates. The police had received complaints against the three stores. All had been charged for black-marketing .

Meanwhile, DM Dr Brahma Deo Ram Tiwari has warned local traders against indulging in black marketing of essential commodities.

Title: Note travel history of patients, relatives: AMA to members
Content: Ahmedabad: It’s not only the government and private hospitals that are busy recording as much details about the patients as possible, your general practitioner will ask you at your next visit, apart from the questions like common symptoms and what did you have for dinner, where were you and your relatives past fortnight.Dr Mona Desai, president of Ahmedabad Medical Association (AMA), said that they have started the initiative to ensure that the GPs can also identify potential COVID-19 infection cases and can guide the patients for further procedure quickly. “We have made representation to the state authorities about apprehension among doctors on whether their clinics and hospitals will be sealed after a potential case. We have assured doctors that their services are essential, and they should continue their OPDs,” she said.It’s also about setting up rules for the patients. AMA secretary Dr Dhiren Mehta said that they have issued a guideline for the doctors to distribute among patients.Dr Pragnesh Vachhrajani, joint secretary of Federation of Family Physicians of India, said that they have advised the senior members to stay home to avoid infection and instead get involved in creating awareness about COVID-19.

Title: Gujarat: Vegetable supply from other states takes a hit
Content: AHMEDABAD: Vegetables grown in Gujarat are abundantly available in local markets, but supply of kitchen essentials like ginger, lemon, green peas among others have registered a decline of 50% as these usually come from other states like Rajasthan, Maharashtra and Karnataka.Traders in vegetable markets say the number of goods trucks arriving from Rajasthan, Maharashtra and Karnataka have declined sharply as the truckers fear harassment on their way back when they do not carry essentials and are mostly empty.“When these trucks enter the state they are loaded with vegetables and hence they are not stopped by the police or the authorities, but on their way back the empty trucks are stopped at each and every crossroads and harassed by cops, despite showing the receipt of sale of vegetables,” said one of the big traders in Jamalpur APMC.Another trader, Ahmed Patel also said there has been a drop in the number of trucks coming from other states. “The APMC has been getting about 50% of the quantity of ginger, lemon, green peas, coriander and capsicums they receive daily.The prices of these vegetables are rising in the APMC. However, the city is receiving a supply of 3,200-3,500 quintals of vegetables daily, on an average, and this is adequate to meet the daily requirement of 3,000 quintals,” Patel said.One Aslam Shaikh, a vegetable wholesaler, said that on Thursday morning, there was a scare as the prices shot up when the market opened, but by afternoon prices stabilized with adequate supply coming in.Another trader said that there had been a 10-15% increase in wholesale market prices because retailers rushed to the market in large numbers to stock up.There is a mild shortage in potatoes and onions, and potato which was priced around Rs 10-14 per kg on Wednesday sold at Rs 15-18 per kg on Friday. The trader said that ginger sold at Rs 50 per kg on Wednesday but it was Rs 62 in the wholesale market on Friday.Ashwin Prajapati, a vegetable vendor in Bopal, said, there’s shortage of ginger and lemon and even if available, the prices are high.He pointed out that ginger and lemon was not available even on app-based markets as the prices are fluctuating daily and these app-based markets take four to five days to deliver, by which time the prices may have changed considerably.

Title: Muzaffarnagar police comes up with helpline number for destitute
Content:
Muzaffarnagar: In its bid to help the needy, police in Muzaffarnagar have come up with a helpline number on which people can inform about those in need of food during the ongoing lockdown period. The helpline number, 9412016669, was made public on Friday.

The district police also released a separate phone number on which volunteers willing to offer their help could call.

“They can call on 9690112112 in case they want to provide food, ration or other essentials to the needy in these times,” a police officer said.

Muzaffarnagar’s senior superintendent of police (SSP) Abhishek Yadav said, “Anyone who wants ration can call on 112. A mobile van will be sent to provide food and medicine.”

Title: No solution for loopholes in ration supply system
Content:
VARANASI: Although the local administration claimed that the supply of essential commodities would be maintained during the lockdown period, several people were seen wandering from one place to another to get ration from the fair price shops, most of which were found closed on Friday.

A group of people from slum area of Bank Colony were found running from pillar to post to get their white and red cards regularised as they had been deleted in the past for irregular consumption of food grains from fair price shop. “The four names out of five of my ration card have been deleted. The shop operator suggested to get it regularised first and then come to the shop,” said one of them Sita Devi.

When contacted, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said that there are some technical issues in the supply from PDF shops, which are being sorted out. He said that efforts are on to begin the supply through these shops by evening. The first priority is to remove the hurdles in supplying ration to the card holders, then the issue of those whose cards had been deleted would be taken up, he added.

Divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal said that the fair price shop owners have been asked to distribute half of April month’s quota immediately. The distribution will start latest by Saturday. Following the government’s orders, the distribution of wheat and rice at Rs two per kg will also be started, he added
