Currently food article distribution is being done in three categories, he said adding, apart from those, who would get it from fair price shop, special packs containing 20 kg of wheat flour, 10 kg rice, pulses and other articles are being distributed among poor and helpless families with the help of social and voluntary organisations. Such distribution has already been started in Jaunpur and Varanasi, he added.

Food packets prepared and packed in community kitchens run by Annakshetra of Kashi Vishwanath temple are being distributed among people shifted to shelter homes from roadsides, railway stations and other place, he said.

Title: For 1st time, Jama Masjid empty for jumma prayers
Content: Ahmedabad/Surat: For perhaps the first time in the city’s recorded history, its Jama Masjid was empty, with only enough devotees to fill one row during the Friday congregation, after which such royal mosques were named.There were not more than 30 persons offering namaz on Friday afternoon with Pesh Imam Mufti Shabbir Ahmed who attended the khutba, the ritual Friday surmon that takes place before the prayer. “Only those who live beside the mosque and those who regularly come to his mosque to offer namaz were present. We have been maintaining proper distance between devotees during namaz. Just the first row that was occupied today,” the mufti told TOI after the Friday prayer. Normally, thousands fill the 75x66 square-metre complex during Friday prayers.An hour before of the Friday congregation and azaan, repeated announcements were from mosques across the city that devotees should not insist on going to mosques and they could offer namaz at home.Local historian Rizwan Qadri said that is was perhaps the first time the Jama Masjid has been was empty. “Even after the 2001 earthquake, there was a rush to offer namaz at the Jama Masjid and it took place in its courtyard,” he said.The scenes were no different at other towns too. Prayer gatherings at mosques have been discontinued for the last couple of days in Vadodara. Barring a few exceptions most mosques are closed. Religious heads even circulated videos and informed devotees about the situation.“Most mosques are locked and in some only the imam, muezzin and a couple of others come. The general public has been advised to stay away,” said former councilor and social worker Javed Dhupelwala.In Surat too, Muslims offered Friday namaz at their homes and stayed away from the masjids following the advisory issued by Qari Rashid Ahmed Ajmeri, high priest of Rander, to contain the spread of Covid-19.Ajmeri told TOI, “Barring imams of the respective masjids and helpers, all community members offered Friday prayers in their homes. We advised the community to strictly follow the lockdown guidelines and stay at home and offer the Friday namaz.”

Title: ‘Online supply of essentials allowed’
Content:
Visakhapatnam: District collector V Vinay Chand said on Friday that people can now buy essential supplies online as five companies are ready to facilitate supply. The district administration has given orders to concerned departments including the police to allow supply of essentials.

The district collector reviewed the arrangements and said that supermarkets and online suppliers like Big Basket, Heritage, More, Spencers and Reliance have agreed to home deliver within GVMC limits.

The collector further said that people will be able to come out and buy essentials from 6am to 1pm provided they maintain social distance. “From 1pm onwards everything will be closed except hospitals, medical stores and milk outlets. If we don’t maintain this, we will not be able to control the coronavirus,” Chand said.

Moreover, government departments such as medical and health, revenue, water supply, sanitation and fire will work round-the-clock. Two committees have been set up in addition to the 19 committees set up earlier to facilitate the movement of essential services and commodities.

“We have identified 16,000 personnel of essential services departments. We will allow essential service vehicles as well as vehicles transferring essential commodities. Anyone stranded outside the district will be allowed in only after 14 days of quarantine. We have set up two shelters for people of other states stranded in Vizag,” the collector added.

Title: Birds come out chirping in lockdown silence
Content:
(Clockwise) Ashy Prinia, Black Drongo and Sunbird

Bhopal: “Three different birds wake me up every day. I am not skilled enough to identify them, but this new morning routine filled with the chirping of birds is absolutely delightful,” says Nirali Singh, a resident of Kolar.

With humans cooped inside amid the lockdown, the stillness on the streets is encouraging birds to step outside.

“There is a fallow patch of land next to our apartment building and I never noticed that there are atleast eight different types of birds there. I am trying to look them up on the internet to identify them. Bird watching is very therapeutic, especially in a time like this I think we all need it,” said Singh.

“You can hear so many different birds now. A ‘kee-kee’ here a ‘tch-tch-tch-tch-tch’ there. I do not know whether it is because the number of birds have increased or is it because we are noticing them more,” says Rita Shrivastav, a resident of Bagmugalia and an amateur birder.

“Birds have always been around. Because of the drop in noise levels, we can hear them more. On an average, we can spot 25-30 species of birds from out home only. Especially now that they are stepping out more,” says Mohammed Khalique of Bhopal Birds.

“Every where in social media, people are posting how birds are more visible and more active right now. Even the common birds can be seen playing about, their activity has increased,” said Shomi Gupta, a bird enthusiast.

“There are some birds which are shy and even when around us hide in bushes or leafy tree. But, now as there are no vehicles moving or people walking about, they do not mind coming out. Bagmugalia earlier had a lot of trees, but now a lot of houses and apartment complexes have come up. This is birds’ natural environment, now that we are inside, they are coming out again. This is the case in other locations as well. Nature resets itself when left untouched,” said Shrivastava.

Many ‘balcony birders’ of Bhopal have spotted common birds like house sparrow, common myna, red-vented bulbul, Asian koel, laughing dove, can be seen in groups of twos and threes hopping about. Other local species like black drongo, ashy prinia, purple sunbird can also be spotted from your balcony or backyard.

Pradeep Ghosh, a resident of Shakti Nagar, spotted a family of peacocks. “A few days ago, we heard a very different sound in the morning and we went to our backyard to check. There is a green belt of BHEL behind our house and there we spotted two peacocks and three peahens. They were there until afternoon. I have lived in this house for 40 years and have never seen this. It was amazing.”

This is also the spring season. Flowering trees in Bhopal like — jacaranda, mango tree, cassia, semal, jarul attract birds, specially song birds, said the expert.

“To encourage more people to start bird watching and also find a new hobby during the lockdown, we have asked residents to send us photos and videos of the birds and their calls that they can spot from the comfort of their homes. We are calling this the home bird count. Through this, families can come together and participate in this activity and also connect with nature while staying safe in their homes,” added Khalique.

Birders’ delight

Some local species of birds, you can spot from your balcony include sparrow, myna, red vented bulbul, laughing dove, spotted dove, collared dove, babbler, ashy prinia, purple sunbird, yellow sunbird, rose-ringed parakeet, Asian koel, hornbill, black drongo, magpie, red-wattled lapwing

Best Time: 7am-9am and 4pm-6pm

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 10 wedding guests held for flouting regulations
Content:
PRAYAGRAJ: Defying lockdown rules and heading to a wedding cost a group of 10 persons an FIR in Phulpur.

A group of 10 wedding guests were arrested while they were on their way to attend a wedding in two SUVs without permission in Phulpur late Thursday evening.

The accused were identified as Noor Mohammad , Mohammad Akshan, Meraz, Babloo Kumar, Mohammad Masooq , Mohammad Zahoor, Mezaj Bano, Pappu alias Mohammad Riyaz , Nizam and Mohammad Mustafa. All of them were residents of Mohammadpur Naugava area near Kalanpur Crossing.

Police also seized the two SUVs in which they the accused were travelling.

A police team led by sub-inspector Sushil Kumar was tipped off about 10 persons heading out packed in two SUVs. Police intercepted and arrested them. The vehicles SUVs were seized under Motor Vehicle Act.

They were booked under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code for defying lockdown rule.

Title: ‘Don’t go out, unless it’s emergency’
Content:
Bhopal: Getting primary medical care is proving to be a real challenge for most residents under lockdown in the state capital and across Madhya Pradesh. Private doctors and their association are adhering to government guidelines and reiterate that ‘people without an emergency should stay indoors’.

Elderly, who are said to be the most venerable to Covid-19, comprise 7.2% of the state’s seven crore plus population. Over 5 lakh people are predisposed with diabetes, common cancers and other ailments as per government data.

On any given day, about 0.5% people of the state capital’s 20 lakh plus population seek medical assistance, according to MP nursing home association advisor Dr Anoop Hajela. Around 90% of the 190 private hospitals are operational, he claimed.

“AIIMS Delhi has stopped routine OPD. Hospitals are open 24x7 and catering to all emergencies. We don’t want people to venture out, unless they have an emergency. People with minor ailments should stay indoors as hospitals can be a hotbed of infection,” said Dr Hajela.

The picture in colonies and residential areas is different. “Going to a clinic is not an option. Many of the doctors are not available. What if a minor infection becomes a major emergency,” said Ravi Verma, a resident of BHEL.

On the flipside, as fear and apprehensions increase, people have approached ‘operational’ hospitals for minor check-up of blood sugar and blood pressure. “People in need with such routine investigation should not come to the hospital,” said Dr Hajela.

He recommends calling 104 and other government-run helplines. However, there are no more than five doctors taking calls from across MP at one of the call-centres in Bhopal. As a measure of respite, Medical council of India has permitted doctors to prescribe over the phone.

Title: HCBA to help elderly members
Content:
a a

PRAYAGRAJ: In view of closure of courts for indefinite period due to threat of coronavirus, the Allahabad High Court Bar Association ( HCBA ) has decided to grant financial aid of Rs 1,000 to its member lawyers having less than 10 years of practice and also to those who are above 75 years of age.

Chairman of Elders Committee of HCBA, VC Mishra said that this decision of providing financial aid was taken in view of the fact that young lawyers, who by and large are going through a period of struggle, are facing financial crisis owing to complete closure of high court. Hence, taking into consideration the on-going situation, which has arisen due to indefinite closure of high court and a lockdown of 21 days, a financial package for young and elderly lawyers have been announced by the HCBA. Regarding financial help to elderly lawyers, who are members of the HCBA, Mishra said that due to their advanced age, they too require special attention as they needed medical aid more often than others.

Meanwhile, the Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh , the apex body of the lawyers of the state, has formed a committee consisting of its three members to help needy lawyers, who find difficult to cope with the situation, which has arisen due to closure of courts across the state.

The committee consists of Amrendra Nath Singh, former chairman of Bar Council of UP, present vice-chairman of Bar Council, Devendra Mishra Nagraha and member of council, Panchu Ram Maurya .

Vice-chairman of Bar Council of UP informed that this committee would try its best to help lawyers in this hour of crisis.

Title: Clubs to offer food packets to needy
Content:
Ahmedabad: The lockdown has forced most of us to be at home but several daily wagers and the homeless have been left without essentials. While civic authorities are ensuring food packets are delivered to the homeless and the needy, city clubs have shown philanthropy in the times of corona.

Ahmedabad-based Karnavati and Rajpath Club have joined hands to prepare 10,000 food packets in a day and supply them to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC). “All the arrangements have been made,” said Jayesh Modi, vice-president, Karnavati Club. “The clubs have joined hands for the initiative, as part of which, 5,000 food packets for lunch and 5,000 for dinner will be prepared and dispatched to the AMC by the authorities of two clubs.”

The initiative began on Friday itself. Modi also confirmed that as the logistics fall into place, the number of food packets may be increased in the days to come.

Title: RML lab gets approval for Covid tests
Content: Lucknow-based RML Mehrotra Pathology will be the first private sector lab in UP to conduct coronavirus testing. The paper work in this regard is underway, officials said, adding that now state has nine labs for Covid-19 tests. Permission has been granted by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR). Secretary to CM Alok Kumar said: “Three proposals were sent from UP, but permission was granted only to one.” He added that 29 private labs in the country have been allowed by ICMR to conduct Covid-19 tests.

Title: Security tightened at AP-Telangana border
Content:
Guntur: Police heightened security at Telangana border near Vadapalli bridge in Guntur district following unruly scenes witnessed late on Thursday night.

A group of youngsters who had waited for several hours to secure police clearance to enter the state from Telangana hurled stones at the cops and made an attempt to break the barricades. At least three police personnel were injured in the incident. Subsequently, the police caned and dispersed the youth from the spot.

After the incident, the police deployed massive force on Friday, setting up iron fencing on the border to discourage youngsters from trying to jump the barricades. Rural district SP Ch Vijaya Rao visited the area on Friday.

The state government made it clear that no one coming from Hyderabad would be allowed to come into the state exce pt for medical emergencies. The police also requested the youth not to wait for long hours to seek permission to enter the state as it was not possible at the moment. The police allowed a few youth to enter the state on the condition that they would be taken to quarantine homes. The youth would not be allowed to go home without staying for 14 days in the quarantine homes.

Meanwhile, DGP Gautam Sawang warned of serious consequences if people tried to attack police. He added: “There is no question of allowing anyone to enter AP despite having NOCs from other states.”

Title: Over 1,500 stranded near Kar checkpost
Content: Tirupati: Tension prevailed at the Andhra Pradesh-Karnataka border where over 1,500 people, belonging to different parts of Andhra Pradesh , tried to get back home on Friday amidst a nationwide lockdown. Many among the 1,500 work at Mangalore port. After learning about the development at the inter-state border, Chittoor district collector Dr Narayana Bharat Gupta and SP S Senthil Kumar, rushed to Nangili checkpost in Karnataka and appealed to the people to stay put.A similar situation also prevailed along the AP-Tamil Naduborder near Satyavedu and Nagari on Friday. tnn

Title: Allahabad: Covid-19 lockdown enters day 3, but rule violations continue
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: As the nationwide lockdown enforced in view of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic entered its third day on Friday, more than 110 Prayagraj residents were booked for flouting rules. The accused were charged under section of 188 (violation of norms) of the Indian Penal Code . Also, more citizens were caught violating rules in trans-Ganga areas of the city as compared to the trans-Yamuna localities.On the other hand, most Muslims in the city offered Friday prayers at home, instead of going to mosques. Earlier this week, clerics had appealed to namazis to stay at home on Friday in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak.Meanwhile, police also caught two persons — one each in Mutthiganj and Mauaima — allegedly blackmarketing essential commodities and lodged FIRs against them under section 3 \7 of the Essential Commodities Act.A man was arrested in Baihrana Khanpur area of th city for allegedly hoading essential commodities on Friday. Te accused was identified as Akbar Ali.SSP (Prayagraj) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said police have stepped up checking in areas like Shivkuti, Muttiganj Nawabganj, Khuldabad, Shahganj, Khiri, Mauaima and Manda area.He added that over 10,000 vehicles were chekced by the police in different parts of the city. “While 1,100 of them were challaned for flouting rules, 29 vehicles were seized,” he added.Like the past two days, city streets wore a deserted look as local residents stayed indoors following the announcement of the 21-day lockdown to check the spread of novel coronavirus. Shops selling essential commodities like medicines and groceries were open from 7am to 10pm.Police teams on Friday visited vegetable markets and urged to citizens to practise social distancing. They also appealed citizens to use the Dial 112 helpline to complain about any trader found blackmarketing essential commodities.“Thana cops on inter-district borders have been directed to not stop those vehicles from entering city limits, which are ferrying essential commodities,” the SSP added. On Friday, over a dozen police teams distributed food packets to the poor and homeless in areas like Civil Lines, Cantonment, Leader Road , Kareli, Naini and Bara.

Title: No new positive case, but suspects pour into SSG
Content:
Vadodara: Even as the city did not witness any new COVID-19 positive case in more than 24 hours, the state-run SSG Hospital continues to witness fresh flow of suspected patients.

On Thursday night, as many as eight new patients were admitted in isolation ward of SSG Hospital, which is already handling seven COVID-19 positive cases apart from one positive case being handled by GMERS Gotri Medical Hospital.

Hospital authorities received some relief when reports of seven out of eight admitted patients tested negative for the deadly virus. All the seven individuals were discharged by the hospital by Friday evening.

Sources said report of one person, who is being treated as a suspect patient of the virus, is awaited at SSG Hospital.

The 57-year-old male patient was brought to SSG Hospital from Anand district at around 2am in the wee hours of Friday.

At GMERS Gotri Medical Hospital, a young intern of the college has been admitted in the isolation ward after he complained of some medical conditions similar to that of COVID-19.

The samples of this intern have been sent to SSG Hospital and his report is expected anytime now.

Meanwhile, a total of 90 individuals were screened at SSG Hospital by Friday evening.

Title: Thousands of labourers stuck at Telangana border with no food
Content: NAGPUR/HYDERABAD: Migrant labourers seem to be worst sufferers of ongoing coronavirus lockdown. More than 200 more of them were found travelling in two containers at Pandharkawda in Yavatmal on Friday. On Thursday, about 350 were found in three containers bound for northern states that were intercepted by the police taking the total to nearly 600.Another 10,000 labourers from Chandrapur are stranded at Telangana border without food or water and not being allowed in as border is closed.According to Pandharkawda police, all these container trucks were heading to Rajasthan, Gujarat, Haryana and other places from where these poor labourers hail. It was only after the police intercepted trucks at Pandharkawda, suspecting them to be carrying cattle that the fact came to light. Though Telangana police denied any such migration, they are keeping tab on such container trucks.The nationwide lockdown from Tuesday to contain coronavirus spread has led to massive exodus of migrant labourers, particularly those hailing from the northern states, as their livelihood has been severely hit.The poor labourers were cramped inside the containers in inhuman conditions, making complete mockery of “social distancing” necessary to keep coronavirus at bay. They were seen sitting over each other in extremely cramped space with their baggage on them.Yavatmal cops asked the labourers to vacate the containers and sent the trucks back to Telangana on both days thus leaving no other option for them than to walk all the way their native states which are over 1000 km away.Local NGOs and police extended a hand to the poor migrants by offering them food and water after which they started walking to their respective destination, according to the locals. But not all headed home. Some of them stayed at the spot, while others went to Yavatmal by taking a lift in trucks headed that way.Some labourers told the police they hailed from villages in Jodhpur and didn’t have any other alternative than to somehow reach their native place. They said they don’t have resources to sustain after the lockdown and therefore, they wanted to be with their families in this crisis. Some of them have farms in their villages.Senior police inspector Ramkrishna Mahalle of Pandharkawda police station said twice containers were intercepted on Thursday. “The first lot of three containers with labourers in them was handed over to Telangana police. The labourers got off from the vehicles and walked back following the railway tracks and others along the roadside. They headed towards their respective states like Rajasthan, Gujarat, Haryana and so on,” he said.O Friday, the police intercepted two more trucks and penalized them for illegally transporting humans. “We handed over the vehicles to Telangana police and RTO. In this case too, the labourers started walking along highways to their destinations,” he said.Though senior police officials in Telangana said that they have no specific information about incidents of hundreds of migrants workers crossing the state borders in trucks during the period of lockdown, police sources confirmed that migrant workers from Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana working in cities like Visakhapatnam, Bengaluru and Hyderabad have been illegally travelling in trucks returning to their home states after delivering supplies in southern states.“More than 200 labourers and even drivers working in Visakhapatnam, Bengaluru and Hyderabad got into trucks that were returning to Rajasthan and Haryana from AP, Karnataka and Telangana. They reached Telangana-Maharashtra border and got down to have food. As it would be difficult to send them back, officials of both the states spoke to one another and allowed them to travel ahead in the same trucks,” said a police source of Adilabad.While Adilabad SP Vishnu Warrier said that no vehicles carrying men and women were allowed to cross the border, additional DG (law and order) Jitender said that there was some information about people hiding in trucks and crossing the state borders to reach their native places but upon verification nothing was found. “We are checking all the trucks now. People are not being allowed to travel in trucks,” the additional DG said.Meanwhile, Chandrapur district administration and guardian minister Vijay Wadettiwar has taken up the matter of 10,000 stranded labourers with Telangana government. They had gone to the neighbouring state to work on farms during chilli picking season and are now returning as work has stopped.District collector Dr Kunal Khemnar informed that they mostly belonged to Bramhapuri, Saoli and Sindewahi tehsils. Guardian minister Wadettiwar called CM Uddhav Thackeray and urged him to intervene in the matter.Wadettiwar stated Thackeray talked to Telangana CM K Chandrashekar Rao and urged him to ensure food and shelter for all Maharashtrain labourers to which the latter has agreed. Thackeray has also agreed to provide food and shelter to the labourers from Telangana stuck anywhere in Maharashtra, he said.Wadettiwar also asked Chandrapur's collector and SP to share the list of names, places to stranded labourers and their phone numbers with Telangana administration and arrange for their relief.

Title: Crunched supply spikes prices of fruits & veggies
Content: Jaipur: Prices of fruits and vegetables skyrocketed at least 30% to 40% due to the crunched supply at Mohana Mandhi, the city’s largest wholesale market.With imports from neighbouring states dipping, supply and reserve are sharply falling resulting into a spike in the prices.Such was the scenario that ladyfinger was sold at Rs 120 to Rs 150 per kg in retail markets while pomegranate was sold at Rs 150 to Rs 200 across the city.“First, we are getting curtailed supply from various states including Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Kashmir and Delhi. Also due to the restriction during lockdown , our retailers and our vehicles are not been able to function. Though there was some relief on Friday, by and large the prices are steadily increasing,” said Abdul Qureshi, a wholesaler dealer of vegetables at Mohana Mandi.Some wholesale dealers also claimed that they are selling vegetables and fruits at normal rates, but retailers were overpricing.“Prices of potatoes, tomatoes, ginger, coriander, bottle gourd, ladyfinger increased in wholesale markets. But retailers are increasing prices astronomically on their own,” said Pappu Lal Prajapt, president of Fal Sabzi Thok Vyapar Mahasangh.Wholesale dealers admitted that local farmers haven’t been able to come to Mohana Mandi to sell their stuff.On the other hand, wholesale dealers complained that their trucks coming from Kashmir, Gujarat and Maharastra are stuck which was the reason for shortage of pomegranates, oranges, grapes and apples.In the areas like C-Scheme, Raja Park, Malviya Nagar and Aadarsh Nagar, prices of onions have increased and were being sold at Rs 50 to Rs 70 per kg.Box Two tables having retail prices of fruits and vegetablesName of the vegetablePrices in Retail (in Rs/kg)Potatoes30-50Tomatoes40-60Coriander80-100Green Chilli50-70Bottle Gourd30-40Ladyfinger120-150Ginger60-80Lemon50-70Name of the FruitsPrices(in Rs/kg)Orange40-60Grapes100-120Pomegranate120-150Papaya60-80Chiku100-120Apples180-200Green Apples220-250

Title: Kanpur: Door-to-door delivery of essentials likely from today
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: The district administration on Friday said it was streamlining door-to-door delivery system and providing food and shelter to the people returning back to their homes from far off places despite all advices.

DM Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari said the door-to -door delivery system could not be fully implemented in the city due to some logical problems and administration was in the process of streamlining the system. Shops that would go for home delivery could not be finalized and time for them was yet to be fixed. He hoped that home delivery might begin from Saturday.

However, he informed TOI that citizens can purchase items of their daily need in between 6 a.m. to 11 a.m. on Saturday too.

Meanwhile ,health authorities informed that no fresh case of coronavirus was reported on Friday. Though as many as 27 suspected outsiders reported and all have been quarantined.

He informed that district administration had discussed the community kitchen in 110 wards of the city with some corporators. He suggested them to provide dharmshalas or school or marriage halls list so that community kitchen could be established there. Besides, all shelter houses had been asked to restore so that people could stay there. The community kitchen and shelter houses were related to check the desertion of labours who were leaving their places and trying to reach their homes at any cost.

The local police station would issue movement passes to those who would be involved in community kitchen. The DM informed that all flour mills had been functional and wheat had been provided to them. There would be no shortage of wheat and flour. He asked the citizens not to store the flour being provided to them as the administration was busy in chalking out the modalities for 24 hours supply.

Some social organizations are already running community kitchens. We need complete information of them so that there it could be ensured that there supply chain could not break. The administration had provided meal to around 10,000 peoples on Thursday, he said.

Later in the evening he inspected the Command & Control centre at Smart City control room and directed to the staff to attend each call and get the disposal of that at the earliest.

Meanwhile, the district magistrate made an appeal to house owners that not to make demand of rent of their accommodation from labourers and poor persons who were helpless due to lockdown. They should come forward to help them.

The police is also playing its role. It not only maintaining the lockdown but also providing food and potable water to helpless persons. During lockdown period it checked 1001 vehicles and challaned 141 out of them under Motor Vehicles Act. The police realized Rs 17,000 from law breakers and seized 4 vehicles.

The police had in all registered 16 cases against traders who were indulge in black marketing.

Title: NGOs, common folk extend helping hand
Content:
Vijayawada: NGOs , good Samaritans and some political parties have come to the rescue of daily wage earners, slum dwellers and the destitute by distributing food and other essential commdoties amid the ongoing lockdown.

Communist Party of India (Marxist) central city committee, under state secretariat member Ch Baburao, distributed food to around 6,000 people at 30 centres on Friday. The Centre ignored the plight of the poor while declaring the 21 day lockdown, he said, addeing: “The Rs 500 monthly financial assistance announced by the Union government for the poor for three months is just an eyewash. The state government also announced free rice and toor dal and Rs 1,000 one-time financial assistance, which can hardly meet the needs of the poor in the existing situation. They have lost their livelihood in the last 10 days,” said Baburao.

Several NGOs and youth handed out food packets to the destitute near bus stops, railway stations and other junctions in the city. G Seethayya, an individual donor, distributed 20 kg rice and 5 kg vegetables to nearly 1,500 families in Ambapuram village on the outskirts of the city. tnn

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Virus curfew reduces pollution, boosts air quality
Content:
View of a deserted road in Lucknow

LUCKNOW: Air pollution levels in UP cities dipped soon after the nationwide lockdown was imposed on Tuesday night. In the past three days, air quality of eight UP cities turned ‘satisfactory’ which was earlier ‘poor’ or ‘moderate’.

Track the pollution level in your city

Closure of commercial establishments, industries, organisations and a reduction in vehicular load and construction activities is believed to be the reason behind the improved air. According to Central Pollution Control Board, the maximum improvement in pollution levels was recorded in Lucknow, with Air Quality Index (AQI) improving from ‘poor’ to ‘satisfactory’.

The city’s AQI was 204 on March 24 (a day before lockdown) and dipped to 84 on Friday, witnessing a drop of 120 units. Industrial towns like Ghaziabad , Greater Noida, Noida and Kanpur also breathed easy with pollution levels falling by 70-100 units in the past three days. Other UP cities such as Meerut , Muzaffarnagar and Bulandshahr, which figured in the top five most polluted cities last year, also recorded their best air quality since post-monsoon 2019.

Kanpur, which attained global infamy in 2018 after WHO placed it as the most polluted city in the world, recorded ‘good’ air for the first time in the year with AQI of 50 on Thursday.

IITR director Alok Dhawan, “The lockdown has improved air quality as it has reduced vehicular load, construction activities and traffic snarls following the closure of commercial and industrial establishments. Rain in some parts of UP has further cleaned the air.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Four brothers organise father’s ‘terahvi’, booked
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Four brothers were booked for making assembly of 50 persons in ‘terahnvi’ (ritual after after death) ceremony of their father amid coronavirus lockdown in Farrukhabad district.

The Mohammadabad Kotwali police on Friday has booked four brothers Amrendra Singh, Satendra Singh , Upendra Singh and Devendra for making assembly of 50 persons during `Terahnvi' rituals of their father on Thursday.

"Their father Ramsanehi had passed away two weeks ago. On Thursday, they had organised a `terhanvi' rituals at their house in Pipargaon village which comes under Mohammadabad Kotwali police station of the district. In the rituals, they had invited nearly 50 persons, which was against the norms of Section 144 CrPc order. They were detained and later taken to police station from where they obtained bail," said beat incharge Ram Sharan Yadav.

The 144 CrPc order prohibits assembly of more than five persons.

Title: Yogi Adityanath: Why Covid-19 cases increasing in Noida?
Content: LUCKNOW: With the number of cases in Noida going up to 18 as four new patients were reported on Friday, chief minister Yogi Adityanath said that additional medical teams should be dispatched to Noida immediately. He has also directed officials to find out why the number of cases in Noida, which has seen the highest number of cases in the state, is on the rise.“In view of Noida’s proximity to Delhi and a large number of industries there, we are seeing a lot of coronavirus cases. The CM has also said testing for the virus should be made available in private hospitals of Noida and Ghaziabad,” said a senior government official. While reviewing the situation in UP on the third day of lockdown, the CM also directed officials that the Garib Kalyan Yojana announced by the Prime Minister should be rolled out by the first week of April. Additional chief secretary, home, Awanish Awasthi said that the additional chief secretary, finance, has been asked to coordinate with the chief secretary’s office to implement the scheme for the poor in the state. Meanwhile, an order under the Karamchari Kalyan Board for payment of Rs 1,000 to daily wage workers has been issued and funds released to 5.57 lakh people. Another 20 lakh would be transferred the financial assistance shortly. “The CM has also made it clear that no religious congregation will take place in the state during the lockdown period,” Awasthi said.Meanwhile, after a video conferencing with President Ram Nath Kovind on Friday, governor Anandiben Patel has appealed to the Red Cross Society, civil society, NGOs and religious institutions to work along with the government to defeat coronavirus.

Title: VZM-Odisha border shut due to self-quarantine by tribals
Content:
Vizianagaram: Self-quarantine has taken a different turn in the porous Vizianagaram-Odisha tribal belt. While villagers in the plains have imposed a strict quarantine, tribals in the porous areas have sealed off their villages.

Sources in the forest department said that out of the 14 mandals in the Parvathipuram division, most share a very porous border with Koraput and Raigada districts in Odisha . Usually these routes are not monitored as they are not easy to reach. Many of these routes have been used for illegal across the border trade.

Due to Covid-19 scare, very few are slipping through the borders.

“Most of the border villagers are tribal. Many of their relatives live across the border in the districts of Odisha. Usually the locals use these paths to sidestep border norms,” said, G Lakshman Rao, DFO, Vizianagaram .

The forest department sources said the porous borders have always been used to sell banned commodities. “Now no one is willing to cross the border due to community quarantine by tribals living in these hamlets. The tribals have ensured that no outsider is allowed entry and no resident allowed to step out for too long,” said sources.

G Lachiah, a tribal and former president of Padmapuram village in Pachipenta mandal said: “We have decided to discourage people to leave the tribal villages. And people are taking no chances with Covid-19.”

Non-tribals from neighboring villages and mandals, who have used these routes to buy and sell are feeling the pinch. B Poli Raju, a native of Pachipenta village, said: “ Country liquor and tobacco products used to be easily available till recently. Now Covid-19 threat has ensured that nobody ventures out or walks in.”

Title: Good samaritans turn saviour for homeless poor, orphans
Content:
Vijayawada: Amidst the ongoing nationwide lockdown, several individuals and NGOs have coming forward to feed the homeless poor and orphans .

The homeless people are used to depend on alms donated by people or food occasionally distributed by charitable organisations.

However, the lockdown as part of containment measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19 has pushed many of the homeless and street beggars into trouble.

Four days ago, social activist Gopireddy Srinivasa Reddy from Nandyal has approached the police seeking permission to feed the poor during lockdown hours. The police have not only granted him permission but also asked him to encourage people with similar intent. Srinivasa Reddy and friends are giving around 500 food packets to the poor in the town.

Taking a cue from Srinivasa Reddy, many of his friends and classmates have started feeding the poor in their respective towns. Guntur district collector Samuel Anand Kumar held a meeting with the NGOs seeking their support to feed the poor.

He extended support to the organisations ready to feed the poor. He directed the police to provide the NGOs permission for providing food to orphans.

An NGO in Guntur, Amma charitable trust, has started distributing food to the poor at railway station, bus station and other public places.

In Vijayawada, a group of youngsters led by Md Aleem is serving food to about 50 street orphans in One-Town area.

Title: COVID-19: Tiger Shroff asks everyone to stay home so the selfless warriors working outside for our safety can go home and meet their families soon
Content: After the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Forensic Medical Board ruled out the murder angle in Sushant Singh Rajput’s death report, an audio tape of Dr Sudhir Gupta has been leaked wherein he reportedly claims that the late actor was ‘murdered’. When ETimes reached out to Sushant Singh Rajput’s family lawyer Vikas Singh for his reaction on the same, he stated, “To be honest, I tweeted my stand yesterday but I would like to speak to him before I take a final call. He is not answering my phone, what if he changes his stand, one doesn’t know. I will wait till I can talk to him.”

Title: UP government steps in to ensure food, care for stray animals
Content:
Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: As nationwide lockdown has left hundreds of stray animals to starve on the streets, the state government has decided to take help from SPCA (Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals) and NGOs to ensure food for them.

Stating that due to absence of food during lockdown, stray animals, especially dogs, may get aggressive or die, the government has directed the animal husbandry department to chart out a plan through which volunteers can provide food to animals.

Chief minister Yogi Adityanath has appointed principal secretary, animal husbandry, Bhuvnesh Kumar , as the nodal officer for the task.

His committee will also ensure adequate feed for cattle and fish, along with medicines and veterinary services during the lockdown period. Government said availability of food and medicines should also be ensured for cow protection centres, temporary/registered cow shelters, Kanji Houses and Kanha Upvans.

In an order issued on Thursday, veterinary services have been declared as essential service and government organisations, private clinics, veterinary pathologies and animal shelters will be allowed to operate. Production of animal food will be permitted and authorities have been asked to allow transport of such food, including hay, cattle feed, corn, soya, cattle and fish feed without any hindrance. Shops selling such products will also be categorised as essential service and allowed to operate. “District chief veterinary officers will be the nodal persons to ensure that such work is carried out without hindrance. Necessary passes should be issued to organisations producing and selling animal feed, and those transporting it, to markets,” principal secretary (animal husbandry) Bhuvnesh Kumar said.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 11 migrant workers reach district, screened
Content: KANPUR: A group of 11 migrant workers, hailing from Malda district of West Bengal , who fled from their workplace in Delhi and Greater Noida on their bicycle after the countrywide lockdown, reached Kannauj on Friday.The police rushed them to the district hospital where they underwent thermal screening and other medical tests. Later, they were made aware about precautionary norms to check the spread of coronavirus and then were allowed to proceed for their journey.“We intercepted 11 migrant workers riding bicycle at district border. Most of them were employed in factories at Delhi and Noida,” said a police official.They were on way to Malda district in West Bengal.The workers said that they had left their work places in Delhi and Greater Noida on March 23. “We will reach our native villages in the first week of April,” said Chavi Lal, one of the labourers.

Title: Prayer at home, Hyderabad mosques near empty
Content:
Mecca Masjid wears a deserted look, in Old City on Friday

HYDERABAD: Mosques across the city wore a deserted look on Friday after Telangana State Wakf Board, several prominent Muslim clerics and seminaries urged Muslims to offer prayers at home.

Taking into account the possible spread of Covid-19 during mass congregation, a common appeal was made to Muslims not to come out for offering prayers at mosques.

Amid fear of epidemic spread, Telangana State Wakf Board on Thursday has asked Muslims to offer prayers at their homes and instructed management committees of mosques to restrict the gatherings at the mosque to only five persons. AIMIM chief and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi urged Muslims not to step out their homes to go to mosques for offering prayers. All India Muslim Personal Law Board took a decision in this regard on Thursday night and appealed to every Muslim in the country to refrain from attending congressional prayers. Jamia Nizamia, a very old seminary of Hyderabad too made a similar appeal to offer Zohar (noon prayers) at Home.

After appeals pouring in, Muslims in twin cities restricted themselves to their houses on Friday. Historic Mecca Masjid too wore a deserted look this afternoon as the turn out was restricted to fifteen persons only. On every Friday, as many as 7,000 people throng to offer prayers. Other mosques across the city including Shahi Mosque public gardens, Darul-Shifa Mosque and Jama Masjid Musheerabad too witnessed meager turn out. All the mosques in old city were seen vacant since the public had obliged the appeals. The police too have has issued notices to the management of the mosque committees to restrict the gathering to only four persons. It further asked the management to remove the carpets from the floor and clean it after every prayer.

Title: NMC launches Covid-19 app to gather info on potential patients
Content: Nagpur: Probably a first in the state, Nagpur Municipal Corporation NMC ) has launched Covid-19 App on Friday. The citizens can record in the app if any they or anyone in family is having problems of cough, fever, and difficulty in breathing and the civic body will get details helping it to control the spread.Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe in association with HLL Lifecare, Government of India , launched the App on Friday. It can be downloaded by clicking the link (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1abB97jEnkrzvIzcOY0eebr_wcQ8tT_sJ/view?usp=drivesdk). The citizens can fill the information about their symptoms and submit. The app will detect whether they have related symptoms or not. A team of NMC doctors will get the alert in case of corona-like symptoms. It will contact the person and take further measures.To control Covid-19, NMC has also launched door-to-door containment drive in entire city to detect any cluster of patients, and also also to get detailed information of severe acute respiratory illness, high-risk patients. It has roped in ward-wise quick response teams (QRTs) to ensure social distancing and is sanitizing houses and areas in the vicinity of known patients. It has engaged Nuisance Detection Squad to find any establishments that continue operations with large number of employees despite ban.

Title: City’s electricity demand takes a dip, courtesy closed commercial units
Content:
Trichy: The nationwide lockdown has resulted in Tamil Nadu Generation and Distribution Corporation Limited (Tangedco) witnessing a marginal fall in the electricity demand in Trichy city. It is attributed to non-functioning commercial establishments and the bulk consumers of electricity.

Trichy Urban division has about 1.6 lakh domestic connection and 40,000 commercial connections all falling within city limits. Besides, parts of the city are also covered by Trichy East and Srirangam divisions. With the majority of the city falling under Trichy urban division, per-day electricity demand of the city is estimated at 40 MW usually.

However, ever since the city came under lockdown from March 24, Tangedco said that there is a slight dip in electricity consumption. Same is the case of Trichy East division. Though the residential buildings have started consuming more electricity than the normal days, the surge in demand was compensated by the non-functioning commercial establishments including showrooms, multiplex theatres and malls in the city.

“As of now, there is no surge in electricity demand despite residents consume more electricity for operating air conditioners. Against the routine demand of 40 MW per day in Trichy urban, only 35-37 MW is being consumed,” an official with Tangedco Trichy said.

Meanwhile, residents in the past two days are apprehensive of unannounced power shutdown in parts of the city during afternoon and evening hours. Locals in Cantonment, Karumandapam, Mannarpuram and Thillai Nagar reported unannounced power shutdown ranging from a few minutes to 1 hour since Wednesday. Tangedco sources, however, said that the minor outages in residential localities have nothing to do with demand and supply factor. “The outages in the localities were due to the minor repair and maintenance work,” Tangedco officials clarified.

Electricity department officials said that uninterrupted power supply will be ensured as a section of people are working from home since the lockdown.

Title: Railways making a trial coach to work as isolation ward
Content:
LUCKNOW: Railways has ordered its workshops to prepare a prototype coach that can work as an isolation ward for Covid-19 patients.

Non-AC sleeper and general class coaches may be converted into an isolation ward with minimum modifications. At present, a trial coach is being made at Coaching Depot, Delhi. It might be ready by Saturday (March 28).

GM, northern railway (NR) and north central railway (NCR), Rajiv Chaudhary, said the coach will be reviewed by medical experts so that it can be used in the time of medical emergency. In the video conferencing held by the Railway Board, on March 25, zonal railways have been asked to gear up and contribute in the country’s fight against Covid-19 pandemic.

At least 30 demonstrative rakes might be made by 15 railway workshops, two by each of the units.

Title: 500 Migrants Try To Walk Home 1,000km
Content:
Nagpur: Over 10,000 labourers from Chandrapur are stranded at Telangana border without food or water and not being allowed in as border is closed.

Maharashtra’s Chandrapur district administration and guardian minister Vijay Wadettiwar has taken up the matter of the stranded labourers with Telangana government. They had come to Telangana to work on farms during chilli picking season and are now returning as work has stopped.

Wadettiwar called CM Uddhav Thackeray and urged him to intervene in the matter. Wadettiwar stated Thackeray spoke to Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao and urged him to ensure food and shelter for all Maharashtrain labourers to which the latter has agreed. Thackeray has also agreed to provide food and shelter to the labourers from Telangana stuck anywhere in Maharashtra, he said. Wadettiwar also asked Chandrapur's collector and SP to share the list of names, places to stranded labourers and their phone numbers with Telangana administration and arrange for their relief.

Though senior police officials said that they have no specific information about incidents of hundreds of migrants workers from Telangana crossing the state borders in trucks during the period of lockdown, police sources confirmed that migrant workers from Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana working in cities like Visakhapatnam, Bengaluru and Hyderabad, have been illegally travelling in trucks returning to their home states after delivering supplies in Southern states. "More than 200 labourers and even drivers working in Visakhapatnam, Bengaluru and Hyderabad got into trucks that were returning to Rajasthan and Haryana from AP, Karnataka and Telangana. They reached Telangana-Maharashtra border and got down to have food. As it would be difficult to send them back, officials of both the states spoke to one another and allowed them to travel ahead in the same trucks," said a police source of Adilabad. While Adilabad SP Vishnua Warrier said that no vehicles carrying men and women was allowed to cross the border, Additional DG ( Law and Order) Jitender said that there was some information about people hiding in trucks and crossing the state borders to reach their native places but upon verification nothing was found. "We are checking all the trucks now. People are not being allowed to travel in trucks," additional DG said.

Meanwhile, more than 200 labourers were found travelling in two containers in Yavatmal on Friday.

On Thursday, about 300 were found in three containers bound for northern states that were intercepted by the police taking the total to over 500. According to Pandharkawda police, all these containers were loaded on the trucks and heading to Rajasthan, Gujarat, Haryana and other places from where these poor labourers hail. It was only after the police intercepted trucks at Pandharkawda, suspecting them to be carrying cattle that the fact came to light. The Adilabad police, however, denied having any information about containers ferrying men. The nationwide lockdown from Tuesday to contain coronavirus spread has led to massive exodus of migrant labourers, particularly those hailing from the northern states, as their livelihood has been severely hit.

The labourers were cramped inside the containers in inhuman conditions, making complete mockery of “social distancing”. They were seen sitting over each other in the cramped space.

Title: Fast-food seller in UP offers ‘cure’ for Covid-19, nabbed & sent to jail
Content:
Meerut: A 40-year-old fast-food seller in UP’s Meerut was on Friday arrested and sent to jail for what police said creating “public nuisance” after he offered a “miracle” medicine to cure the novel coronavirus.

“Pawan Yadav has been charged with Indian Penal Code’s section 420 (cheating), 268 (public nuisance) and section 66 of IT Act and sent to jail,” said superintendent of police (rural) Avinash Pandey.

Not only Yadav uploaded a 9-minute video holding the “miracle” medicine in his hand on social media platforms, but also offered himself to Prime Minister Narendra Modi “to be tested amid 1,000 novel coronavirus patients.”

According to police, Yadav generated curiosity on social media sites, and started getting phone calls.

“The entire 9-minute video is addressed to the Prime Minister. Yadav claimed the medicine was made 27 years ago and can destroy any form of virus, let alone novel coronavirus. He runs a small shop of fast food near a college. The video is simply aimed at drawing attention. We have arrested him,” the SP said.

Yadav also said that his entire family was consuming the medicine for the last six years and the disease cannot even “touch anyone of them”.

Title: Patient with SARI admitted
Content:
Vadodara: Panic spread in the Jekot village near Dahod after a woman there was admitted to a hospital and tested for COVID-19. Officials said that the woman was suffering from Severe Acute Respiratory Infection (SARI) and had no history indicating exposure to COVID-19 patients. As per the new guidelines, samples of patients having severe respiratory infections are also tested for COVID-19.

“The woman has been admitted taking necessary precautions as per the guidelines. Her samples will be sent to Vadodara for testing. She is a local and has not travelled abroad and has neither come in contact with any COVID-19 case,” said an official.tnn

Title: Fresh spell of hail, rain damages standing crops in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
‘I was about to harvest my crop when the rains started,’ said a farmer

BHOPAL: Unseasonal rainfall caused extensive damage to the standing rabi crops in many parts of Madhya Pradesh. Rain and hail at many place also damaged the crops of oranges, especially in the Agar Malwa region.

Mustard crops spread in large area of Gwalior, Chambal region are also affected adversely due to rainfall. Wheat and chana crops were ready for harvest when the yet another unseasonal spell of rain and hail struck the farms. The two crops are sown early in major part of the state, except in Chambal and Gwalior divisions.

Wheat and Chana in the Gwalior and Chambal region were still not ready for harvest like in other parts of the state, a farmer in Morena told TOI. These two crops are sown late in the region because of the dominance of mustard here, he added.

Beni Prasad, a farmer in Lakhapur village, said, “ I was about to harvest my crop when the rains started. It looks like I have suffered a huge loss”.

Harivallabh Patidar, an orange farmer of Agar Malwa said, “As the hail struck on the orange plants, the fruits fell down on the ground. Accompanying rainfall has also affected the crops badly.”

“Though the actual extent of damage is still unknown, it is believed that farmers in large part of the state in Bundelkhand, Vindhya Pradesh and Malwa region are most affected,” said one of the government sources requesting anonymity. The government may announce compensation to the farmers, but it is difficult to mobilize funds in the state where the annual budget is yet to be passed, added sources.

Covid-19 spread has already hit the economy and the Centre is also busy mobilizing funds for the relief and medical care, said government sources. Sources said the rainfall is likely to continue till March 30.

Title: Veggie mkt to function from Central bus stand
Content:
Trichy: The Trichy district administration has temporarily relocated the Uzhavar Sandhai functioning at Thennur Anna Nagar to the Central bus stand premises. The makeshift vegetable market will open on Saturday (March 28). Similarly, the congested Gandhi Market will be temporarily relocated to G Corner Ground at Ponmalai. The market will start functioning from there on March 30.

Trichy has two Uzhavar Sandhai complexes functioning at Thennur Anna Nagar and KK Nagar. As authorities are unable to manage the crowds, a decision was taken to ensure social distancing as part of the efforts to prevent the spread of Covid-19. “One-metre gap on all sides is being given for the traders to set up shops at the bus stand. The makeshift facility will function from Saturday morning,” an official source said.

Around 50-75 traders can be accommodated in the bus stand complex was recently disinfected by the Trichy Corporation.

District administration said that vegetable traders willing to relocate from the KK Nagar market will also be accommodated at the bus stand. Other Uzhavar Sandhai facilities in Lalgudi, Musiri and Thiruverumbur were relocated to the Lalgudi boys higher secondary school, Musiri boys higher secondary school and Thiruverumbur Mukkulathor higher secondary school from Saturday respectively. tnn

Title: Hyderabad: Home guard held for extorting students
Content: HYDERABAD: The coronavirus scare has given rise to a new racket. A home guard of Hyderabad police commissionerate and two others — a manager of a private hostel in SR Nagar and a residential society president — were arrested on the charges of extorting money from desperate students to get them no objection certificates (NOCs) issued from police to reach their native places in Andhra Pradesh. The trio was remanded to judicial custody on Friday.In their bid to encash the demand for NOCs from hostellers, Bheem Singh (40), home guard attached to the central zone police control room (PCR), in collusion with E Rama Krishna (42), manager of Pavan Boys’ Hostel, and Hari Singh Yadav (42), colony president of Bapu Nagar, began collecting money from the inmates of the hostel, SR Nagar police said.The issue came to light on Thursday night when SR Nagar SI D Ashok Naik received specific information on the trio extorting money. The SI along with a constable and a home guard rushed to BK Guda in SR Nagar and apprehended the trio.“The accused took Rs 100 each from seven students,” said a police official.Based on a complaint of the SI, a case was registered against the accused trio under sections 384 (extortion) and 420 (cheating) of the IPC.In the last few days, hundreds of students and private employees staying in private hostels had approached SR Nagar and Panjagutta police requesting to permit them to go to their native places in AP.Students and the employees approached cops after the hostel owners started forcing them to vacate rooms in the wake of the lockdown.

Title: Stranded in Lucknow? dial or WhatsApp UP 112 for help
Content:
24x7 support

LUCKNOW: The UP 112 has started a special service to rescue people stranded without means in the city or outside the district. To ensure that all such people reach their destinations, the UP 112 has set up a control room which will remain in touch with district magistrates. On the first day of the service the control room received 75 calls in just two hours.

Talking to TOI, Uttar Pradesh additional director-general, UP 112, Asim Arun said that in the last couple of days it was seen that many labourers and workers, stranded in different districts, had started walking down to their native places. Some of them were seen seeking lift from vehicles bringing essential commodities, including LPG cylinders and milk.

“After consulting the matter with senior officials we decided to forward all calls to control rooms set up in different districts,” said Arun. Highlighting main features of the special scheme, the ADG said that people, who are stuck anywhere, can dial 112 or send a Whatsapp on 7570000100. “In case you are sending us a Whatsapp then it must mention your name, phone number, the place where you are stuck along with the destination,” Arun said and added that the calls and messages will be forwarded to control rooms set up in each district under DMs who would make arrangement for ferrying the stranded people to their destinations.

Soon after the facility was launched on Friday, as many as 75 calls were received from different districts of the state.

Title: Hyderabad: Trapped Odisha workers plead with police for help
Content:
Workers hoping to get transport home in Yousufguda

HYDERABAD: Twenty-six migrant workers from Odisha who are stuck in Hyderabad for the last few days, on Friday approached Jubilee Hills Police seeking help. They said they have been without food or shelter for the last two days as they had run out of money.

“We have become weak without food. We need transport back to Odisha,’’ Manoj Kumar, one among the stranded, said in the letter to the police mentioning 26 names. They were travelling from Mumbai to Odisha whenthey got stranded in Hyderabad, a transit point. “Police have taken our letter, but not responded yet,” Manoj told TOI.

Meanwhile, many migrant marble workers from Rajasthan, who work in Yousufguda, were seen making an effort to leave the city and return to Rajasthan as they fear that they will not be in a position to purchase groceries in the next few days, as they do not have any money left. More than 25 people took to the streets with their luggage hoping to board some vehicle to reach Rajasthan.

Title: States nudge KT Rama Rao on migrants’ woes
Content:
KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: On the third day of India lockdown, a number of requests poured in from different states urging the Telangana state government to take care of migrant workers of the states working in Hyderabad. Several people stuck in different cities too sought help from IT minister KT Rama Rao in a crisis situation.

Jharkhand chief minister Hemant Soren urged chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and IT minister K T Rama Rao to provide necessary support to 5,000 workers from Jharkhand in Telangana. Jharkhand’s minister for drinking water and sanitation Mithilesh Kumar Thakur provided all the details. They also mentioned the workers were also at IIT, Hyderabad in Sangareddy. “We will take care. Not to worry,” KTR said in response to the Hemant Soren’s request on Twitter. A request also came from former Bihar chief minister Lalu Prasad Yadav’s son Tejashwi Yadav, the leader of the opposition and former deputy chief minister of Bihar. He said migrant labourers from Bihar were stranded at a house at Nade Ali Baig, Yakutpura in Hyderabad. “Kindly arrange for food for them during lockdown period,” he urged. KTR responded saying he would take care. Tejashwi Yadav also wrote to chief ministers of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Himachal Pradesh, West Bengal, and Delhi.

Meanwhile, a group of workers from Telangana also put out a video appeal to in which they requested CM KCR and minister KTR to help them. They said they were starving and many of the were packed in small accommodation for the last few days.

Title: Covid-19 fight: Ministers try to make presence felt
Content: LUCKNOW: Feeling left out of the battle against Covid-19, some UP ministers have found way to make their presence felt. While several have donated from their development funds, many others are going beyond to do their bit. Minister for law and justice, Brajesh Pathak, on Friday started a 24x7 control room at his official residence in Lucknow to help people of his assembly constituency. Anybody in Lucknow Central facing any kind of problem in the long-drawn lockdown can call up his helpline number and there are fair chances that Pathak would himself receive the call and direct the authorities concerned for their intervention.“I have publicised the mobile, WhatsApp and landline numbers so that the constituents can directly call my control room,” Pathak told TOI.MSME minister Siddharth Nath Singh is also the spokesperson of the state government. But nowadays, it’s additional chief secretary Awanish Awasthi and principal secretary, health, Amit Mohan Prasad , who are briefing the media about the government’s steps to tackle coronavirus challenge. Singh, who has also donated Rs 15 lakh to the state’s war kitty, is totally focussed on whatever he could do for the people of his constituency in Allahabad.He is also helping the needy from other states. Recently, when Telengana CM K Chandrashekar Rao called him up for rescuing a number of migrant labourers of his state in Varanasi, he intervened to ensure their safe and timely return to their native place.Energy minister Srikant Sharma ensured a series of measures for officials and staff in his department, including timely payment of salary to 50,000 staff on contract, availability of sanitizers and masks to the linesman and interest rebate on online payment of electricity dues. “I have set up different teams in my Mathura assembly constituency to stay at Mathura-Haryana border, where hundreds of labourers are gathering everyday from adjoining states. We are taking them to their native places with the help of district administration,” Sharma told TOI.Chief minister Yogi Adityanath has set up 11 relief committees to tackle the Covid-19 challenge. The committees have 20 IAS officers and 5 IPS officers, but no minister has been able to find a place.Meanwhile, Pathak has also written to the additional chief secretary, home, about “insufficient and incomplete measures by LMC in sanitising the city”.Quoting the provisions of the Disaster Management Act, the law minister said when the state was fighting against the pandemic, the primary duty was of the fire department, which is missing from action. “In other states, the fire department and fire tenders have been used extensively and deployed, while in Lucknow there is no deployment of fire department. It is most needed for sanitisation," the minister said in his letter.

Title: Urgent hearings online as Telangana courts shut till April 14
Content: HYDERABAD: Close on the heels of the Supreme Court’s steps to restrict functioning, the Telangana high court on Friday declared the closure of all courts in the state till April 14. A full bench comprising Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan, Justice MS Ramachandra Rao and Justice A Rajasheker Reddy, however, kept some avenues open for hearing urgent matters.The bench decided that advocates have to send their petitions to the registrar through e-mail and the same will be considered by the CJ. If it is decided that a hearing is required then it will take place through video conferencing medium. Lawyers will be sent a message with the allotted time slot and a video link. Through this method, lawyers can argue their cases from home.For those who cannot operate video-conferencing media by themselves, the high courts has arranged for other avenues. For instance, quarter number three near the chief minister’s Camp Office which is equipped with video-conferencing equipment can be used by lawyers to argue cases. Similar arrangements were also made for district and lower courts.“All cases where stay was granted in the past shall be extended until further orders. HC will hear urgent matters thrice a week through Skype and video-conferencing mode. Execution orders passed in favour of decree holders at the lower courts too are stayed till further orders,” registrar general A Venkateshwar Reddy said. “We will notify the procedure on the high court website for filing pleas through email and also the methods of e- hearings,” he added.All staff of courts in the state, except a few notified ones, were told to stay at home but be available over the phone. The high court would be monitoring judicial administration through principal district judges who have been asked to send periodical reports.Most of the staff of courts were told to stay at home but be available over phone. HC will be monitoring judicial administration through principal district judges

Title: Kuwait to allow illegal expats to go home
Content:
Hyderabad: Kuwait has announced a decree which would facilitate illegal residents and overstaying workers from leaving the country without any cases against them but much as Indian workers are relieved, the problem of international flights being suspended remains.

The amnesty will be from April 1- April 30, but the suspension of international flights to India has already been announced till April 14. Those who do not leave the country by the stipulated deadline will be required to pay penalties and will not be allowed to return to Kuwait once they are deported. If they make use of the opportunity presented in the decree announced by the interior minister, they can leave the country without paying fines. Kuwait has also been affected by the spread of coronavirus and as of March 27, as many as 225 cases were detected. Of these, 57 have recovered. The decree by deputy PM Anas Al-Saleh on March 26, however, did not give any reason why the opportunity was being given for illegal residents to leave without paying fines.

Title: 3 arrested for fake viral audio clip of ‘59 +ve corona cases’
Content:
Nagpur: Three persons, all from well-to-do families and excellent academic background, were arrested by city police in the early hours of Friday for recording and sharing a fake 4.52 minute audio clip ‘revealing scary details of 59 positive corona cases in Nagpur’. The clip went viral on social media after it was created on March 23, leading to a panic of sorts.

The three claim to have made the fake audio clip to scare their own children and family members, including the wife of one accused, who was not taking the corona outbreak seriously despite having just become a mother.

The culprits, speaking in convincing tones to each other, had referred to one Dr Kamlesh, who was on ventilator due to corona infection, and also discussed about Nagpur having around 200 suspect cases, which accentuated the fear in listeners. The speakers also referred to one ‘Nitin’, which sounded similar to a Vidarbha-based politician who is currently coordinating the fight against corona in the district.

Cyber cell, in collaboration with Sadar police station, managed to crack the case within 48 hours of filing a complaint against unidentified persons. The case is also the first where the source of a social media forward was traced, and the culprits brought to book. Joint CP Ravindra Kadam has announced Rs50,000 reward for the team that succeeded in doing this.

The persons arrested have been identified as Jay Gupta (37), Amit Pardhi (38), and Divyanshu Mishra (33), who were remanded to police custody for one day by the court later on Friday. Police had sought five days remand.

It’s learnt Gupta, a management graduate and working in the automobile industry, had teamed up with his friend Pardhi to create the audio clip. Pardhi, a mechanical engineer, had just left his job and was looking for another. It’s learnt Gupta had recorded the conversation and forwarded it to his friend Mishra.

Mishra, finance manager with a Delhi-based corporate company, later sent it to his wife, who has just delivered a baby. His wife sent it to a friend, and then the clip went viral. Gupta had later tried to destroy evidence by deleting the clip from the mobile phone of Mishra’s wife but the cops managed to pin the three down and even recovered the deleted data.

In view of the devastating effect of the clip, even the Press Information Bureau from New Delhi had issued a clarification. Even collector Ravindra Thakare and city civic chief Tukaram Mundhe too had to issue clarifications.

After the offence was registered, cybercrime team of APIs Vishal Mane, Keshav Wagh, and Ashwini Jagtap under DCP Shweta Khedkar and Addl CP Nilesh Bharne had started checking the forwards in the social media. They quizzed around 40 people before they were able to crack the case.

Sadar police team under PI Mahesh Bansode and others including head constable Vinod Tiwari also rounded up some people for questioning.

CP BK Upadhyay and Jt CP Kadam said there would be stringent action against the perpetrators.

Title: Hyderabad hearts open up to feed needy caught in coronavirus storm
Content: HYDERABAD: The coronavirus pandemic may have stopped people from shaking hands but it has not stopped people from lending a helping hand. In one such instance, a city couple have started a kitchen service at their Rajendranagar apartment to feed the homeless and labourers who find themselves stranded in wake of the lockdown.Aizazuddin, a 43-year-old IT professional and his wife Shehnaaz, cook the food along with the help of their two daughters and deliver the food in an autorickshaw. “We have began supplying food in parcels a few days ago. We serve rice and daal to nearly 150 people every day. As of now, we are bearing the expenditure” Aizaz said.The couple began surveying slums in their area and in Aramghar almost immediately after PM Narendra Modi announced a nation-wide lockdown.“We are focusing on feeding the homeless, migrant labourers and are distributing it to different groups every day” Aizaz said.“Our security guard helps us in distributing the food. Residents of our apartment are cooperative and understand the effort we are putting in,” says Shehnaaz.The couple had initially stocked rations for three days. “We want to continue this effort till the lockdown continues but it is becoming difficult for us to obtain the ration. Until now, I had procured it through a wholesaler whom I know,” said Aizaz.“Few of our friends who are also engaged in social work support this idea. We will take their help if we find it difficult,” he added. The family also spreads awareness on basic hygiene methods to curb the spread of corona The idea of a community kitchen is finding more takers around the city. In Attapur, a group of ten members have started a similar initiative. “We are ten friends working in the same company and have decided to supply meals for 1,000 people every day in and around the Aramghar area,” said Shamiudeen, one of the group’s members.

Title: Looking for a drink, M’rashtra, K’taka locals cross jungles to get into Goa
Content:
Keri: With a complete lockdown on all things alcoholic, people from the border villages of Maharashtra and Karnataka are desperate for a tipple.

Closed roads and highways mean there is no easy way into Goa for their usual urrack and feni. For the last three days villagers from Virdi, Talekhol, Aayi in Maharashtra have resorted to walking across the border into Goa through traditional jungle paths.

On Thursday, Valpoi police inspector Shivram Vaigankar received information that some people from neighbouring villages were to arrive in Shiroli. On investigation, police found villagers from Virdi and Talekhol had assembled at traditional liquor distillery units here. When it was revealed that they had come specially to drink urrak and feni, they were forced to disperse after police threatened to beat them with lathis.

Vaigankar told TOI, “We have taken serious note of those coming from Maharashtra. To control the movement of villagers from across the border, instructions have been given to police officials to take action against violators of the lockdown.”

In Surla of Sattari, a village on the border of Karnataka, liquor outlets have been closed for years now. However, there are some people who still sell alcohol on the down-low.

Khanapur police in Karnataka and the excise department on Thursday took stringent action against those who were attempting to carry liquor into Karnataka. Since, all the interstate roads have been blocked, buyers and sellers of alcohol are making use of old pathways and offbeat ghat roads to enter their destinations in Karnataka and Maharashtra.

Title: Celebrity chef Vishnu Manohar lines up lockdown menu
Content:
The 21-day lockdown has naturally shaken up many with the biggest concern being running out of food. Many others are wondering how much they can innovate in kitchen with limited ingredients. Celebrity chef Vishnu Manohar says there’s no need to panic as the average kitchen shelf packs enough punch to take us through

Common belief is that 3-week lockdown needs heavy stocking up of food items

No, because all essential commodities shops are open so you can always go and buy things. But even if that’s not the case, regular items like wheat flour, oil, rice, daal etc will be more than enough for you to have a variety of items that will keep your appetite satiated for the next three weeks. There is no need to panic and hoard up on grocery items. According to my experience, for a family of five the amount of items needed for a 21-day period is very minimal. For the typical three meals a day , you only need 10.5kg of rice, 6.5 litres of oil, 8.5kg tur daal etc. So why buy 20 or 30 kg rice at one go?

The other concern is that limited items can be made during the period

That’s the biggest misconception. Variety of food does not mean using dozens of ingredients. Variety can be brought about by cooking the same food item in a different way. For example, we all have had sprouts at one time or the other. So the item is same, but you can cook it like a gravy item, or have it like a salad. In fact, I suggest people make it like a bhurji. Just sauté onion, tomatoes and green chilli in oil and add the sprouts with salt etc. Don’t add water and let it sizzle. I guarantee that you will forget egg and paneer bhurji . So the food item is the same, but the way you approach a dish makes all the difference.

Parents are worried about kids, who are usually fussy eaters

Here the trick is, which obviously is possible because of the lockdown, to get them engaged in cooking process. The other day we decided to have pasta in white sauce. Now to get the kids involved I said to them we will make the pasta at home rather than boil the packaged product. So we kneaded wheat flour dough, flattened it and then cut strips which were boiled. Get kids involved in the cooking process , according to their age, which will ensure they enjoy eating it too. The white sauce can be made so easily if you have butter, milk and flour. I later gave it an Indian twist by serving it with tempered daal, which is somewhat like Gujarati daal dhokli.

Most have potatoes or onions stocked up and will avoid going to vegetable markets

They don’t need to either. Use the stuff that’s already there. Potatoes are extremely versatile and so many dishes can be made using it. Similarly, for those missing non-vegetarian food, and avoiding to buy it in the current scenario, patodi rassa is something that can offer you a nice spicy kick. The good reliable soyabean wadi is also there as an accompaniment for a spicy gravy. So there is no need to panic, no need to hoard food. There’s enough of it available in shops and even the stuff in your kitchen and fridge will go a long way.

Title: Spyware in garb of Covid-19 info: Police
Content: Hyderabad: Telangana police have issued an advisory asking people to be cautious of emails that come in the name of World Health Organisation ( WHO ) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) with information on Covid-19 as cyber criminals could steal sensitive information by installing spyware.On Thursday, the ministry of home affairs issued an advisory asking people to be wary of frauds in the name of coronavirus . “Some cyber fraudsters are circulating a malware link ‘corona live 1.1’ which, when opened, steals confidential data from the receiver’s phone or computer. Sometimes, cyber criminals are also taking advantage of rising conronavirus concerns for collecting charity,” the advisory warned.Police on Friday advised people to be wary of emails that come from CDC and WHO.
