Emails that come from adresses like CDC-covid19@cdc.gov will have an attachment of safety precautions. “Do not click on the attachment. If you click on the attachment, the information on your phone or computer will go to the fraudster,” police advised.As per the advisory, ‘corona live 1.1’ is a spyware. “So far, no complaints have been received. But, cybercrime police are getting phone calls from people who received such emails. They have been advised to not open any attachments or click on link in such mails or SMSes,” DSP Srinath Reddy said.

Title: Special control room set up by city police
Content:
Madurai: A special control room has been set up in the city on Friday to help the public during the lockdown period. The control room set up at the office of the city commissioner of police at Alagarkoil Road would function from 9am to 6pm daily.

Addressing reporters here on Friday, additional director general of police and Madurai city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvadham said that people could call the control room on 0452-2531044 and 0452-2531045 when they are in need of essential commodities and arrangements would be made by the police officials. He said that people can also contact the control room in case of any emergencies.

Devasirvadham said that since Section 144 is promulgated, nearly 2,000 police personnel are on the field to prevent the public from moving around the streets unnecessarily. This apart, five drones are also to be used to monitor the movement of people during the lockdown.

So far, 33 cases have been registered against those violating Section 144 promulgation in the city, he said and added that 332 two-wheelers were seized from those who were unnecessarily roaming around the city without any valid reasons. People should also cooperate with the officials in order to contain the spread of Covid-19 in the city, he added.

Title: Shahjahanpur’s Dalmiya sugar mill to manufacture ethanol-based sanitiser
Content:
Bareilly: Dalmiya sugar mill in Nigohi area of Shahjahanpur district will manufacture ethanol-based sanitiser to meet the requirement of the state government. The sugar mill will prepare nearly 8,000 litres of sanitiser from its distillery and supply it directly to the government. Alcohol-based sanitisers are extremely effective in preventing the covid-19 spread.

Earlier, the state government had sought proposals from sugar mills and private distilleries for manufacturing sanitiser as its demand shot through the roof.

High production of sanitiser by sugar mills will also help check its price in the market.

Deputy executive director of the sugar mill Kuldeep Kumar told TOI, “After getting a nod from the government, we have started the production of ethanol-based sanitiser in accordance with the WHO (World Health Organisation) guidelines. We have been granted permission to manufacture 96,000 litres sanitiser, while the monthly output will be nearly 8,000 litres. We have raw material available with us and our unit will ensure that we produce high quality sanitiser for the public.”

“We have prepared 500 litres sanitiser on the first day of production and the cost of the production is nearly Rs 150 per litre. We have also informed the district administration that we are able to meet their requirement,” he added.

Local resident Harshit Jain told TOI, “It’s a really nice step forward by the government as there is a shortage of sanitiser and we are forced to use spirit (isopropyl alcohol) for sanitising our hands. I hope the sanitiser will be provided to the public at reasonable price through district administration soon.”

Title: Lockdown cripples Hyd childline team
Content:
Hyderabad: Childline team members in Hyderabad, who play a decisive role in rescuing vulnerable children across the state, say they have been struggling to find shelter for rescued children and transportation for ChildLine staff due to the government imposed lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19.

Speaking to TOI, Y Madhavi, district coordinator and in-charge of Hyderabad Childline said, “After the lockdown was announced, we have rescued children in three sexual abuse cases, two physical abuse cases and a few medical help cases. We are getting at least two or three cases every day and the main problem we are facing while attending these cases is transportation and shelter.”

ChildLine teams also said that transportation for staff is becoming an issue as they are not being allowed to go anywhere using private transportation. Palsa Chennaiah, Railway Childline coordinator, Kacheguda child helpdesk said, “We have been facing difficulty like other Childline teams when it comes to transportation. We are planning to go and ask police for an ID card that will help us travel to attend emergency recues during the lockdown period.”

Nimboliadda Center in-charge and superintendent Maithili said, “As of now we have 44 children in the shelter, and we are denying new admissions as a precaution to contain the spread of Covid-19 cases. We are also ensuring that the staff are using sanitizers before they enter the premises.

“In case there are new rescues, we are asking the Childline teams to get the necessary medical tests done and take them to Sakhi centers until we get the test results,” she added.

Title: NU defers Phase-III of exams involving 2.20L students
Content: Nagpur: Following coronavirus lockdown of 21 days, the Nagpur University has decided to indefinitely defer its third and biggest phase of examinations in which over 2.20 lakh students were supposed to appear, as per its officials.The third phase involving over 283 papers was supposed to commence from April 3. It involved exams of major courses like BSc, BA and BE and regular students are supposed to appear in them.“We don’t have any choice but to postpone the exams following the lockdown which would continue till April 15. We are waiting for some directives from Maharashtra government. The officials of State Higher and Technical Department are busy with the ongoing crisis of coronavirus, so they’re yet to respond,” Board of Examination and Evaluation (BOEE) director Prafulla Sable told TOI.The university has already postponed its second phase of examinations involving 85 papers in which over one lakh students were supposed to appear. It was to start from March 26. NU’s first phase of examinations started from February 27 in which 133 papers were to be held. Due to outbreak of Covid-19 virus, the university has deferred 33 papers of this phase.“If we can start the exams by April 21, in case curfew is lifted, we would be able to complete it before June 25. We had actually advanced exam dates this time which proved handy for us. The fourth and last phase is slated to start from April 26 which involves engineering papers. We haven’t taken any decision on that yet,” Sable said.Registrar Neeraj Khaty had already informed TOI NU would conduct exams even on Sundays so those couldn’t be delayed further. He had also informed that paper setting, evaluation and moderation were already suspended by NU after receiving directives in this regard from the government.

Title: Med JAC seeks protective gear
Content: Representative of the Telangana government’s medical joint action committee Dr Putla Srinivas on Friday to discuss issues faced by doctors. “...We have requested for immediate supply of sufficient N95 masks, sanitisers and PPE kits. As we know, mean incubation period for Covid-19 is five days we have requested for self-imposed quarantine for all medical employees including ministerial staff by doing duty on rotation-basis without causing trouble for common people,” said Dr Srinivas. A transport facility for healthcare staff was also requested . TNN

Title: Bithri CHC becomes level 1 isolation ward, govt building & hotel converted into quarantine centres
Content:
Bareilly: With the cases of novel coronavirus increasing across the country, the local health department has started expanding the isolation and quarantine wards across Bareilly district.

The community health centre in Bithri Chainpur has been made an isolation ward, while a block meeting hall and a hotel near the CHC has been converted into a quarantine centre. Besides, the health department has reserved beds at three private medical colleges for both isolation and quarantine.

Additional director (health), Bareilly division, Dr Rakesh Dubey said, “The state government has directed us to create isolation and quarantine wards at level 1 and 2. We have set up a 30-bed isolation ward at the CHC in Bithri for level 1 and the block meeting hall and a private hotel in the area have been converted into mass quarantine centres. For level 2, we have reserved beds at three private medical colleges in Bareilly.”

“Although Bareilly district has not reported a covid-19 positive case, so far, we are expanding the isolation and quarantine wards as we don’t know how many wards we will require in the future. We are planning to use the CHC in Kyara, too, for the purpose.”

Apart from the CHC in Bithri Chainpur, two isolation wards of 10 beds each have been set up at the district hospital. According to officials, a total of 500 beds have been reserved at the three private medical colleges for isolating suspected cases, while quarantine wards with 980 additional beds have also been set up at these colleges. Besides, another 100-bed quarantine ward is almost ready at the building of new government hospital in Khuram Gotiya locality.

Chief medical officer Dr Vineet Shukla said, “Apart from the district hospital, the samples of suspected covid-19 cases can be collected at the private medical colleges. We will send those samples, along with the samples that we collected, to Lucknow for testing.”

Title: Homebound natives stuck on NH-8
Content:
Cars coming from Maharashtra were detained by police near Kapurai Crossroads

Vadodara: While the lockdown has brought out the good in police, the uniform is also tainted at times with shades of rudeness sometimes. Such an example was reported in Kapurai Crossroads on Friday, when 120-odd people from Surat were stopped from going to their hometown in Amreli district. Among the lot was a woman who was around 4-5 months pregnant and two small children.

“If you are pregnant, why are you travelling right now? Show me your medical certificates,” a cop on Vadodara border allegedly asked, stopping the diamond workers on the highway. Even after an entire day was spent convincing the cops that they were going to their own hometowns, they reportedly didn’t relent and made them sit in a bunch by the roadside for six long hours, flouting social distancing norm suggested by the government.

“I showed the cops medical papers of my wife Sangita but they argued that there was no need to travel as she wasn’t expecting soon. I work as diamond polisher in Surat and didn’t want to take any risk by staying back in Surat. So we were on our way to our hometown in Bhavnagar. Our vehicle was detained at about 11am and we were forced to sit by the roadside all day. They didn’t even care for the two kids travelling with us,” alleged Mohan Vadadariya.

Vadadariya told TOI that the cops then took their samples for Coronavirus tests.

Jayesh Bhataiya, a resident of Amreli who was also travelling with his family from Surat, alleged that they were not stopped anywhere within Surat, but no sooner they entered Vadodara, their vehicles were detained.

“Cops issued a memo to us and asked us to pay penalty at the regional transport office (RTO). But the RTO is closed due to lockdown. When we asked the cops how can we pay the penalty, they told us to pay when the RTO opens and then take our vehicles,” he said.

When asked why the cops made a pregnant woman wait by the roadside for hours, B H Rathod, PSI, Varnama police station said, “She was just four to five months pregnant. They shouldn’t have been on the road.”

“We detained about 20 vehicles that were moving on the highway amid the lockdown. Some of them were from Surat and Navsari while some were from Maharashtra. We allowed the people to go later,” he said, while defending the action.

When asked where they would stay, Rathod said that the mamlatdar will decide on that.

Title: Bareilly admin sets up community kitchens, Shahjahanpur DM calls for urgent donations
Content:
Bareilly: Amidst nationwide lockdown due to Covid-19 outbreak, the administration in Bareilly has set up at least 10 community kitchens at different locations in the district to ensure the food reaches the needy, Bareilly district magistrate (DM) Nitish Kumar said on Friday, adding that a ‘0581-2457042’ helpline has been set up.

The DM of Shahjahanpur, meanwhile on Friday, has appealed to locals to support those who are facing difficulties and make urgent donations to support the needy. The residents have been urged to donate directly into the bank account of ‘District Magistrate Corona Relief Fund Shahjahanpur’.

In Bareilly, community kitchens are being set up in cooperation with some of the city’s wealthy residents and additional district magistrate (city) Mahendra Kumar is tasked with the coordination work. One can approach ADM on ‘9454417198’ for any query related to contribution towards community kitchens.

ADM Kumar told TOI, “With the help of certain NGOs and private individuals we have set up 10 kitchens with food to fill up at least 5,000 stomachs daily. Around 100 people have approached us till now for the cause. We are issuing vehicle pass to move to such organisations and individuals.”

The officer said that after talking to police, it was decided that the food for the needy will reach through the area’s station house officers as the beat constables would know the exact situation on the ground.

In Shahjahanpur, district administration has set up five kitchens with the help of local gurudwaras and local industrialist. Supply of food materials is being done through dial 112 police team. Around 1,500 poor families, mostly daily wage earners and beggars, were given ration bags containing rice, flour and other items to ensure that they don’t sleep without food. Similarly, SSP S Channapa and DM Indra Vikram Singh have set up a kitchen near NH-24 where hundreds of people returning from Delhi and Uttarakhand were fed by the police.

Additional district magistrate Ram Sevak Dwivedi told TOI, “We are concerned about the safety of everyone and the people passing through Shahjahanpur are also examined by medical staff to ensure they are not carrying any infection. If someone needs support, the person can contact police or dial the DM’s control room number. All the SHOs have been instructed to act immediately on the stress calls and coordinate with administrative officials in providing food or goods for ration for the needy. We have made a centre at Roza mart on NH24 where hundreds of people are offered food and they are also educated about maintaining social distancing.”

“People have approached us for support but we cannot allow them to come on roads and distribute goods to the needy. This is why we are accepting contributions through ‘District Magistrate Corona Relief Fund Shahjahanpur’ account,” he added.

Title: Uttar Pradesh to pay for its people stranded in other states
Content: LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh will bear the expenses for arrangements made for its people in other states, chief minister Yogi Adityanath announced on Friday.The move comes a day after the chief minister spoke to his counterparts in neighbouring states and in Maharashtra , requesting them to take care of UP’s people.He also assured them that UP would look after people from their states as well.Chief secretary RK Tiwari has also written to his counterparts in these states, asking for food and boarding arrangements to be made for people from UP.On Friday, the CM also appointed senior bureaucrats and IPS officials as nodal officers for 12 states where a large population of people from UP, especially labourers, resides.As factories, offices and industries have come to a grinding halt due to the lockdown, thousands of people have been trying to make their way back to their hometowns. There have been reports of hundreds attempting to walk back from places like Delhi to their villages in UP.The CS has directed district magistrates and senior police official in border districts to ensure that those who have already entered the state are provided with shelter and food but under no circumstances are they allowed to travel further into the state. They should also coordinate with DMs and the police in other states to ensure that those trying to enter UP are stopped wherever they are but provided with food, shelter and basic necessities till the lockdown is in place.“If people continue crossing state borders, it will be a violation of the lockdown imposed by the Centre and would lead to the danger of the virus spreading. The CS has requested the other chief secretaries to ensure that due to closure of industries and offices, people from UP living in their states should not be evicted from their rented accommodations,” said a senior government official. The CS has requested his counterparts to provide to his to office in writing what arrangements had been made especially for those from UP in these states.On Thursday, the CM spoke to Bihar deputy CM Sushil Modi, Uttarakhand CM Trivendra Singh Rawat , Haryana CM ML Khattar and Maharashtra, assuring them that people from their states would be looked after in UP and asking that people from UP were also looked after in their respective states.“UP will bear the expenses for the arrangements made for our people in other states. The Centre has also made provision for their expenses to be covered under the national disaster relief fund. I have appointed 12 IAS officers for states where there is a high population of people from UP. An IPS officer will also assist them in coordinating with the governments of these states to ensure that people from UP do not face any problem and people from these states in UP are also comfortable,” the CM said. He requested people to stay where they are, “especially the labour class which has started walking towards their homes”.

Title: Three more government labs begin testing in Telangana, private labs to charge Rs 4,500 for test
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Three more government labs began testing for the novel coronavirus in the last two days. Gandhi Hospital and Osmania Medical College in Hyderabad have already been conducting the tests. Apart from this, the Indian Council of Medical Research has authorised five private labs in Hyderabad to conduct Covid-19 tests.

Fever Hospital, NIMS and Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) began taking the samples and doing the coronavirus tests. In Fever Hospital, out of 20 samples tested, two came positive on Thursday and Friday. IPM test results are being sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, for further confirmation, Fever Hospital superintendent Dr K Shankar, who is also in-charge of IPM, said.

However, the private labs though having real-Time PCR equipment and imported testing kits have been asked to wait till the Telangana government issues separate orders.

Director of public health Dr G Srinivasva Rao told TOI, “We are going issue guidelines for coronavirus testing to private labs. As it is an infectious disease, we need to have surveillance and reporting. We have enough kits even if we get more samples.”

He said hospitals should collect nasal and throat swab samples of suspect cases and send them to labs.

Director of medical education Ramesh Reddy said MGM Hospital in Warangal will also soon start taking the samples and testing them. “The tests will be sent to NIV, Pune, and confirmed. ICMR is sending the testing kits,” he said.

He said the spike in the positive cases in Telangana has got nothing to do with increased testing but is related to more samples being collected.

Apollo Hospitals said it would start conducting the tests once the state government issues guidelines. Vijaya Diagnostics Centre, which was also allowed by the Centre to conduct he tests, said it would collect Rs 4,500 per test. The tests would be done only at its Somajiguda centre.

Title: Block-level health teams to visit villages, towns to screen sick people
Content:
Bareilly: Block-level health teams will now visit villages and towns to screen people who have fallen sick upon returning home from cities after the lockdown.

According to health department officials, with scores of migrant workers returning to their villages, locals are calling them out of fear that the returning people might be carrying novel coronavirus with them to the villages. Officials said on receiving complaints, the block team would visit the village or town for the screening of the suspected person.

Chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Vineet Shukla said, “We have been receiving complaints such as someone has returned from Delhi and is suffering from fever or a migrant worker has cold and cough. If workers are returning to their homes from metro cities like Delhi and Mumbai, it does not mean that they are suspected cases of Covid-19. But, as we have been receiving complaints from locals stating that their neighbour who has returned from the city is sick and might be a covid-19 positive patient, the block-level health team will visit the sick person and screen him. The team led by a medical officer will conduct check-up only if they will receive a complaint.”

If the patient is sick, they will give him medicines. “However, we will take the sample for testing novel coronavirus only if the person will show symptoms of covid-19. If any suspected case is found, the patient will be admitted to the isolation ward of the community health centre,” said the CMO.

For visiting the house of patients in rural areas, the block team can use ambulance or vehicles of Rashtriye Bal Swasth Karyakaram (RBSK). Officials said RBSK programme has been temporarily suspended due to the spread of novel coronavirus in the country.

Meanwhile, the health department on Friday conducted health check-up of 34 migrant workers coming from Delhi and Meerut. They were on their way home in Shahjahanpur and their bus from the Meerut depot took a halt at Satellite bus stand.

Sources said the health check-up was conducted on the directions of the chief minister’s office. A health team led by Dr Ajmer Singh and Dr Ranjikant screened all the 34 migrant workers and none of them was found to be sick. They, later, left for their native place.

Title: Man shot dead after nephew’s buffalo grazes neighbour’s field
Content:
Bareilly: A 45-year-old man, Mahesh, of Mehuahasanganj village under Rajpur police station in Sambhal district was shot dead on Friday in the ensuing brawl after his nephew’s buffalo entered the field of his neighbour.

Upon getting information, police rushed to the spot and sent the body for post-mortem examination. Meanwhile, the accused managed to flee the scene.

Police said one Vijay Pal had bought a piece of land from Rajendra of neighbouring village Pavsara and had started construction on the land.

On Friday, after Pal’s buffalo entered Rajendra’s field located adjacent to his land, Rajendra’s two sons started abusing Pal, said police.

Sensing the situation going out of control, Pal’s uncle Mahesh intervened into the matter and tried to pacify them. According to witnesses, as soon as Mahesh intervened, Rajendra’ family members started indiscriminate firing from the terrace of their house and two bullets struck Mahesh into his stomach.

Mahesh was rushed to the community health centre, where doctors proclaimed him dead upon arrival.

According to circle officer KK Saroj, following a complaint lodged by Mahesh’s son Avdesh, an FIR has been registered against Rajendra’s five sons, who are absconding.

“We are conducting raids to nab the accused. They will be arrested soon,” said the police officer.

Title: Experts lay trap in rubber factory to tranquilise elusive tigress
Content:
Bareilly: To tranquilise the elusive tigress who has made a defunct rubber factory its home, the forest department has now placed a trap in one of its rooms where the big cat prefers to take rest.

Forest officials said that they have kept a goat as bait. They expect the trap’s automatic door to shut on its own when the tigress tries to enter the room. Once trapped in a “safe location”, it will be easier for experts to tranquilise the animal.

On Friday, divisional forest officer Bharat Lal explained, “After monitoring the movement of tigress within the rubber factory, we have placed a trap in the room where it visits more often. When the big cat is trapped here, an expert will fire a dart from ventilator or terrace to tranquilise the animal.” The abandoned factory has old tunnels, trenches and tanks, and so, it is difficult to tranquilise it here, he said.

Officials said a team of forest staff while combing the area saw the tigress resting near a plant within the factory on Thursday. Though the camera traps installed on the factory premises captured the images of the tigress a few times and forest staff found its pugmarks, it was the first time when someone had actually spotted it. The forest department had earlier placed three cages with bait to trap the tigress, but to no success.

Meanwhile, a team from Wildlife Trust of India (WTI), which was assisting forest department in the operation, has left Bareilly following the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. However, officials said their operation is still underway and they have called additional forest staff from adjoining district.

The Synthetics and Chemicals Limited - known as the rubber factory here - spans across 1,200 acres and has remained shut since 1999. Over the years, it has turned into a mini-forest providing a safe haven for big cats due to easy availability of prey, plenty of water in large tanks, dense forest cover, soft grass and suitable places to hide.

A sub-adult tiger was tranquilised from the factory in 2018. Even a leopard spent two years here.

Title: Man suffering from TB dies at government hospital, samples sent for Covid-19 test
Content:
Bareilly: A 23-year-old youth, who was suffering from tuberculosis (TB), passed away during treatment at a government hospital in Moradabad on Friday. Health department officials said that the patient’s blood samples have been sent to lab to know if he was suffering from Covid-19, or not.

According to chief medical officer (CMO) Dr MC Garg, the patient had completed the treatment for TB a while ago. He was a resident of Hathivala Mandir area in Moradabad. “It may a relapse of TB,” he said.

“The youth was admitted to the emergency ward a few days ago. He was in the last stage of TB. Doctors also suspected that it was a coronavirus positive case. So, the nodal officer of Covid-19 also examined him and talked to his family to get his detailed history,” CMO said.

The family said that he was suffering from TB for the last two months. “During preliminary health audit, he didn’t seem to be a Covid-19 infected patient. However, we have sent his blood samples for further examination,” the CMO added.

Title: Veggie prices rise on supply glitches but situation manageable
Content:
Nagpur: The situation on commodities front remained manageable in the city even with bulk traders in vegetables and fruits absent at the agriculture produce marketing committee’s (APMC) yard in Kalamna. The vegetable traders will only begin working on Tuesday while fruit traders are off for full 21 days.

The neighbourhood fruit and vegetable vendors said they could manage getting supplies from semi-wholesalers at Santra Market and Cotton Market respectively. The traders here work for a limited period however.

The semi-wholesalers have been operating for 2-3 hours in the morning till 9 am. With Kalamna now shutting down, uncertainty has increased. Other essential commodities too were available though there were some hitches in procuring fresh stocks especially for fast moving consumer goods.

Dealers in medicine too were apprehensive about not being able to get fresh stocks due to restrictions on transport. The matter has been taken up with the police commissioner. The supplies of grain and milk continued without disruption.

There was an increase of Rs 10 to 25 per kg in the rates of common vegetables. Vendors TOI spoke to said potatoes that were sold at Rs 25 to 30 a kg when things were normal are now being sold at Rs 40. Onions have touched Rs 35 to 40 kg fom Rs 30 to 35. Tomatoes that were Rs 15 to 20 a kg are now upto Rs 30, they said.

Mohamed Vakil, a vendor at Amravati Road, said, “ we could manage till now. Let’s see if there is enough stock at Cotton Market even tomorrow, because Kalamana is closed till Tuesday.”

Next to him, a fruit vendor Seema Naik said fruits like bananas and grapes were still available in enough quantity. If not abundant supply there is no shortage also.

The complaint among the grocers was that none of the FMCG distributors were sending stocks. There was a dearth of branded disinfectants like Dettol too. Anusuya Majgaonkar of Anusuya Kirana near Ravi Nagar said, “we have enough grains but none of the companies’ distributors are replenishing stocks. Finally, I got a call from a detergent maker. Hope he delivers fast.”

Virendra Thakkar of Logists Park Pvt Ltd said, “some permissions are being granted, many applications are being turned down.” Logistics Park is the sole distribution centre of pharmaceutical companies like Lupin, Cadila, Mylan, Shreya Pharma. FMCG companies include ITC, Reckitt Benckiser, Marico among others.

He said there was a shortage of disinfectants like Dettol and Savlon because stocks were lying at the godowns. The transportation from the godowns has now begun but fresh stock needs to come from manufacturing centres too. Else, the supplies may not last beyond 10 days or so.

Hetal Thakker, president of Nagpur Chemists and Druggists Association, said traders had taken up the issue of bottlenecks in transportation with the commissioner of police and the problem will be resolved.

A group of cooking gas delivery men said these days they were delivering the cylinder at the doorstep instead of taking it inside the homes to avoid contact.

Title: Saving lives top priority: Gehlot
Content:
Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Friday said there is nothing more important to his government than protecting the life of the people at this critical juncture. The CM called PM Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah and sought support in the wake of pandemic.

Gehlot on Friday evening was discussing the measures taken by the government to fight coronavirus menace with opposition leader Gulab Chand Kataria and state BJP president Satish Poonia at his residence in presence of senior officials.

The chief minister said that the government will take their suggestions very seriously and act on them. Chief minister said that all sections of the people were affected due to the lockdown, but its biggest blow is on the daily wage labourers, agricultural labourers, street vendors and the poor living in slums. The government will ensure that the poor and needy do not have to sleep hungry due to the lockdown. In this hour of crisis, it is to be ensured that animals and birds should get fodder, grain and water, he said.

He exhorted philanthropists, public representatives, representatives of institutions to come forward and generous contribute to his cause. He directed the officials of animal husbandry department to set up groups at state and district level for arranging fodder and grain and water for birds and animals. He said the government is getting full support people in Chief Minister Kovid-19 Relief Fund. The Chief Minister said that the government is providing food packets to poor families in urban areas. A relief package of Rs 2,000 crore has also been announced to provide relief to the needy families.

Gehlot informed that Rs 310 crore has been released to people whose livelihood affected due to the lockdown. The government will provide Rs 1,000 per family. He urged both public representatives to cooperate with the government in providing ration and other help to the poor. During the discussion, health minister, Raghu Sharma said 46 patients were found positive for coronavirus in the state so far. “We have also asked private hospitals in the state to be prepared to provide health services in case of emergency situation,” he said.

Chief secretary D B Gupta said a core group of senior officials has been formed at the state level for round the clock monitoring and find solution to the problems faced by the public.

Title: Arunachal CM pats officials for helping students facing racism
Content:
Trichy: The timely aid by Srirangam sub-collector in arranging essential commodities for a group of students from Arunachal Pradesh has earned the appreciation of the chief minister of Arunachal Pradesh, Pema Khandu. While the students ventured out to purchase essential commodities during the lockdown put in place to tackle the spread of Covid-19, they faced racial discrimination from few locals.

Sources said that a group of 15 students hailing from various parts of Arunachal Pradesh, studying in the Art and Science College in Trichy, were staying in a rented apartment near their college. Following the nation-wide lockdown, the attempts made by these students to buy food products failed as they were being racially discriminated by a section of people here.

Official sources said that the students were being criticized for their appearance. Subsequently, the students contacted the helpline of Arunachal Pradesh government. Officials with the government of the northeast state alerted the officials of district administration in Trichy.

Sources said that Srirangam sub-collector Sibi Adhithya, who was apprised about the incident, insisted that these students should not step out of their apartment. The district administration then with the help of the revenue department employees purchased and delivered the essential commodities to the students. As the Arunachal Pradesh government came to know of this effort taken by the district administration, Khandu took to twitter to thank and appreciate Adithya’s efforts in helping the students in need.

Title: Sanitary workers assigned only for quarantined houses
Content:
Trichy: The city corporation has assigned an exclusive team of sanitary workers and vehicles to collect and dispose waste from houses having people under home quarantine. The civic body said that the separate waste collection mechanism was initiated on Friday as a precautionary move and to allay fears among neighbours.

The urban local body has allotted at least two vehicles in each of the four zones here for the exclusive door-to-door waste collection from around 2,000 quarantined houses in the city as on Friday. Each zone will be allotted up to four sanitary workers.

The sanitary workers and vehicles will be disinfected before and after collection of waste. “Though it is not proven that novel coronavirus may spread through waste, we do not want to take any chances. Since nearby residents are apprehensive over common waste collection practice, we initiated the separate waste collection process,” an official with the corporation said.

Unlike the routine waste collection, the civic body said that the waste collected from the houses under isolation will be incinerated at the micro compost centres. “People under home-quarantine are extremely cooperative to the exclusive waste collection process,” a sanitary official with Trichy Corporation added.

Sanitary workers collecting waste from quarantine homes have been provided with face masks and hand gloves. The workers are periodically disinfected, the official added.

Title: Excise dept wary of bootlegging
Content:
Jaipur: For tipplers, nothing could be more tormenting than the ongoing lockdown. They are ready to pay anything a black marketer demands. But there are not many at the moment to meet the demand.

A senior official in the excise department said such situations are a perfect foil for a black market to thrive, but the travel restrictions and sealed borders have plugged all such possibilities.

But he said that it is a peculiar social issue that led Kerala and Punjab to keep liquor in the essential items list. In Punjab, the shops were shut down after curfew was clamped down. Kerala too flowed suit. But in Haryana, shops were open till Wednesday and closed after opposition criticism and on fears of collecting crowds.

But there is a fear of bootlegging taking place which is a main reason for hooch tragedies witnessed in the past. A senior official in the excise department said they are keeping a watch.

“The demand for liquor cannot be eliminated as some people are used to it. In such situations, there is real chance for bootlegging. We are alert to this possibility,” said the official.

Abstinence is a long process. In the absence of liquor, the regulars develop behavioral problems and they need to be counselled which is not possible under the current circumstances, said the official. On Friday, a man in Kerala committed suicide for not finding his daily kick. That was one of the reasons the southern state had allowed outlets to open before the countrywide lockdown was imposed.

The state had also planned to facilitate home delivery of liquor. But move was subsequently scotched in view of the practical problems.

For many states, liquor is a major revenue churner. Rajasthan gets around 8,000 crore annually from liquor. It has already received the application money of Rs 860 crore for retail liquor shops.

The fund-strapped government was banking on excise department for meeting its revenue shortfall. It had made several new changes to its liquor policy for 2020-21 to increase the income, including giving permission to all types of hotels and restaurants for selling liquor.

But the lockdown will seriously impact the revenue targets it had set earlier.

Title: Rajasthan: Two more patient scured, take total to 5
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Even as Covid-19 cases continue to rise in the state, news that's holding out hope to citizens and giving confidence to healthcare workers, who are working tirelessly to contain the disease, has come from SN Medical College, Jodhpur. Two Covid-19 patients have tested negative in two successive tests at the hospital.

The two were undergoing treatment at MDM Hospital attached to the medical college. Three patients have already been cured in SMS Medical College, Jaipur, taking the total cured patients to five in the state so far.

He had asked villagers not to spread rumours

An Italian tourist couple and a 85-year-old person, who returned from Dubai, have already been declared cured by the state government.

“Two Covid-19 patients have tested negative for the disease. One of them was shifted from Pali to MDM Hospital, Jodhpur, while another is a 58-year-old woman, who had returned from Turkey along with her 61-yearold husband,” said Dr G L Meena, principal and controller, SN Medical College, Jodhpur.

The patient from Pali, a 39-year-old, had tested positive for Covid-19 on March 21. He had returned from Dubai on March 18. He landed at Mumbai airport and travelled by train from Mumbai to Pali. He got off the train at Rani station and travelled in a jeep with other passengers to Sumerpur, his home, in Pali district. On March 22, he was shifted to MDM Hospital, Jodhpur.

In a video, which went viral, he had addressed his villagers in Pali and appealed to them not to panic and that he would get well and return home soon. He had also appealed to the villagers not to spread rumours on Covid-19.

A 59-year-old woman, who had travelled to Turkey, also tested negative for the disease after undergoing treatment at MDM Hospital.

Title: Social workers in Rampur go online to feed the needy
Content:
Rampur: Social workers and volunteers in Rampur are increasingly using social networking sites to distribute food and the other edible items to the poor during the nationwide Covid-19 lockdown. The homeless, e-rickshaw drivers, daily wagers are the worst hit as the city has come to a standstill.

Making use of the social networking sites, people are uploading photographs of the poor on their Facebook and WhatsApp pages with their addresses and asking social workers to help them. Some of the needy are also posting photographs with their addresses requesting help.

On Friday morning, photograph of a handwritten open letter of a girl whose ailing father who pulls rickshaw for a living went viral on social networking sites. He is currently suffering from paralysis. The family has appealed for help as they are left without food during the lockdown. She had also mentioned her address in her letter.

Fawad Khan, president of a local NGO, said, “After reading the letter of the girl on my Facebook wall, we immediately reached out to the girl and her father. We provided them with 20kg of food ration.”

“The girl’s family said that the only bread-earning member - 55-year-old Firasat Khan - is suffering from paralysis and they had not eaten food for the past day,” Khan said, adding, “We are maintaining a social distance while distributing the food packages to the needy.”

According to him, some volunteers have distributed around 500 ration packages of 10 kg each consisting of wheat, rice, sugar, tea and pulses.

Title: University of Hyderabad researcher develops vaccine candidate
Content: HYDERABAD: Hyderabad has joined the scientific race to find a vaccine for novel coronavirus. A researcher from University of Hyderabad (UoH) has already developed a “vaccine candidate”, crossing the first hurdle in developing a new vaccine that could help prevent the spread of Covid-19. With coronavirus likely to emerge season after season like SARS and MERS viruses, a vaccine could help contain the rogue germ.Dr Seema Mishra of department of biochemistry, School of Life Sciences, UoH, designed the potential vaccine candidates, which will help in development of actual vaccine. She identified the vaccine candidates as ‘T cell epitopes’. They will help in understanding all structural and non-structural proteins of Covid-19 for experimental testing. “Right now, best defence to prevent further Covid-19 infections is social distancing. Vaccination will take some more time due to the need for further work on these candidate epitopes. We are hopeful that our computational findings will provide a cost-and time-effective framework for rapid experimental trials towards an effective Covid-19 vaccine,” she said.Like other viruses, novel coronavirus is a protein molecule with a lipid of fat covering or coat. But, it has its own genetic make-up that makes it different from other viruses.Dr Seema disseminated her finding to scientific community worldwide through chemistry research and blueprint platform called ‘ChemRXiV’. She said laboratory studies (in vitro) are needed for conclusive evidence. “These vaccine candidates are small coronaviral peptides, molecules which are used by cells to trigger immune response to destroy cells harbouring these viral peptides. Using powerful immune-informatics approaches with computational software, I designed these potential epitopes (part of antigen recognised by immune system) in a way that can be used to vaccinate entire population,” she said.A UoH statement said vaccine discovery usually takes 15 years, but powerful computational tools helped in enlisting these vaccine candidates in 10 days. A ranked list of potential candidate vaccines, based on how effectively they will be used by human cells to stop the virus , is generated by Dr Seema. “With no matches present in human protein pool, these coronaviral epitopes pose no cross-reactivity to human cells and hence, immune response will be against viral proteins and not human proteins,” the statement said, adding that these results will have to be investigated experimentally to provide conclusive evidence.This research is first such study on Covid-19 vaccine design from India.

Title: Here residents share cleaning and waste disposal tasks
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The lockdown of the city might have helped to break the chain of Covid-19 transmission. But, it has also broken the ‘chain of daily life’ in city’s apartments. Residents, who had been served by helpers, security personnel and home nurses in apartments, have started to feel the pinch of the lockdown.A quick, random check at city’s apartment complexes revealed that majority of the residents have risen to the new challenge. “We have around 70 apartments with 60% occupancy. We used to employ three cleaning workers. These days only one person can reach for work. The residents happily divide the rest of the work among themselves. They have taken up cleaning of the lobby and common area on a daily basis,” said Anand Thomas, secretary of Kowdiar Manor owners’ association.Daily waste disposal is among the major issues faced by the residents post the lockdown. “We have an incinerator with which we burn the paper and sanitary waste. We have contracted a corporation authorized agency to collect the food waste, but they haven’t turned up for the last five days. We are planning to use incinerator as a temporary arrangement to burn wet waste. Plastic waste is collected and handed over at corporation collection points. We can keep that here till the crisis is over,” added Anand.G T Raveendran, secretary, Samrudhi Thampurans Owners’ Association, Thampuranmukku, said that the residents have divided the cleaning work among themselves as the two housekeeping staff can’t reach for work due to police checking.“There are 40 apartments here. The lobby area and floor are cleaned by apartment owners on rotation. It is not much difficult to maintain the area as we all work collectively. We have a waste converter to process organic waste. It was earlier managed by the cleaning staff, now the residents bring the waste down, drop that in the machine and one of us operates it. It will take 24 hours to convert it to manure,” said Raveendran.The association also arranged bulk purchase of groceries, milk and vegetables for residents. “We have tied up for direct supply of milk, vegetables and grocery to all flats. Consumerfed mobile shop supplied grocery to us on Thursday,” said Raveendran.Praveen Manikantan, a resident of SFS Cyberpalm, Akkulam, said the residents there had sent the food waste to a nearby farm as cleaning workers were absent.Environmentalist Shibu K N said that it is the duty of each citizen to minimize the garbage generated in this hour of crisis. “Try to make new recipes by using the leftover vegetables, which we normally put in the bin. Also, try to use the vegetable waste as compost for plants. Even in a flat, this is possible as vegetable waste can be used as organic fertilizer for flowering plants on the balcony,” he said. Shibu also urges city residents to try to boost the confidence of cleaning workers. “They are scared too with a lot of news on disease all around. Try to segregate and wrap materials like used masks and gloves. Speak to them empathetically. Encourage them to wash hands in between their work,” he said.

Title: Tellapur residents cry foul as villagers block roads
Content:
Hyderabad: The blockage of roads connecting Tellapur to the rest of the city have left residents of the area fearing that they will remain isolated in case of an emergency.

The roads have been blocked by villagers in the area, say residents.

Abhishek Asthana, who lives at Indus Crest Apartment, said, “The Osman Nagar village road has been blocked using branches. While we understand that villagers want to protect themselves during this time, it could hamper emergency cases.”

The apartment complex is in Osman Nagar, a village that is part of the Tellapur municipality. The road that has been blocked connects locals to Lingampally and Nallagandla.

Asthana said that there are road blocks on both sides of the road. “Pregnant women, elderly and those who are ailing are finding it difficult to enter the city,” he added.

Amit Bharti, another local, said, “The day after the lockdown was announced, villagers blocked the road. There was no space to take a car out and only a bike can pass. Since my flat mates cannot ride a bike, only I have to go out to get supplies which is tedious.”

Srinivas A, who lives at an apartment complex down the same road, said, “My mother is a senior citizen. Getting medicines for her has become a problem. If she needs medical attention, I fear we will be in a tough position.”

Title: Kerala government suspends IAS officer who violated home-quarantine
Content:
A bed and other essential items are seen inside a quarantine facility of Southern Naval Command to combat Covi... Read More

LUCKNOW/KOLLAM: IAS officer Anupam Mishra, who violated home-quarantine instructions after his return to Kerala from Singapore and left for his native place in UP’s Kanpur district, was suspended from service pending a departmental inquiry.

Health officials in UP’s Kanpur and Sultanpur districts had been looking for Mishra, a Kerala cadre officer who had been booked by the Kerala government for not adhering to the mandatory quarantine prescribed to al travellers, and finally tracked him down to his grandfather’s house in Sultanpur, UP. Violating the quarantine, Mishra, who belongs to Kanpur’s Swaroop Nagar Colony, had returned to his home from Kerala four days ago.

When health officials in Kanpur reached his residence, they learned that he had moved to his grandfather’s place in Sultanpur on March 23 to participate in a puja.

Sultanpur CMO CBN Tripathi, who tracked down Mishra, said: “He and six members of his family have been isolated in their home.”

According to an official statement by Kollam district magistrate Abdul Nasser, “Newly-wed Anupam Mishra and his wife returned from Singapore on March 19 and were advised home-quarantine for two weeks. Instead of staying at his official residence, he left for Bengaluru with his wife the same day. Now we know that he has gone back to his hometown in UP.”

Nasser told TOI that though Mishra did not show any symptoms, the protocol says every traveller should be quarantined. “The point is that he left without informing anyone,” he said.

Sources said Mishra and his wife could be quarantined in Kanpur and their contacts would also be traced. “The officer went to Bengaluru and met his relatives. He then took a flight, which means that people in the flight are also to be tracked and tested. Besides, his family members in Kanpur will be screened for infection,” an official involved in surveillance said.

The bureaucrat fraternity, at least in Kerela, is not happy about the way Mishra behaved, saying it was irresponsible and the government should act tough.

A senior police officer in Kerala said, “Kerala is among the worst-hit states in India. It also has a high number of people with travel histories. If someone from the government takes orders lightly, the general public is bound to follow. Action must follow to establish that no one is above the law.”

TOI tried to contact Mishra but he was not available for comment.

(With inputs from Faiz Rehman Siddiqui in Kanpur)

Title: Now, helpline for employees of essential services
Content:
Hyderabad: Employees of the essential services sector can use the Hyderabad police helpline: 040-23434343, if they face difficulties during commutation in the the city.

Hyderabad police in press note said that that the 24- hour helpline can be used in case of any hindrance to movement. “The officers will also co-ordinate the movement of vehicles from one district to another. It will facilitate loading, unloading and further distribution of goods to the last end,” the press note stated.

Meanwhile, for the benefit of essential service providers, electronic passes will be issued by city police. The department is in the process of working out modalities. “All essential service providers can apply for individual and vehicles passes. The details will be on city police Facebook page,” officials said.

Title: Residents oblige, most stay indoors
Content:
Madurai: The third day of the lockdown on Friday witnessed lesser crowds on the roads in Madurai, compared to the first two days, and traffic movement was almost nil in many parts of the city. The city police booked three people for violating the rules on Friday.

In some places like South Veli street and near the Meenakshi temple, people came out to the streets in the morning, but were warned by the police against venturing out. Earlier in the day, the Central vegetable market opened at around 3am. President of the Madurai Mattuthavani Vegetable Market Association, P S Murugan said they had asked only retailers to come and purchase in bulk to ensure that they sold more during the limited time given to them by the government. “We didn’t want individuals to be harassed in the market, so we discouraged them from coming to the market,” he said.

Many shops which were listed by the corporation to supply groceries to people after they made bookings over the phone, were seen operating with their shutters down. The manager of one of the shops said they were taking orders over phone and the workers were asked to pack them for delivery. “If people come to the shops this would lead to crowding again,” said Kumar, a shopkeeper.

The corporation also added seven more shops taking the number of shops authorised to deliver goods to the people in the city to 26, covering all parts of the city. Smaller neighbourhood grocery stores that did not figure in the list, too opened early and shut down by 12 noon. “Vegetables were selling at a higher price. Shallots sold at Rs 100 per kg and onions at Rs 50 per kg in the wholesale market. Since we would find it difficult to sell them in the local areas, I bought very little vegetables for Rs 1,000 as a precautionary measure,” said Pandi who runs a store in KK Nagar.

Meanwhile, the Madurai district superintendent of police N Manivannan said that four cases were registered against people who had violated Section 144 promulgation on Thursday. The Kalllikudi police registered a case against nine people as they had organised a cricket tournament at T Valayankulam village in the district. The Thirumangalam Taluk police registered a case against two men for gathering people to discuss about the arrangements to be made for the consecration ceremony of a temple at Thirali village. They also registered a case against one person for roaming near the Vagaikulam junction without any valid reason. The Melavalavu police registered a case against two for hoisting the SDPI party flag at A Vellalapatti village.

Madurai city police registered seven cases against people for opening tea shops, petty shops, bakery for violating the order on Thursday. Similarly, 11 cases were registered against those roaming in the city without any valid reasons. Cases have been registered against two people for selling liquor in the city. In Tirunelveli, the city police registered 12 cases against 19 violators and the district police registered 40 cases against 64 violators so far. About 120 cases were registered against 142 violators in Tenkasi district.

Title: Kanyakumari police get help from drone operators
Content:
Kanyakumari: Ten professional drone operators have come to the aid of the Kanyakumari district police to ensure there is no crowding at important places where police presence cannot be ensured. They made the offer to superintendent of police (SP) N Sreenath who agreed after being convinced that the operations won’t cause inconvenience to the public.

“Those who will be engaged in the task have submitted our basic details to the SP office and formed a WhatsApp group in which we will share pictures of crowding with the police officers in the group,” president of Tamil Nadu Professional Aerial Cinematographers Association (TNPACA) R Daniel told TOI. On Thursday morning the SP also had a live demo of the operation by the team at Vadassery bus stand in Nagercoil. In the last two days they managed to capture pictures of boys playing in open grounds, group of fishermen catching fish from the shore and a few other incidents and shared it with the police, who in turn initiated action. “We are ready to extend our free service beyond the lockdown period if there is a need,” Daniel said.

The drone operators will primarily monitor Nagercoil, Thuckalay and Marthandam towns and coastal areas such as Kanyakumari, Manakudy, Muttom, Colachel, Thengapattanam and Neerody apart from a few places along the Tamil Nadu – Kerala border. The operators said that their drones can travel up to 5 kms in height and cover a range of 7 kms. They can capture clear pictures of the violators from a distance of 500 feet during the day and 150 feet in low light.

Title: SC relaxes March 31 deadline for sale of BS-IV vehicles
Content: NEW DELHI: In a relief to automobile dealers, the Supreme Court on Friday allowed sale of BS-IV compliant vehicles beyond the March 31 deadline and till ten days after the nationwide lockdown due to Covid-19 is lifted.On a plea by Federation of Automobile Dealers’ Association (FADA), a bench of Justices Arun Mishra and Deepak Gupta permitted dealers to sell their inventory ten days beyond the lockdown period. The court, however, made it clear that dealers will be allowed to sell only 10 per cent of their existing BS-IV stocks and those vehicles will not be sold in Delhi.The bench conducted the proceedings through video conferencing with lawyers presenting their case from their office through video calls. Though the apex court had earlier refused to extend the March 31 deadline and rejected dealers’ plea for more time, it agreed to grant them relief now in the wake of the lockdown.FADA had pleaded the court for more time to sell the stock of BS-IV vehicles—around seven lakh two-wheelers, 12,000 commercial vehicles and 15,000 passenger cars. The apex court had in October 2018 ruled that not only manufacturing but sale of BS-IV vehicles will not be allowed after cleaner BS-VI fuel norm comes into force from April 1, 2020 to curb pollution.FADA contended that the inventory of BS-IV vehicles had piled up with dealers as they were not being purchased due to economic slowdown and pleaded that they be allowed to sell till April-end. The SC had in 2018 said health will have to be given precedence and asked the automobile industry to show the “will, responsibility and urgency” to adopt cleaner BS-VI fuel.

Title: Curfew in Walled City; 50 positive cases so far in Rajasthan
Content:
‘We are trying to trace them’

JAIPUR: Curfew was imposed in the entire Walled City late Friday evening after two persons reported positive for Covid-19 from the area over the past two days. One more person was diagnosed with the disease from the area on Friday. He is the friend of the patient, who had returned from Oman, and diagnosed with the disease on Thursday. “Curfew has been imposed in the area where the cases of Covid-19 have been detected,” said health minister Raghu Sharma.One more person died late on Thursday and seven persons tested positive for the virus on Friday.Jaipur: Those who were found positive on Friday are two each from Bhilwara and Dungarpur, and one each from Jaipur, Churu and Jodhpur. This took the total number of cases of Covid-19 to 50 in the state.The two who died had both undergone treatment at Bangar Hospital in Bhilwara, which is the epicentre of the disease in the state. While one of them, a 73-year-old, died on Thursday morning, the second, a 60-yearold, died late Thursday night.The second person to die in the state, a resident of Najariyawas of Raipur in Bhilwara, was initially treated at a private hospital after he suffered a heart attack on March 6. He was then shifted to Bangar Hospital on March 7. He was admitted to the ICU and remained there till March 9. He visited the hospital again on March 12 and 17 for check-up. “His samples were taken on March 23. He tested positive on March 25 after the confirmation test was done," said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health.In Jaipur’s Walled City, curfew has been imposed in seven police station areas after one more person was found infected with the virus. Extensive screening of contacts of the two Covid -19 patients has been launched. “We have identified 66 contacts, out of which 43 have been sent to a private medical college for quarantine, while one has been sent to SMS Hospital (the person, resident of Phhuta Khurra tested positive for Covid-19 ), the rest 23 of the close contacts have not been traced. We are trying to trace them but finding it difficult to reach them,” said a health department official.In Bhilwara, the situation continues to worsen as two more persons were found infected. “They are the close relatives of the 60-year-old person, who tested positive and died on Thursday evening,” said Singh.In Jodhpur, a student who was studying in UK, has also been found infected with the disease. He returned to Jodhpur along with his roommate in UK and landed at Delhi airport on March 19. From Delhi airport, they hired a taxi and reached Jodhpur. However, health department officials said that he is asymptomatic and fine. He has been admitted to the isolation ward along with his friend and co-traveller, who has fever and other symptoms of Covid-19.In Dungarpur, a 48-year-old man and his 14-year-old son tested positive for the virus. “They rode a bike from Indore to Aaspur of Dungarpur. Both live in and have a grocery shop in Indore. They were screened for Covid-19 on March 26 and admitted to the district hospital,” said a health department official.

Title: 17 co-passengers of Covid +ve patient quarantined
Content:
Trichy: A day after a 24-year-old Dubai returnee from Erode tested positive for Covid-19, public health and preventive medicine department officials identified 17 of his co-passengers from Dubai to Trichy here on Friday.

Meanwhile, a doctor and 14 others have tested negative. “Considering the necessary one-metre distance, we have picked up the details of 18 passengers including the affected patient in three rows of seating on board the flight. Of the 17 passengers, two are natives of Trichy district. They have been identified and quarantined. None of them had symptoms of Covid-19,” Trichy collector S Sivarasu told reporters.

The officials traced the 15 other patients to Nagappattinam, Tiruvarur, Thanjavur, Perambalur, Ramanathapuram and Sivaganga. The flight which landed at the airport in the early hours of March 22 had a total of 86 passengers and six crew members including pilots. “The information about the co-passengers has been conveyed to the respective district collectors. All the crew members are from other states and they have also been alerted,” said the collector.

As the man travelled on seat number 13C, officials picked up passengers in rows 12 and 14. As the man had symptoms of cough and fever, he was rushed to the isolation ward of Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital. The swab test at viral research and diagnostic laboratory at Tiruvarur government MCH and reconfirmation test at King institute of preventive medicine and research showed he was infected.

“The health condition of the positive patient is stable. The doctors will decide on his discharge after tests on 7 th and 10th day after the confirmation of the disease,” said the collector.

As on Friday evening, the lab at MGMGH confirmed that 15 people including a dentist, four in the isolation ward and others on home quarantine tested negative for Covid-19.

The doctor had a recent travel history to Madurai. As he had the symptoms, he got himself admitted to the isolation ward at the six-storey building at MGMGH on Friday.

A doctor told TOI that he will be kept under observation for a few more days. A list of 4,120 passengers of Trichy district who returned from foreign countries has been prepared and they have been quarantined. “None of the quarantined people violated the curfew,” said the collector.

Title: Cops lend helping hand to seniors living alone
Content:
A cop helping senior citizen Indu Oza, a resident of Warasia Ring Road

Vadodara: Since PM Narendra Modi announced a countrywide lockdown three days ago, she was worried as her son and daughter-in-law got stuck in Rishikesh. Indu Oza, a senior citizen, was alone at her home on Warasia Ring Road and there was no way she could reach out to them. When the police learnt about her, a team rushed to her home on Thursday and helped her contact her son.

In a bid to help scores of senior citizens, the police have activated its senior citizen cell. “We inquired about her health, called up her son and assured him that we will look after Oza till they return. Our team also gave her hand sanitizer and masks,” said Saroj Kumari, DCP (admin).

“Like Oza, there are many senior citizens who are staying alone in the city. Either their kids are staying abroad or stranded somewhere. Our senior citizen cell will reach out such senior citizens and help them during the lockdown. We will ensure that they get their necessary provisions and medicines,” Kumari told TOI.

The police maintains a register of many senior citizens staying alone so that it can patrol in their areas to prevent any crimes. “Elderly people can hardly move out and in case of emergency, they need quick help. So we decided to dedicate an entire team for helping senior citizens during the lockdown period,” Kumari added.

Title: SCR contract staff to get full salary
Content: Hyderabad: South Central Railway (SCR) will be releasing full salaries of all contractual employees even as all its passenger services remain suspended till April 14 due to the coronavirus pandemic. According to officials, there are several employees of private establishments including temporary, contractual, and outsourced engaged in providing services in trains, stations, and offices.“The contract employees will be directly affected by the suspension of services and lockdown situations, but according to directions from Indian Railways they will be treated as ‘on duty’ and will be paid accordingly till the expiry of suspension of services,” said an SCR official.In an order issued recently, the railways have noted that several contractual staff engaged in onboard housekeeping service, sanitation, pantry car, and commercial activities are stranded to compulsorily stay at other places. This is applicable to contracts awarded on manpower basis, informed officials.For contracts awarded on the lumpsum basis (not on manpower basis), the maximum payment which may be made shall be limited to 70% of the contract value. This move is likely to benefit at least 50,000 contractual and outsourced employees involved in providing services across the Indian Railways network.

Title: Is Uttarakhand still in Stage-I of pandemic?
Content: DEHRADUN: A day after the state government claimed that the Covid-19 pandemic in Uttarakhand has been restricted to Stage-I with five positive cases (all with a history of travelling abroad) been found in the state till now, medical experts say that this may not necessarily be the case. With only 350 people tested in Uttarakhand till March 27, the experts say that more testing is required to get the accurate picture, considering that there has been an influx of foreign travellers in the Himalayan state in the first week of March for yoga events as well as a large number of people returning to their villages from cities like Delhi and Mumbai, where there is a significant outbreak of Covid-19, and no mechanism deployed to test them.Dr Sunil Sanon, Mussoorie-based physician who provides voluntary medical services in the villages of Garwhal, told TOI, “Ghar Wapsi (Homecoming) of the men of the hills working outside the state may cost dear to the health authorities who are neglecting this large influx of people returning to their homes after the lockdown. Many of them returned to their homes as early as in the first week of March and managed to reach the hills unchecked. I have written to both health minister Dr Harsh Vardhan and PM Modi highlighting this issue.”Another senior doctor from AIIMS Rishikesh who didn’t wish to be named, added that it is important that the government does more testing in order to arrive at conclusive figures. “At present, only people who have a history of travelling abroad and those who came in contact with identified Covid-19-positive patients are being tested. The government needs to test more, considering that the three forest service trainees and the man who was found positive in Kotdwar were not showing many symptoms when they were diagnosed as Covid-19-positive.”

Title: 24-year-old woman dies of swine flu in Haridwar
Content:
Representative Image

DEHRADUN: A 24-year-old woman from Haridwar died of swine flu on Friday. This is the third death of H1N1 in Uttarakhand this year. Haridwar chief medical officer ( CMO ) Dr Saroj Naithani confirmed that the death had been caused by swine flu.

“According to the family of the patient, she was admitted at a private hospital in Dehradun for a week, from where she was referred to a higher centre on Thursday,” she added.

That health department on Friday sought to collect samples of the family of the woman, but they refused. The family has been kept in home quarantine, as Covid 19 symptoms are similar to those of swine flu.

Talking about preventive measures aginst the communicable infection, the CMO said that people must cover their nose as H1N1 spreads through droplets.

“Swine flu is a form of influenza, which is curable but the virus can prove to be fatal in case of diabetics, children and the elderly. Hence, I advise early treatment and avoiding contact with people who show symptoms of the flu. One should immediately consult a doctor in case of consistent fever and breathlessness,” she added.

Title: Only 50% NREGA workers reporting for work daily
Content:
Jaipur: Around 10 lakh workers are engaged under MGNREGA in Rajasthan now. Of these, around 50% workers are present at the work site on any given day due to COVID-19 scare, said an official. As the centre has refused to sanction an amount of Rs 301 crore to the state for payment without work, the state government could not stop MGNREGA work.

While chief minister Ashok Ghelot had earlier said that MGNREGA workers need not come to the work site till March 31 and they would be paid their wages during the lockdown period, the department had urged the chief minister’s office (CMO) to bring out a fresh direction stating that the decision violated the provisions of the Act. It is not permitted to pay wages to the workers without coming to the work site under the Act.

“About 10 lakh families have demanded for works under the scheme in the state. The demand is very less due to the ongoing crisis. Now, those who have demanded work, we cannot refuse them. These workers are given individual tasks to ensure social distancing. We may also reduce the size of the groups. Around 50% workers are absent on any any given day due to the fear of spread of the virus,” said state MGNREGA commissioner P C Kishan.

These workers are engaged in individual as well as community works under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY), Apna Khet Apna Kaam, cattle shed works etc.

“Also, there was a rush in demand for work in March because families wanted to complete 100-day quota of work for current fiscal. If they don’t complete 100 days of work this year, the remaining days will not be carried forward,” he added.

Title: Markets in Madurai district to spread out shops from today
Content:
Madurai: In a move to avoid overcrowding in the vegetable markets, the civic body has decided to spread out the shops in the major markets in the city to four zones for better access.

A meeting to this effect presided by the Madurai corporation commissioner S Visakan, assistant commissioners Palanisamy and Jeyaraman, city engineer S Arasu and PRO Chitravel was held in Madurai on Friday. The shops in the Matuthavani vegetable market has been segregated and spanned out to the four zones of the city.

According to this plan, in zone 1, 25 shops from the Matuthavani market would be shifted to the stretch from TB Road to the Railway Colony campus. Another 25 shops will be established on the stretch from Fenner Junction near the regional passport office to the Kochadai Muthaiahsamy temple.

In zone 2, 100 shops would come up from Apollo hospital junction to Aavin junction and another 100 from Race Course Road to the District court entrance. Seventy five more shops will be established in AR grounds also. Hundred shops would come up on the stretch connecting Surveyor Colony to the Mattuthavani bus stand and 75 near the Krishnankoil in Iyer Bungalow.

In zone 3, 50 shops would be established near the southern wall of the Thiagarajar school. In zone 4 the stretch from Harveypatti to Kalaivani theater would have 50 shops.

Similarly in a move to decongest the shops in Thayir market in East Veli Street, 50 shops are being established on Kalpalam bridge in Yanaikkal and 50 from the Teppakulam Road to St Mary’s school stretch.

The commissioner has said that there would be floor markings to ensure social distancing by the customers and temporary toilets and handwashing facilities would also be available in these markets. The markets would function from 6 am to 9 am. He has urged the public to park their vehicles on one side to ensure that there is no overcrowding.

Title: Pilot to CMs: Ensure safety of Raj people
Content:
Jaipur: Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Friday wrote to all the chief ministers and lieutenant governors of the states requesting them to ensure safety, security and availabilty of essential commodities for the people from Rajasthan residing and working in their states.

He appealed to the people from Rajasthan living in other states not to panic in this situation of crisis and to stay calm. Pilot also urged them to follow the directions and advisories issued by the states and central government to stay safe and healthy.

In a letter to the chief ministers and lieutenant governors, Pilot said, “Many people from Rajasthan are engaged in businesses, jobs, daily-wage earnings in your states. For these reasons, they are either residing in your states or have to trevel frequently.”

Title: No field work for sanitation workers above 58 years: Min
Content:
Jaipur: All the sanitation workers above 58 years of age have been removed from field duty involving spraying disinfectant and appointed for some other work.

Urban development and housing (UDH) minister Shanti Dhariwal gave the orders on Friday. As per doctors, coronavirus mostly affects elderly people above 60 years. Hence, all such employees have been assigned with other works in the department.

At present urban bodies in the state have been spraying 2,38,455 litre of sodium hydrochloride in the city with the help of municipal workers’ teams and fire brigade. Around 20 fire tenders have been employed in Jaipur city to spray disinfectant. Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) has also made 120 teams working all over the city.

For purchasing masks, gloves, sanitizers for all the sanitary workers and officials on duty everyone is been provided with Rs 1,000 by the government.

Special instructions have been given to the officials to go in interior areas and outskirts of the city. Fire brigade vehicles have been given orders to spray disinfectant on roads as well. According to the information, officials have already sprayed 1,35, 987 of disinfectant on Friday.

Title: Stickers to mark homes of those in quarantine
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The district administration, which is troubled by people skipping home or hospital quarantine, has started marking houses of people on quarantine. Though stamping on the hands of persons under home quarantine was adopted in other states, Kerala was taking a sensitive approach so far. With the spike in cases of people violating home quarantine instructions, the district administration began pasting stickers on houses from Friday.

The sticker was released by tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran after a meeting at the collectorate. Minister said that the home marking would make quarantine effective. Around 11,024 persons are on home quarantine in the district. The surveillance team of district administration keep a track on them and their daily needs.

The stickers will carry specific serial numbers, date of start and end of quarantine, number of persons on quarantine etc. This will help health workers to keep a watch and co-ordinate works to support such persons effectively.

Collector K Gopalakrishnan said that marking of houses is not to isolate such persons, but to provide them support.

As many as 3,062 persons were brought under quarantine in the district on Friday, while three persons successfully completed their 28-day quarantine period.

A total of 101 persons are on hospital quarantine, of which 43 are at Medical College, 27 at General Hospital, three at District Model Hospital Peroorkada, nine at District Hospital Neyyatinkara, seven at District Hospital Nedumangadu, nine at SAT and three at KIMS. Some are staying at other centres. There are 31 persons at the university men’s hostel, 40 at women's hostel, 36 at IMG hostel, 19 at Veli Sameti hostel, 15 at co-operative institute Manvila and 12 at SUT Royal Hospital. Pullivila school has around 30 under quarantine and Poovar LP School has around 102 people under quarantine.

Meanwhile, the district crime branch on Friday launched a probe against Sreekaryam station house officer inspector Abhilash David for alleged atrocity towards motorists during the lockdown vigil. The probe was launched after the motorist, who faced the alleged atrocity filed a complaint before the state police chief. The state police chief directed crime branch Thiruvananthapuram unit SP A Shanavas to conduct the inquiry.

The complainant is the husband of a doctor working at a private hospital in Venpalavattom. He alleged that the inspector stopped his vehicle and harassed him on Thursday while he was returning after dropping his wife at MCH.

Title: Wife, son of first Covid-19 victim also test positive
Content: Madurai: The wife and second son of the 54-year-old man from Anna Nagar, who died of Covid-19 on Wednesday, have also tested positive for the virus, confirmed health minister C Vijayabaskar on Friday. Both patients are stable and this takes the total number of Covid-19 positive cases in Madurai to three.The woman and her two sons were admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) and their samples taken for testing the day after the death of the man. On Friday, the samples of the woman, 49, and second son, 22, alone returned positive and they continue to undergo treatment. Hospital sources said that samples of the 27-year-old elder son have been sent again for re-testing.Meanwhile, health officials are struggling to pinpoint the source of infection of the 54-year-old victim and his family. This was because the test results of all eight Thailand preachers who were in contact with him were negative. “We are unable to ascertain who all were in contact with him and are only pursuing the leads given by family members.
