We are widening the net as far as possible but the point of infection is unknown,” said an official adding that they can’t conclude whether it was a case of local transmission.The Thailand preachers despite testing negative continue to held at a quarantine facility, according to district officials. In Madurai, 3,643 people continue to be under home quarantine while 20 are staying in a quarantine facility.In Tirunelveli district, a 39-year-old man and a 23-year-old man were admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward at Tirunelveli Government Medical College Hospital on Friday. Samples have been sent for testing and five others previously admitted are also awaiting results. The 43-year-old Covid-19 positive patient also continues to undergo treatment at the isolation ward. A total of 2,268 people are under home quarantine in the district.In Kanyakumari, more than 4,480 people are currently under home quarantine, one of the highest in the state. Health officials with aid from revenue officials and police have started cracking down on those violating home quarantine. On Friday alone, FIRs were registered based on complaints by health officials against 25 people for leaving their houses despite being under home quarantine.

Title: Colleges resort to online classes to wrap up portions
Content:
Trichy: Faculty members of city colleges have been resorting to virtual classes using mobile applications and software to complete the remaining portion of the even semester this year.

The even semester was on the verge of getting over when institutions were closed as a preventive step to contain the spread of Covid-19. Since students are confined to home during the lockdown, teachers are using the opportunity to engage with them to complete the portion.

Virtual classes are effective than asking students to self-study through e-content. The students can also clear their doubts at the end of the session, said the head of Biotechnology and Microbiology department M S Mohamed Jaabir.

The biotechnology department of National College Trichy (NCT) has been effectively using ‘Google handout meet’ mobile application to conduct online classes.

“Some departments have completed their portions and are focusing on their practical exams. But biotechnology comparatively has large portion and this software has been effective in bringing students together to cover the remaining portion,” he said.

Students only have to find a space in their home to attend the classes. It was easy to take classes through the software to share the presentation apart from discussing and answering their questions, added Jaabir.

“We should have completed the portions in a matter of seven or eight more days when colleges had to be closed,” said K Valavan, principal, Saranathan College of Engineering.

They were told that the academic days lost will be compensated with rescheduling of working days. It is vital to complete one or two remaining chapters to go ahead with practical examinations, he said.

“We are sending e-content to students and looking into the possibility of conducting the third internal assessment online. But we will have to see how sincerely students are taking it,” he said.

There are many softwares to conduct online classes, he added.

Title: Case of youngest Covid-19 patient in state stumps authorities
Content:
2 test positive for

One positive case in Udupi

MANGALURU: The medical case of ‘ P-56 ’, a 10-month-old boy from Dakshina Kannada (DK), with no prior history of travel to Covid-19 affected countries, testing positive for the disease, has stumped the district administration. ‘P-56’ incidentally became the sixth positive Covid-19 case in DK, and is touted as the youngest patient in Karnataka. The infant was among the two positive cases to emerge from Dakshina Kannada, taking the total tally to 7.Confirming the case of ‘P-56’, deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said on Friday that the child from Sajipanadu in Bantwal taluk suffered from fever and severe acute respiratory illness, and was admitted to a private hospital in the city on March 23. As per testing protocol, and with approval of the state team, his throat swab was sent for testing the next day, and the report that the administration received on Thursday confirmed it to be a Covid-19 case.‘P56,’ along with his mother and grandmother, have been kept in isolation at a designated hospital. As per a preliminary investigation, the family had taken the child to Kerala. A detailed investigation is ongoing, and six primary contacts including the child’s grandmother, have been traced and are under quarantine. The second throat swab of ‘P56’, and swabs of his mother and grandmother will be sent for testing, and further action taken after reports are received.Affirming that the infant is responding well to treatment, the DC said that as a precautionary measure, Sajipanadu village in Bantwal taluk from where the family hailed, has been quarantined. “No one is allowed to enter or exit the village,” the DC said. Authorities sought the help of a neonatologist from Bengaluru to suggest the course of action for treating ‘P56’, given his age. All the necessary care is being taken to ensure the child’s well being along with that of the mother and aged grandmother,” she said.Two new Covid-19 cases were reported in Dakshina Kannada on Friday.Meanwhile, six were admitted for observation in the district, and the total number of people in home quarantine touched 3,032.Samples of a ten-month-old-boy from Sajipanadu in Bantwal taluk and a 21-year-old man from Karaya village in Belthangady taluk tested positive, taking the total number of Covid-19 cases to seven in the district. The 21-year-old had arrived in Bengaluru International Airport on March 21. He had travelled to his native village in a KSRTC bus. He was admitted to Puttur Government Hospital due to showing symptoms on March 24. His throat swab was sent for testing on the same day, and the results arrived on Friday.While his close relatives are under observation, efforts are on to trace all his contacts.While 64 people were screened for Covid-19 in the district on Friday, the total number people who underwent screening touched 38,115. Samples from 15 people were sent for testing, and 20 people completed 28 days of home quarantine on Friday.Asha workers visited 3,20,359 houses and created awareness on coronavirus among 13,17,439 people.Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh said all necessary measures are being taken to treat Covid-19 patients in the district.In Udupi district, a person tested positive for coronavirus on Friday. While the district has sent 124 samples for testing as on Friday, results of 92 cases were received, wherein 91 samples tested negative. Reports of 32 samples are yet to be received. A total 21 people were kept under observation on Friday, due to the coronavirus scare.

Title: With kids stuck abroad, parents a worried lot
Content:
Dehradun: Scores of Uttarakhand-based parents whose children are studying in countries such as UK, US, Mauritius where lockdown has been announced, are making desperate attempts to bring back their wards before the situation further deteriorates.

After the Covid-19 outbreak swept the world, the state government has made a separate desk to provide help to Uttarakhand diaspora when they return to their native state.

But now the parents’ biggest fear is the deteriorating condition in the countries where the death toll is rising.

Speaking to TOI, Seema Bakshi, whose son is in Mauritius, said, “On March 22, there was a flight, but my son missed it and now he is stuck there. Our government must get charter flights to bring back students who are stuck abroad.”

Haridwar-based Bakshi, who is in touch with her son over phone said that mess service is closed in the hostel and food is bring brought from outside. “I do not know what will happen if the situation worsens further. I have pleaded to Indian authorities to urgently do something,” she said.

She added that several parents, mostly based in Delhi and Mumbai, are exploring options to book a charter flight to bring the children back from Mauritius. “However, the civic aviation ministry has not responded yet,” she said.

Echoing similar fears, Abdul Ahad, whose son is studying in the UK said, “The university has told students to stay indoors and online classes for their course are going one. But there is no clarity how the students will return home.”

Ahad, a resident of Haldwani, added that 40,000 students of Indian origin are studying in UK alone and most of them are stuck there as flights are not available.

Meanwhile, there are others like Haldwani-based Shweta Kapoor, whose daughter studies in the US and has returned on March 17. “We were really worried for her but thankfully her university gave her the option to return to native country.”

Title: Annual Panguni festivals of temples cancelled
Content:
Madurai: Major temples in Madurai district have cancelled their annual Panguni festival, which attract huge crowds to the temples.

The Palani Dandayudhapani temple has two major festivals, the Thaipoosam and Panguni Uthiram. This year the flag was to be hoisted for the 10-day Panguni Uthiram festival on March 31. But, as the country is under lockdown mode to curtail the spread of Covid-19, the temple administration has announced that the festival was being cancelled this year.

A priest at the temple said that this is the first time in the recent history that the festival is being cancelled. During the festival, devotees vow to bring water from the river Cauvery, which flows through Kodumudi in Erode district to perform Abhishekams for the deity of the temple.

Lakhs of people from across the state come for the festival every year where they go to the river and begin their procession. While the festival is being cancelled, the poojas are taking place as usual in the temple.

Meanwhile, the Sivaganga district administration has asked devotees to not attempt to come for the annual Panguni festival of the Thayamangalam Muthumariamman temple. The festival was to begin with the flag hoisting on Saturday. Tahsildar Ramesh has asked people to refrain from coming to the temple as ban orders under section 144 of CrPC were in effect in the state.

The Panguni Uthiram festival, which was to begin at the famous Arulmigu Nellaiappar temple in Tirunelveli on March 28 with the flag hoisting, has also been cancelled in view of the lockdown.

Title: To ensure supply, Doon admin regulates timings of wholesale markets
Content:
Dehradun: In ensure smooth supply of essentials, the Dehradun district administration has regulated the timing of the Arhat Bazaaar, the wholesale grain market, and Niranjpur vegetable market. The move will also help keep the general public at bay.

The wholesale market remained opened on Friday only from 2 pm till 4pm for dealers and retail shop owners. Ttraders were allowed to enter the market only with a valid pass.

Sandeep Goyal, joint secretary of wholesale dealers association said, “The arrangement made by the administration helped a lot in carrying out loading of goods and the general buyer was kept away from the market. Traders who had booked their orders in advanced were allowed to enter the market on Friday. Police along with authorities from the administration closely monitored the situation.”

Similar arrangements were made at the wholesale vegetable market in Niranjanpur where officials had to close the gates of the market for some time after many residents gathered inside the market. Officials then vacated the market and only traders and buyers with permission were allowed to stay.

Talking to TOI, Deepak Arora, a trader at the vegetable market said, “We are working as per the timelines provided by the district administration to ensure supply of vegetables to the dealers with valid passes. Individual buyers are being discouraged from entering the market. Though the supply of vegetables has been affected due to the lock down, we hope normalcy will return soon.”

To further facilitate the process of carrying out trade, the Dehradun Smart City Project Limited has started the online facility of issuing lockdown passes to essential services providers.

Ashish Kumar Srivastava, chief executive officer, DSCL said, “The passes will be issued only to essential services providers along with general people who have to move out of their houses in case of emergency.”

Dehradun addtitonal district magistrate Ramji Sharan Sharma has been appointed the nodal officer for the online facility for monitoring the issuance of passes and related matters.

Title: Special TNSTC buses ferry health staff to and from work
Content:
Madurai: The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) has arranged 11 special buses on directions from the district collector T G Vinay to ensure that all health personnel do not face any logistical issues while going to and returning from work. The services became functional for the past three days and will continue till required.

While six buses ply to and from Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH), five ply from Periyar Bus Stand to various primary health centres (PHCs) in the district. “We have six spots identified by officials at GRH namely, Karuppayurani, Samayanallur, Kadachanendhal, Melur, Thirumangalam, and Chekkanoorani. Staff are picked up from these points and dropped at GRH and vice versa. The GRH buses operate three times a day. Sometimes, we have up to 50 people on board while other times it is less than 20. It depends on the shift timings and area,” said an official from the TNSTC.

As per current schedule, buses functioning for GRH have three trips per day at 7am, 2pm and 7pm. All staff nurses, para medical staff and sanitary workers can make use of this service for free. “During this lockdown, it is extremely difficult to find any kind of transportation. Such bus service helps us to keep doing our work efficiently and reach the workplace on time,” said a GRH staff.

Special buses from Periyar Bus Stand are plying twice a day at 8am and 5pm to Vadipatti, Kottampatti, Kallupatti, Kallikudi and Elumalai. “First day of service we had only six buses overall but currently there are 11 buses. Depending on requirement we will make arrangements and increase the number or frequency,” the TNSTC official said.

Title: Raj seals borders for safety
Content:
Jaipur: In the wake of coronavirus crisis in the country, the inter-state borders of Rajasthan have been sealed on Friday and Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot has requested the residents of Rajasthan working in other states not to return to the state at this moment.

The CM also said that in this hour of crisis, the government has given exemption to the MLAs to spend up to 100% of their funds for social welfare and arrangement of food for the poor.

"If a person from Rajasthan face any difficulty in other states, then Rajasthan government will coordinate with the state government concerned and get it resolved. Similarly, people from other states who are working in Rajasthan should also stay wherever they are. Rajasthan government will take full care of them by providing them with food, ration and other facilities," said Gehlot on Friday.

Title: Uttarakhand government allows transportation of essential products during lockdown
Content:
DEHRADUN: In an effort to ensure that the essential products reached the people and also that the agriculture sector was not adveresly impacted, the Uttarakhand government on Friday passed the required instruction in this connection.

The instructions by secretary finance and disaster management Amit Singh Negi mentions, “While it is imperative to successfully implement the notified lock down and take special measures to prevent spread of coronavirus, it is also necessary to ensure the unhindered operation of manufacturing, processing, transportation and distribution related movement of certain essential supplies.”

The permission has been granted for movement of harvested agricultural produce, milk and other dairy products, eggs and meat to be treated as essential items. Their transportation as well as retail selling be allowed.

The order further states that agricultural inputs such as seeds, planting material, pesticides, fertilizers and fungicides to be exempted and should be treated at essential items both for transportation and retail selling.

The continuous transportation of government food supply has been permitted across the state and so has the transportation of petroleum products and LPG cylinders.

During the lockdown period, the movement of sellers, brokers and wholesalers of essential items like flour and rice mills has also been permitted.

The 13 district magistrates have been directed by Secretary disaster management Amit Singh Negi to get 1,000 food packets prepared and distribute them about poor, needy, expectant women, elderly people and labourers.

Title: ‘Help! My 10-yr-old turning aggressive in the lockdown’
Content:
Q: I have a 10-year-old daughter who has become extensively aggressive for the past two weeks. Due to staying at home, she gets irritated and it’s hard to keep her locked inside. What ways should I adopt to make her feel better?

| Ankita Kapoor | Charbagh

A: Talk to her, listen to what she is feeling and avoid any negative communication. Connect with her daily for 25-40 minutes and try having a routine. Engage her in home-related small tasks like cleaning her toys, organising cupboards, dusting her own spaces. Play games, get a little creative, make her speak to her friends. Channelise energy of children and involve physical activities. This will help in both yours and your child’s mental well-being. | Swati Bhagchandani, student counsellor and clinical psychologist

Q: I am 6 months pregnant and the scare of coronavirus is causing a lot of stress. What should I do? | Mona Saini | Gomtinagar

A: Just stay happy and do not watch depressing news. Stay updated with the latest news and take precautions. There are also some heart-warming and inspiring stories about infected people who have recovered. Read such reports and you will feel better. Remember 98% infected people recover and only those are suffering from other complications take ill seriously. The elderly and people with low immunity and low nutrition may be vulnerable but precautions can save all. | Dr SC Tiwari, former head of geriatric mental health department, KGMU

Q: I have a history of depression and isolation during lockdown is taking a toll on my mental health. I feel very lonely at times. How to cope with it? | Arshit Sen, Alambagh

A: Begin your morning by thinking about things you are grateful for. Make sure you have a family routine, talk to them, plan your day in advance. Have a good night’s sleep since it has a significant impact on our mental heath, take a stroll in fresh air, even in social distancing, you can sit on the terrace and breathe fresh air. Eat healthy as this is a time to stay fit and healthy inside as well. Don’t read social media forwards. Rely on authentic information on government websites or WHO | PK Dalal, head of psychiatry department, KGMU

Q: My grandfather is 78 years old. He used to take morning and evening walks in the park. Since the lockdown, we have been requesting him to walk on the terrace. However, he says his digestion is getting affected by walking elsewhere. He is in a very unhappy state. What should we do? | Rudransh Srivastava | Hazratganj

A: Any elderly person in a habit to do things on time does not like it if they deviate from their routine. The family should explain to him the purpose of the lockdown and tell him that it is not going to last long. For his own benefit and for his family, he should walk on the terrace from where he can see all the houses and people. Grandchildren should spent some time with him and find out what he likes to do so that they can communicate with him | Dr SC Tiwari, former head of geriatric mental health department, KGMU

Q: My classmate lives in a PG while her parents are in Gorakhpur. She gets anxious sometimes. What can I do to help her out? | Nikita Srivastava | Sarojninagar

A: Many people, students, parents are affected by this lockdown in ways we cannot see. You should keep on checking on her since you don’t know what she might be feeling staying alone, away from friends and family. Have video calls and conversations where she is able to tell you what she is going through. Ask more friends to join in. Make her understand that the lockdown is for our own safety and things will soon get better. Catch up on virtual gaming with her | Swati Bhagchandani | student counsellor and clinical psychologist

Title: 60% of trucks on roads are stalled by ‘non-essential’ tag
Content:
Times News Network

The domino effect of the three-day-old lockdown continued to tell on the goods supply chain across states on Friday, with government intervention failing to resolve operational complexities like 60% of the 1.2 crore trucks stuck on highways and cities being held up because they are laden with “non-essential” FMCG cargo.

In Rajasthan, the state government has issued directions to all collectors to ensure regular supply of food items to people during the lockdown period. Food and civil supplies secretary Siddharth Mahajan said shops selling groceries, essential commodities and medicines can remain open 24x7 in the state. But persons coming to grocery stores cannot come in vehicles.

“People can go to grocery stores on foot or on bicycles,” the secretary said, adding door-to-door and online deliveries should be encouraged so that people need not go to the market for their daily needs during this period.

Title: Govt distributes 1.14L food packets to labourers in city
Content:
Jaipur: The local-self government (LSG) department has distributed 1.14 lakh food packets to unemployed daily wagers due to lockdown in the city on Friday. With the help of NGOs and civil societies, the authorities have distributed 3.10 lakh food packets among the needy in the state.

All business establishments are shut and the administration has been receiving calls all over the city for helping the migrant workers.

UDH minister Shanti Dhariwal on Friday explained that special instructions have been provided to the district collectors to distribute the food packets. People have been asked to donate and contribute in the time of crisis.

Many organisations laid a helping hand for the people. In Jaipur Akshay Patra Foundation donated 11,200 food packets, Jain Rasoi 4,000 food packets and Ganesh Temple distributed 700 food packets.

Similarly, in Ajmer, Akshay Patra gave 6,000, Janta Rasoi gave 2,200 and Dargah committee distributed 2,000 food packets to the people. In other cities of the state similar donations was made.

Title: Delhi Police lay down norms for sellers
Content: NEW DELHI: Carrying both the e-pass and the company’s identity card will now be mandatory for those engaged in delivering the essential goods . Shopkeepers may show the licence copy instead of the ID card. The new rule will apply to all sellers, including e-commerce companies supplying essential goods. Delhi Police on Friday issued an order, laying down a standard operating procedure for all suppliers of essential goods.Police commissioner, SN Shrivastava, has directed the local police, traffic cops and PCR staff members to strictly comply with the order with immediate effect. He has also directed the district DCPs, ACPs and SHOs to ensure that the guidelines are clearly explained to the field-level officers.According to the order, the sellers must be registered with the state government or have an approval from the local authorities to sell their goods in Delhi. They will also have to allow the cops or government officials to audit their wares. The sellers will have to ensure that the warehouses are sanitised and minimum staff members required for smooth functioning are engaged at work. Regular medical check-up of staff will also have to be conducted.As per the order, a ration shop dealing with groceries, vegetables, fruits, dairy products, meat, animal fodder, seeds and pesticides will be allowed to function. Home delivery of food, pharmaceuticals and medical equipment is also allowed.Delhi Police has said it will follow these orders strictly.“Movement of essential goods will also not be restricted further. In view of the manufacturing of several essential goods in different cities across the country, Delhi Police will allow inter-city and inter-state goods vehicles. Warehouses where non-essential goods remain stored will not be shut by police,” said a senior officer.The retailers will, however, have to give an undertaking that they will only sell the essential goods.According to the MHA order, the state government also has to open a 24X7 control room to register complaints of employees and people facing issues in procuring food items.

Title: Rajasthan: Salary cut for govt employees
Content:
Rajsthan CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: In a bid to combat coronavirus crisis and provide relief to people infected by it, Rajasthan government on Friday decided to deduct salaries of all officers and employees from one to five days.

The amount collected will be donated to the Chief Minister's Covid-19 Mitigation Relief Fund. Five days of salary of all the employees under all-India services (IAS, IPS, IRS, IFS etc), central services and state services will be deducted.

Three days of salary of all the employees of Rajasthan subordinate services will be cut, two days salary of the employees under ministerial services and one-day salary of Grade-IV employees will be deducted, stated an order issued by the finance department.

A statement will be issued to all the employees on deduction of the amount from their salaries for the month of March.

Title: Rs 2.5cr for revamp of exam wing
Content:
T’puram: In a first, Kerala University passed its budget for the fiscal year 2020-21 by convening the senate meeting online.

As many as 72 senate members participated in the meeting via online forums and among them 15 participated in the post budget discussion. Finance committee convenor K H Babujan presented the budget at the university senate chamber where syndicate members and statutory officers participated in discussions. They sat as different groups.

The budget anticipates revenue of Rs 669.15 crore and an expenditure of Rs 671.08 crore during the fiscal.

One of the major proposals in the Rs1.93 crore deficit budget is a comprehensive revamping of examination wing by spending Rs 2.5 crore. The university was under fire recently for the alleged issues pertaining to the examination software which the university authorities have cited as a reason for allocation of undue marks to several students.

The budget set aside Rs 50 lakh for the modernisation of Central Laboratory for Instrumentation and Facilitation and proposed to open the laboratory to students of all affiliated colleges, schools and for research scholars. It set aside Rs 50 lakh for organizing a Young Scientists’ Summit in which leading scientists below 45 years of age, from across the world, are expected to participate.

The budget has also given stress to renewable energy sector. It has set aside Rs 50 lakh, using which the Centre for Renewable Energy under the university would carry out research work and production of bio-fuel cells, sodium ion batteries, hydrogen fuel cells, super capacitors etc.

Rs 25 lakh has been allotted for the renovation of university’s observatory. Physical education department would be upgraded into a teaching department and post-graduate and MPhil courses would be started there. Rs 10 lakh has been set aside for giving financial assistance to researchers for book publishing and publishing research papers in international journals. The varsity would, said the budget, set up a multi-disciplinary research centre by spending Rs 40 lakh. tnn

Title: CCMB readying testing kits under Rs 1,000
Content: Hyderabad: The city-based Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB) is likely to come out with a special kit to test coronavirus in the next two or three weeks. The kit could substantially bring down the cost of coronavirus (Covid-19) tests. CCMB plans to make the kit at an affordable price so that the cost of each test is below Rs 1,000. CCMB is also planning to culture Covid-19 virus.The premier research body is working round-the-clock to develop cost-effective and accurate diagnostic kits that could be used for covid-19 tests. The CCMB is also supporting incubation companies attached to it for the development of the kit. It is also testing and validating the diagnostic kits proposed by these incubation centres.“CCMB may soon come up with diagnostic kits for Covid-19,” CCMB director Dr Rakesh K Mishra said, hoping that the kit will be ready in next two or three weeks.Dr Rakesh said CCMB is helping its incubating companies and they have come out with ideas. “We are supporting them. We are testing and validating the diagnostic kits proposed by them. We may come up with some good kits and it may take at least two to three weeks if everything goes well. Quality and accuracy of the kits are the most important things. If the kits give 100 percent results, then only they will be approved,” he said.The CCMB is also keeping in mind the cost, according to an official press release from the Union ministry of science and technology. The CCMB estimate is that the test should be less than Rs 1000.“We are also thinking of kits which are as cheap as Rs 400 or Rs 500, but at present we cannot assure that, as it is a different route, and all this needs more standardisation”, said Dr Rakesh.Stating that the CCMB is planning to culture the covid-19 virus, the official statement said the institution has facilities for this and approvals from the government. The CCMB is waiting to receive sample and kits to initiate the culture.Dr Rakesh told TOI that the CCMB has trained 25 people in testing covid-19 in other recognised laboratories across Telangana.The teams were drawn from covid-19 testing laboratories - Nizam's Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS), Gandhi Hospital, Osmania General Hospital, Sir Ronald Ross Institute of Tropical and Communicable Diseases, all in Hyderabad, and also Mahatma Gandhi Hospital in Warangal.Stating that vaccine and drug development are another aspect of fighting the virus, Dr Rakes said as of now CCMB is neither working on the vaccine nor on the drug development. “We have no expertise for working on this. However, when the virus is being cultured, we will try to set up a system as it can be used for screening,” he added.

Title: Govt extends farmers loan repay date to June 30
Content:
Jaipur: The state government on Friday extended the date for repayment of Kharif crops loan from cooperative banks from March 31 to June 30 in wake of Covid-19 outbreak.

Cooperative minister Udaialal Anjana said that to give relief to the farmers of the state due to coronavirus, the recovery period of Kharif-2019 cooperative short-term crop loans has been extended from March 31 to June 30 or a year from the date of availing crop loan, whichever is earlier. Orders have been issued to this effect.

Anjana said that in order to protect the farmers from the lock down impact, it has been decided to extend the date of loan recovery of the farmers who got crop loans from cooperative banks so that they can avail the benefit of zero percent interest facility.

He informed that chief minister Ashok Gehlot was apprised of the problems faced by the farmers in depositing loans due to the corona virus epidemic and he instructed to take quick decisions in the interest of the farmers.

The minister informed that short term crop cooperative loans are distributed by the Central Cooperative Banks to farmers through the Village Service Cooperative Societies. He said the cooperative farm loans for Kharif crops have to be repaid by March 31.

The minister said that due to the corona epidemic, the state government has extended the due date of March 31 of Kharif crop cooperative loan till June 30 or one year from the day the loan has availed, whichever is earlier. He informed that this will allow zero percent interest facility to lakhs of farmers who took loans for Kharif crop in the year 2019 through Central Cooperative Banks in the state.

Title: Raj hikes DA of govt staff by 5 per cent
Content:
Jaipur: Rajasthan on Friday increased the dearness allowance for its employees by 5 per cent. Thus, the total DA of employees has increased from 12 per cent to 17 per cent. The revised allowance will be effective from July 1, 2019, according to an order of the finance department. About 8 lakh employees and 4.40 lakh pensioners will be benefited.

The government will incur a financial burden of Rs 3,417 crore in 2020-21 on this count, said a government release. The amount of increase for the period from July 1, 2019, to February 2, 2020, shall be credited to the general provident fund account of employees in April 2020.

Tthe arrears of DA from July 1, 2019, to February 29, 2020, to employees recruited to the civil services on or after January 1, 2004, and who are governed by the Contributory Pension Scheme shall be paid in April 2020 and cash payment shall be admissible from March 1, 2020.

Title: Ajmer civic body on clean drive
Content:
Ajmer: The civic body has taken the initiative to clean and sanitise the town. On the first day, it carried out cleaning of drains and fogging.

“We have daily door-to-door garbage collection and we take action against those who fail to act,” said a civic body official. Even garbage is lifted from different places daily to keep the city clean. Places like Baradari, Choupati, railway station, bus stand are washed with chemicals. Four fogging machines are working from morning to evening. “The main aim is to keep the city clean to make the place hygienic,” said Ajmer Municipal Corporation commissioner Chinmayee Gopal. The dargah was also washed and the drain linked to Dargah Bazaar was cleaned. “We have now started fogging even in the lanes and bylanes,” Gopal added. The lockdown helped AMC workers as they can move freely from one place to another. “Previously it was not possible to work 8 hours a day because city remain jammed. But now we are working non-stop,” said a cleaning worker of AMC. tnn

Title: Nampally exhibition ground now shelters beggars, workers
Content:
Hyderabad: The Exhibition Grounds at Nampally has been turned into a temporary shelter for destitutes during the ongoing lockdown. GHMC officials shifted 563 people, including migrant labourers and beggars, to the Exhibition Grounds on Friday.

The officials also picked up some persons from Secunderabad and Hyderabad railway station and shifted them to the ground. According to GHMC officials, despite congregating over 500 people in one place, they are ensuring social distancing.

“We have drawn boxes to ensure social distancing. Precautions will also be taken up while serving food to them. The destitutes have also been briefed about precautionary measures to be followed to tackle the spread of coronavirus,” said P Pravinya, GHMC zonal commissioner of Khairatabad.

Food is being provided to them from Annapurna Canteens which serves meals for Rs 5.

The GHMC initiative to shelter homeless and beggars has received support from civic activists and techies. “After I saw several people sleeping in public places and running short of food, I am ready to do help the needy along with my colleagues. I urge media, private organisations and individuals also to chip in and come to the rescue of the needy,”said Harish Daga, an activist.

The destitutes were identified by GHMC deputy commissioners and officials of GHMC’s urban community wing who went around the city in the last three days. After they were shifted to the Nampally ground, daily wage workers also joined them. Some migrant labourers have decided to take shelter at the ground till the lockdown period ends, while some others are coming there only to have food.

To rehabilitate the destitutes, LB Stadium, a community hall in GHMC Charminar zone and Victory playground in Chaderghat had been identified initially.

Later, GHMC officials came to a conclusion that the Exhibition Grounds at Nampally would be ideal considering availability of a large space and washrooms.

Title: Some maids on leave, some can’t afford to stay at home
Content:
Nagpur: People are keenly practising social distancing and isolation at home but persons paying regular visit to their houses are house help and maids.

Many have given their maids paid leave while others still have to carry on with domestic work. Apart from working in the kitchen, maids do the dishes, mop floors, and clean toilets at the household which increases threat of contamination for them during this alarming situation. TOI spoke to a few housewives and maids to get a closer look at the situation.

Kavita Borkar, a cook is still going to homes for cooking. She says maids have now become more aware of hygiene and properly clean themselves before entering kitchen. “I have not taken any leave as of now, don’t know about the coming situation. I make sure to properly clean my hands and feet before cooking food,” she says.

These maids were very keen towards taking off on the day of Janata Curfew , “We didn’t do any work this particular day. But staying at home every day is not feasible for us,” Kavita says.

Another maid who didn’t want named, says, “I have got paid leave as I asked for it. I have received my part of payment as I wanted to stay at home during such time. Also I am thankful to the people where I work for understanding my situation,” she says.

Housewives and working women are a bit worried about maids directly enter the kitchen or coming for cleaning hence some have decided to give them a long holiday until the situation is in control, “I have give my maids full paid holiday way before. I am taking all necessary steps about hygiene. Why invite the diseases by being careless. I think everyone should give leave to their house help, its beneficial for both the parties,” said Madhvi Kavishwar , a professor.

Aarti Bawariya, who has small children at home, works days and nights to earn that extra penny. She was doubtful about taking long leave. She was also worried about leaving her children at home during this time. “We have to go out and work, but I am always worried about my children. Did they wash their hands? I am sure I won’t get paid leave, but I am going to take leave at the earliest,” she says.

According Suman Patle,a maid, staying at home and not working is not workable for her. “Even if I want to, I cannot afford to take leave. I know a few who have taken leave. But I cannot afford it,” she says.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Beni Prasad Verma, doyen of social justice movement, passes away at 79
Content:
Beni Prasad Verma

LUCKNOW: Veteran socialist leader Beni Prasad Verma passed away on Friday leaving behind a void in the Samajwadi Party, which he and his friend and mentor Mulayam Singh Yadav had founded in November 1992 to challenge the might of the Congress and the BJP.

Verma passed away after prolonged illness on Friday evening. He was admitted to a private hospital in Lucknow where he breathed his last. He was 79.

Hailing from a family of farmers in Barabanki, Verma’s rise from a humble background marked the assertion of backward sections in politics through socialist ideology and heralding of the anti-Congress movement.

Having started his career as a small-time employee in a sugar mill, ‘Beni Babu’ (as Verma was popularly known), joined the activities of sugarcane union and contested his first election in 1974.

Beni never looked back since then and make strides from Barabanki to Lucknow and finally to Delhi where he served as a Union minister twice, as telecom minister in the Deve Gowda government and as minister for steel in the Manmohan Singh government.

The Mulayam-Beni combination represented the rise of Yadavs and Kurmis, as was also seen in Bihar with Lalu Yadav and Nitish Kumar, and Vakkalingas-Lingayats in Karnataka, during the same era.

These forces of social justice finally formed the SVD (Samyunka Vidhayak Dal) governments in different states heralding anti-Congressism.

Chief minister Yogi Adityanath led the political fraternity in offering condolence to the veteran socialist leader. UP assembly Speaker Hridaya Narayan Dixit said, “Those were the days when politicians did not have much money. Mulayam and Beni often used to take rickshaw to Aminabad market in Lucknow or go to watch films.”

In Mulayam-led government in UP, Verma used to be the second-in-command and held key portfolios like PWD and parliamentary affairs. He once claimed that his idea of ‘cycle’ appealed to Mulayam so much that he officially announced it as the symbol of Samajwadi Party.

Verma was the one who challenged the alleged corporatisation and glamourisation of the party by Amar Singh. Before 2007 assemble elections, Verma parted ways with Mulayam to form his own outfit, Samajwadi Janata Party. He merged his outfit with the Congress in 2009.

The Beni-Mulayam split also weakened the social justice movement.

It was due to Beni’s political acumen and understanding of the pulse of the masses that Congress president Sonia Gandhi included him in the Congress Working Committee and elevated him as Union steel minister after the Congress won 10 out of 21 seats in 2009 in Oudh and Terai belts, where Kurmis unitedly voted for the party.

Later, Beni parted way from the Congress and returned to SP in 2016. He was currently a sitting member in Rajya Sabha.

Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav, also expressed deep sorrow over his demise and said he played a key role in the party’s formation.

Title: With no +ve case, Ajmer seals borders with Bhilwara; 262 home quarantined
Content:
Ajmer: In the wake of Bhilwara emerging with high numbers of coronavirus positive cases, Ajmer police sealed the borders with Bhilwara on Friday.

Police is keeping 24-hour watch on the borders. Though there are 262 people in quarantine in the district, residents fear that if any infected person from Bhilwara enters the city and comes in contact with others, then there can be a major outbreak in the city too.

So far, Ajmer has not reported any case of coronavirus. Over 50 patients were tested, but negative. SP Kunwar Rashtradeep said the borders adjoining Bhilwara have been totally sealed and police is checking every vehicle moving close to the border.

Ajmer is just 60km away from Bhilwara city. “Both roads from Bhilwara are completely blocked and no one is allowed to enter the district,” said an official. Even the adjoining Kekri border is sealed. But there are villages like Nagelao, Kadera and Kairut from where people can enter into the city. District chief medical and health officer K K Soni said there are 262 people in Ajmer city who are quarantined, including people from Bhilwara. However, there might be over 600 such people.

“The major problem is that no one informs about such people coming from Bhilwara and that is a lapse in security measures,” said Soni. He added that they are appealing everyone that they should inform about such people so that the health department can quarantine them in their houses for the next 15 days. The health department initiated a survey and also deputed teachers to check that people who are quarantined don’t leave their houses. Ajmer police is on heels and checking every unnecessary movement on road.

Title: Madurai: Villagers show the way, bar entry of outsiders
Content: MADURAI: While the district administrations and police are finding it difficult to keep people indoors, a village near Usilampatti and a refugee camp in Tirunelveli have come up with their own solution by barring the entry of outsiders into their areas.There are about 150 families living at Meenakshipuram in Jothilnayakanur near Usilampatti in Madurai. While there is a belief that people in villages are not aware of the dangers of Covid-19 virus, these villagers are showing that they are perhaps a step ahead. On Thursday, men and women cut thorns and used them to block the road leading to their village.A handwritten signboard saying outsiders are not welcome was also hung up on the thorns. The signboard says the road has been temporarily closed and that people from outside, other districts and states are not welcome. The police will be informed and action taken if people forcefully enter the village, it stated, adding that this dictate would last as long as Sec 144 of the CrPC is in force in the state.Ramalingam, a villager, said that many people who pass through their road stop by their village asking for small help or even water. ``We have been seeing so much information on how this deadly disease is spreading through outsiders. Hence we have decided to block our road for our own safety,’’ he said.They have also decided not to go out of their village till the curfew is lifted and are creating awareness among their villages on the importance of handwashing.Similarly, a signboard asking outsiders to stay away has been put up outside the refugee camp at Subramaniapuram in Tirunelveli. The people of Melapalayam in Tirunelveli have also put up a board asking outsiders to keep off their place for their own safety as well as that of the village.

Title: Drug wholesalers, retailers face disruption in supplies, especially in non-metros
Content: NEW DELHI: In the midst of lockdown and the scare of coronavirus spread, drug wholesalers, distributors and retailers are facing major disruptions in supplies, especially to remote areas and states which do not have manufacturing units.Drug manufacturers and retailers said while warehouses have stocks for around 15 days, panic buying by people may lead to shortage of essential and commonly used medicines if hurdles in supply chain continue.“With the threat of Covid-19 infection and lockdown in place, truckers are refusing to go on long routes as they are being harassed by police in the absence of enough curfew passes. There is also shortage of food on the route for these truckers,” said Sandeep Nangia, President of Delhi Chemists’ Association.On Friday, availability of medicines in retail outlets improved in major metros such as Delhi, Mumbai and Bengaluru with state authorities ensuring that chemists are allowed to operate without curfew passes.“But there is a problem faced in logistics for transporting from factories to clearing and forwarding agents because like every other industry, we are also facing staff crunch and those available are being stopped by police,” said an executive of a pharma company.Meanwhile, All India Organisation of Chemists and Druggists (AIOCD) approached the Prime Minister’s Office to ensure smooth functioning of chemists and take measure to facilitate the functioning of the supply chain.The government on Friday formed a task force with representatives from various related ministries including the department of pharmaceuticals, home affairs ministry, shipping ministry and others to ensure that essential supplies and commodities do not face supply disruptions.

Title: Uttarakhand: Eight people of marriage party, including groom, arrested for violating lockdown
Content: NAINITAL: Udham Singh Nagar police late on Thursday booked and arrested eight people after it came to light that they were performing a wedding in contravention to the country-wide lockdown.The incident took place in Khatima area of US Nagar district around 11.30 pm when police were informed by some residents that a crowd had gathered at a house in the Islam Nagar locality of Khatima.“When we reached the spot around midnight, we found that a baraat had travelled from Kichha to ward number three of Islam Nagar area for the wedding. A few people from the locality had also gathered there for the ceremony. However, since the entire country has been under lockdown, this was against the law therefore we stopped the wedding and took them to the police station,” said Khatima SHO Sanjay Pathak He added that they arrested and booked eight people including the groom named Salim, his father Faheem, bride’s father Nizakat and two brothers Arbaaz and Shahbaz as well as the kaazi Syed Mohammed Ali performing the ceremony. “We took them to the police station where an FIR was registered. However, all the arrested were let go after they filed for bail,” Pathak said.The police has invoked section 269 (unlawfully or negligently doing an act which is likely to spread infection), section 271 (disobedience to quarantine rule) and section 188 (offence of disobedience of an order by a public servant) of the Indian Penal Code against all the offenders.Pathak said that the area is especially sensitive since eight suspected cases of novel Coronavirus were reported from the area on Thursday as well. While the health department is yet to confirm the reports, the officials said that all of them have been quarantined and, therefore, the police are maintaining vigil so that the crowd does not gather in the area.

Title: Women home deliver supplies using e-autos
Content:
Hyderabad: In order to minimise the movement of people for procuring essentials, a women’s self help group in Narayanpet is delivering supplies to doorsteps using e-autos.

As many as 11 autos will be pressed into service for 11 mandals in Narayanpet. The locals can either send the list of essentials on WhatsApp or call the group for same.

The 11 mandals have been given one dedicated number each for placing orders. According to officials, a delivery fee is not being charged from senior citizens.

“For senior citizens and especially abled, the delivery is free of cost. For others, delivery fee of Rs 5 to Rs 10 will apply. The move, apart from ensuring social distancing, will also give employment to women,” said Harichandana Dasari, the Narayanpet district collector.

According to officials, all the precautionary measures are being taken up while delivering the supplies. “Precautionary measures like safety gear for women, spraying of disinfectants is being ensured,” said an official from Narayanpet district collectorate.

Title: Three arrested for spreading fake news on social media
Content:
Representative image

AJMER: Beawar police on Friday arrested three people for spreading fake news related to coronavirus on social media platforms.

The message came out on March 25 stating that a woman named Vimala Devi was admitted to Amrit Kaur Hospital in Beawar and that she tested positive for coronavirus. The message also showed the admission record of the patient as well as the report for Covid-19.

The message created panic in Beawar city forcing police to launch an investigation. On Friday, they arrested three people. It was revealed that the message originated from Shri Ram Bhakt Sewa group on WhatsApp, whose admin Lokesh Jangid of Beawar was interrogated by police. He said the message was forwarded by Inder Chand Jangid, who got message from Kailash Choudhary. After confirming, police arrested Lokesh Jangid, 23, Inder Chand Jangid, 37, and Kailash Choudhary, 43. Police made an appeal not to share any fake news on social media. tnn

Title: Keeladi excavation phase VI put on hold
Content:
Madurai: The sixth phase of excavation at Keeladi and neighbouring villages of Agaram and Konthagai in Sivaganga district, which began on February 19, has been officially put on hold, in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, on Thursday.

The excavation works were being carried out by 55 volunteers and workers, and five archaeologists from the state archaeology department. While work was yet to begin in Manalur, at Keeladi, Agaram and Konthagai trenches had been dug up, some up to a depth of three feet. The sixth phase was extended to the villages following demands to make the excavation and research activities more extensive.

Last week, the authorities prevented the public from viewing the ongoing work at Keeladi, following a request by the Keeladi panchayat president as a precautionary measure. As many of the workers work closely in some of the trenches which had been dug for more than three feet, it was decided to stop the excavation works till further notice.

On Thursday, the workers and archaeologists covered the pits that had been dug up with tarpaulin to prevent sand and water from entering it.

Archaeology department sources said that it was disheartening that they had to put the work on hold at this stage when they were making important discoveries including a skeleton inside a burial urn in Konthagai.

Title: SDMC to rope in restaurants to provide free food packets
Content: NEW DELHI: South Delhi Municipal Corporation has decided to rope in restaurants and eateries to provide free food packets to the poor and needy during the 21-day lockdown period “SDMC will be able to arrange 20,000 food packets in association with hotels, restaurants, mid-day meal kitchens and a few NGOs. We have also arranged distribution of food to affected people with the help of respective district magistrates,” Radha Krishan, the spokesperson of south corporation said.The civic body has also opened a dedicated bank account where any individual, group or company can contribute funds, which will be utilised as per the government rule to take measures to contain the spread of novel coronavirus and to help the affected persons. “The SBI account number 39238693858 with IFSC code SBIN0000631 and branch Chandni Chowk will be maintained as per prevalent norms and can be used for such contributions,” the spokesperson added.

Title: Shops to stay open, but opt for safe home delivery: Goa CM
Content: PANAJI: Hours after the Bombay high court directed the state government to take all necessary measures to promote home delivery of essentials immediately, chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Friday that the government has established home delivery chain to supply essentials at the doorsteps and will promote it.“It is not as if people are interested in defying the curfew and queuing in front of grocery shops and pharmacies. Therefore, if a robust system for home deliveries of essentials is in place, the implementation of the lockout and the policy of social distancing will be achieved,” justice Mahesh Sonak said in the order.Sawant said all shops selling essential commodities will continue to be open, but people should refrain from venturing out.“People should themselves follow lockdown in totality. If you come out from your homes, then there is a possibility that you will take back coronavirus and risk your family,” he said after a meeting with MLAs.Sawant said during the meeting, BJP MLAs took the responsibility to start home delivery services in their respective constituencies.The high court impressed upon the state government the need to constantly monitor, supervise and if necessary review or recall its decisions if the situation at the ground level demands.“If the experience suggests that there is necessity to revert to the earlier decision involving closure of all grocery shops, such decision will have to be taken and not avoided,” the court said.Sawant said they have issued volunteer passes to panchayat members across 191 villages and councillors of 14 municipal councils including the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP).“Besides these, we have also issued 20 volunteer passes to all MLAs to supply essential commodities to the public,” Sawant said.Sawant said booth level officers (BLOs) of the respective wards have also been issued volunteer passes.Sawant said food packets of Rs 300, Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 would be made and it would be distributed in constituencies.Sawant said only bona fide residents would be allowed entry into the state through the borders after putting home quarantine stamp.He said the government has established five quarantine centres in north Goa and four in south Goa and the virology lab has already begun operations.“If any one comes across people with travel history, then people of that villages should inform authorities, so that he can be kept under home quarantine. Lots of people did not disclose their travel history. People in Goa are still not serious about the issue and I know what the repercussion would be if coronavirus spreads,” he said.Sawant said that all the hospitals in Goa will have to be utilised to treat coronavirus patients and hoped that such a situation does not arise. He also said that some people want to politicise the issue and people should not fall prey to it.He also said that Valpoi has observed 100% lockdown and Sakhali had 99% lockdown.

Title: Folk singer held with stolen bike in Vadodara
Content:
Representative Image

VADODARA: A folk singer who has ‘timli’ music albums to his credit was held by the Panchmahal police with a motorcycle stolen from Vadodara. The singer also has music albums of ‘timli’ – a tribal folk music form – to his credit and is popular in Panchmahal, Mahisagar and Dahod districts.

The accused Rakesh Raval, a resident of Godhra, was riding a Bajaj Pulsar motorcycle without registration plates. When the police stopped him and sought documents from him, he was unable to furnish any papers to the police. The accused was detained by the police and the motorcycle was seized under provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code.

Title: Over 500 people throng SMS hosp for coronavirus test
Content: Jaipur: People with influenza-like illnesses are flooding the Sawai Man Singh Hospital even as the city reported 10 Covid-19 cases till Friday evening.With people becoming more aware about the symptoms of Covid-19, they do not want to take chances and are flooding SMS Hospital ’s out patient department which is dedicated for Corona patients. Some people are also forcing the doctors to carry out Covid-19 tests despite not having any travel history or having been in close contact with corona positive patients.Cases of Covid-19 cases have been reported from Adarsh Nagar , Vaishali Nagar and Jagatpura . “With each passing day, the number of patients registered at Covid-19 OPD has been increasing. On Thursday, 532 people came for virus tests,” said Dr DS Meena , medical superintendent, SMS Hospital.Out of the 532 persons, 34 were suspected Covid-19 patients, who were immediately admitted to the isolation ward for tests. Hospital officials said on March 25, the registration of patients at the Covid-19 was 403 and out of those 40 were admitted with symptoms of Covid-19.The hospital has created a separate OPD in the hospital by converting Charak Bhawan into a corona hospital. It has 150 beds available for keeping the patients in isolation.

Title: Biomedical waste from Covid-19 wards to be collected separately
Content:
Trichy: Special vehicles have been assigned to collect biomedical waste from the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) government hospital, in the wake of a positive Covid-19 case admitted at the hospital on Thursday. The waste will be taken to the common biomedical waste treatment facility in Thanjavur which collects from over 900 hospitals in eight district including Trichy.

The facility, operated by Medicare Enviro Systems, operates 13 vehicles to collect biomedical waste daily, of which four vehicles collect waste from Trichy alone.

“A dedicated vehicle will be operated to collect biomedical waste generated in the ward where the Covid-19 patient is being treated,” said district environmental engineer R Lakshmi. A 24-year-old man who returned from Dubai was tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday. A native of Erode district, he had gone to Dubai seeking a job and reached Trichy airport on March 22. He was taken to the MGM isolation ward after he showed symptoms.

“Revised guidelines have been issued by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) on handling biomedical waste involving Covid-19 suspected and confirmed patients,” she said. “All the five government medical colleges in our jurisdiction have been informed about the directives from CPCB that needs to be followed in preserving biomedical waste,” she added.

K Velmurugan, manager of Medicare Enviro Systems, said that workers shall be provided with necessary protective equipment to handle such waste. This will include three-layer masks, splash proof aprons/gowns, nitrile gloves, gum boots and safety goggles. “We have asked CPCB to inform us of any Covid-19 positive cases,” said Velmurugan.

Priority will be given to incinerate biomedical waste from Covid-19 treatment wards, he added.

Title: Bengaluru’s air quality improves
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: There may be panic in the air, but there’s certainly a sharp dip in pollutants, thanks to the lockdown . The decrease in pollution levels has been recorded across several major localities in the city, reveal Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB) data.

Air Quality Index in Bengaluru has shown a consistent improvement over the past three weeks. At the usually bustling Silk Board Junction, the AQI fell from 98 on March 11 to 68 on March 18 and 44 on March 25. In Hebbal, the AQI stood at 101 on March 11 and improved to 66 on March 18. On March 25, it was 48.

The presence of harmful pollutants in the air has also shown a dip. While at 10am on March 4, the PM 2.5 level at Silk Board Junction stood at 114 ug/m3, at the same time on March 25, it steeply dipped to 37 ug/m3, show data on the KSPCB website. Carbon Monoxide (CO) levels, have, meanwhile, gone down from 105 mg/m3 at 10am on March 4 to 43 mg/m3 at the same time on March 25.

Data collected by Bengaluru-based Ambee, a hyperlocal air-quality data provider, show the average PM 2.5 level in Bengaluru has fallen consistently from March 22 to March 27 — from 30.82 ug/m3 to 29.34 ug. On March 21, Ambee recorded a PM 2.5 level of 34.47 ug/m3 in Bengaluru.

Madhusudan Anand, CTO of Ambee said: “Over the past few weeks, due to decreased vehicular movement in Bengaluru, rain and reduced garbage burning and construction, there has been a significant improvement in air quality. Indiranagar and MG Road had AQI levels of about 57 and 42, a remarkable shift from what we see otherwise.”

Noise pollution levels in Bengaluru have also stayed below permissible limits. In Whitefield and Yeshwantpur , the decibel levels stood at 57.9 dB and 64.9 dB respectively, below the permissible limits of 65 dB and 75 dB.

Title: Kamal Nath shedding crocodile tears for farmers: BJP
Content:
Madhya Pradesh, September 18 (ANI): Congress General Secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia with Madhya Pradesh Chief ... Read More

BHOPAL: Amid lockdown to contain spread of coronavirus, Congress and the ruling BJP have started a blame game accusing the other for the plight of farmers . With by-polls to 24 seats to be held in the next six months, both the parties want to be seen on the right side of the farmers’ in the state that is predominantly agrarian dominated.

A day ago, former chief minister Kamal Nath had written a letter to chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan demanding special attention towards the farmers. The BJP in reply hit out at Nath alleging delay in farm loan waiver has affected the farmers. Former BJP minister, Narottam Mishra said that Nath kept himself under isolation for 15 months and now is taking up farmers’ problems.

"It's now after 15-months that Kamal Nath is concerned about the farmers. During his entire tenure, he remained on the fifth floor of the Mantralaya, in isolation. Also, the Congress government, that came to power on the promise of farm loan waiver, failed to keep its words," said Mishra.

Former CM, Nath in a letter on Thursday appealed to chief minister Chouhan to extend monthly relief of at least Rs 7,500 to each farmer for the next two months, in view of the imposed lockdown to contain the COVID-19 threat.Mentioning that the Rabi harvest and sale had already begun, Nath wrote, “Several crops like wheat, peas, coriander , mustard and gram are ready to be harvested. But, due to the lockdown harvesting is not possible and there is a chance of crop damage.”

He demanded an interim relief for farmers for the next two months, so that they could make up for their losses to some degree. Taking a jibe at the concern shown by the former chief minister, Mishra said, "Congress government didn't do anything and now, they are shedding crocodile tears over farmers’ plight." He said chief minister Chouhan has already announced relief for the farmers and procurement of Rabi crops.

Title: US returnees flout isolation order, booked
Content:
Vijayawada: Two returnees from the US were booked on Friday for violating home quarantine orders at Velvadam village of Mylavaram mandal in Krishna district. The duo has been identified as Konasani Sagar alias Aluri Rajasekhar Reddy and Lakkireddy Viswanath.

According to police, the duo returned on March 14. They were screened and tested negative but placed under home quarantine. On Thursday morning, the local village secretary spotted them venturing outside and informed the police.

A team led by Mylavaram sub-inspector reached the spot and booked them under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the IPC. Police said the duo has been kept under house arrest and are under surveillance.

In a similar instance, a city youth was booked by Pedaparupudi police in Krishna district after he left home against the instructions to remain under home quarantine.Police said the youth returned to Vijayawada from Dalhousie, US, on March 16. He underwent test but did not display symptoms of Covid-19 and was advised to remain under home quarantine. Based on the complaint from the health department, a case was registered and the youth placed under home quarantine again.

Till date, the door-to-door survey by the state government has identified 12,953 foreign returnees, of which 2,052 have completed the observation period of 28 days, 10,841 are under home quarantine and 60 are under observation in hospitals.

Police said cases will be registered against returnees who violate orders.

Title: Sanitation workers and housekeeping staff working day and night
Content:
Nagpur: Confined to their homes due to lockdown, many are taking care of hygiene and keeping track of developments from the comfort of their houses. At the same time, there is an army of sanitation workers and housekeeping staff which is working tirelessly, cleaning and mopping public places such as government offices , airports, sweeping roads etc. They are our heroes who are working day and night to keep it clean and safe for us.

These workers, however, are at a great risk of contracting the virus. What measures are being taken to ensure their safety? “These workers have been provided all the safety measures and equipment,” chief sanitation officer at Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) Deendayal Tembhekar said.

The workers are following social distancing while on duty. “They are maintaining a distance of 5 metres from each other. They have stopped going in groups. A group of more than two workers on duty together is taught how to maintain a safe distance,” said Tembhekar.

Sometimes, lapses do happen. “On some occasion, they hesitate to wear masks while cleaning,” he said.

Housekeeping and toilet cleaners at the government offices and buildings have been asked to work in shifts. Sachin Tadwadkar , who’s deployed in a government office, works in three different shifts. His job includes cleaning, disinfecting doors, windows, toilets tables and working spaces of employees.

“I reach the office at around 8.30 in the morning, and leave after two hours. The second shift starts around noon and ends after two hours. The third shift is in the night. There should be no compromise in cleanliness and we are told to keep everything clean,” he said.

What about leaves? “We cannot take long leaves, as somebody is always required in the office to clean and sanitize. Since we can go home in between shifts, there is a relief,” he said.

Talking about the safety equipment given to sanitation workers, NMC health officer Pradeep Dassarwar said that besides gloves, jackets are also provided to them. “They work in 6am-2pm shift and they are following all the protocols cautiously,” he said.

TOI also spoke to a few in the housekeeping staff at the airport. They wished not to be named but spoke about the continuous working hours and cleanliness routine. They don’t hope of getting any leave as of now. “We also want to protect ourselves from the virus. Unless the airports are shut, we cannot expect off-day,” said a female housekeeping staff.

“We wear masks, sanitize ourselves and start our routine, which includes cleaning the railings, windows, door knobs and almost everything,” a male housekeeping staff said.

Devidas Wadhai, who supervises the housekeeping and cleaning work at a government organization, said, “We do our duty religiously, all the workers works in multiple shifts but now we make sure to put on a mask, gloves before cleaning. Coronavirus is dangerous, but it’s our duty.”

Adding to this, Praveen Tekam, another sanitation worker, said, “We are keeping ourselves safe by following all the precautions. We are provided with disinfectants, sanitizers, masks and gloves while working,” he said.

Title: Collector warns of stern action as violations rise
Content:
Trichy: Stung by the callous attitude of the people in venturing out to the streets unmindful of the disaster in waiting in the form of Covid-19, a livid Trichy collector S Sivarasu warned the violators of severe action here on Friday.

“Rampant violation of the curfew happens every day in both city and rural. We are out here to protect you. If you stay indoors, your life will be safe,” said the collector expressing serious concern about the congregation of 40 to 50 people in public places not paying heed to the advice and appeal of the government.

He also asked the police to act tough against the violators in the days to come. “I warned several times. If two people are found riding on two-wheeler, they will be booked and vehicle will be seized. They cannot take back their vehicle. Those out for medical purpose and to buy essential things will be allowed, that too only after scrutiny,” said the collector.

Quoting the survival of fittest theory of Charles Darwin, collector Sivarasu advised the people to adopt the change and safeguard their lives.

On the third day of the curfew, vehicles were seen on the roads everywhere. While some had valid reasons, several got an earful from the police for loitering.

On Friday, Trichy city police arrested 123 people in 42 cases and seized 75 vehicles besides collecting a fine of Rs 26,310 by evening.

The situation was same in Trichy rural, Ariyalur Perambalur, Karur, Pudukottai, Thanjavur, Tiruvarur and Nagappattinam. As at 5 pm on Friday, 319 people have been arrested and 131 vehicles seized in 254 cases in the central zone. From March 25, a total of 2,011 people were arrested and 1,006 vehicles were seized.

Title: TTD performs ceremony for universal well-being
Content:
Tirupati: Even as the state and central governments work to break the chain of transmission of Covid-19, the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) is preparing to conduct the ‘Dhanvantari yagam’ to combat the virus.

The TTD has roped in renowned priests to perform the ‘yagam’ at the Dharmagiri Veda Pathashala at Tirumala for three days. The three-day yagam which began on Thursday will conclude with ‘Purnahuti’ on Saturday.

TTD chairman YV Subba Reddy said the ‘yagam’ was being performed to seek the divine intervention of Lord Venkateswara to save mankind from the pandemic. “We pray for the universal well-being of mankind and are hopeful that the ‘Dhanvantari yagam’ will bear results and the world will soon be relieved of novel coronavirus,” said the TTD chairman.

YV Subba Reddy also appealed to the people of the state to adhere to the calls given by Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to stay indoors during the lockdown period.

Title: Mangaluru: Pandemic hits wedding industry hard
Content: MANGALURU: The wedding business is facing an uncertain future due to the Covid-19 crisis . For the time being, most weddings that were to be held in April , have been postponed indefinitely. Caterers , event management firms, photographers , halls, musical ensembles, hotels and other related businesses are busy attending to calls, and refunding advance payments made by their clients.Sudhakar Kamath of Kamath Caterers said, “Most weddings that were scheduled for April have been postponed. It is a difficult phase for the industry that is currently engaged in repaying the advances taken from clients. So far, we have received cancellations till April 26, and people are closely watching the situation,” he said.On the other hand, people are considering organising functions with smaller gatherings, once the lockdown ends. “Instead of calling 1,000 people, they may settle for 100. All functions have been cancelled up to April 14. Almost all halls and convention centres were booked during this period for functions, including birthday parties, baby showers, engagements and other functions. Even the Uttarkriya function, observed on the 11th day, following the death of a person, is restricted to homes,” said Kamath.For those who have postponed weddings, finding the required venue could also be a challenge, as people have made advance bookings till February 2021. December bookings are full. One of the options left for those who have postponed weddings is to conduct the wedding in a temple, and the reception could be held as per availability of the venue, because muhurats are not seen for the reception. In Mangaluru, the trend is to conduct the wedding and reception on the same day.Bhojraj Kalladka, manager, Sanghaniketan Convention Hall,said, “We have been receiving calls, and people have been sending letters to the office, seeking postponement of weddings. We have refunded a few people and the rest will be refunded after the lockdown is lifted and our office reopens. We had about 14 weddings booked in April, of which seven have been cancelled so far,” he said.With the cancellations of weddings on the rise, the commercial photography industry has been hit hard. Shridhar N Shettigar, president, South Kanara Photographers Association, consisting of 3,224 professional photographers from Dakshina Kannada and Udupi, said, “April-May is considered as the peak season, and it is unfortunate that weddings are postponed in this period. Since it is important to keep pace with the latest technology, many photographers have invested several lakhs of rupees on mirrorless cameras and other equipment, recently,” he said.“On an average, a photographer gets up to 10-15 orders during the peak season, in the entire year, and mostly relies on this season for earning. Everyone was happy that there was no moudya (days when weddings are not conducted as per the Hindu calendar), but with the Covid-19 pandemic, the industry has come to a standstill,” he added.The industry’s expectations were high this year. When compared to the previous two years, this year had no moudya for April and May, which meant more functions would be held.

Title: Brahma Kumaris head Dadi Janki dies at 104
Content:
Dadi Janki, administrative head of the Brahma Kumaris, the world’s largest spiritual organisation run by women... Read More

UDAIPUR: Dadi Janki, administrative head of Brahma Kumaris , the world’s largest spiritual organisation run by women, passed away at the age of 104 here on Friday. Dadi Janki breathed her last at 2am at a hospital in Mount Abu. She had been suffering from respiratory and stomach-related ailments for the past two months.

Her last rites were performed at the Shantivan campus of the institution here. Expressing grief at the passing away of Dadi Janki, President Ram Nath Kovind tweeted that her contributions in the fields of spirituality, social welfare, and women’s empowerment had been invaluable. Prime Minister Narendra Modi too expressed grief over her demise. “Rajyogini Dadi Janki Ji, Chief of the Brahma Kumaris, served society with diligence. She toiled to bring a positive difference in the lives of others,” he tweeted. Modi said her efforts towards empowering women were noteworthy. “My thoughts are with her countless followers in this sad hour. Om Shanti,” he wrote.

Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla, defence minister Rajnath Singh, and Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal also sent their condolences.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot and deputy CM Sachin Pilot, Chhattisgarh chief minister Bhupesh Baghel, Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani, Madhya Pradesh CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan and Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath also expressed their condolences. Veteran BJP leader L K Advani, party president J P Nadda, Congress leader Shashi Tharoor and Baba Ramdev were among others who paid tributes to Dadi Janki.

Due to the lockdown in the country to slow the spread of the coronavirus, only a few people connected with the Brahma Kumaris, besides local officials, could be present during the last rites. However, the funeral was shown live on YouTube and on the Awakening television channel of the Brahma Kumaris.

Title: Over 7,500 home guards join war on coronavirus in Rajasthan
Content: Kota: Home Guards have joined the police in the war on Covid-19 in all the districts. They are assisting police and administrative machinery to ensure that the lockdown is properly maintained.“Home guards has joined the war on corona and is assisting police and administrative machinery in the state,” DG Rajeev Dasot said.At least 7,569 home guards have been deployed in all the districts, the DG said.Following permission from the home department , over the home guards were deployed on Tuesday.Besides, 1,000 home guards are patrolling the streets alongwith the police at night, Dasot said.Meanwhile, Rajasthan state department of home guards on Friday has decided to donate a day’s salary to chief minister Covid-19 fund.Dasot said all the employees and officials of the department would donate one day’s salary to chief minister Covid-19 fund. All the employees and officials of the department have voluntarily come forward to donate the amount, he added.

Title: Home-quarantined people get fruit hampers
Content:
Madurai: The Theni district administration has sent fruits and health supplements to those who are under home quarantine in the district.

As part of creating awareness among the public about limiting the spread of Covid-19, the Theni district administration has also launched an app on Friday for the purpose.

The administration with an aim of ensuring the wellbeing of those who have been home quarantined sent baskets of fruits and health supplements.

Theni district collector, Pallavi M Baldev, through her officials sent the kits which had an assortment of fruits like apples, oranges, grapes, bananas, apart from health supplements and a pamphlet detailing precautions to be taken.

On Thursday, each of the 144 people under home quarantine in the district received the kits from the administration.

An app was also launched by the district administration to take forward the fight against Covid-19.

The Theni Kaavalan app, which is compatible with android phones, has awareness material on Covid-19 in English and Tamil along with notifications and instructions by the government.

It also has news feed available in English and Tamil with real time updates. The details of testing centres are also available on the app.
