In order to ensure that the people maintain social distancing while shopping, the Theni vegetable market has been temporarily shifted to the main bus stand complex in the town and markings were drawn to ensure people observed social distancing.

Meanwhile, cases have been booked against 203 people in Theni district for violating the prohibitory orders under section 144 which in place.

As many as 153 two wheelers were also seized from by police. Nearly, 10,000 homeless persons have been fed through the Amma canteens in the district in the past two days.

Title: Social distancing forgotten in lure of free grocery
Content: Nagpur: Charity by Prakash Gajbhiye , a Member of Legislative Council (MLC), of the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) created its own dangers on Friday.Gajbhiye, who has his stronghold in the slums near Ram Nagar and Ambazari, was distributing free ration to residents. His call led to nearly a thousand of them gathering at Gajbhiye’s office near Ravi Nagar Square.All efforts to maintain social distancing by the government machinery were negated as people stood on the streets in dangerous proximity to each other in times of Covid-19 threat. The queue also had a number of aged people and also some children.Even as Gajbhiye and his associates were sporting masks and spraying sanitizer on people, many standing in the queue had their faces uncovered. The MLC’s men were trying in vain to make them maintain a distance.The cops who arrived at the scene tried to maintain five-feet distance between them. However, as they were forced to stand in a queue stretching out along the Canal Road, confusion led to people jostling against each other.Amid the crowd, Gajbhiye went to buy more supplies as his stock ran out, and the long queue continued to wait.“It goes without saying all these are poor people living on daily wages. The lockdown has left them starving,” Gajbhiye told TOI.Sarla Patil, a woman in her 70s, sat on the ground as she waited for her turn. “There is nobody in my house so I had to come out on my own,” she said.Another group of women preferred to stay away. “We don’t want to go into the crowd,” said one of them.Earlier, a number of women even reached Ambazari police station inquiring where they would get free rations.

Title: Helpline for essential service providers
Content:
Tirunelveli: The Tirunelveli city police on Thursday launched exclusive helplines for essential service providers after receiving several complaints from them that they are getting held up at police checkposts.

They can call on 0462-2562651 or 94981-01720 for the intervention of police officers at the Tirunelveli city police commissionerate. The landline number will be manned by the city police control room whereas the mobile number will be handled by officers in the intelligence wing.

“The Tamil Nadu government has made it clear that essential services should not be affected. There are 16 checkposts at the entrances to the city and many other locations within the city where we are checking unnecessary movement of people to ensure the lockdown is properly implemented. But at times those working in essential services like employee of a mobile phone tower are stopped by the police,” the DCP said.

The officer added there could be communication gap as the police personnel at the checkpost would not listen to the explanation offered or are unable to understand the same. “Under such circumstances the person can call the helpline numbers. The authenticity of the person will be immediately verified and instruction will be passed to release them,” he said.

Saravanan added that those working in essential services will not have trouble if they have obtained pass from the PA to collector (general). Police asked the youth to play a proactive role in ensuring social distancing by helping people of the locality.

Title: Army gears up to battle Covid-19
Content: Hyderabad: The Indian Army in Secunderabad has set up quarantine centres for its personnel. Resident welfare associations have been deputed as ‘procurement officers’ to supply essentials, including vegetables, dairy products, cereals, medicines, to the families.Delivery of items to the separated families (husbands on duty in field areas), is carried out twice a week and to regimental colonies once a week. Arrangements have been made for the products available at unit run canteens to be delivered at doorsteps as well.Movement of army vehicles has been restricted to essential duties only and all vehicles are being sanitised twice daily. Military hospitals are maintaining a close liaison with state and district health officials. TNN

Title: Ministers made in-charge of districts
Content: Dehradun: To step up the fight against Covid-19, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Friday named eight ministers as in-charge for the 13 districts of the state to oversee the preparedness of each district.Tourism minister Satpal Mahraj has been made minister in-charge for Haridwar, Subodh Uniyal for Tehri and Uttarkashi, Harak Singh Rawat for Pauri, Dhan Singh Rawat for Chamoli and Rudraprayag, Arvind Pandey for Pithoragarh and Champawat, Rekha Arya for Bageshwar, Yashpal Arya for Nainital and Almora, and Madan Kaushik for Dehradun & Udham Singh Nagar.Also, taking into account the fact that the turnout in market areas was lower on Friday, the Uttarakhand government has decided to stick with the plan to open shops selling essential products for six hours on Saturday as well. The state government has also allocated Rs 50 lakh to bring back stranded people of the state from Delhi.The CM also lauded the efforts of doctors while handling the Covid-19 positive cases in Uttarakhand. He said that of the three IFS trainees tested positive, the second report of one has come negative because of the care given by health personnel. “It is because of the efforts put in by the entire health staff, doctors and nurses that the patients are recovering. We salute their efforts,” he said.Rawat also sought public support in the lockdown and urged all to maintain distance while buying essential items. “The response from people, NGOs, social organisations and individuals has been positive. Many people have contributed to CM Relief Fund to fight novel coronavirus and we appreciate their contribution,” he said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh man stuck in Gujarat, pregnant wife in Tikamgarh
Content:
BHOPAL: I had shifted from Bhopal to Vadodara two months ago, because of my job. Now my wife is expecting a baby in April second week, (due date is April 8). Right now, she is with her parents in Tikamgarh, Madhya Pradesh and I am stuck up in Vadodara due to lockdown and want to be with my wife at this crucial time.

I have tried explaining it to the local police here, but they refused to issue any authorisation letter to help me reach there, claiming they don’t have any authority to do that. I have contacted travel agencies, but they also refused to take me to Madhya Pradesh. Since, I have shifted to Gujarat recently and my car is in Bhopal, so I don’t have any conveyance to reach there.

I am trying my best to remain calm and find appropriate way to reach MP, but there is so much uncertainty. I don’t know exactly when public modes of transport will restart. I don’t want to use any illegal method or to break any protocol to reach there hence I’m trying to get help from government officials. I have written an email to Vadodara district collector also this morning to seek his help.

(As told to Ramendra Singh by Amit Jain)

Title: Jaisalmer administration arranges food for Langa Manganiyars
Content:
Jaisalmer: Jaisalmer district administration has made special arrangements to provide food to the hundreds of Langa Manganiyars — the folk musicians who perform music and dance during the nine-month tourism season at hotels, restaurants — as they are forced to sit at home due to the lockdown.

On the directions of district collector Namit Mehta , information on the Langa Manganiyars residing in remote hamlets and villages is being collected and after identifying them, help is being extended to them.

Rotary club and Priya Foundation have come forward to provide food packets to police personnel, home guards and RAC jawans and officers deployed on field duty. Cooperative Consumer Store has also started home delivery of ration and food items. Hundreds of people from Jaisalmer and Barmer stuck in Gujarat on Friday reached Jaisalmer and Barmer border where after intensive health checking and screening, they were allowed to go to their homes and have been directed to remain in home isolation.

The Langa Manganiyars remain busy in Jaisalmer due to the tourist season generally till March 15 and later, they go abroad in groups, but now they are at home and many are facing problems earning their livelihood. The Jaisalmer district administration has made arrangements for them.

Collector Mehta said that information about these folk artistes is being collected and help is being provided to them. Those artistes who come under NFSA category are being provided food and other facilities as per rules and those who are not registered under NFSA, are also being provided food and other facilities. These artistes have been identified in villages in Jaisalmer and food items and packets are being provided to them.

He said that on Thursday, after the order to release the Rajasthanis stuck in Gujarat, large number of them is reaching here and they are being given entry after screening. Over 100 residents of Jaisalmer reached here on Friday, who after the health check-up and screening, were allowed to enter the district.

Collector said that Jaisalmer cooperative consumer wholesale store will sell food items daily in the city through two mobile vehicles in two shifts.

Title: Rajasthan: 4,100 beds ready in Jaisalmer & Barmer
Content:
Representative image

JAISALMER: Over 4,100 beds for quarantine have been arranged in Jaisalmer and Barmer districts in the wake of coronavirus spread. Isolation wards have also been set up in the districts.

In Barmer, 2,560 beds have arranged at 26 places. District collector Anshdeep appointed an in-charge officer and a nodal officer for the purpose. In Jaisalmer, 1,590 beds have been arranged at 22 places.

Around 398 teams surveyed 4.37 lakh people in 78,069 houses in rural and urban areas of Jaisalmer till March 24. Collector Namit Mehta said the teams made people aware about the virus and also directed them to follow the lockdown norms. Over 600 people who came from outside Jaisalmer have been advised to remain in home quarantine.

Till now, 22 samples from Jaisalmer have been sent for testing and all have turned negative. Similarly, in Barmer, 18 were sent and tested negative.

The district administrations also issued guidelines for Gangaur festival and advised people to perform puja at the peepal tree near their houses and immerse Gangaur idols there itself.

In Barmer district, donors and philanthropists have come forward with aid. So far, Rs 24.90 lakh has been collected in Barmer district.

Apart from this, donors are also assisting with masks, sanitisers and food packets to poor and needy. In Jaisalmer, too, Rs 16.5 lakh has been received as donations, including Rs 11 lakh from Ramdeora trust.

Title: Police, volunteers help the destitute
Content:
Kochi: When the city got literally shut down , the homeless and the destitute in the city who used to rely on alms and generous shop-keepers were the most affected bunch as they were devoid of methods to satiate their hunger . However, the society came to their aid, with the police themselves leading the way in the city to mobilise generous people who wants to serve food to the poor and to connect them with the needy.

According to police, food packets are distributed at North and South railway stations, KSRTC bus stand, high court junction, MG Road and other important junctions.

“It is our responsibility to provide food for those sleeping by the roads. We get the food material from generous citizens and later distribute it among the needy. At times, officers themselves buy food products for the needy,” said ACP K Laljy, Ernakulam Assistant Commissioner.

Sources said the word has been spread among the homeless about where to get the food from and they come to the locations by noon or at night to get the food.

Fr Joseph Koluthuvellil, director of Sharudaya , a charitable organisation of the Ernakulam Angamaly Archdiocese, said there are around 1,000 destitute in the city who are in need of food packets.

“We have been making over 300 packets on our own and has collaborated with police to distribute them among the needy. We have arranged a caterer to make the food and pack it,” said Fr Koluthuvellil.

He added that apart from homeless, migrants who are in the city for daily wages are also in need of food. “Migrants who used to somehow manage to make ends meet are now struggling for food. They deserve our help. Some who are stuck at railway stations also got the packets from us,” said Fr Koluthuvellil.

Sahrudaya has been giving lunch and dinner to the homeless in the city since Wednesday. Police officials said other organisations are also helping the poor in finding their meal.

“Volunteer individuals are organisations that are coming forward to help the needy. It is a time to stand together,” said a police officer.

Title: Mangaluru man ends life over coronavirus fear
Content: MANGALURU: A few days after a man committed suicide in Udupi as he feared that he had been infected by coronavirus, another person allegedly committed suicide in Bantwal taluk, fearing an outbreak of Covid-19 A a 55-year-old man allegedly committed suicide in Abettu village in Bantwal taluk on Friday morning. He left behind a suicide note which stated that he was depressed over the Covid-19 crisis and feared that he may become a victim to it.Police said that the deceased is Sadashiva Shetty ,55, a resident of Abettu, and he worked in a petrol bunk. Police said his death note stated that he was depressed in the past few days due to the Covid-19 pandemic. “I am mentally pained to hear about the pandemic and don’t have enough courage to endure it,” stated his death note. He had allegedly tried to end his life two days ago, but was unsuccessful. A case has been registered at the Bantwal Rural police station in this regard.

Title: 1 dead, 6 hurt as tin shade walls collapse
Content:
Kota: A 58-year-old woman was killed while six others of her family sustained injuries after the tin shade walls of the house collapsed over the sleeping family early on Friday morning in Mandawar town of Jhalawar district .

The deceased woman was identified as Sitabai, wife of Ramgopal, resident of Mandawar town of Jhalawar district. The body was handed over to family members after postmortem on Friday noon, while six of the family including three minors sustained injuries in the mishap. While five of them were discharged after primary healthcare at SRG hospital, the woman’s husband Ramgopal is undergoing treatment.

tnn

Title: Family of 3 stranded in Sri Lanka
Content:
Chaitanya Bandaru and his family

Visakhapatnam: As borders come up around the world to contain the spread of Covid-19, those stranded in foreign lands are looking for ways to return home.

A family of three from the city that visited Sri Lanka on tourist visas has now been stranded in the country for over two weeks. Chaitanya Bandaru, his wife and son have been staying at a hotel in Wadduwa ever since their holiday was suspended on March 15. Since there were restrictions on international travel, Chaitanya initially shifted their date of return to India to March 22 from 24.

He then extended his stay till March 29 as all flights on March 22 were suspended, stating, “Because of shutdown announced by states till March 31, my flight on March 29 too got cancelled. I had later booked flight on April 1 to Hyderabad for approximately one lakh Sri Lankan rupees. But, because of total lockdown for 21 days, the flight on April 1 has been cancelled.”

Chaitanya continued, “Now, I had to book tickets for April 17 on Sri Lankan Airlines at a cost of 1.86 lakh Sri Lankan rupees. Because of this extended stay for additional 24 days, I have to shell out $2200 approximately for accommodation and food for my family. This is causing a lot of financial strain as my trip duration tripled from 11 days to 34 days,” adding that he had written a letter to the Indian embassy in Sri Lanka to help him travel back.

In its reply, the Indian embassy said, “It is to inform you that as per latest guidelines, no scheduled international commercial passenger aircraft is allowed to land in India from March 22 for one week. You are advised to continue staying back at your current location until situation improves. You will be informed as the commercial flights resume its operations.”

Title: Jodhpur cops feed needy
Content:
Jodhpur: Police have emerged a good samaritan for the starving destitute scattered around the city in various settlements .

Contrary to its ‘anti-human’ image, police in Jodhpur have been consistently reaching out to this distraught lot, mostly daily wager and labour class due to loss of their jobs because of the lockdown and providing them with what the need the most during this testing time — food.

Right from maintaining law and order arising out of the lockdown to pleading to citizens to remain indoors to distributing sanitisers to keeping an eye on the influx of migrants ensuring that they are screened, police have been playing a pivotal role in ensuring compliance of the orders and directions of the administration and the government. Various thana police in city have identified settlements in their respective jurisdiction where people have been finding it difficult to get ends meet and have distributed food packets either on their own or with the help of donors or charitable entities.

A senior police officer said they have to play multiple roles in any calamity or crisis. “As police remain in the field 24/7, it is our duty to ensure compliance as well as to attend to deprived ones,” said the officer.

On Friday, Mandore police distributed food packets among the settlements of Pak Hindu migrants under the police station area.

These persons, mostly daily wagers, have been finding it tough to sustain during the lockdown.

Hindu Singh Sodha, president of Seemant Lok Sangthan , appreciated police for their service. Even Government Railway Police and the Railway Police Force have arranged food for the needy.

Title: 2,000 garment workers in Mumbai plan to trek 1,400km to UP homes
Content:
Employers’ body provides food to workers but provisions are running out

MUMBAI: The Covid-19 pandemic has spawned a humanitarian crisis in the narrow bylanes of Wadala. Deprived of income to meet their living expenses in Mumbai, around 2,000 workers employed in small-scale textile units here plan to trek 1,400km back to their homes in Uttar Pradesh.

These men are employed in the small-scale textile units in National Market—among India’s oldest readymade garments markets—along Rafi Ahmed Kidwai Marg. Their units shut almost 20 days ago, since Covid-19 cases began to be reported.

Their employers promised them meals if they continued to pay the rent for their kholis —tiny rooms shared by around 10 workers. After almost three weeks of providing them two meals daily, now the employers’ association has said it won’t be able to keep up the charity any longer.

The textile workers, who earn Rs 15,000 to Rs 20,000 a month, want to return home and plan to walk to Uttar Pradesh as they are worried about the plight of their old parents, wives and young children there.

Rafiq Shaikh is one of the workers preparing to leave for Kanpur where his parents are. “I have just Rs 5,000 left in my bank and don’t want it to get depleted further by staying on here,” he said. Shaikh’s parents have been asking him leave Mumbai.

“Trains and buses are not functioning. If no group or people come forward to help soon, I am going to start walking,” he added. His roommate said, “It is better to die in our villages than due to starvation and coronavirus.’’

The employers’ association, comprising 300 wholesale dealers of garments, had put up a makeshift structure in the marketplace 10 days ago to serve as a kitchen for the workers. National Market president Yasin Shaikh said the association has no means to continue feeding them for months. “The lockdown has handicapped us. Our groceries’ stock and money are depleting,” he said. Moreover, it is a challenge to buy provisions in bulk during the ongoing lockdown. “To feed 2,000 workers, we need huge quantities that can best be brought from the APMC market in Vashi, but how do we go without policemen beating us,” he said.

Since several workers stay in one room where they eat and sleep, “even if one of them gets infected, the infection will spread easily,” said Shaikh. The association wants the government to organize a special train or bus to send the workers to UP.

Social worker Imran Khan said locals donate rice and dal for the stranded workers. “The fear right now is starvation more than coronavirus. Even if these men start walking, it will take them a week or more to reach home. Given their poor nutritional status, they could contract the virus along the way,” said Khan.

Congress corporator Sunil More, who visited the slums adjoining the market, said, “I have spoken to a local gurudwara as well as a few builders to continue providing meals for these stranded workers from Uttar Pradesh.” He also has given a contract to a private contractor to fumigate the workshops and houses.

But men like Rafiq Shaikh don’t want to stay on. In times of Covid-19, they would rather be home than thousands of kilometres apart from their families.

Title: Social distancing, lockdown go for a toss in Diamond City
Content:
Residents had thronged the grocery shops, milk counters on the entire stretch from Ramnagar to Adajan

Surat: It seems lockdown order and social distancing to combat COVID-19 have gone for a toss in the city. Apart from movement of vehicles in most parts of the city, residents were seen thronging grocery shops and vegetable markets, discarding the appeal for social distancing made by Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) and district administration on Friday.

Residents had thronged the grocery shops, milk counters and medical stores on the entire stretch from Ramnagar to Adajan. People were standing in queues outside the shops without keeping a safe distance. The scene was horrific at Sardar Market at Sahara Darwaja, where large number of people had come to purchase farm fresh vegetables and fruits, without worrying about spread of contagious COVID-19. They had gathered in large numbers at one place rubbing shoulders with each other.

Rajesh Kaladiya, a vegetable wholesaler at Sardar Market, said, “We had closed the gates of the market in the morning and asked customers to enter in small groups. But when the gates were opened, a sea of people entered the market. We couldn’t do much to stop them.”

Kaladiya added, “The market is regularly getting supply of vegetables, but still people are coming to the market to buy vegetables at wholesale rates. Majority of customers are from residential apartments.”

Nilesh Thorat, secretary of Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC), which manages Sardar Market, said, “We immediately asked senior officers of municipal corporation and district collector’s office to visit Sardar Market. A team of officials visited the market and ensured deployment of cops to stop people from gathering at the market from Saturday.”

Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), told TOI, “Residents need to understand the seriousness of COVID-19. They have to maintain social distancing when standing at grocery shops, vegetable markets etc.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man, forced into isolation by kin, commits suicide
Content: TRICHY/COIMBATORE: Loneliness can kill. Just a few days into the nationwide shutdown, and some people are going to the extreme. A 29-year-old man forced to live in isolation committed suicide in his farm house at Maramadakki village in Pudukkottai district on Friday. And in Coimbatore, police rescued a man living alone who tweeted that he was having suicidal thoughts.Police said C Suresh of Maramadakki village had gone into depression after his parents and elder brother refused to let him into the house last week fearing he could be infected with Covid-19.Suresh had gone to the Maldives in 2019. After working there for a few months, he returned to Pudukkottai on January 15. From there he went to Tirupur in search of a job. He had to return because of the nationwide shutdown.His family insisted that he remain in isolation and sent him to the farm house.C Balu, his elder brother said they suspected Suresh may be infected with Covid-19 since he returned from the Maldives and decided to keep him in isolation for a few days.“Though he didn’t like it, he stayed in the farm house and we didn’t allow children from our house to meet him,” said Balu.On Friday morning, when a relative went to give him breakfast, Suresh was found hanging from the ceiling of the house.The Aranthangi police have filed a case and are investigating.In Coimbatore, a 35-year-old private bank employee from GN Mills tweeted that he was alone at home and was having suicidal thoughts. He tagged his tweet to the Union home ministry.Coimbatore city police commissioner Sumit Sharan, who noticed the tweet, informed SP Sujit Kumar to send cops to GN Mills. The man told two sub-inspectors from the Thudiyalur station who rushed to the place that his parents were in Kotagiri in the Nilgiris and he unable to travel there. Police promised to take him to his parents’ house.To distract him, they asked him to join them in checking vehicles at GN Mills junction.Later, officials instructed police to allow him to go to Kotagiri in his own vehicle.“His parents left for Kotagiri a week ago. So, he was alone in the house at GN Mills and he felt mentally sick. He has now reached his home town safely and is all right now,” said sub-inspector Dhamodaran.

Title: Dabbawallas can work, but use disposable boxes: Official in Nashik
Content:
NASHIK: The district civil supplies department has directed dabbawallas in the city to start providing meals to their customers in disposable boxes.

The decision was taken after the department received requests from residents and meal service providers that due to the lockdown in the city, they were unable to get food delivered to their homes.

Arvind Narsikar, district supply officer, told TOI that many people are suffering due to the services being disrupted in the city amid lockdown.

“We have decided that the service providers can continue with their work while taking necessary precautions,” he added.

According to Narsikar, there are many senior citizens and patients who cannot cook food and require ready-made food.

“Those who cannot cook on their own, as they are old or sick, depend on the delivery services for their meals. We have permitted the service providers to supply food to such people. Also there are many students who could not go to their native place. In addition, the servicemen who live alone and working from whom have to arrange for food from outside,” he said.

Narsikar said that the department has directed the meal service providers not to pack food in plastic bags.

Sanket Joshi, who runs such service, said “We could not provide food for three days and received several enquiries during that period. Those who cannot get up from their bed to cook food are dependent on our service. The district supply department has asked us that if we have to deliver food to anyone who is in quarantine, we should stay careful.”

Title: Only 60-70% pharmacies functioning in Madurai
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Only 60-70% of the pharmacies, with measures in place to maintain social distancing, in Madurai district are currently functioning as opening of all pharmacies is not mandatory in view of lockdown. Meanwhile, sugar factories have started getting license to produce hand sanitizers, which is set to bring down prices and ensure enough supply for public.

“It is up to the owners of medical shops whether to open or not. We try to insist on enough shops to be opened to ensure medicines reach public accordingly in different areas,” said an official from the Tamil Nadu drugs control department (TNDCD).

“Some of the smaller pharmacies are afraid to open considering the COVID-19 scare as they don’t have many preventive measures in place. There is definitely no shortage of medicines. However, it could be that some brands are not available because of the current issues in movement of goods we are facing due to lockdown,” said pharmacist from KK Nagar. While medicines are available in plenty to cater to public needs, masks continue to remain in high demand but short supply. Pharmacists and TNDCD said that though there is a shortage of hand sanitizers now, it would soon be sorted. “Licenses are being given now to sugar factories to enable them to produce sanitizers using ethanol. Few factories have already started production. Soon, we will have enough supply to meet the public demand. This would also bring down prices,” said a medical representative.

The TNDCD, meanwhile, continues to monitor and conduct inspections in pharmacies to ensure no illegal practices are taking place. Any person with complaints regarding non-availability of medicines, overpriced medicines and substandard or overpriced masks and hand sanitizers can contact the department officials.

Title: LTROs to ease mutual funds' debt pain
Content: MUMBAI: Long-term repo operations (LTROs), the central bank’s new instrument to provide liquidity to bond investors including mutual funds, is showing good results in supporting bond prices at lower levels, market players said. On Friday, the RBI said it would conduct LTROs aggregating an additional Rs 1 lakh crore, which fund industry executives say will help stabilise bond prices for some more time.Due to the coronavirus pandemic, there have been large sell-offs in the equity, bond and forex markets in the country. “With the intensification of redemption pressures, liquidity premia on instruments such as corporate bonds , commercial papers and debentures have surged. Combined with the thinning of trading activity with the Covid-19 outbreak, financial conditions for these instruments, which are used, inter alia, to access working capital in the face of the slowdown in bank credit, have also tightened,” the RBI said.To mitigate their adverse effects on economic activity, the RBI, through LTROs of three-year tenure, will infuse up to Rs 1 lakh crore into the system, it said.According to Nimesh Shah , managing director & CEO, ICICI Prudential Mutual Fund, LTROs worth Rs 1 lakh are aimed at soothing the bond market, which over the last one month had witnessed a spike in yields. “This measure will aid in enhancing liquidity in corporate bond markets and consequently lead to easing in short term bond yields of high rated corporate bond papers,” Shah said.Since the beginning of the month, as the pandemic-led selling intensified in the stock and bond markets, mutual fund industry had been asking RBI to provide a line of credit to meet higher redemption requests, just like the central bank did during the 2008-2009 global financial crisis.

Title: Uncertain future lies ahead for Jhunjhunu’s diaspora in Italy
Content: Jaipur: Walking through the deserted lanes of Khatiko-ka-Mohalla and Shiv Colony in Jhunjhunu, foreign news channels or Italian ones are more heard than Indian ones. For, this arid district has about 4,000 to 5,000 of its residents stationed in Italy.It's difficult to miss the Italian imprint in the three tehsils of Mandawa , Nawalgarh, and Jhunjhunu. The interiors and design of houses are a testimony to the local diaspora flourishing in Italy.But the times have changed. With a pandemic striking the world this soldier town's fears are now well beyond its borders.Adding to their woes are worries that a major concentration of people from Jhunjhunu stay in areas worst-hit by the novel coronavirus like Lombardy region (Milan, Brescia and Bergamo) and Campania region (Naples and Marmo So Napoli).Engaged mainly in the hospitality, agriculture and manufacturing sectors, it is mostly the Khateeks, listed under the Scheduled Caste community, who have ventured into Italy. But if for so many years they were marked by their branded clothes, watches, bags, shoes, now it is fear of being stigmatized that haunt these men.Rohit Nehra (35) is spending time in isolation at the Rani Sati Mandir guesthouse ever since he came into contact with a Covid-19 positive couple who had returned from Italy. “Thirty years of our hard work has fallen like a pack of cards. My elder brother completed his isolation last week after coming from Italy. The pandemic has shaken us up to the core as we lie quarantined here with an uncertain future," he says.Explains Shravan Panwar (71) the passion of the Khateek community for Italy, "When the Middle East opened its doors for Indian workforce it was a time for us to break the caste and economic barrier. Unfortunately, all unskilled and semi-skilled jobs were preferred to Muslims while highly skilled to the upper caste Hindus. Here again, we were left unattended due to our caste. During the same period, we heard stories from Punjab as how lower caste people were heading for Europe for menial jobs. Initially, some courageous members of our community took the risk via ships but soon it opened a passage for the rest, " says Panwar, who has retired from his work in Italy and is now living in Chidawa with his grandchildren. He was among the first wave of migrants in the late 80s.Back in Italy, the residents are reluctant to return due to fear of losing jobs and for avoiding the ordeal of travel from Italy to Delhi to Jhunjhunu to be followed by quarantine period at home. Poonam Chand (58) who works as a cook in a restaurant in Bolzano City, North Italy , has been in a lockdown since March 11. "I have told my family to be the last Indian to leave Italy as it is our Karam Bhoomi (workplace). This is what has given us an identity and a better life, " said Chand over the phone.Sharing how life was in a state facing the worst face of Coronavirus, he said, "Until March 11, we were not aware of the scale of the problem. It is only after the lockdown was announced that we focused on how Italy is in the middle of it's biggest crises, " said Chand.But not everyone is like Chand who do not want to return. Ranjeet Khateek, (34) who is in his third years in Italy, would like to come but is scared of travelling on a train to Rome and to Delhi-Jaipur-Jhunjhunu followed by 14 days quarantine. Even the administration is its toes and is preparing to host its residents if they manage to come back to Jhunjhunu.Brijendra Singh Ola, MLA Jhunjhunu, has shot a letter to the ministry of external affairs to take necessary steps in bringing the stranded Indians from Italy. "They are sons of the soil who have greatly contributed to the economy of the city. They can approach the state government for any assistance, " said Ola.

Title: Woman employed in Chennai mall tests positive in Ariyalur
Content:
Trichy: A 25-year-old woman employee of a shopping mall in Chennai tested positive for Covid-19 at the government headquarters hospital in Ariyalur on Friday. Health minister Dr C Vijaya Baskar confirmed the case by re-tweeting the National Health Mission’s tweet in this regard.

Said to be an employee of a famous mall at Velachery, the woman, a mother of two, developed symptoms of fever and cough on March 19. She travelled to her native Ariyalur by train from Chennai and stayed at the house of her mother. However, she got admitted to the government hospital the next day.

The doctors sent her swab and blood samples to the viral research and diagnostic laboratory (VRDL) at the government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur which confirmed the infection. Sources said her health condition was stable.

Since the mall where she worked witnessed big crowds, the public health officials have alerted their counterparts in Chennai to trace all those who contacted her during her work. Public health officials led by Dr V C Hemachand Gandhi identified the people who were in contact with the woman in Ariyalur. As she met her parents and relatives on her return, the officials put 14 people including them on home quarantine.

Sources said she was married to a man in a village near Meensurutti in Ariyalur district. While her husband and children were residing in the village, the woman was staying in Chennai for the past two months.

“We have informed Chennai Corporation for cross reference. They are tracing all her contact persons as per protocol. Since she travelled from Chennai by train, we have passed on the information too,” Ariyalur collector D Rathna told TOI.

The officials were perplexed by the contradictory information given by the woman about her work and stay in Chennai. An official said she claimed to be staying at Saidapet. “She was working in the mall but we have no idea in which shop and where she resides. Since the woman is not revealing the exact details to the health team, we have asked the police to enquire with her,” said the collector.

As of today, four patients including three women are kept under observation at the isolation ward at the government hospital in Ariyalur. She is the second infected person under treatment in a hospital in central Tamil Nadu after a 24-year-old Dubai returnee in Trichy.

Title: Youth goes missing from GGH isolation ward
Content:
Guntur: A youth, who was admitted to Government General Hospital (GGH), Guntur, with suspected Covid-19 symptoms, went missing.

However, sources said the police have detained the youth and are likely to hand him over to the hospital authorities.

The 27-year-old is a native of Penamalur in Krishna district. He was admitted to GGH isolation ward three days ago. After finding the youth missing from the isolation ward, GGH resident medical officer (RMO) Adinarayana lodged a complaint at Kothapet police station.

The RMO said that the youth fled even before they could collect swab samples to ascertain whether he is suffering from coronavirus. He said they have entered the details after he approached the doctors with symptoms and asked him to stay in the isolation ward for check-up.

The youth fled from the hospital along with the case sheet to avoid investigation. Inspector Rajasekhara Reddy said that they have booked a case against the youth.

GGH superintendent Dr S Babulal said no one should be worried as the government is taking care of their health once admitted to the hospital. He said that getting admitted to the isolation wards would not only help the patient but also his family members and society.

Title: Bhopal: Covid-19 journalist booked for ‘endangering life of others’
Content: BHOPAL: Shyamla Hills police, acting on complaint filed by CMHO Dr Sudhir Dehariya, on Friday night registered a case against the journalist who tested positive for Covid-19 on March 25.According to ASP Manu Vyas, the complaint says that the scribe was instructed to stay at home after his daughter tested positive but he “roamed around in the city, attended press conferences and endangered the life of others”.He had attended a press conference called by former CM Kamal Nath. Now, all the journalists who attended the presser are in home quarantine. The scribe has been booked under IPC sections 188, 269 and 270.

Title: Pune: Court grants interim bail to two directors in Girivan case
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Additional sessions judge SM Agarkar on Friday granted interim pre-arrest bail till April 15 to directors of Sujata Farms Private Limited Jayant Ramchandra Mhalgi (63) and his wife, Sujata (58), in the alleged Rs96.99 lakh cheating case related to a plot scheme at Girivan hill station project floated by the firm at Dongargaon and Hotale village, about 40km from the city.

Judge Agarkar referred to the Covid-19 outbreak and said in his order, “Looking towards this extreme situation, granting of interim relief is the need of the hour. Due to present situation, the hearing of bail matter can be adjourned till April 15.”

The judge said, “The allegation in the FIR does not disclose need of immediate custodial interrogation . Imposing reasonable condition ensuring cooperation of applicants (the Mhalgis) in investigation will meet the ends of justice and so far will not hamper the investigation. The investigating officer (IO) on query by the court submits that attendance of applicants is sufficient for investigation at this juncture. Moreover, the IO can apply for urgent hearing in between in case of extreme urgent situation.”

Earlier, the Paud police submitted a report opposing anticipatory bail for the two applicants. The lawyer for the original complainant too objected to the bail plea, contending that the affected investors have been struggling for last 19 years to secure justice in the matter. Lawyers Suchit Mundada and Swapnil Jagtap, representing the Mhalgis, argued that custodial interrogation of their clients was not needed considering that the dispute was of civil nature.

The court directed the interim protection on the two applicants furnishing personal release bonds of Rs15,000 each and sureties in the like amount. Among other conditions, it directed the Mhalgis to report to the police for interrogation as and when required and not to leave India without the court’s permission.

Title: Covid-19: Plan to send samples to Thiruvananthapuram irks healthcare providers
Content: KOCHI: Healthcare providers in Ernakulam district are upset with the state government’s decision to send samples of those suspected to have Covid-19 in the district to a lab in Thiruvananthapuram.Now, the samples from the district are send to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Alappuzha, for testing and the results arrive in 2 to 3 days. On Friday, 24 samples were send to NIV, Alappuzha.Health officials fear that sending the samples to Thiruvananthapuram, which is almost 200 km away, means that more time will be lost and there would be further delay in announcing results if there is a surge in numbers due to community outbreak.The matter was discussed by the Ernakulam district medical officer (DMO) and doctors in the district Covid-19 team with the district collector and he was requested to take up the matter with the state government.“We are still sending the samples to NIV, Alappuzha. We are concerned that there may be a delay if we send it to Thiruvananthapuram. We have taken up the matter with the collector. For us, the closest testing lab is NIV, Alappuzha,” said district medical officer (DMO) Dr M K Kuttappan.As per the guidelines for distribution of laboratories issued by health secretary on March 25, it has been instructed that district surveillance officer from Ernakulam will have to send samples to Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology, Thiruvananthapuram. The lab will also receive samples from Kollam district. Meanwhile, NIV Alappuzha will henceforth cater to testing samples from Alappuzha and Malappuram districts, as per the government guidelines.NIV, Alappuzha, was one of the first testing labs in the country that was permitted to confirm Covid-19 positive samples without sending them to NIV, Pune. Due to increase in the number of people who needed to be tested for Covid-19, Kerala received permission from Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) to set up two more labs. Now the state has nine labs, all in the public sector, with four in the state capital alone. No lab in Ernakulam district has yet received permission for Covid-19 testing yet.ICMR has updated the protocol for coronavirus and now the criteria have been expanded to include health workers attending to Covid-19 patients who start showing symptoms. Earlier it was limited to symptomatic people with a travel history to affected countries or those who come into contact with infected persons.Incidentally, as the number of people in quarantine increases, there is excess burden on the approved testing labs with a government official admitting that often the waiting time for test results now is 3 to 4 days. Health officials said that what they need at the moment is not more private labs but more testing kits at reasonable price to be made available to the states.

Title: Help, food pour in for needy people in Kota, Bundi districts
Content:
Kota: Many people have come forward to provide food to needy people during the lockdown period so that they don’t go starve. Around 50,000 coaching students who are stuck in hostels, PGs are being provided with food by various organisations.

Lok Sabha speaker Om Birla has sent ration material for nearly 500 families for 10 days for distribution among the needy in Bundi. His OSD Rajiv Dutta on Thursday handed over the ration material to Bundi district administration and asked to arrange distribution of the same among those in need of food material during lockdown.

Besides, the 2003 bath Rajasthan police officer Dutta along with his team of volunteers moved to Bheel Basti in Banganga area of Bundi district and distributed round 750 food packets among the locals who are mostly daily wagers and finding it hard to meet both ends meet in absence of work during lockdown. Food material among the needy during lock down would continue to be distributed by teams of volunteers in Kota and Bundi, Rajiv Dutta said and added the teams of volunteers maintaining social distancing are moving in the localities and distributing the food packets.

The distribution of food packets aims at ensuring that daily labourers, people living on roadsides, destitute may not stay without food during lock down, he said. Meanwhile, police teams are also engaged in distribution of food packets in localities of daily labourers and workers and are moving door-to-door. Kota city SP Gaurav Yadav has asked locals to report for donation of food and ration at emergency phone number 100 so that cops can collect it to distribute among the needy.

Title: Assault on public: Action against cops after inquiry
Content:
Vijayawada: Even as videos of police beating people on roads and other public places during the lockdown went viral, the police department is yet to initiate action against the officials for their excesses.

Sources in Director General of Police (DGP) office said that inquiries have been ordered in all the incidents and action will be taken only after receiving the reports.

In the Dachepalli incident that took place at the border of AP and Telangana on Thursday night, the cops booked cases against those who pelted stones at the cops. As the police stopped people from entering into AP unless they agree to go on quarantine, clashes broke out between the cops and the people headed to their native places in AP from Telangana.

While the people pelted stones at the cops after heated arguments, the cops unleashed force by caning them. The videos of the police beating people including women went viral on social media platforms.

The cops said a DSP rank officer and five other cops on duty were injured in the stone pelting and lathicharge was done to control the situation.

In the Peravali incident, where a sub-inspector was seen beating up a man who returned from abroad, the home minister had announced his suspension but, the higher officials have reconsidered the decision after taking the cop’s version into consideration.

Sources in the DGP’s office said the SI had been working for the last four days and the man returned from abroad ignored repeated requests by the cops to stay in home isolation. He took the extreme measure only to keep him in isolation as a last resort, said the sources.

Even in other incidents reported at Hanuman Junction, Kurnool and other places across the state, the department has backed its officials. Sources in the DGP office said that the police took the extreme action only after running out of all options.

On the other hand, Piduguralla CI was placed under vacant reserve for dereliction of duties as he was not properly monitoring the people placed under home quarantine.

Title: Mask is not compulsory: Udupi DC
Content:
Representative image

UDUPI: An acute shortage of masks has arisen in the district following the announcement of the lockdown . Due to the fear of contracting coronavirus, all those who are stepping out of homes to buy essential commodities are wearing masks. As a result, demand for masks has shot up, and most of the medical shops in the district have run out of stock.

Udupi deputy commissioner G Jagadeesha has asked people not to resort to panic buying of masks. “A healthy man need not wear a mask. Only people undergoing treatment and doctors need to wear N95 masks. If people are going near someone who has fever and cough, they need to wear a triple-layer mask. This is what the guideline says,” he said.

KV Nagaraj, assistant drug regulator, Udupi, said, “N-95 masks are used by those at high risk like Covid-19 patients, doctors and medical staff. Triple-layer masks can be used by health staff in the hospital’s outpatient department and patients with cold and cough. There is no need to buy washable masks from medicals stores, because they can be made at home with cotton and rinsed with hot water.”

Title: West Bengal: Two foreign returnees on list of 500 wedding guests
Content: TAMLUK/KOLKATA: Amid the scare of community transmission , the state health department has traced at least two people with foreign travel history scanning a 500-odd guest list at the Egra wedding on March 13, which the 63-year-old Nayabad resident had attended and later tested Covid-19 positive. While the first person had already left for Singapore after the wedding, the second person is in Midnapore having returned from the US in March first week.The first person’s wife and the US returnee have been shifted to an isolation facility in the Egra super-speciality hospital on Friday along with 11 others, who attended the wedding and later complained of unease and mild fever. The samples arrived at IPGMER’s laboratory on Friday. The health department has also kept every guest in the wedding under home isolation with health officers keeping a check twice-a-day.“We have kept in touch with this man in Singapore, He has no symptoms,” said an official. According to them, his wife who lives in in Midnapore too attended the wedding. The woman also has not shown symptoms. But her samples too have been taken. The US returnee, also a Midnapore resident, does not have any symptom, but his sample too has been sent. The health department had conducted a screening of more than 500 people who had attended the wedding.Swab samples of the four family members of the 66-year-old Nayabad resident was also collected on Friday. His wife, son, daughter in-law and four-year-old granddaughter have now been shifted to isolation at MR Bangur Hospital The health department said they were also being helped by the victim’s kin and their extended relatives as they try to trace the origin of the infection. A Salt Lake household, for example, had asked its own kin who stay in isolation in Egra not to return to his Kolkata home after they learnt he too attended the Egra meeting. Pandemonium has broken out in this East Midnapore town, 188 kilometres from Kolkata, with several persons now trying to leave the vicinity of the family of the homeopathy doctor where the wedding had taken place.“My uncle had gone to a relative’s place in Egra, whose entire family had been at the wedding,” said a Kolkata resident unwilling to be named. The resident said after the news broke, Egra health workers sent the doctors family into quarantine and began tracking all other guests who had attended wedding, the relative is now unwilling to stay there especially with the family and is making amends to come back to Kolkata. “We have advised him not to return and adhere to all government health protocols,” he said. Kolkata Municipal Corporation has started a special clean-up drive at Ward 107 in east Kolkata where both the Nayabad patient and the city’s first Covid-19 positive victim lived. “We are doing our bit but this is such a disease that cannot be stopped without the help of the people. They need to understand the same and must stay at their homes at any cost for this entire lockdown period,” said Ananya Banerjee, the local councillor.

Title: Govt sets up high-level taskforce to monitor battle against Covid-19
Content:
Amaravati: The state government on Friday constituted a high-level taskforce to monitor measures taken to contain the spread of Covid-19.

Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy directed the officials to constitute the taskforce with five ministers, 10 senior IAS officers and four senior officials from the CMO.

Ministers Alla Nani (health), Buggana Rajendranath Reddy (finance), Botcha Satyanarayana (municipal administration), Mekathoti Sucharitha (home) and Kurasala Kannababu (agriculture) will be part of the taskforce.

The cabinet chaired by the chief minister met here in the secretariat on Friday and discussed the measures initiated by the government to contain the spread of the coronavirus in detail. Interestingly, the seating of the ministers and senior officials in the cabinet meeting hall was arranged in such a way that it maintained the social distance of two metres.

Giving details of the cabinet discussions to the media, information and public relations minister Perni Venkataramaiah (Nani) said that the chief minister directed the officials to strengthen the medical infrastructure and fully gear up the administration to tackle the crisis.

He said that the government has kept a close vigil on all the 28,000 foreign returnees in the state. “The state has so far reported 12 Covid-19 positive cases. All are undergoing treatment. All the suspects have been moved to quarantine homes,” said Nani.

He said that four hospitals--one each at Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam, Tirupati and Nellore--have already been converted into dedicated super specialty hospitals to battle Covid-19. He said that 100-bed isolation centres are in place at constituency-level and 200-bed isolation centres at district-level.

He said about 400 ventilators have been kept ready with PPEs (Personal Protection Equipment) such as Hazmath suits for the medical professionals. He said that they have also procured over 10 lakh surgical masks for patient attendants along with over 52,000 N-95 masks. He said that they have placed orders for more equipment which is likely to be reached in a couple of days.

The minister expressed serious displeasure with the students and software engineers trying to rush back to their native places. “It is very sad to see that students and others from our state are stranded at other places but the situation prompts us to say no to their entry. They are all educated and they should understand the situation better,” said Nani.

He, however, said that the government is ready to allow people into the state if they were willing to go to quarantine homes instead of their own homes. He advised students and techies to stay back in the places of their work and study till the completion of the lockdown period.

The minister said that the chief minister has directed the collectors to immediately convert all function halls into shelter homes to provide food to the homeless and orphans. The cabinet appealed to philanthropists to come forward to feed the homeless during the hour of crisis.

Title: Dial 14567: Hyderabad elderly get special helpline for ration, medical aid
Content: HYDERABAD: The state women and child welfare department (WCWD) with Tata Trust and HelpAge India has set up a helpline for the old-age homes and senior citizens who are stuck in their homes during the 21-day lockdown for assistance.A monitoring team has been formed by WCWD, which will reach out to the elderly and help them on caregivers and for their medical needs. “The senior citizens can reach out to us on the helpline number 14567. They will be given the required assistance,” said MS Shankar, spokesperson, WCWD.NGOs, which provide shelter to abandoned elderly, have also raised similar concerns. “We have ration which will last for less than 10 days. Forty people are staying at our home,” said George Rakesh Babu, founder of Good Samaritan India , an NGO.WCWD, meanwhile, has issued an order after the lockdown directing the district welfare officers (DWOs) to identify, verify and get connected with all the old-age homes and ask them about passes, ration, medicines and access to hospitals.“Our monitoring team that was operational at state level working in coordination with GHMC, district administration and police to address all their issues one by one. Apart from this, the department is coordinating with Tata Trust and HelpAge India to help old-age homes,” said D Divya, commissioner, WCWD.

Title: Public places in Sec’bad disinfected
Content:
Secunderabad: The disinfection of public places by spraying of disinfectants was done in civil areas of Secunderabad Cantonment on Friday.

The SCB chief executive officer, SVR Chandra Sekhar reviewed the measures taken up for fight against Covid-19. Accordingly, the CEO visited multiple areas in the Cantonment and interacted with civilians.

As part of creating awareness, the Cantonment Board officials also distributed pamphlets about preventive measures to be followed to prevent the spread of the virus. Announcements advising people to stay indoors and maintain minimum social distancing were made by designated vehicles. The officials also directed the shopkeepers dealing with essential commodities and instructed buyers to maintain minimum distance. The SCB officials are coordinating with police to monitor the home quarantine imposed on those who have returned from foreign countries.

Title: Health department teams complete screening of 28 lakh in Bhilwara
Content: Jaipur: In the worst affected Covid-19 district of the state, heath department teams have been screening people on war footing. According to the Bhilwara district administration officials, there are 1,950 teams in rural areas and 332 teams in the urban areas, conducting door-to-door survey. So far, they have completed screening of 28 lakh people in Bhilwara.Health department report shows that report of 139 suspected persons is awaited in Bhilwara only. While in the entire state, the report of 278 suspected Covid-19 cases is awaited. However, health department has issued directions to all the collectors to prepare a list of private hospitals, which can be taken over for expanding isolation wards and quarantine facilities.Also, directions have been issued to deploy doctors doing their internship from different medical colleges in Sirohi, Jodhpur, Jalore and Pali. Also, directions have been issued to deploy 15 more doctors for Ramganj area, where cases of Covid-19 have been reported. Moreover, health department has issued directions to its officials to acquire all medicines such as ritonavir, lopinavir, oseltamivir and hydroxychloroquine which are useful in the treatment of Covid-19.

Title: Crammed labour camps again in focus
Content: Kochi: Squalid conditions in which some sections of the migrant workforce in the district are being forced to live have come to sharp focus again in the backdrop of lockdown Out-of-work and immobile, migrant workers who were employed in multiple shifts are now forced to share room space with almost double the number of people in areas close to industrial units. “Many contractors had devised a system where accommodation is provided in sync with the shifts. With the lockdown, these people are forced to share rooms with almost double the number of people,” said Benoy Peter, executive director, Centre for Migration and Inclusive Development. Local bodies across the district are now on a scramble to identify places where these people can be accommodated in the backdrop of Covid-19 There are three major pockets in the district where migrant workforce is concentrated — Ambalamugal-Karimugal stretch, Vathuruthy and Kandanthara in Perumbavoor.Ambalamugal area has close to 10,000 migrant labourers employed by contractors and sub-contractors who have taken up works related to the expansion of Kochi refinery. Kandanthara has close to 4,000 workers, while Vathuruthy has around 3,000 labourers.Sathi Jayakrishnan, chairperson, Perumbavoor Municipality, said the issue came up for discussion at a meeting attended by the RDO on Thursday. “Plywood companies and hotel owners have agreed to take care of their workers but there is a concern regarding people who have taken up temporary accommodation on terraces of lodges. In some buildings, these sheds accommodate up to 100 people. Lodge owners are not ready to take care of them,” she said. The municipality has identified schools in its limits where these labourers can be moved.Velayudhan P K, president, Vadavucode-Puthencruz panchayat, said they have decided to visit labour camps and sanitise them. “We will identify schools where they can be put up if such a directive comes from the government,” he said. As of now there are no issues regarding availability of food since the labour contractors have ensured that they get provisions. “If the lockdown period is increased we would provide them help,” said Velayudhan.

Title: High alert issued in Ayodhya Nagar
Content:
Vijayawada: Ayodhya Nagar in Vijayawada was declared a high alert zone on Friday after a 28-year-old man, who returned from Stockholm in Sweden, tested positive for Covid-19 the previous night.

This is the third Covid-19 positive case in Vijayawada. A 3-km radius around the patient’s residence has been declared as the core zone and cordoned off while a radius of 2 km beyond the core zone has been declared buffer zone.

Officials of the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) declared division numbers 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10,11, 14 and 19 under Vijayawada East assembly constituency surrounding the residence of the patient as the containment zone and sealed the area within its one kilometer radius. A complete lockdown has been announced for all divisions, said VMC commissioner V Prasanna Venkatesh.

The VMC and health department sanitised the core zone and its sanitation wing sprayed bleaching powder and sodium hypochlorite, the commissioner said. City police set up 12 check-posts in and around Ayodhya Nagar to ensure implementation of the lockdown and appealed to locals in the area to stay at home.

Krishna district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz said police and health officials have been deployed to monitor the situation in the area. Medical and police teams will shift persons complaining of symptoms to isolation wards.

A senior police officer said movement of people and vehicles have been restricted in the containment area with checkposts manned by police, health and sanitation officials. Over 20 teams have been roped for door-to-door survey to identify foreign returnees, he added.

Title: Across Goa, frantic scramble for supplies
Content:
People thronged the streets from as early as 6am for essential goods

PANAJI: Chaos ensued in the state on Friday as desperate citizens threw social distancing norms to the winds and thronged provision stores in large numbers to stock up on basic food supplies, a day after chief minister Pramod Sawant announced that grocery shops would be opened following ‘public demand’.

People thronged the streets from as early as 6am to scout for essential goods like rice, milk, pulses, flour, oil and vegetables and mobbed grocers and other vendors, maintaining virtually no distance from each other.

In some places, police tried to enforce distance between customers, while in other places, the regulations were hardly there.

With no clarity on the availability of groceries and the promised home-delivery of goods not forthcoming in most areas, citizens indulged in panic-buying as many of them had exhausted their essential provisions, with the shops having been closed for several days now.

“I do not want to go into the crowded shop, but I ran out of rice two days ago, and atta yesterday and I don’t have a fridge to store cooked food. If the shops close again tomorrow, what will we eat? Yesterday we only ate boiled potatoes,” said Uma Yadav, who works as a domestic help in Taleigao.

In Panaji, mayor Uday Madkaikar on Thursday night announced that the municipal market would remain closed.

Some departmental stores which were open tried to enforce social distancing guidelines, by marking one metre notches so as to maintain space between people waiting in queue. However, in many places people crowded the shops in a scramble to buy food before stocks were wiped out, and police had to act against some persons in Bicholim, Valpoi and in the outskirts of Mapusa. Authorities were forced to close down the Valpoi market after people began crowding it on Friday.

While the Mapusa municipal council and several panchayats have started door delivery of essential groceries, the chairperson of the Valpoi municipal council has promised to follow suit and ensure all residents receive basic supplies.

Meanwhile, support for a petition demanding a total shutdown to prevent crowding in grocery and vegetable shops continues to grow, after three people in the state tested positive for Covid-19.

Title: Mangaluru: Village bans entry of outsiders
Content: MANGALURU: Even as the district administration and police have been a keeping strict vigil on the movement of people in the city to prevent the spread of Covid-19 , residents of a village near Konaje have banned the entry of any outsiders entirely.Residents of Aladka in Harekala have blocked the only road to their village to prevent the entry of people from neighbouring villages. Aladka has nearly 200 houses. When villagers were fed up with the frequent visit of people from other villages, who come to their village by riding two-wheelers and other vehicles, they took a decision to block the only connecting road.A resident said that the number of vehicles and people moving around in Harekala increased recently, after the national lockdown was announced. “Moreover, drug addicts and gamblers may also make our village a safe haven for their illegal activities. To prevent this, we have decided to close down the road,’’ he said. However, they have been allowing vehicles and people who supply essential commodities into the village.

Title: Gurugram youth breaks quarantine, lands in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: The city police has started looking for a youth who had returned from the US but broken his quarantine period after reaching Gurugram. The young man, instead, travelled to Kolkata in a flight after serving merely five days in quarantine instead of the minimum of two weeks. The cops went on an overdrive after a Gurugram resident brought the matter to the notice of Kolkata Police through her tweet.She also tweeted a photograph of the Gurugram Muninicipal Corporation notice put up outside the man’s residence warning others not to visit his residence.According to the post by Gurugram-based Anjali Sharma, a resident of the same tower and the same condo at Sector 56, where the youth had put up, the man had been put on quarantine by Gurugram Corporation between March 16 and April 1. But he reportedly boarded a Kolkata-bound flight on March 21. “His house in our society was marked quarantine on March 23 (ex post facto date March 16). But, the family had already flown to Kolkata on March 21. This is for the necessary information of authorities,” she wrote in her tweet. “We are in touch with relevant authorities in this regard,” said a senior officer of the social media cell of Kolkata Police.

Title: Bhopal: 25 booked for defying curfew
Content:
Representative Image

BHOPAL: Police on Friday registered 25 cases against people violating lockdown order.The accused were booked under section 188, 269 and 270 of IPC.

With this, total 78 cases have been registered against violators since March 22. Most of the cases were registered against people loitering out on city roads without any reason and the shopkeepers, who opened their shops despite restriction.

A car driver, who ventured out without any valid reason was booked by Kamla Nagar police. A case was also registered against the owner of an under construction house in Chhola to continue construction work in lockdown.

Meanwhile, cops distributed masks and other material amongneedy people in their respective jurisdiction areas. TT Nagar police started a mess at the police station to supply food packets to needy and arrange food for the cops, who were not able to go to their homes due to constant tiring duty.

SHO TT Nagar Sanjeev Saxena said that enforcing lockdown is the duty of police for safety of people but at the same time they also thought that many people residing in their jurisdiction area were short of food supply. CSP (Govindpura) Ankit Jaiswal said that he appealed the locals in the area who can donate food items, which will be collected by police and distributed among the needy.

Title: Covid-19: Use of plastic products allowed in events inside secretariat, previous order put on hold
Content: Dehradun: Taking note of the need to maintain personal hygiene in the fight againstCovid-19, the state government has reversed its previous order, which banned the use of plastic products in meeting and workshops inside the secretariat. Till further orders, plastic products such as water bottles can be used in meetings and other events inside the state secretariat. A letter in this regard – written by chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh– was circulated on Friday. The CS told TOI, “Right now the focus is on Covid-19, therefore, approval has been given on use of plastic bottles in secretariat premises.”Earlier, on August 1, 2019, additional chief secretary Radha Raturi had passed directions, through a circular, to all senior officials of the state government that no plastic products should be used in meetings and workshops inside the secretariat.In the letter dated August 1 last year, Raturi wrote, “All are aware of the adverse impact the use of micro plastic has on the environment as well as human health. The use of plastic products is also a stumbling block in the sustainable development programme.”

Title: BMHRC evacuated amid protest by gas-hit, activists
Content:
Bhopal: All gas victims — except two serious patients — were evacuated from the Bhopal Memorial Hospital & Research Centre (BMHRC), on Friday, amid stiff resistance from the gas victims, activist groups and the Supreme Court Monitoring Committee.

The hospital set up at the behest of the Supreme Court with a clear mandate to provide “best possible” treatment to gas disaster survivors was taken over by the state government for treatment of Covid-19 patients on March 24. The order issued by the principal secretary, health, government of MP Pallavi Jain Govil, had led to ‘outrage’ among gas victims and activist groups working for their cause as the hospital is run by the government of India’s department of health & research (DHR) and how well the hospital is serving the gas victims is regularly monitored by a division bench of M P high court on the order of the Supreme Court. The bench headed by the Chief Justice had been insisting on personal appearance of DHR secretary in the previous three hearings of the petition on medical care of gas victims to know what his department had done so far to comply with the apex court order of August 2012 to restore BMHRC in a condition that it serves the gas victims in the best possible manner. His alibi for absence due to Coronivirus threat in the country was also rejected by the judges.

The same hospital being abruptly taken over by the state government for designating it as an isolation centre for Coronavirus patients did not go down well with anyone. Gas victims and activist groups were joined by the Supreme Court Monitoring Committee to protest the evacuation of gas victims from the hospital, but failed.

“I talked to Pallavi Jain Govil twice on Wednesday, she appeared to be considerate She suggested the order can be reviewed if collector Bhopal has no problems. When I talked to the collector, he said there was no problem on his part and he would comply with whatever order he receives from above but the order was not revoked,” said Purnendu Shukla, a member of the monitoring committee.

Meanwhile, 86 patients undergoing treatment at the hospital, including five patients on ventilator have been evacuated. According to hospital sources, only one patient who is on ventilator and another serious patient in ICU are still there, but they are also being asked to go.

Shukla said that he had asked for a record as to where these patients have been shifted but it has not been provided to home till now.

Title: No petrol, diesel for those without masks in Surat
Content: SURAT: If one is not wearing a mask, he or she won’t get petrol or diesel at the petrol pumps in Surat.Petrol pumps across the city have initiated efforts to contain the spread of coronavirus by refusing to serve the customers who come without covered faces.The South Gujarat Petrol Pump Dealers’ Association (SGPPDA) has taken the decision that those customers not wearing masks will not be sold fuel. Also, the vehicle owners will have to maintain social distancing at the petrol pumps.President of SGPPDA, Suresh Desai told TOI, “Petrol pumps comes under essential commodities and we can’t ignore the aspect of cleanliness and hygiene when the city is under the grip of the virus. Thus, all the petrol pumps have unanimously decided not to entertain customers who are not covering their faces.”Desai added, “We have started this mandatory rule since last two days. Even this rule implies to the car owners visiting the petrol pumps. The car owners are asked to sit in their car at the time of refuelling of the vehicle.”According to Desai, the petrol pumps are also keeping utmost care while handling the customers wanting to make payment through cards. The customers are not allowed to hold the point-of-sale swipe machines. The attendant at the pump holds the machine and that the customer must enter the card and PIN.Shailesh Pandya, a resident of Rander said, “In a hurry, I forgot to wear the mask and went to the petrol pump. I was told that he will not refuel my vehicle as I was not wearing a mask. So, I visited the nearby medical store and bought a mask to get my tank refuelled.”Rajesh Patel, owner of a petrol pump in Adajan said, “We even refuse entry to many customers coming without wearing masks or at least covering their faces with handkerchief.”

Title: Bhopal gets third Coronavirus patient; MP count goes up by 7
Content:
Representative Image

INDORE/ BHOPAL: Seven more patients — three in Indore, two in Jabalpur and one each in Bhopal and Ujjain — tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday, taking the state count to 33.

Bhopal got its third Coronavirus patient — a 53-year-old railways employee. He is a train guard and officials are checking his duty logs to see who all he may have come in touch with. He arrived in Bhopal on March 22 and went to the Covid-19 unit at AIIMs the next day. After a second sample tested positive on Friday, he was admitted to AIIMS and his family quarantined as well.

Indore now has 16 Covid-19 cases — nearly half of the state’s count. Jabalpur is next with eight patients, four of whom got it after coming in touch with three members of a family who first tested positive.

In Indore, the new patients are men, aged 60, 42 and 23. They have been admitted to MY Hospital , MRTD Hospital and Arihant Hospital. In Ujjain, a 23-year-old man from Jansapura has tested positive and is admitted to Madhav Nagar Hospital. Ujjain now has three cases, including one of MP’s dead.

The Jabalpur patients are among those who had come in contact with three members of the family that had tested positive on March 20 after returning from Dubai. The city, which is under curfew, now has eight Coronavirus patients.

The last four to test positive in Jabalpur worked on the premises owned by the family that has tested positive. The administration has identified 32 people, who had come in contact with the eight Covid-19 patients in Jabalpur, are kept them under observation.

Two Covid-19 patients have died in the state, one each in Indore and Ujjain.

Title: Police initiates legal action against BJP leader for spreading fake video
Content: Kolkata Police has decided to take legal action against BJP leader Anupam Hazra for what they initially believe to be “a false representation of facts” regarding lockdown in the city. Hazra had allegedly tweeted a video which showed cops being manhandled by a few citizens, claiming it was recorded in Kidderpore. However, Twitter handler Wasim Akram stated that the claim was false and alleged that the video was shot in Mumbai. Akram later tweeted the video and tagged Kolkata Police. The cops, in turn, tagged Hazra and announced that legal action had been initiated against him. “The complaint is being enquired into & legal action initiated…,” it read. Hazra later deleted his tweet. The BJP leader, however, said he had done nothing wrong. “I have heard they are lodging an FIR against me. It is true that there was some confusion as I had received this video as a WhatsApp forward. But what I tweeted stated that it was from a minority-dominated area. I did not specifically mention any place contrary to what is being alleged. I have also posted about the good work of cops and how certain cops faced problems while ensuring the lockdown. Yet, none of that was considered. Is it because of my political views that I am being singled out?” he asked. tnn

Title: Search on to identify contacts of cop & his son who tested +ve
Content:
Vijayawada: The AP and Telangana administration have launched a search for persons who met a senior Telangana police officer and his son who have both tested positive for Covid-19 during a housewarming ceremony at Raghavapuram in West Godavari on March 20.

The father and son, who returned from London in mid-March, had visited Khammam and Kothagudem in Telangana and West Godavari in AP.

Both the father and son tested positive for Covid-19. The son was shifted to Hyderabad and the cop to MGM in Warangal. The cop’s housemaid, too, tested positive, the reports suggested.

Later, the officials found that the youth had also visited Raghavapuram for a housewarming ceremony. As the youth lives in London, the relatives met him at the function and even shook hands with him. The officials are now looking for those who met the youth at the function. The housewarming ceremony was attended by several people from Chinthalapudi mandal and Vemsuru in Telangana, located near the border of the two Telugu states.

Village volunteers in Raghavapuram sent the names of those who met the cop’s son to higher officials. Villagers in Raghavapuram and the neighbouring area are jittery fearing Covid-19 outbreak as some of them had attended the housewarming ceremony. The father and son travelled to Raghavapuram through Vemsuru, Kandukur and Duddepudi villages and interacted with some relatives. It is said that officials have identified about 18 persons who met the duo during their travel.

Title: Covid-19: Special flight to take Germans home
