Content: MYSURU: A special flight carrying German nationals, including 16 tourists in Mysuru , will depart the Kempegowda International Airport in Bengaluru on Saturday for their home country. Due to increasing Covid-19 cases in India, the German embassy had asked Karnataka, Tamil Nadu Kerala , Andhra Pradesh and Telangana to make arrangements to send the stranded Germans back.Accordingly, the authorities in Mysuru arranged the Germans’ travel to Bengaluru on Friday after the tourists underwent medical test at a temporary camp at Kalamandira. After confirming their fitness, they were taken to the German consulate in Bengaluru in a non-air conditioned luxury bus which had a paper with Covid-19 written on it pasted to its windshield.Tourism department deputy director H P Janardhan said, “We had got the list of 18 Germans who had come to Mysuru. Among them, two had already returned to their country. We are sending the 16 Germans to Bengaluru from where they will be sent to their country in a special flight,” he said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: CM Shivraj Singh directs for a separate team to monitor Indore situation
Content:
Shivraj Singh Chouhan, CM Madhya Pradesh

BHOPAL: Alarmed by the sudden spurt in number of Covid-19 positive cases in Indore, chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan on Friday directed for constituting a separate team of senior officials to monitor and tackle with the situation.

Chouhan directed the officials to ensure proper supply of personal protection equipment (PPE) kits and other necessary medical equipment to the health staff and people in the state.

“Necessary steps should be taken in Indore and a team of senior officials be formed to control the situation. The government will help migrant workers and poor sections of the society who have gone to other places for work, and now want to return to their homes. We have nominated an officer in each district to address the issue," said Chouhan during the review meeting on Covid-19, here on Friday.

The government has provided over three lakh three-ply masks in the districts. Apart from this, efforts were also being made to increase the number of ventilators in the state.

Chouhan held discussions with representatives of social and political organisations through video conferencing in all district and emphasised upon social distancing and isolation. He said corona control is the top priority of the government.

"Supply of essential commodities like food will be ensured for all poor families. There is no restriction on vehicles carrying food items, medicines and other essential goods. Also, no restriction has been imposed on opening of drugs and grocery stores," the chief minister said.

Directing strict enforcement of lockdown, Chouhan warned strict action against the black-marketing and hoarding and instructed the district authorities to ensure supply of essentials to those in need through PDS. He instructed officials to keep a strict vigil on the state borders to check any unauthorised entry in the state.

The government has also announced a new WhatsApp number to help residents of MP stranded in other states during lockdown. There were about 11,000 calls for assistance on the number on Friday.

Title: Shirdi temple to donate Rs 51 crore to CM relief fund
Content:
File photo of Uddhav Thackarey

NASHIK: Shri Saibaba Sansthan Trust, Shirdi has decided to donate Rs 51 crore to the Chief Minister Relief Fund to combat the Covid-19 outbreak in the state.

Arun Dongre, chief executive officer (CEO) of the trust said that the trust has decided to contribute to the state government fund to help them fight the outbreak.

“The state is taking all necessary measures to keep a check on the rising positive cases. The government would need financial resources to tackle the disease,” Dongre told TOI.

The CEO also said that the trust management decided on Friday to immediately hand over the amount to the government. “In this time of crisis, we stand with the government to combat the current situation,” Dongre added.

Subsequently, Sai Prasadalaya of Shri Saibaba Sansthan Trust has started providing free-food to all the officials, patients, relatives stationed at their two hospitals. They will also be extending their services to the residents of the orphanage, staff at the hearing and speech impaired school, old age home and temple staff.

The free-food facility would also be extended to the homeless at Shirdi bus station.

The trust has also made arrangements of 3000 food packets for the police officials deployed in the area and delivered them to the police headquarters.

The temple trust has earlier donated Rs five crore during Kerala floods, Rs 12 crore during state floods and Rs 2.51 crore to the families of the soldiers, who lost their lives during the Pulwama terror attack.

Title: 2 temporary shelters for homeless people
Content:
Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has opened two temporary shelters on Friday to accomodate homeless people during the lockdown. VMC officials said that this will help contain the spread of Covid-19.

VMC officials have already shifted these people to shelters and provided them with food, water and blankets. The VMC estate officer has been charged with providing food in these centres.

Concerned sanitation inspectors will deploy sanitary workers to clean the premises. Special officers will ensure that inmates maintain distance. tnn

Title: Priyanka Chopra opens up about starting a family with her hubby Nick Jonas; read details
Content:
SUBSCRIBE NOW

to get the latest news, gossip on your favourite stars & oven-fresh movie reviews from top reviewers right in your inbox.

Title: 10 Telugu students stranded in Agra desperate to return
Content:
The students lack access to food

HYDERABAD: Ten Telugu students , who went to pay their college fee in Agra, are stranded there following the lockdown in the aftermath of the coronavirus scare. The students are desperate to come back.

They also complained they are not being allowed to come out of their rented flat, but UP police finally got them food on Friday.

Speaking to TOI over phone, Shiva Reddy of Karimnagar said ten of them were stuck in a single flat in Kalindi Vihar without access to food. “Whatever little food available outside is exorbitantly priced,” he said.

All of them are students of RB PG College and are in various stages of completing BSc (Agriculture). “We came here about a month ago to pay our fee after the exams got over, but have not been able to leave the city since then,” said the 20-year-old Reddy.

The students are also facing language issues. The students, who are fluent in Telugu, are ill at ease in the Hindi heartland, unable to express what they need. Mami Sekhar, a native of East Godavari in Andhra Pradesh, said language was an issue for them. Sekhar is in his degree third year.

Nagaraju of Warangal said they booked the train tickets for March 24, which got cancelled. “Some of our friends were lucky enough to travel out on March 17, but we were not able to get tickets.” Sounding desperate, Nagaraju said: “All we want is to head back home.”

Title: Gangaur festival witnesses low-key celebrations
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: In wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, the Rajasthani community in the city celebrated the Gangaur festival in a low-key manner.

The 16-day long celebrations concluded on Friday, which started on the Holi celebration day on March 10.

However, this year people remained indoors and performed the customary rituals. The women celebrated the festival with traditional fervour and gaiety by staying indoors.

Rajani Jategaonkar , a member of Maheshwari Mahila Mandal , said that every year the community celebrates the festival in a grand manner. “We take out processions and perform various rituals at Mahalaxmi temple. But this year, due to the lockdown we performed the rituals at home,” she said.

The custom followed on the last day of Gangaur festival includes the sowing of a wheat plant in the house, which marks the onset of the harvesting period in Rajasthan . “The plant is vital for the festival as wheat is our staple food. We also make a sweet dish of wheat flour and jaggery for unmarried and newly married girls. Unfortunately, we could not gather the womenfolk in our houses today,” added Jategaonkar.

Title: Docs team up to offer free online consultation
Content:
Bhopal: At a time, when the world is standing together in the fight against coronavirus, a few doctors of the state capital are walking the extra mile to help those in need.

In addition to their regular duties, they have set up an online group which provides medical advice free-of-cost. As many as 35 health professionals, including surgeons, dentists, orthopaedics, eye specialists, among others have come together to form this group and is reaching out to people through social media.

Their post on social media reads, “Online Medical help during lockdown. Currently, we have a pool of 35+ medical professionals who are ready to provide online help. We have cardiologist, dermatologist, ophthalmologist, pathologist, paediatrician, general medicine, internal medicine, neuro and dentist. In case anyone need medical help, please connect.”

The collective has also asked other medical professionals to join them. “If you are a medical professional and ready to serve the society in this critical time by providing online help, please register using link.” Rajneesh Rai who works for BHEL posted on Facebook.

With most local clinics shut and government hospitals engaged in tackling the corona situation, the group is receiving a lot of queries.

Two days ago, Juhi Malviya, an SBI employee was having trouble in her eyes, but could not find a doctor nearby. “It was a very bad situation for me, I had to seek medical help. While checking online, I came across this pool of health professional who are providing medical consultation. I contacted eye specialist Dr Vaishali Rai and she responded immediately. She treated me and also prescribed some medicines,” said Juhi, a resident of Ayodhya Nagar.

Speaking to TOI, Dr Vaishali said, “As a doctor, I have a responsibility towards the society, specially in such a crucial time. Social media is the best way to help even those who are kilometres away from us.”

Earlier this week, Katara Hills resident Amol Shrivastava had developed rashes on his body, but did not want to break the curfew. “I was told about this pool of medical professionals and got the number of dermatologist Dr Manish Rathore. Not only did he treat me but followed up on my condition for the next two days. I only had to go outside to buy medicines,” said Amol, an entrepreneur.

Dr Rathore said, “Like media, police and others who are helping the society, we are also doing our bit. This is the time when all of us have to help all who need us.”

Title: Labourers in Navi Mumbai start long trudge to Karnataka villages
Content:
Labourers on their way to Karnataka from Navi Mumbai on Friday

NAVI MUMBAI: Following stoppage of work due to the Covid-19 lockdown, several daily wage labourers from the construction sector hit the deserted Sion-Panvel Highway on Friday. Trudging under a hot sun, they were headed for their villages in Karnataka at least 500km away.

Walking past the Vashi toll plaza, 40-year-old Malshetty Chavan told TOI: “We are a group of over 15 workers with families. We have been walking for over five hours from Bandra in Mumbai, where we used to work.”

Chavan said, “We have run out of money. We used to earn around Rs 250 per head daily at building construction sites. Since there will be a lockdown for three weeks, we have no option but to walk it to Karnataka. Otherwise what will we eat here?”

When told that the police is not allowing anyone to cross the state borders due to the lockdown, another migrant worker said: “There’s no one here to even give us one square meal. Our construction supervisor is also unreachable on his phone. Hence, we are walking.”

Several women were seen walking alongside, their heads covered with towels or sarees to protect themselves from the sun. All kept looking around constantly to see if they could source food or water from someone.

City-based activists said it is likely that more and more daily wage workers will hit the highways on foot, if the state government does not organize camps to provide them with essentials during the lockdown period.

“The government has announced schemes to give free food to the poor in the country during the lockdown. However, most of the food parcels will be distributed to registered labourers and workers. The daily wage migrant workers, who are mostly unregistered and exploited for cheap labour, will sadly not get any free food. Hence, there is a gap between what the government thinks and intends to do, and what really is transpiring on ground zero,” said city-based RTI activist Anarjit Chauhan.

Title: ‘Locked’ in, Divar residents struggle
Content:
The island, home to 8,000 people, got fresh supplies only on Friday

PANAJI: The island of Divar, whose sole connection to the mainland is by way of a ferry, faces its own piquant situation. Since the nationwide lockdown, its residents have been facing a severe supply crisis with their grocery stores cleaned out and life-saving drugs running out.

According to the island’s two panchayats, fresh grocery supplies arrived only on Friday and by Saturday a home-delivery system will be put in place.

The island is home to 8,000 people and ever since the lockdown the ferry plies once every two hours and suppliers who miss the ferry turn back.

“There is a problem in getting supplies because the ferry is after every two hours. I sent some of our boys to get stock from Uccasaim, but police beat them. The Naroa ferry is completely stopped. Our home has some stock of fish and rice, but for the last three days we have been having black tea, which many of the elderly don’t like,” said Sr Monica Rodrigues, who runs the Lar Santa Margarida (home for the senior citizen) in Piedade.

Though the chief minister allowed grocery stores to remain open, most remained closed on the island. While there is a pharmacy, some of the more critical medicines are available only with bigger chemists in Panaji.

“Just three days earlier, some people were struggling for medicines. People have to cross over to Old Goa and Panaji to get certain medicines. Some have medicines for just 10-15 days,” Jerry D’Souza, a prominent resident on the island, said.

Sarpanch of Sao Matias, Mohan Volvoikar said that of the six to eight shops on the island, two agreed to seek permission from the deputy collector and on Friday received stock. “Vegetables are not there, but by Sunday or Monday, the horticulture department will supply vegetables,” he said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh breathes easy as air pollution levels go down
Content:
BHOPAL: Barely a week into the nationwide lockdown — with little vehicular movement — pollution levels have dipped in major cities of the state, said officials on Friday.

Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) data shows Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior, Ujjain improved in just a week’s time, with Jabalpur being the only exception. Construction activities, which have come to a halt also helped.

Data says that air quality of Bhopal on March 20 was ‘moderate’; it turned into ‘good’ on Friday. In Indore, the air quality was ‘moderate’, which turned into ‘satisfactory’ on Friday. Air quality of Gwalior was ‘satisfactory’ on March 20, which moved to ‘good’ on Friday. In Ujjain too, the air quality has changed to ‘good’ from ‘moderate’ for the past one week. Surprisingly, air quality remained ‘satisfactory’ from March 20 till this report was filed on Friday.

Air quality is measured taking into account the levels of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxide (Nox), RSPM10 and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). While vehicle emissions lead to rise in SO2, increase in nitrogen oxide is due to human activity. PM-10 is caused by dust and construction, including building of roads. PM2.5 levels are sensitive to dust, human activity and climatic conditions. Of the four, officials said, PM2.5 is the most harmful as it causes severe lung diseases.

Title: Nashik: Blood donation camps resume
Content:
NASHIK: City-based NGOs have started organising blood donation camps in the city after the state government’s appeal to restart such camps as the blood banks may not have enough supply following the lockdown.

Jankalyan Rakthpedhi has started such camps for a week and has appealed to citizens to donate blood so that the city hospitals do not run out of it during emergencies.

Vinay Shouche, administrative officer of Jankalyan Raktpedhi , said, “Every year there is a shortage of blood in the blood banks during summer. This year, we cannot conduct many camps due to lockdown.”

According to him, due to the lockdown, the number of accidents has decreased and thus the demand for blood has also reduced.

A corporator of the Nashik Municipal Corporation , Varsha Bhalerao, donated blood on Thursday at the camp organised by Jankalyan Rakthpedhi.

Nearly 63 people have donated blood in the last two days at Jankalyan Raktpedhi, she added.

Rotary Club also organised a blood camp on Thursday at Ashwini Shraman Sector.

“We had come to know from Arpan Blood Bank that they are falling short of their supply. We arranged a van near the Ganesh temple and informed our contacts from the vicinity of 400m. We asked only two people at a time to come ,” said Jayant Pawar, member of an NGO.

Rajendra Lodha, president of Navkar Group (NGO), CIDCO has sought permission from the police authorities to organise a blood donation camp.

Title: Covid-19 stalls Rs 17,000 crore road projects in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has stopped all ongoing road projects worth more than Rs 17,000 crore in the state following the complete lockdown of the country to fight Covid-19 outbreak.

NHAI officials said 22 road projects under the Centre’s Bharatmala scheme to develop 1,076 km national highways at a cost of Rs 17,800 crore were at various stages of implementation in Tamil Nadu.

“After completing land acquisition and clearing the legal hurdles, a few of the projects had gathered momentum a couple of months ago. Now, the lockdown has pulled us back. It can even lead to fresh legal disputes, cost escalation and inordinate delay in completion of the projects,” said a senior official in NHAI.

Eight projects, covering 558 km of roads, were being implemented in Chennai Region. They include Rs 1,250 crore project to six-lane the 148 km stretch of NH 46 from Krishnagiri to Walaja, Rs 1,020 crore project to four-lane Trichy-Kallagam section of NH 227 and Rs 1,071 crore project between Kallagam and Meensuriti on NH 227. These projects are being implemented in Kancheepuram, Villupuram, Krishnagiri and Chennai districts.

In Madurai region 14 ongoing projects were put on hold. The total cost of the projects was Rs 11,416 crore. They include improvement of 517 km of roads on NH 45 C, 45 E, 47, 67, 209, 785 and 785 E. Six of them are worth Rs 1,000 crore each. The projects were being implemented in Thanjavur, Nagarcoil, Madurai and Dindigul districts.

Title: Docs, staff who checked Covid-19 patient without protection kit quarantined
Content: Dehradun: The state health department on Friday quarantined doctors and medical staff , who checked the recently-diagnosed coronavirus- positive patient from Kotdwar, as they were not wearing any protection kits.Talking to TOI, a senior official from the office of director general (DG) health, confirmed that three doctors, four staff nurses and two ward boys from Base Hospital in Kotdwar were quarantined after they checked the 26-year-old patient, who had returned from Spain and was admitted to the general isolation ward.“As the patient wasn’t showing any symptoms of coronavirus and was admitted here only because of travel history, the doctors neglected the personal protection kits. After he was diagnosed as a positive case, the people who came in his contact were quarantined,” said the official.

Title: 9 firms get nod to make hand sanitiser
Content: Panaji: The directorate of food and drugs administration ( FDA ) has granted permission, on fast-track basis, to nine parties for manufacture of hand sanitisers. Six are distillers and three are pharmaceutical firms . It had granted two approvals for the purpose earlier. tnn

Title: Isolation rooms ready at city hotels, but no boarders yet
Content:
Kolkata: Hoteliers who offered rooms for isolation to the health department are gearing up to operate the facility, but they are yet to get any boarder. Till Thursday evening, nobody had checked into isolation at any of the hotels. T S Walia, former national president of Federation of Hotels and Restaurants Association of India (FHRAI) said the association was hoping that in next 24 hours people would start arriving.

“In most of the hotels there is no boarder. A skeletal staff has been kept to serve those who will stay in isolation, but they want to go home too. It will be better if people start coming to these facilities soon,” he added.

Hotel and Restaurant Association of Eastern India (HRAEI) has offered 645 rooms in 32 hotels and guest houses for this facility. Walia added that the state had asked for another 200 rooms for isolation. “We are looking for more rooms, but the problem is that the state wants this in bulk. Ideally, we need 200 rooms at a few places. This is a little difficult. If required, we may request the health department to talk directly to some hotel owners,” he added.

Incidentally, in a circular on Wednesday evening, the government has included establishments used or earmarked for quarantine facilities on the essential list. It may be noted that the Ambuja Neotia Group, too, has offered 30 suites in The Ffort Raichak resort to the government for an isolation facility.

The Bengal government had sought help from hoteliers to arrange rooms for isolation last Sunday. The health and tourism departments had asked HRAEI to request their members to assign rooms for this purpose.

HRAEI secretary Sudesh Poddar pointed out that all association members who have agreed to assign rooms are ready to offer this facility on a cost-to-cost basis. “The charges will be Rs 3,000-Rs 5,000, depending on categories (three-four star or five-star), which would include breakfast, lunch and dinner,” he added. Poddar said that at present, there are 2,500-2,600 rooms in the five-star and five-star deluxe categories in the city while there are 2,000+ rooms in the three-four star categories. Besides, there are 15,000 rooms in non-star category hotels in the city and surrounding areas.

Title: In a first for city, mosques cancel Friday prayers
Content:
Cops on vigil near Taj-ul-Masajid in Old Bhopal on Friday

Bhopal: Despite being a Friday, most mosques in the state capital remained shut and no mass Friday namaz was held.

Bhopal Shahar Qazi Syed Mustaq Ali Nadvi in a notice had urged Muslims to offer namaz at homes and refrain from congregating in large numbers.

Taj-ul-Masjid, among Asia’s largest mosque, was closed with a notice by the qazi pasted on the entrance. The notice by Shahar Qazi said, “There will be no Friday prayers at Taj-ul-Masajid. Namaz will resume only after further directives.”

Abdul Arif Qureshi, a resident of Karond area told TOI, this is the first time that mosques are closed. “It is a good move in the present circumstances,” he said.

There were no mass prayers at Soofiya Masjid at Koh-e-Fiza and other mosques as well.

Talking to TOI, Abul Hasan, a resident of Koh-e-Fiza said, “This is the first time that Friday namaz was offered by people at home. Even during the Bhopal Gas Disaster, Friday prayers was not disrupted in the city. This is an extraordinary situation that none of us has thought about. The need of the hour is to help ourselves by following government orders and staying at home.”

Earlier on Thursday, an offence was registered against a cleric and 27 others, for allegedly defying the coronavirus lockdown, by offering prayers at a mosque in Islampura locality of the city, police said on Friday.

Title: Surat: Safai worker defeats fear for swachhata
Content: SURAT: Anil Rathod ’s five-year-old daughter Pooja wakes up as soon as he prepares to leave home at 6am every day. “Pappa tame bimar thay jaso, bahar na niklo’ (Dad you will fall ill, please don’t go outside),” she pleads with him.But Rathod, a safai worker with Bhesan village panchayat, gives her a reconciling smile and promises to return home safely by afternoon.Amid the lockdown and the coronavirus scare, this 34-year-old moves out with his tractor to collect garbage from the residential apartments falling under the panchayat’s jurisdiction in Jehangirpura.Wearing gumboots, covering his hands with gloves and a handkerchief tied on his face, Rathod is on the duty to load his vehicle with the garbage collected from 15 housing societies and dump it at the collection facility of the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) at Adajan.“They say some dangerous disease has spread in the city. I don’t know much about it, but I was informed by my superior to wear gumboots, gloves and handkerchief” says Rathod, while emptying the garbage drums kept outside Vaishnaodevi Apartment in Jehangirpura.“I have been doing this job for the last six years and I am alright. If I would stay home fearing the disease, my family will die of hunger,” he told TOI.Few days ago, Rathod’s colleague took ill and was told by the panchayat officials to not stay at home. “I have to drive the tractor, collect the garbage and drop it at the collection centre in Adajan all alone. My co-worker who used to collect the garbage is ill. Clearing garbage from the housing societies is very important during this period, which I know very well” says Rathod, who earns a paltry Rs 8,000 per month.He is quick to mention that the attitude of the people in the residential societies has changed after the spread of COVID-19. The residents are offering him with tea and some are also feeding him snacks, water and giving clothes.“Earlier, nobody used to care, but now people have become compassionate. They have changed a lot after the disease spread in the city,” he said..“Two days ago, a woman approached me while I was emptying the garbage drums in my tractor. She enquired about my children and their age and asked me to wait for her. After 15 minutes, she came back clothes for my children,” said Anil.When asked if he is worried on handling the garbage when the virus is spreading fast, Rathod said, “I know the consequences would be dangerous, but I have faith in god. If I don’t lift the garbage, it will harm the health of several thousand people.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Animals roam free on Ooty streets
Content: UDHAGAMANDALAM: The empty roads seem to have lured wild animals, which have started roaming freely around human habitats in the hill retreat. Residents of Drummulla in Coonoor taluk said they had spotted sloth bears and a black panther in their locality in the past couple of days. As the reserve forest is located close to their area, they said chances of leopards straying into their area were also very high.A resident said, “Last evening, we saw a pair of sloth bears roaming in our area. As the roads are almost deserted, wild animals have started coming out of forest area. The reserve forest close to our area is known for leopard population. We have had incidences of leopards straying into our locality in the past.”The situation isn’t any different in areas such as Garanji, Mel-Garanji and Bandhishola, which all fall on a single stretch.Shivakumar, a resident of Garanji, said, “There has been hardly any traffic on roads ever since tourist spots such as Lamb’s Rock and Dolphin’s Nose were closed for public 10 days ago. The silent atmosphere invites wild animals from the nearby forest.”He said a black panther had passed through their area two days ago. “In the absence of tourists, wild animals are freely roaming around the hill retreat.” Sloth bear movement has, meanwhile, become common in Drummulla and surrounding areas.

Title: 5,000 infrared thermometers arrive in city for nCoV check
Content:
Kolkata: A SpiceXpress freighter on Thursday morning landed in Kolkata with a consignment of 5,000 infrared thermometers that are key to early detection of Covid-19 cases in the absence of adequate diagnostic kits. The shipment that arrived from Hong Kong was swiftly cleared by Customs. The devices are expected to be distributed across various facilities in the city, including hospitals and fever clinics, as well as health facilities in the districts.

The need to check temperature using infrared thermometers has become vital as conventional mercury thermometers cannot be used for fear of contamination. The infrared thermometer does not require body contact since it checks temperature by sensing the infrared energy radiated by the body. The gadget also reads the temperature in a fraction of the time required by mercury thermometers, thereby enabling mass checks in facilities like hospitals, airports, offices, malls and hotels.

With demand for infrared thermometers shooting up worldwide, it has been difficult to procure the instruments. And with all commercial passenger flights banned in India till at least April 15, the consignment for Bengal had to be brought on a freighter operated by SpiceJet.

The Boeing 737 SpiceXpress aircraft is the only one that is touching down at Kolkata airport every day. Blue Dart, which also operated every day, cancelled its Kolkata-Dhaka shipment. There is uncertainty if Qatar and Cathay Pacific will each continue to operate two freighter services to Kolkata every week. Qatar last operated a freighter on Monday. Cathay is yet to operate one after the lockdown. Alliance Air is expected to operate a chartered fight.

Sources said domestic carriers are planning to convert their passenger planes to cargo during the lockdown.

Title: Police help dialysis patient’s mom to get blood
Content:
Representative image.

KOLKATA: The Beliaghata police helped a woman, who came to the city from Baduria in North 24 Parganas on Friday, in search of blood for her daughter’s dialysis at the ID Hospital in Beliaghata — the nodal hospital for Covid-19 patients.

Around 12:45pm, Reba Rani Kundu (55) came to Beliaghata police station, asking for transport to Manicktala Blood Bank as her daughter, Tapati (32), was admitted in the hospital since March 16. She was undergoing dialysis as both her kidneys got damaged.

Cops arranged a truck for her to reach the blood bank. She collected two units of blood and returned to the ID Hospital, said Ajoy Prasad, DC (ESD).

Title: Archdiocese finds Biblical similarity in 21-day lockdown
Content:
Kolkata: At the special prayer at the Archbishop House late on Wednesday evening, the decision of PM Modi to lock down the country in a bid to fight coronavirus was compared with the Biblical reference of Prophet Daniel. This was part of the Adoration and recitation of the Rosary by vicar general Dominic Gomes on Wednesday — at the Feast of Annunciation.

“In the PM’s 21 days of lockdown , we see a Biblical similarity to the book of Daniel, chapter 9:15 where Prophet Daniel closes the door outside and, in obedience behind the locked door, he prays and fasts for 21 days, doing God’s will and saves his people,” the vicar said. He called out to the followers of the archdiocese to similarly spend time in prayers, because at the end of the lockdown, once again life will beckon. “As we worship, He will heal us from Covid-19,” the Adoration prayer read.

During the recitation of the Rosary, a five-step prayer, the traditional words from the Bible were suffixed with references to coronavirus to pray for healing.

Just like the previous Sunday, this week too, Archbishop Thomas D Souza has decided to read online mass that will be broadcast on social media for all parishioners to see and participate in. Churches are shut for prayers at the moment and in this month of Lent, this initiative had made sure parishioners are not missing their Sunday service.

Title: Procurement of milk sees 40 per cent drop
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Milk procurement from the grassroots levels — villages — has been affected due to fear of spread of coronavirus. Milk procurement personnel of the government-managed Vijaya Dairy have been stopped by villagers in several gram panchayats following which procurement has come down.

Milk procurement by Vijaya Dairy has fell down from five lakh litres per day two years ago to less than three lakh litres per day. “There has been a 40% decrease in milk procurement by Telangana State Dairy Development Cooperative Federation (TSDDCF) which sells packaged milk and milk products under Vijaya brand name in the last few months,” officials said.

As per the orders issued by the government, milk procurement is among the essential commodities and vehicles or personnel collecting milk should not be stopped even in the lockdown period.

Title: Mumbai: Essential services pass clears way for supplies, but no shop open 24/7
Content:
A biker on way to a grocer wears a placard to ensure police don’t beat him

MUMBAI: The supply of vegetables and other essentials to the city improved marginally on Friday, thanks to the distribution of the Essential Services Pass to deliverymen, shop workers and transporters. The pilot exercise has worked in certain locations like APMC Vashi and Andheri East.

Meanwhile, chief minister Uddhav Thackeray said the state had taken a “courageous decision” to allow essential shops to be open 24 hours in the time of the lockdown. “There is no reason for the public to crowd shops and markets. Essential supplies will be smooth now,” he said.

Indeed, the movement of vehicles carrying vegetables, fruit and foodgrains to and from APMC Vashi smoothened after the RTO and APMC administration issued passes and vehicle stickers to transporters. In all 765 trucks loaded with onion-potato, vegetables, fruit, grains and spices arrived in the five market yards. “The market is limping back to normal. Supplies will increase on Saturday,” said APMC deputy secretary Krishnakant Pawar. The relief percolated to markets in Mumbai. More varieties of vegetables were available and prices cooled by Rs 20 per kg.

The pass also helped small retail outlets and vendors who could ply their trade without facing police ire. Virutheeswaran Nadar, who runs Egg Centre at Sion-Koliwada locality in GTB Nagar, applauded new passes.

E-commerce companies are facing jurisdictional issues in Mumbai as all their warehouses are in Bhiwandi. So, these companies have to deal with both Mumbai and Thane authorities to get clarity on passes for delivery.

Meanwhile, despite the state's attempt, no shops were open 24/7. Medical stores worked to schedule, and shops in Borivli shut at the usual hour.

In coming days, though, milk supplies from Kolhapur and Pune may become erratic as labour, fodder and transportation have trickled to a minimum. Buffalo shed owners in Mumbai say they are not getting fodder.

LPG outlets in Thane and one along Ambekar Marg, Parel, saw long lines as deliverymen were scarce. Elsewhere in Mumbai, gas deliverymen were seen on their tricycles. A Bandra man got his refill in 12 hours of booking. Officials of BPCL and HPCL said there was no shortage of cylinders. Both issued directives to dealers to look into grievances.

In Tardeo, vegetable vendors visited large societies. Vasai-Virar civic body has said at ration shops, yellow card holders will get 12kg rice at Rs 3 a kg, 10 kg wheat at Rs 2 a kg and 14 kg sugar at Rs 20 a kg.

Dadar wholesale vegetable market to be partly shut

In a bid to to curb overcrowding, Mumbai police along with the BMC has decided to partially shut the Dadar vegetable wholesale market on Senapati Bapat Marg. Instead, wholesale vendors entering the city will be stopped at various locations in eastern and western suburbs and retailers will be asked to pick up what require from them. The initiative is most likely to take off on March 29. Kiran Dighavkar, assistant municipal commissioner of G-North Ward, said, “We tried markings to ensure social distancing from vendors but thousands land up.”

(With Madhav Chanchani)

Title: Rane launches 24x7 medical aid app
Content: Best eReaders For Kids: For Your Keen Little Reader At Home

Title: Cops help out woman, kids with medical emergencies
Content:
Kolkata: The city police — that set an example on Wednesday by helping senior citizens during the lockdown — came to the aid of a woman whose car broke down while she was in labour and on her way to a hospital in Tangra. Cops also helped an eight-year-old suffering from thalassaemia to reach Shisu Sadan from the Jinjira Bazar area. In Baguiati, Bidhannagar City Police arranged an ambulance for a couple after their daughter developed a respiratory ailment.

“Around 12.15am on Thursday, Itisha Das from South Tangra Road went into labour. While she was being taken to RG Kar Medical College and Hospital, the vehicle broke down near the GK Road-Christopher Road crossing. They tried to hire another vehicle, but there was none due to the lockdown. The constable at a kiosk nearby alerted the Tangra OC, who sent sub-inspector S C Kotal and a woman cop to the spot. They drove the woman and her family to RG Kar in a truck owned by Tangra police station. She was declared safe by doctors,” said DC (eastern suburban) Ajoy Prasad.

At Jinjira Bazar, an eight-year-old child with thalassaemia got stuck on the road as time ran out for his transfusion. The southwest traffic guard OC, Prasenjit Chatterjee, helped arrange an ambulance and provided a pilot car so that the family could reach a hospital in Bhowanipore at the earliest. The cops also prepared a list of blood donors in case there was a shortage.

During patrol, a Baguiati police team met a couple ,Tapas and Jhuma Das, and their daughter who was suffering from respiratory trouble. “Cops thought of calling an ambulance, but when the couple said they couldn’t afford one, the cops took them to BC Roy Sishu Mangal Hospital,” said an officer.

Title: Waterman who goes the extra mile to quench city’s thirst
Content:
Rajkumar Yadav has been maintaining water supply during lockdown

JAIPUR: In his 27 years of service, 50-year-old Rajkumar Yadav never thought that it will be his job which will one day make him proud.

Today, Yadav’s heart swells with pride when even those unknown to him walk upto him and appreciate his role in maintaining regular water supply in these testing times. “I have been doing this for almost three decades. Its only now people are looking at my service in a different light and appreciate it very much,” said Yadav.

The Panipech Pump House where Yadav is posted had a work strength of 40, which has been brought down to 12. In the supply department, four of the 8 employees report in shifts to work.

“Those who live far away have been allowed to stay at home. Why the unnecessary risks?” he says. Yadav has been reporting for duty, which involves distribution of water every day since the coronavirus outbreak. He starts at 6 am till 2 pm after which another person takes over.

Everyday, he has to keep a watch on the Bisalpur water supply in the city. Quantity of chlorine has to be monitored and supply has to be on time. Yadav explains, “We are working in shifts. We have to be vigilant in these times as the load has increased. People are staying indoors so water usage has risen. Tubewells that were not unused have started functioning to supply more water. We have increased 15 minutes timing in all the areas for handwash and sanitising.”

He describes his work as a service to the nation. “This job has given me everything. Potential to feed my family, educate my sons and independence. Now, when the times are bad, it is our duty to serve the people. This is also a service to the nation,” said Yadav, who is dressed in a suit, headgear and mask. He wears these to work every day and makes it a point to disinfect them at home everyday using a home-made alcohol-based sanitizer.

“Precautions are necessary as I live in a joint family which includes my elderly parents. My son is a pharmacist and has to go to the shop, too. Both of us take precautions and are particular about following the guidelines of frequent handwashes, use of sanitisers and minimum physical contact with others,” he says.

This is the first time in his life he has seen such crisis in the country. Yadav appealed to people to stay at home and contribute to the nation. Thousands like me are working day and night to make it these difficult times easier. If people are not following the rules than our sacrifice is waste, ” he signed off.

Title: These TN workers trudged 80km from Karnataka
Content:
Krishnagiri: Stranded in Karnataka without any work and earnings to run their families due to national lockdown, at least 136 Tamils returned to their native villages in Tiruvannamalai district on Friday. The journey back home was nothing but a harrowing tale for all of them.

Working in different parts of Karnataka, they first managed to reach Majestic bus station in Bengaluru city in trucks. From there, they started walking home at 2am on Friday.

They reached Hosur, which is nearly 40km away, at 8am and officials at the check post could do little to stop them. They walked for another 40km, but this time the Krishnagiri police stopped them near the office of district superintendent of police. Most of the workers were denied payments by their employers, going against Centre’s orders.

M Samikannu, of Cheyyar in Tiruvannamalai district, said he was working in a factory at Tumkur in Karnataka. “The factory downed its shutters on Tuesday night and the owner asked us not to come for work until the coronavirus issue was sorted out.” A daily wager, he used to earn Rs 300 a day with which he used to run the family. He decided to return home as there was no other way to earn bread and butter for his family during the lockdown period. When he reached Tumkur bus stand with his wife and two children on Wednesday, the area was deserted and there was no public transport available. Left with no other option, he waited there and managed to get into a truck laden with vegetables that was heading to Bengaluru city on Thursday evening.

“The truck driver demanded Rs 500 per head. I paid him the money as we were desperate to reach home after such a tiring wait at the bus stand,” Samikannu said. He shelled out Rs 2,000 to reach Bengaluru city, which is 75km away from Tumkur.

From Bengaluru, he joined other Tamils from his district and started walking to their native early on Friday as there was no other way out.

T Kishore Kumar, another member of the team, said he was working in a coffee estate in Coorg. A native of Gingee in Tiruvannamalai district, he was also accompanied by his family members.

The group reached Krishnagiri town on Friday morning. Police officials stopped them and contacted collector S Prabhakar after the team members recounted their harrowing tale. The collector subsequently directed transport department officials to arrange them buses to return to their native. Revenue officials, meanwhile, provided them food and water. Later, they were screened for Covid-19 symptoms and taken to their native places in Tiruvannamalai district in two buses.

Title: Cop gives pep talk, plays music to chase away hopelessness
Content: Bengaluru: When the nation went into a lockdown, residents panicked wondering if their local grocery shops would still be open. Many went on a stockpiling spree, crowding supermarkets and medical shops. At such a time, one policewoman helped restore calm among hundreds of residents of Pulikeshinagar, east Bengaluru.Armed with a public address system, ACP Tabarak Fathima , 32, has been going around several localities, giving pep talks to residents, playing songs about staying in and sanitising one’s hands and spreading the message of hope.The officer has so far visited Richards Town, Netaji Road, Diamond District in Domlur and Polluramma slum in Doddigunta, Cox Town, with similar songs and messages, and now hopes to cover every locality in her sub-division.Videos of Fathima have gone viral on social media with hundreds of people appreciating the move. In one such video shot at Richards Town and posted by Bengaluru police on Instagram, Fathima can be seen giving a new twist to the song ‘Hum Honge Kamyaab’ (We shall overcome) and singing “We shall stay at home, we shall sanitise.” It was viewed more than 24,000 times.“When the first announcement came, I went around the city and realised everybody was scared. When you are in fear, people need some hope. ‘Hum Honge Kamyaab’ is a song of hope,” Fathima told TOI. “The moment people hear there’s a lockdown, the first thing that comes to their mind is ‘where will my food come from’? The lockdown’s purpose is to ensure people don’t come close to each other and this can’t be achieved if they are panic buying at crowded supermarkets. I realised it was very important to assure people their access to essential commodities is secure,” she said.“Every day, even when I get a little bit of time, I try to visit people and talk to them. Public-police cooperation is extremely important now,” the ACP added.Residents of localities she has visited have also posted videos of the ACP addressing them. “What an excellent speech, reassuring us that all essential services will not be affected, yet calmly asking us to stay indoors and not panic. Am talking about this police officer who came to Davis Road this afternoon. This was outside my apartment today,” tweeted @sai_ganesh, a resident of Davis Road, along with a video. The post was shared over 1.9k times.“All essential services, be it medical or groceries, are open like any other normal day. Please do not get scared or panic thinking you are not getting essential commodities. Milk, vegetables, fruits and medical services, everything is available and is getting transported to your local stores,” the police officer can be heard calmly informing residents in the 2 minute and 20 second video clip.Awareness is keyFathima, who joined city police in December 2019, sets out in the morning, at times as early as at 6am, and is on the field till late at night. “The police department has been at it 24*7. If there is a situation that demands our presence, we get on the job right away,” she said. Speaking about how cops are keeping themselves calm in this scenario, the ACP pointed out that awareness is key. “We have educated police officers at all levels on the dangers of the virus, how it spreads and the precautionary measures to be taken. We maintain distance between the staff and between the staff and public as well. Out stations are sanitised every day and we also have a hand wash and sanitising facility on the premises,” she said

Title: City clubs and corporates donate to state corona fund
Content:
Kolkata: Premier clubs and corporate houses in the city has started contributing to the corona relief fund of Chief minister Mamata Banerjee.

The first club to do so was 161-year-old Calcutta Rowing Club (CRC). Some other clubs like Tolly Club, Dalhousie Institute, Calcutta Club, too, are likely to join soon in this drive. The corporate houses, too, are coming forward for the contribution. Credai Bengal, Boroline, Patton have already contributed to this fund and other may soon join them soon.

Tapan Mitra, president of CRC said: “We must salute to our beloved Chief Minister and state govt administration for taking an appropriate step in this hour of global crises to combating COVID-19, by creating an additional special fund to cope with the situation and taking further necessary steps to prevent and control the emergent situation. We have transferred to your designated account Rs 2 lakhs only through IDBI Bank today and request to acknowledge the same for our accounts record.” The CEO of Tolly Club Anil Mukherjee said that it will be doing contribution to state government soon. “We shall also do something for the casual workers coming to club,” he added.

The president of DI, Joyjeet Biswas, too, indicated it will soon contribute into the kitty. Besides, the club is calling its senior members and extending helping hand in procuring necessary commodities during lockdown.

Credai Bengal president Nandu Belani has promised Rs 2 crore on behalf of Credai Bengal, to the state government as contribution for Covid-19 fund. G D Pharmaceuticals, the manufacturer of iconic brands like Boroline and Suthol, has donated Rs 50 lakh to the chief minister’s corona relief fund.

Its MD Debasish Dutta told TOI: “Amid the current situation, we cannot go out and arrange relief materials for the needy people. Thus, we have decided to send it to the state relief fund. As a corporate citizen, we believe it is our primary social duty.” Sanjay Budhia, MD of Patton, who donated Rs 25 lakh, said: “We salute tremendous efforts by CM, who is leading from the front and her dedicated team, who are working tirelessly.”

Title: Doc who treated Thai patients in Erode develops symptoms
Content:
Coimbatore: The Railway Hospital in Podanur was shut down on Friday morning after a doctor, who recently reported for duty, developed Covid-19 symptoms. The doctor had earlier treated the two Thailand nations, who tested positive for the virus, at the Perundurai government hospital in Erode. While the doctor said she had not met anyone in the hospital or consulted any patient, the hospital shut itself down as a precautionary measure. At least five people - including her husband, two children and a maid – have been isolated as they were in contact with her.

Meanwhile, health department officials in the city have sent throat swabs and blood samples of two suspected cases, including that of the doctor, to King Institute Chennai for re-testing as the tests conducted at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital’s Covid-19 testing centre were inconclusive.

Officials have, however, begun providing treatment to both the patients, one of them a woman with a travel history from North India. “Both have symptoms and while the doctor had direct contact with a positive patient, the woman has a travel history,” an official said.

The officials are also tracing the contacts of these two patients. “The doctor says she has not met anyone in the railway hospital and in Perundurai after treating the Thai nationals. The names of few that she does recollect are being passed on to Erode public health department for tracing. The other victim said she had travelled to the city from North India by train last week. So, we are getting details from the railways on people who travelled in the coach with her and trying to trace them,” said a senior district administration official. Both the patients are admitted to the ESI Hospital, along with the other Covid-19 patients in the region - the 25-year-old Spain returnee and the 47-year-old businessman from Tirupur.

In another instance, 15 more patients were admitted to the ESI Hospital on Friday. While six of them are contacts of suspected Covid-19 patients, four are with travel history from abroad and symptoms. The remaining five are people who have travelled within the country.

Title: Nashik: Over 1,200 get permission to travel for medical purpose
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The city police have granted permission to over 1 ,200 people who were in need of medical emergency to travel within the city for health purposes in the past two days.

In the past two days, police received 5,000 requests through the helpline numbers.

On Wednesday night, the police released the helpline numbers on which people could request for travel permission within the city.

The senior police officials said that they were getting lot of calls from people all across the state, as the number that was published went viral

Under this system, the concerned citizens have to give their name, address, vehicle numbers, photo, the reason for the need to travel.

The police on verifying the details of the applicants and the documents sent on the numbers through Whatsapp grants permission or rejects the request.

The police said that the permissions were granted only for medical emergencies. The city with a population of approximately 18 lakh has a large number of people suffering from some ailment. There are also incidents of someone suffering from cardiac arrest, some kind of injury, or in need of dialysis, chemotherapy and other such medical necessities.

Since the police have barred the use of vehicles in the city, it has become a major problem for citizens to go to hospitals. The helpline thus proved handy for citizens.

A senior police officer of the rank of ACP, on the condition of anonymity, said, “There were also some instances in which the callers did not have any means of transportation to take their patient to a hospital. In five cases, we arranged ambulances and send them to the callers’ address.”

The officer said that the police would not reject anyone’s request if it is a medical emergency and would ensure that the patient is rushed to the hospital at the earliest. However, people think that they could also get permission for going to a grocery store, medical store, vegetable market and others. They are available in every lane and by-lane of the city and people can easily walk to such places by taking proper precautions.

The officer added that more than 3,000 requests were rejected. The police also take note of the vehicle number, photo IDs of the caller so that the police permission cannot be misused.

Title: Nashik police use drones to keep an eye on public movement
Content:
NASHIK: The Nashik police on Friday did a trial run of using drone cameras to keep an eye on public movement on the city road amid lockdown.

Police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil said, “We conducted the trials of the drones in the Old city area on Friday. The actual deployment of the drones would begin from Saturday. With the help of the drones and a public announcement system, we would also make appeals to people to stay indoors.”

“If people do not pay heed to the announcements and continue to linger outside, action will be taken against them based on the footage received from the drone,” Nangare-Patil added.

Inspector Seetaram Kolhe said eight cameras would be put to use across the city. He added that despite the lockdown, people were rushing to the markets and not listening to the police appeals.

“The aim is to keep check on areas where people are neglecting the prohibition orders. Action will be taken against those found violating the orders,” said Ashok Bhagat , senior inspector of the Panchavati police station.

The drone will also deter people from venturing out of their houses unnecessarily as they know that their images can be captured by the cameras, Bhagat added.

The police have been constantly appealing to people not to venture out of their homes unless they have to purchase essential commodities. However, citizens are not taking the appeal seriously. Action has been taken against 295 people from March 22 to March 26 under section 188 of the IPC.

Title: Moratorium: RBI cuts rate by 75 bps, steepest in over 10 years; you can defer EMIs by 3 months
Content: MUMBAI: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on Friday cut interest rates by 75 basis points (bps)—the sharpest in over a decade. It also made available Rs 3.74 lakh crore of additional liquidity to banks and allowed almost all borrowers to defer loan repayments by three months.The measures are aimed at buying time for the government to deal with the coronavirus crisis by preventing stressed borrowers from being ejected from the banking system and avoiding bond markets going into a freeze due to the sudden cessation caused by the lockdown.Advancing the monetary policy committee meeting by a week, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das said, “This decision was warranted by the destructive force of the coronavirus. It is intended to mitigate the negative effects of the virus, revive growth, and above all, preserve financial stability.”Das said that along with earlier measures, the liquidity made available amounts to 3.2% of the country’s GDP.The rate cut had its impact with the State Bank of India cutting interest rates on loans by 75 bps. Besides the conventional rate cut, RBI took an unconventional step of making available Rs 1 lakh crore to banks through targeted long-term repo (lending) operations. This allows banks that have bought bonds from private issuers to finance the purchases at a cheap rate.Another Rs 1.37 lakh crore was released to banks by reducing the cash reserve ratio (CRR)—a portion of deposits that are impounded by RBI. This reduction in CRR by one percentage point of total deposits will release Rs 1.37 lakh crore to banks. Another Rs 1 lakh crore was made available through a marginal standing facility for emergency loans.In addition to making available funds, RBI incentivised banks to buy corporate bonds by exempting them from any writedown due to rise in interest rates in future.To push banks to lend, RBI reduced its reverse repo rate—the rate it offers banks for their surplus funds—by 90 bps to 4%. “The moratorium provides relief to borrowers from being tagged as non-performing assets. Going forward there will be a need to have a restructuring scheme for sectors like hospitality and aviation that are most affected by the crisis,” said Rajkiran Rai, managing director & CEO Union Bank of India.“As regards the outlook for 2020-21, apart from the continuing resilience of agriculture and allied activities, most other sectors of the economy will be adversely impacted by the pandemic, depending upon its intensity, spread, and duration. If Covid-19 is prolonged and supply chain disruptions get accentuated, the global slowdown could deepen, with adverse implications for India,” said Das.The measures come on the back of a Rs 1.7 lakh crore relief package for the poor through direct benefit transfer announced by the finance minister on Friday. According to C H S S Mallikarjuna Rao, managing director & CEO , Punjab National Bank, another relief is the RBI decision to defer prescriptions for high capital requirements to September 2020. “However, challenges remain in terms of transmitting these measures to customers amid social distancing. Effective digital and electronic delivery to the last mile will remain the key issue,” he said.While the stock markets opened positive to the news of an MPC meeting, the sensex closed 131 points lower. “Unlike the Fed or the ECB, the RBI did not announce direct purchases of corporate bonds or commercial paper, but instead passed the buck on to the banks; this could have led to the initial market disappointment post the policy meeting. Moreover, it was disappointing to see no special credit facilities for the worst-hit sectors like aviation, hospitality and an absence of direct liquidity support for the NBFCs,” said Abheek Barua, chief economist, HDFC Bank.

Title: Residents barricade entry to village, keep virus at bay
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Setting an example for the rest of us in the fight against the coronavirus, residents of Bakkorai village in Kundha taluk here have decided neither to go out of the village nor let outsiders in.

“We held a meeting with the residents and decided not to go out of the village till April 14 as prescribed by the government,” a villager told TOI. “We will not allow relatives or other people enter the village. This will make the 80 families here live fear free.”

The villagers have installed a board at the entrance stating that outsiders are not welcome. They have also blocked the entrance using sandbags.

Outsiders who want to enter the village must produce doctor’s certificate, said B Bhojan, a resident. “We have cancelled all the proposed functions and festivals till April 14. We will strictly follow the rules imposed on us by us.”

Title: Surge of citizens force Bicholim shopkeepers to down shutters
Content:
Bicholim: Local market vendors were compelled to close shops on Friday morning following a rush from citizens, especially the labour class residing in Bicholim for essential commodities.

A day after the state government relaxed the curfew for making purchases, scores of people thronged grocery and vegetable stores, refusing to pay heed to shopkeepers ’ pleas for maintaining social distancing.

The shopkeepers were then compelled to close their outlets, but opened later following requests by locals.

At the Bicholim Bagayatdar outlet, PI Sanjay Dalvi was seen streaming the surge of crowds.

Bicholim mamlatdar and municipality chief officer Pravinjay Pandit oversaw the situation at Sakhali market.

Title: City schools begin virtual classes for next session
Content: Jaipur: Due to lockdown in the state, the schools in Jaipur have started virtual classes for their students. The lockdown will go on till April 15 and the new session for Class X and XII usually starts in March. Hence, to prevent loss of academic session, schools have come up with virtual classes where students are taught online and assignments are given for practice.Principal of Jayshree Periwal International School Jaya Singh said from Nursery to Class XII, all the classes are being held online. “We are conducting live interactive sessions for students. Students can ask for any queries online. Some of our teachers are available all the time. If a student fails to attend live session, he/she will later on ask teachers about it,” said Singh.Ryan International School has its own portal that is now being used for virtual classes. Principal Sarita Kataria said, “We already had our portal – Ryan My Class Board. We have been uploading examination results, notifications and some worksheets for summer vacation on it. Now, with the lockdown, our teachers have started uploading notes, worksheet and assignments for Class X and XII students. They have been given ID and password to login and read the notes of the teachers.”Most of the schools have started virtual classes with board classes but if the lockdown is extended, they are planning to extend it to junior classes as well. While conducting virtual classes schools are keeping in mind the time of the classes as parents are working from home as well.Delhi Public School, Jaipur will be starting session from junior section from April 1. The school said that unlike live sessions for senior classes, for juniors, videos will be uploaded online. “Junior class students do not have long attention span. At present, we are working on creating content for the junior classes and we will upload the videos on Zoom application with worksheets to be completed on time,” said Ravi Dutt, principal.As per schools, they have received good feedback from parents about the classes.Jaya Singh said that in nursery and kindergarten classes, students don’t want to leave the session when it ends. “They are stuck at home and this lockdown affects them as well. We give poem recitation, art work and illustrations for homework to nursery and kindergarten sections. Students usually don’t like to leave the classes as they enjoy so much. Even if the lockdown extends, we are prepared for it and our students will not face any loss of studies,” said Jaya.

Title: SMC’s home quarantine app replicated in four Guj cities
Content:
SMC commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani

Surat: The Diamond City, which had experienced a horrific plague outbreak in 1994, has taken the lead in fighting novel Coronavirus pandemic in Gujarat. Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC)'s three unique initiatives to fight against pandemic has found place in 'Managing COVID-19- good practices in 100 Smart Cities'. These initiatives can be replicated anywhere in the country to effectively fight against global pandemic.

In fact, Gujarat government on Friday announced that the COVID-19 Tracker App, developed by SMC, will now be replicated in Ahmedabad, Gandhinagar, Vadodara and Rajkot to effectively monitor home quarantined people in respective cities.

"SMC was the first civic body to develop a special app to track home quarantined people on a real-time basis. Our in-house team developed the app within 48 hours. Google and Apple are not approving applications quickly at present, so we are distributing this app from our website. Till now, 3005 people have downloaded this app and we are constantly monitoring them,'' Banchhanidhi Pani, municipal commissioner, Surat, told TOI.

"Every home quarantined person has to upload their selfie and status twice in a day on this app. This has helped us warn 42 home home quarantined people who were violating the rules and we have issued warning to them,” Pani added.

"Till Friday evening, we have 4,331 people under quarantine including those at home in Surat city, the largest numbers in the state,'' Pani said.

SMC has adopted three Ts approach to deal with the outbreak - Track, Test and Treat.

Eight FIRs have been filed against those found violating home quarantine.

SMC's two other initiatives also found place in good practices. These include self declaration forms on its website by travellers in the city and voluntarily declaration of their travel history. The civic body has has started a toll free helpline number (1-800-123-800) where citizen can share details about travellers or suspects.

The details are verified by SMC team including health officials. A field team visits the location and if the details provided on helpline is verified, the individual is asked to stay in home quarantine and assigned unique tracker ID. They are asked to download SMC COVID-19 tracker app.

Title: Govt relaxes rules, firm on social distancing
Content:
As the lockdown entered the third day on Friday, the state government appeared to relax the rules to ensure adequate supply of essentials.

More vegetable markets were opened across the state and facilities were made for door delivery of provisions from super markets ending anxiety of the public about shortage of essentials.

Uzhavar Sandhais came alive after a gap of five days across the state and in some places the markets were shifted to spacious locations to ensure public maintain the one metre distance among each other while buying goods.

The R S Puram and Singanallur Uzhavar Sandhais were reopened for three hours on Friday and the authorities said 10 more major markets will be opened during their usual work hours from Saturday.

In Tuticorin, the bus stand was turned into a vegetable market to accommodate more traders and public. “The prices of vegetables have come down after spiking up for the past few days,’’ said KM Swaminathan, an insurance agent from Vadavalli.

In Madurai, traders at central vegetable market have decided to sell goods only to retail shop owners instead of public to prevent mass gatherings.

“This ensures that public don’t crowd here and get chased away by police. They can buy vegetables from retail stores in their locality,’’ P S Murugan, president of vegetable market traders association, said.

Civic bodies have also roped in provision stores for door delivery of goods. While 20 such stores were enrolled in Coimbatore, Madurai corporation has taken on board 26 shops.

Police too refrained from beating motorists but have started booking more cases and in some places confiscating the bikes of loiterers.

But the cops had to grapple with slow emergence of offences like theft and illicit selling of liquor. In Coimbatore, a grocery store was broken open and 50kg of rice and edible oil were stolen while in Namakkal police arrested two men for selling liquor discretely. “We have seized 2,650 bottles of liquor kept for sales at Namakkal and 144 bottles in Tiruchengode,’’ said Namakkal SP Arivarasu.

Though much of the roads were deserted, police felt the compliance to curfew was not total in some places like Cuddalore and Thanjavur where people were stepping out in droves, apparently to buy essentials. The vegetable market in Cuddalore for instance was so crowded and police had to chase them away.

Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami made a fervent appeal to the public not to venture out unnecessarily. “The government has ensured that there was adequate supply of vegetables. But people should cooperate and not crowd the markets. Section 144 is being imposed for you, your family and the country,’’ he said in Chennai.

The officials have also permitted weddings and allowed people to prepare for the ceremonies with a restriction that not more than 30 people should congregate for the events. Coimbatore collector K Rajamani has allowed 30 weddings to be conducted on March 30, an auspicious day. “The weddings were fixed much before the curfew. I have told the entire wedding hall should be sanitized and all the participants should wear masks,” Rajamani said.

Title: Permission granted to conduct 30 marriages
Content:
Coimbatore: Collector K Rajamani has given permission to conduct 30 marriages in the district. Only 30 people can attend the functions and all of them should wear face mask.

“I have given permission to conduct 30 marriages that were fixed earlier. Only 30 people can gather and the places should be sanitized. The couple and their family members should wear face masks,” said Rajamani.

People are approaching the collector to seek permission to travel to other districts. “We are issuing permission letters to only those who have genuine reasons to travel,” he said.

The district administration has set up a special control room (0422-1077) manned by doctors for creating awareness about Covid-19. People can contact the toll-free number round-the-clock to clarify their doubts.

“Many people contacted the control room to inform about the houses that should be quarantined as people who returned from foreign countries are staying there. Some callers informed us about the people in self- quarantine, who had come out of their houses. The control room staff have been advised to contact the police control room and public health department officials for further action,” said Rajamani.

The state government has allotted Rs 3 crore for the district to procure materials to prevent Covid-19 spread, the collector said. The city corporation has received Rs 1 crore from the state government. The district also received Rs 15 lakh from the disaster management fund and Rs 12.5 lakh from the DRDA fund.

Title: Worried over safety, pvt hosps reluctant to admit Covid-19 patients
Content:
Bengaluru: Of the 54 Covid-19 patients undergoing treatment in the state, only five are in private hospitals. Officials lament that private hospitals are not shouldering the Covid-19 burden to the extent they can, despite meetings held with their representatives twice in a week.

At Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases, the state’s nodal centre for Covid-19 treatment, all 15 isolation beds are occupied. Cases coming to RGICD are now being referred to other government hospitals.

The Federation of Healthcare Associations of Karnataka recently wrote to the government asking it to be ready for the fast-worsening situation with 2,000 critical care beds. The association offered some staff but there is no mention of private hospitals willing to admit patients.

According to private hospitals, the reason for their reluctance is non-availability of Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) and hydroxychloroquine tablets, which have been prescribed by ICMR for prophylactic treatment of healthcare professionals who will be involved in treating the infected.

“We have repeatedly brought the PPE situation to the government’s notice at every meeting but the equipment is still not available. If the situation does not improve, hospitals will have to shut down. We can’t compromise on the safety of our doctors, nurses and allied personnel,” said the representative of a leading hospital.

Medical education minister K Sudhakar had earlier stated that patients can choose the hospital at the time of admission and decide if they want to get treated in a private facility. There are 35 first responder private hospitals in Bengaluru, including some private medical colleges.

In Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, the governments have already moved forward by taking over some private hospitals. The Rajasthan government has taken over a hospital and asked it to shift all its patients to a government medical college. “If the directions are not followed, action will be taken as per IPC Section 188 and Section 57 of the Disaster Management Act, 2005,” says the Rajasthan circular, a copy of which is with TOI. The situation is similar in Madhya Pradesh, where two private hospitals in Indore have been taken over by the government.

Do not mix patients: Expert

Dr Nagendra Swamy, principal coordinator of Federation of Healthcare Associations Karnataka, said the need of the hour is to keep all Covid-19 patients in one isolated hospital instead of several hospitals which will have many other patients. “There are chances of healthcare workers contracting the infection, which is spreading fast. Private hospitals have other patients too. Medical professionals have to be fit. If they also get infected, where will people go?” wondered Dr Swamy.

Title: Odisha: Koraput villagers erect bamboo checkposts to restrict movement of visitors
Content: KORAPUT: In the wake of a 21-day national lockdown, residents of 10 villages under Mastiput panchayat in Koraput district have erected temporary bamboo checkposts at the entrance of their respective villages to restrict the entry and exit of visitors.“The checkposts have been installed to restrict the movement of villagers and outsiders. As the only precaution to defeat the virus is staying home, we can’t be complacent,” Arjun Pradhan, a Dongri villager, said.Two youths from each village will guard the checkposts on a rotational basis. Every visitor will be screened and asked about his/her purpose of visit. “There is soap and a bucket of water near every checkpost. This will ensure that whoever steps into the village is clean,” Pradhan added.Several villagers in the district have even perfomed pujas, believing that it would prevent the entry of coronavirus into their village. “We don’t know much about the virus, but learnt that it is very dangerous. God can help us in this crucial moment. We are praying for every life,” Rabi Hantal, a resident of Dalaiguda village, said.

Title: Nashik: Transporters to get permit at RTO
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Regional Transport Office (RTO) has set up a control room at its premises to grant permission to transporters for supplying essential commodities to stores.

The aim is to ensure that the transporters of essential services are allowed to commute during the lockdown period. Transporters coming to the RTO during office hours would be given permission certificate.

A release from the Nashik RTO said that the control room has been set up on the instructions of transport commissioner’s office, Mumbai.

RTO official said that those who are unable to go to the RTO can get the transport certificate online by applying on mh15@mahatranscom.in

The transporters will have to submit their application along with registration certificate, all vehicle related documents, insurance papers, fitness certificate, permit, license of the driver and the identity of the driver’s assistant.

On verification of the document, the certificate would be sent on the e-mail address of the applicant.

Title: Nashik: NGOs told to identify places where poor can get food
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Police authorities in Nashik district have appealed to non-governmental organisations (NGOs) to identify places where the destitute and poor can be served food during the ongoing lockdown.

Superintendent of police Arti Singh and deputy commissioner of police Amol Tambe have sent out the messages through social media platforms appealing to people to come forward and help those who are facing hardships due to the lack of work and money to buy food.

“Many workers belonging to the agricultural sector across the district are unable to feed themselves due to lack of labour. We have, therefore, appealed to citizens to come forth and contribute towards helping them,” Arti Singh said.

On the other hand, police have appealed to people to help them find safe haven for destitute or workers until the lockdown is lifted. “Many NGOs have started distributing food among homeless people. But, when the food trucks arrive at Gangaghat , Ramkund these people start crowding to collect food packets. It creates a chaos and it becomes impossible to maintain social distancing at such places,” Tambe told TOI.

The homeless are unable to maintain personal hygiene and that is another concern for the police authorities, he said.

“The idea is to find community halls or college premises where the homeless can be shifted in the groups of 100-200.,” Tambe added.

Title: 1,342 societies call AMC for veggies
Content:
Ahmedabad:The scheme of the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) to coordinate buying of all daily vegetable for residential societies in the city received a massive response with 1 ,342 housing societies calling the corporation to get vegetables.

However, just 52 societies could provide all the details prescribed in the advertisement. G H Solanki, the deputy municipal commissioner, handling the project said a total of 2,144 families in 52 societies availed of the facility, and bought a total 8,095kg of vegetables.

Solanki said that majority of calls were those who thought the AMC was giving away free vegetables and backed out when we enumerated the costs.

Another set of people were placing orders for 5kg or 10kg but did not place orders when told the minimum requirement was 100kg.

According to the scheme, the society has have to nominate a representative who then places bulk orders — of 100kg or more including all vegetables — for the society with the AMC’s WhatsApp helpline number 94087-53064.

The civic body’s zonal representative will commission a vehicle for the society’s bulk purchase at the nearest vegetable market. A society representative will have to accompany the vehicle to the market.

Once the purchase is made, the AMC’s team will help load the vegetables at the market and unload them at the society’s entrance.

Title: With Kolkata reeling under lockdown, citizens come together to feed strays
Content:
Kolkata: Have you encountered a familiar stray dog behave in an aggressive way in the past week? In all probability, it’s because he was starving . With the city in lockdown mode and eateries and food vendors shut, stray animals that feed on the leftovers, have been left nibbling at nothing.

Hopefully, not for too long. A group of animal lovers have formed online groups to feed stray dogs and cats in neighbourhoods around them.

Fashion designer Nandita Thirani has contacted a member of people residing at her apartment in a building off Theatre Road to join her in feeding strays on Camac Street, Russel Street, Park Street, Short Street, Wood Street and Chowringhee.

She has appealed on the WhatsApp group of the apartment for help and asked them to put their leftovers and a little extra in boxes at specific points from where she will pick up and distribute.

On Thursday morning, she and her daughter Anuradha, were seen distributing rice and chicken to dogs in these localities. “There’s no time to waste. It’s been over 48 hours that they have gone hungry.
