These stretches teem with food vendors on whom the dogs depend for food. With the stalls shut since Saturday, they are starving,” she said.

KMDA employee Deboshree Ganguly and her husband Kuntal Ghosh, was seen in several Salt Lake Blocks, Karunamoyee and Central Park, feeding strays. The duo have been passionately doing this for seven years now but have now extended their radius because of lockdown.

They already have neighbour Hansa Patodia with them. “We are a bit tense. Till date, we needed 450 kilos of rice but this time it will increase. However, even if we manage funds, we are not sure of the supplies. Hansa aunty is trying to contact suppliers,” Deboshree said.

An appeal to feed helpless strays has gone out from Stray Love, a shelter for strays run by Mystic Yoga Foundation, that is taking care of 125 strays. Sudhir, Chiroshree and Abhishek, the founders have connected with friends all over city to start feeding at the earliest.

Title: Four new Covid-19 patients in Nagpur, 1 in Gondia
Content: NAGPUR: Three family members and one close contact of a city businessman, who tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday, also tested positive on Friday. This takes the number of positive patients admitted in isolation wards of government hospitals in Nagpur to eight.Family members of the 43-year-old businessman who have tested positive include his 60-year-old mother, 34-year-old wife and 14-year-old son. A 39-year-old manager of his shop, who had travelled along with him to New Delhi between March 16 and 18, has also tested positive. With the 14-year-old boy being the youngest ever Covid-19 patient in Vidarbha, the 60-year-old mother is the eldest patient reported in the region as yet.Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar confirmed that five new patients were found positive on Friday. “Total five patients, including one from Gondia, have tested positive on Friday. Four of them are admitted in IGGMCH while the Gondia patient is in GMCH Gondia,” said Kumar.Samples of a 23-year-old youth from Gondia, who had gone to Thailand along with some friends in Chhattisgarh in February, tested positive on Friday. Gondia civil surgeon Dr Sangeeta Bhise told TOI that the youth is asymptomatic carrier of novel coronavirus “As one of his friends who travelled with him to Thailand tested positive in Rajnandgaon (Chhattisgarh), the authorities from Chhattisgarh informed us about this youth. He was called and his samples were sent to Nagpur for testing,” she said.District collector Ravindra Thakare denied that the four new cases found in Nagpur could be cases of local transmission. “Four people from close contacts of a patient have tested positive. But, this is not a case of community spread or phase three of Covid-19 as the patient has travel history to New Delhi,” he said.As soon as three family members of yesterday’s patient tested positive, NMC swung into action. Civic officials brought total 18 close contacts, including family members of a manager who tested positive, for testing at IGGMCH. Three servants working in the businessman’s shop were also called for testing.By Friday evening, 14 of these 18 people had tested negative. They include the businessman’s daughter, the manager’s elder brother, and two of the three servants in the shop. Results of other samples were yet to arrive. Moreover, NMC conducted door-to-door survey of 70,000 households in Khamla locality on Friday, and sent 12 more persons for testing to IGGMCH on Friday evening. Their samples will be tested late Friday night.Even if other family members and servants of the businessmen test negative, the administration has asked them to stay in home quarantine for next 14 days. NMC also tested four employees of AG Enviro, the agency entrusted to lift garbage door-to-door from five of the 10 zones, and asked them to stay in home quarantine. These four include one driver and three workers who visit houses in Khamla area, where the businessman stays.“I appeal to people not to panic, and stay calm. Those who face any health problems should directly call our helpline numbers. Till then, stay at home, follow hand hygiene and social distancing strictly,” said municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe.On Saturday, NMC will also collect swab samples of the positive patient’s housemaid, who resides in a slum adjacent to Khamla. Two children in the locality, who are close friends of the 14-year-old boy, and two close friends of a manager will also be tested on Saturday.Situation in Khamla Market lanes has seen some panic from Thursday afternoon since the businessman was detected as Covid-19 patient. On Friday, after four more in the same locality tested positive, panic gripped the entire area. Shops of essential goods, including medical shops, were closed and houses were locked.By Friday evening, the video clip of a businessman admitted in isolation ward went viral, in which he is appealing to residents not to panic and follow the lockdown properly.Three patients at GMCH may be discharged todayThree positive patients who have been recovering in the isolation ward of GMCH from March 13 and 14, are doing well. Officials confirmed that the samples of their first test after the 14-day isolation have already tested negative. At least two of them will be discharged on Saturday. These include the wife of first Covid-19 positive patient in the city, who recovered and was discharged on Thursday. He is doing well and in home quarantine for a further 14 days.

Title: Rayagada sends Chhattisgarh pilgrims home
Content:
KORAPUT: The Rayagada district administration on Friday facilitated the return of 18 pilgrims of Chhattisgarh , who had arrived in the district from Tirupati in Andhra Pradesh on Thursday, but had failed to proceed due to the lockdown.

Official sources said the pilgrims from Nandgaon village under Mahasamund district in Chhattigarh had arrived in Kerada village on the Odisha-Andhra Pradesh border, in Rayagada district with much difficulty.

From Kerada, they had travelled around 35 km on auto-rickshaw to reach the border of Rayagada town.

“Health examination of pilgrims was carried out by our rapid response team. As they desired to return home, they were sent to their village in four special vehicles,” said collector (Rayagada) Pramod Kumar Behera.

According to the collector, details of the pilgrims will be sent to his counterpart in Raipur and the pilgrims have been asked to remain in home quarantine for 14 days.

The administration has taken all necessary steps to ensure that the migrant labourers of other states stuck in the district are provided with food and shelter.

Title: Maharashtra: Eateries, hotels can restart home delivery but restaurateurs say staff on leave till March 31
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Even as the state government on Friday decided to allow hotels and restaurants to restart their kitchens and home delivery service, hoteliers and restaurateurs said they may not be able to as they have sent their staff on leave till March 31. Indian Hotel and Restaurant Association (AHAR) said it will take a call on restarting services after the month-end.

The state decided to allow eateries to reopen as part of its measures to ensure maximum essential services are made available to citizens so that they do not need to step out during the lockdown.

Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar was informed of the inconvenience people have been facing to source cooked food during a meeting with officials on Friday. Pawar was told this was one of the main reasons why people step out. Pawar asked hoteliers to provide delivery services at the gates of housing societies. He also instructed cooks and delivery personnel to take proper precautions against Covid-19 and maintain hygiene.

An official from the deputy chief minister’s office said Pawar has also instructed all local authorities and district collectors to cooperate in this regard.

However, Shivanand Shetty, president of AHAR, said, “ There are other issues involved such as supply of raw material and shortage of delivery boys.”

Pawar also clarified there are no restrictions on the sale of eggs, meat and fruits, including “the famous mangoes from Konkan.”

Meanwhile, Pawar said the government letter seeking military assistance is limited to receiving medical help.

Title: Navy transports 60k face masks from Delhi
Content:
Panaji: With the country under a lockdown that has seen all states seal their borders, the Indian Navy came to the rescue and helped airlift a consignment of face masks for Goa’s healthcare providers.

Based on a request from the Indian Medical Association (IMA), a naval long rage maritime reconnaissance aircraft flew to Delhi to bring back 60,000 face masks on Friday.

“An Ilyushin 38SD (IL-38) of the Indian Navy was promptly readied to depart INS Hansa for Palam Airport, New Delhi. The collection of the items at Delhi was coordinated by Air Force Station Palam and the aircraft returned to Goa with the masks on the same day,” a senior naval officer said.

The shipment of 60,000 face masks, ordered by IMA– Goa, is meant to offset its shortfall in the state.

The consignment was stuck at Delhi after the truck ferrying the consignment could not travel to Goa because of the lockdown.

Over the last week, people have rushed to pharmacies and bought out most of the face masks. Doctors and nurses, who are in the frontline in the fight against coronavirus, have also had to purchase their own face masks after government hospitals ran out of the crucial gear.

A few days earlier, a naval Dornier 228 aircraft helped airlift a team of doctors from Goa to Pune and back. The doctors went to a virology centre in Pune to undergo training in testing of coronavirus cases.

Title: Odisha: Milk procurement declines, dairy farmers hit
Content:
KORAPUT: The 8,340 dairy farmers of Koraput, Malkangiri, Nabarangpur and Rayagada districts registered under the Odisha State Cooperative Milk Producers Federation (OMFED) to sell milk have been badly hit as the federation has stopped procuring milk from farmers citing a huge decrease in demand.

“We are in a huge problem as OMFED has suddenly stopped procuring milk. Also, milk being a perishable item it cannot be stored for long. For many farmers, dairy farming is the only source of income and they are in deep trouble,” said Shyam Rout, president of Koraput Malkangiri Nabarangpur and Rayagada Milk Union (KMNRMU).

According to Rout, many farmers, mostly tribals, have bought cows on loan. In the current situation, maintaining their dairy farms and arranging fodder for the cattle is a big challenge before them, said Rout.

Though the government said that milk booths will remain open, people are not coming out to buy milk products. “We don’t know for how long the deadlock will continue but if it stretches for a long time, then certainly it will ruin the dairy farmers,” said Rout.

Official data reveals that prior to the lockdown, the OMFED used to procure around 19,000 litres of milk from farmers. Of it, 80% of the milk was procured from Nabarangpur district.

“Since the lockdown there has been 80% decrease in our sales and now we hardly sell between 2,000 and 3,000 litres of milk a day. Though our booths are open, people are not coming to buy milk. So we are procuring less,” said Suprabhat Kanuango, plant manager of OMFED Jeypore.

According to the officer, the tea stalls and sweet shops were the major consumers of OMFED milk and since those are closed, there is less demand for milk.

“We have to make instant payments to farmers for the milk procured. When, there is no demand, how can we procure,” said Kanuango.

“Also, we have huge stock of milk products like paneer and sweet curd but there is no demand. We can’t store milk for a long period at our plant,” he added.

The dairy farmers have demanded for establishment of a powder plant at Jeypore so that milk could be procured to make milk powder which could be stored for a longer period.

Title: Many takers for open veg market in Nilgiris
Content:
Udhagamandalam: After shifting the uzhavar sandhai to an open municipal ground near the Shanthi Vijai School on Friday, customers are finding it easy to maintain distance from each other.

The vendors are also comfortable with the open space. “As there is enough space, customers are comfortable forming a line and we can also do our business with satisfaction,” said L Vasanthi, a vegetable vendor.

M Raghavan, a local resident, felt that at least half of the shops in the uzhavar sandhai could have been retained there itself for the benefit of people residing in that part of the town.

According to Nilgiris collector J Innocent Divya, open space vegetable markets were introduced in Coonoor and Gudalur towns also. One will be introduced in Kotagiri today, she said.

Title: ‘Pvt schools not to cut salaries of teachers during lockdown’
Content: Jaipur: The education department has issued orders to the private schools asking them not to cut salaries of teachers during lockdown The orders were issued on the basis of complaints received by the department from school teachers, who were informed by the school managements that they will be paid on the basis of the number of days they come to school.Education minister Govind Singh Dotasra on Friday said these orders must be strictly implemented. “No educational institute can cut salaries of teachers. If any school violates the orders, the district collector can take action,” Dotasra said.Schools have been shut for the last two weeks due to the spread of coronavirus . Many schools were in the middle of conducting their exams.Sourabh Swami, director, secondary education, Bikaner, said mostly small schools are involved in such act. “Schools who usually change their teachers every three months are likely to be involved in this. In bigger schools, teachers are valued a lot. But in any case, action will be taken against violators. Orders have been issued after many complaints have been received by the district education officers that teachers have been informed by the school authorities about the cut in monthly salary ,” Swami said.

Title: NGOs offer help to senior citizens
Content:
Hyderabad: As the lockdown continued, several organisations have come forward to help senior citizens.

Youngistaan Foundation, an NGO , is helping elderly couples and senior citizens in a 3-km radius. “Our 60 volunteers are getting groceries, vegetables and medicines for the elders,” said Arun Daniel Yellamaty, president of the NGO.

Senior citizens can reach Youngistaan Foundation on 9100142224 for assistance.

The Helpage India had also reached out to all the Senior Citizen Associations in the city and have provided with contact numbers of 10 doctors. Similarly another organisation, No Food Waste Hyderabad, has also created an online form to supply cooked food to the help elderly in the city. TNN

Title: Rs 50 lakh from each legislator’s fund to be used to fight Covid-19: Bihar CM
Content: PATNA: The Bihar government on Friday constituted Corona Eradication Fund (CEF). The Planning and Development Department would deduct the minimum amount of Rs50 lakh from the MLA and MLC local area fund to help the health department in fighting against the Covid-19.CM Nitish Kumar said the health department would open a separate bank account for the CEF and necessary modifications have been made in the guidelines of the Mukhya Mantri Kshetra Vikas Yojana (MMKVY) to facilitate the transfer of amount from the state legislators’ funds. “The amount will be utilized for purchasing medicines, mask, kits and equipment to fight against the corona epidemic,” CM said.Each MLA and MLC in Bihar is authorized to make recommendation for spending Rs3 crore per annum on development works in his or her constituency under the MMKVY. With the modifications in the guidelines, the minimum amount of Rs50 lakh from their funds will be deducted as contribution to the CEF.The CM asked health department’s principal secretary Sanjay Kumar to open the bank account at the earliest. “If a legislator wants to contribute more than Rs50 lakh, s/he is free to do so,” Nitish said.Minister of Planning and Development Maheshwar Hazari told TOI that the decision was taken in the wake of requests by several legislators that they wanted to contribute from their area development fund for the government’s fight against corona epidemic, Hazari said. His department controls schemes under the MMKVY.Bihar currently has 316 legislators. “If minimum Rs50 lakh is deducted from each legislator’s fund, it will create a corpus of Rs158 crore,” a health department official said.Nitish further asked the officials to run disaster relief camps at different places to provide shelter and food to the people who are stranded in different cities due to the sudden lockdown.Disaster management department’s principal secretary Pratyaya Amrit informed the CM that camps were functional in all districts.Former chief minister and HAM(S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi said he would contribute Rs60 lakh to the CEF . Manjhi said he and his party was with the state government in its fight against corona.

Title: Narvem locals oppose accommodation of homeless
Content: Bicholim: The residents of Narvem in Bicholim , including the local panch, strongly opposed the move of the civic administration to accommodate homeless people in the government primary school The villagers created a ruckus after they suspected that people infected with coronavirus were kept in the school.Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit visited the area and pacified the protesting panch members and locals. He informed them that the district administrations has designated the school as a shelter house for those who are homeless. He also said the district administration is creating infrastructure in each taluka to accommodate those who are stranded in the state.Pandit further said that only the homeless will be moved to such centres since they should not be exposed during the pandemic. The mamlatdar also said that around five people are shifted to Mayem Residency and eight to the WRD rest house in Bicholim.

Title: Pay power bills online: Discom
Content:
Times News Network

Jaipur: The lockdown announced by the Central government to combat the coronavirus had hit the cash-strapped power distribution companies (Discoms) badly. Since the beginning of spot billing, electricity bills are collected every month. But with the announcement of lockdown, the consumers were not able to pay their bills at the collection centres.

Jaipur Discom in an official statement said, “It had to pay for the electricity purchased every month to the power generations companies. If the consumers default on payment, it will not be able to purchase power and power supply could be adversely affected.”

It said in Jaipur Discom alone about Rs 570 crore bills issued till March 20 are pending for payment.

It asked the consumers to pay online or by downloading Bijili Mitra app or could deposit at the office of assistant engineers’ office.

Title: Food shortage leaves many pet parents anxious
Content:
Bengaluru: At a time when citizens are scrambling for groceries, pet parents in the city are a worried lot. Reason: getting meat and pet food is turning out to be a big challenge.

A large number of pet parents rely on chicken from neighbourhood stores and e-commerce retailers. With the lockdown in place, stores are closed and e-commerce retailers are mostly out of stock, leaving Bengalureans with no routine food for their pets.

“I live in an area where sourcing meat is difficult even on normal days. Now, the local stores are closed and police are stopping deliveries. Procuring food from e-commerce retailers is difficult as they too are mostly out of stock. My orders got cancelled several times and I’m yet to get the refunds. With a lot of difficulty, I got some meat on Friday. But I have to keep checking all the sites for availability as my dog has a medical condition and has to be on a meat-based diet,” said Thiyam Sophia, a medical student in Basavanagudi, who has two dogs.

“We have 130 dogs at our adoption centre and we usually need 50-60 kg of meat a day. Our regular vendor has been unable to source meat for us every day. So we have been forced to ration the chicken, limiting it to 25kg per day, complementing it with rice. We have found suppliers for bigger chains, but the rates are different. It’s a difficult situation,” explained Sanjana Madappa, who works for Compassion Unlimited Plus Action (CUPA), a shelter for dogs.

Many have, in fact, tweaked their pets’ diet owing to the scarcity. “We fed our dogs curd rice and rice with veggies for three days till we could source some meat,” said Prashant P, a resident of Hennur, who has a Labrador and an Indie.

Suchishmita Datta, a resident on Sarjapur Road, who owns an English Cocker Spaniel, Whiskey is worried as she doesn’t know when she’d get to buy meat again. “I also feed the street dogs here. We have to shift to rice and pulses. As we hadn’t anticipated this situation, we have to make do with the food we have stored for us, but it’s not sustainable,” said the IT professional.

Those relying on food from pet stores aren’t that lucky either. “We have been trying to get passes from the DCP’s office. There are frantic calls from pet parents. We open every couple of days for a few hours and help them. The shop was extremely crowded on Thursday. With no meat supply, people are stocking up on dog/cat kibble. Stocks are running out,” said Ritima Coelho, co-founder, Heads up for tails, Magrath road.

Officials in the department of animal husbandry said transportation of chicken will be smoother in the coming days and the problem will get sorted. “There’s no hard-and-fast rule on the shutdown of stores. The issue was with the transportation of chicken. There has been a meeting on this and things will be better soon,” said S Shashi Kumar, joint director, department of animal husbandry, BBMP.

Title: Police dept’s water cannon used to sanitize govt bldgs
Content:
Coimbatore: A 23-year-old water cannon used to disperse crowds came in handy for police on Friday when it was taken out to spray bleach solution at the office of city police commissioner, ESI Hospital and Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH).

The state government had provided the vehicle to the city police in 1997 for mob control. But it was seldom used. The vehicle was used to douse fire at a building on Lakshmi Mills junction and another fire near the G. Kuppuswamy Naidu Memorial Hospital a few years ago.

“We plan to use the vehicle to disinfect all government buildings in the city,” deputy commissioner of police S Selvakumar said.

The 24,000-kilogram vehicle has a 16,000-litre tank and a 500-litres additional tank.

Selvakumar said that police vehicles were also sanitized on Friday. “We have santisized all police stations in the city.”

Cops have been ordered to seize the vehicles of those who come out of homes deliberately, the officer said. “We found many motorists roaming through the city. They claimed they were out to buy medicines and vegetables. We have decided to seize the vehicles of such people.”

Title: Over 1,000 in home quarantine in Pune district seek health check
Content: PUNE: Sixty medical teams, comprising doctors and nurses, will visit each of the 1,065 home quarantined persons who called for a health check saying they felt they had ‘ coronavirus symptoms’.As many as 22,475 people from Pune city, Pimpri Chinchwad and the rural areas of the district are in home quarantine.Earlier, the district administration would advise such cases to report to the local doctors. Now, a medical team will take up house visits.These persons have returned from high risk countries or are related to those who travelled to such countries or friends who have been in touch with those who travelled abroad.“Those who said they felt the symptoms have got in touch with us. Our teams will check whether there is any cause for concern,” zilla parishad CEO Ayush Prasad told TOI.The district administration has divided the monitoring into hospitalisation, isolation and quarantine.Hospitalisation is for a serious patient and isolation is being done at Naidu hospital in Pune and YCM hospital in Pimpri Chinchwad.Institutional quarantine is for those who cannot be managed at home and home quarantine is when they can manage, V Deshmukh , in-charge of the district administration’s quarantine monitoring facility, said.Home quarantine is monitored by health, revenue and police teams. “Our team monitors them and once they rule out Covid-19 symptoms, they continue staying in quarantine and are checked at the end of it,’’ the officials added.A web portal has been created for health authorities to supervise people under home quarantine. The portal http://www.idsp.mkcl.org, will require them to create an account with their cellphone number and submit details of their travel history, and update after 12 hours, their health observations and the precautions they are taking.“They can stay in contact with health officials and report their progress,” Prasad added. Doctors will register and fill in the details of patients who they feel are showing some symptoms.Each person has to provide information pertaining to travel history, details of the symptoms like sore throat, sneezing, fever, chest discomfort and information about the doctor they are consulting.

Title: Man forced into isolation kills himself, another tweets of suicidal thoughts
Content:
Trichy/Coimbatore: Loneliness can kill. Just a few days into the nationwide shutdown, and some people are going to the extreme. A 29-year-old man forced to live in isolation committed suicide in his farm house at Maramadakki village in Pudukkottai district on Friday. And in Coimbatore, police rescued a man living alone who tweeted that he was having suicidal thoughts.

Police said C Suresh of Maramadakki village had gone into depression after his parents and elder brother refused to let him into the house last week fearing he could be infected with Covid-19.

Suresh had gone to the Maldives in 2019. After working there for a few months, he returned to Pudukkottai on January 15. From there he went to Tirupur in search of a job. He had to return because of the nationwide shutdown.

His family insisted that he remain in isolation and sent him to the farm house.

C Balu, his elder brother said they suspected Suresh may be infected with Covid-19 since he returned from the Maldives and decided to keep him in isolation for a few days.

“Though he didn’t like it, he stayed in the farm house and we didn’t allow children from our house to meet him,” said Balu.

On Friday morning, when a relative went to give him breakfast, Suresh was found hanging from the ceiling of the house.

The Aranthangi police have filed a case and are investigating.

In Coimbatore, a 35-year-old private bank employee from GN Mills tweeted that he was alone at home and was having suicidal thoughts. He tagged his tweet to the Union home ministry.

Coimbatore city police commissioner Sumit Sharan, who noticed the tweet, informed SP Sujit Kumar to send cops to GN Mills. The man told two sub-inspectors from the Thudiyalur station who rushed to the place that his parents were in Kotagiri in the Nilgiris and he unable to travel there. Police promised to take him to his parents’ house.

To distract him, they asked him to join them in checking vehicles at GN Mills junction.

Later, officials instructed police to allow him to go to Kotagiri in his own vehicle.

“His parents left for Kotagiri a week ago. So, he was alone in the house at GN Mills and he felt mentally sick. He has now reached his home town safely and is all right now,” said sub-inspector Dhamodaran.

Title: Undeterred, a health worker drawing inspiration from others
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Guru Prasad Satpathy is a contractual health worker at Capital Hospital . The 40-year-old provides assistance to patients — facilitates their consultation and admission, helps them get their tests done while also assisting nurses. Satpathy, who has been doing this for as long as he can remember, knows the perils of his profession, especially in this testing times. But he is not afraid because like him, there are others who are putting their lives at risk to defeat coronavirus Satpathy leaves his two-room asbestos home in Dhauli area, on the outskirts of the city, for the hospital at 7am every day.“I am not scared. After many years of working in a hospital, this comes naturally to me. I am not the only one who is working in this difficult time. There are many like me. I know my work is important and I am taking all precautions like wearing gloves and masks and washing my hands frequently,” said Satpathy, adding that his family members are worried. “Their concern is obvious,” he said.Satpathy is the only earning member in a family of five, including his father, wife and two children. He gets a consolidated amount of Rs 10,000 per month. His shift starts at 8 in the morning.“I generally work with critical patients like accident victims, those who have tried to commit suicide by consuming poison and elderly persons. I also work with critical patients in the ICU,” he added.On Wednesday morning, while Satpathy was going to work, he was stopped by policemen who were out on the streets to impose the lockdown. He showed them his identity card and they allowed him to go.“They are also doing their duty like me. I see doctors and nurses who are working day and night during this emergency. But I feel doctors and nurses have better protection than lower level health workers,” said Satpathy, who volunteered to come to work amid the lockdown.“I have served patients suffering from HIV/AIDS, swine flu, Hepatitis B, cholera and other diseases. But Covid-19 is different. We can only hope and pray for this to end quickly,” Satpathy said.EoM

Title: Individuals, NGOs give food to poor people in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik district administration has said that many individuals and non-governmental organisations have come forward to provide ready meals to the needy people.

“At this point of time, we have about 33 individuals and about 18 organisations who have expressed their readiness to serve the food to the needy people. Rough estimates show they can provide food to about 10,000 people,” a senior officer from the district administration’s Emergency Operating Centre (EOC) said.

The official said that the administration is compiling a list of people, who require food and at the same time the areas they need it. While the city has the highest numbers, the food requirement is also there in talukas like Sinnar, Niphad, Malegaon, Chandwad, etc.

There is a strict advisory to all the individuals and orgnaisations while mingling with people — be it procuring goods, cooking food, packaging, transporting and even serving. “The kind of emergency today is completely different from the other times. Today, there should be no human to human contact at all. Hence, the task of ensuring food has to be delivered in the most hygienic condition is of prime importance. This is the reason for the coordination,” the officer said.

As the country is under lockdown, the movement of people has to be minimised. The movement of vehicles also has been suspended until further notice. In such a case, the transportation of the food grains or ready meals to the areas has to be done with prior permission. “We are facilitating the same. The NGOs and individuals would be given passes by the police, which will further help to feed the people,” the officer added.

On Thursday, as many as 1950 people were given food at various places by the individuals and the NGOs. The meals were distributed to tribals in Takli village, Gandhi Nagar, Rokdobachi Wadi , Aurangabad Naka , Peth Road canal, Kalika Mata Mandir, Tapovan and other areas.

Title: Fisherman stranded in Mangaluru reach Erode
Content:
Erode: The fisheries department of Karnataka brought 664 fishermen from Rameswaram, who were stranded in Mangaluru , in special vehicles and dropped them at the Erode district border on Friday evening.

Now, the Erode district administration has arranged food and shelter for them and taking steps to send them to Rameswaram.

“We went to Mangaluru about a month ago for fishing activities,” K Manimaran, one of the fishermen told TOI. He said more than 1,500 fishermen went to Mangaluru from Tamil Nadu for fishing activities.

Following total curfew across the country, the fishermen were asked to return to shore from sea. They reached the Mangaluru shore on Thursday morning and approached the fisheries department there.

The officials arranged 28 vehicles to send all the 664 fishermen to Rameswaram. All the 28 vehicles reached Karapallam, the bordering check post on Tamil Nadu – Karnataka border in Erode district, around 4pm on Friday. The fisheries department officials have also handed over a letter from the Karnataka government to the Tamil Nadu policemen at the check post, who informed the district administration.

Erode collector C Kathiravan instructed the policemen to arrange vehicles to bring them from Karapallam to Erode town.

Talking to TOI, the collector said he has taken steps to send all the 664 fishermen to Rameswaram in 16 government buses. “We have spoken to the government and obtained special permission,” he said, adding that, the doctors and the nurses from the health department were checking all the fishermen whether they have any coronavirus symptoms. “We also have given them precautionary medicines and will send them to Rameswaram with all the precautionary measures,” he added.

Title: Odisha: Villagers seal entry points to keep coronavirus at bay
Content: KENDRAPADA: As the fear of coronavirus continues to grow by the day, residents of Kendrapada district have set up checkpoints and banned outsiders from entering their villages.“We have put up barricades on both sides of the roads in our village and set up 24-hour checkpoints in the fear that those returning may bring the virus along with them,” Sarbeswar Pradhan, the sarpanch of Gupti gram panchayat, said.Several villages have been sealed with makeshift road blocks and signboards saying, ‘Visitors are prohibited as a precaution against coronavirus.’At many places, residents have also asked migrant workers, who returned to their villages recently from Delhi, Mumbai, Surat and other places to remain in home isolation and informed the authorities concerned about them.Rasmita Sahani, the sarpanch of Satabhaya gram panchayat under Rajnagar block said, “We do not want others to visit our village until the situation limps back to normal. Around 120 youths of our gram panchayat have returned from Kerala , Punjab and Delhi recently. Most of them work as plumbers and in plywood factories. Many have come back in groups. Such people, who go to other states to seek work, often travel in groups. They sleep and eat together. If one of them contracts the virus, it can easily spread to the others. Therefore, we have advised them to stay in isolation in their homes on their return.” He added, We have also asked the villagers to inform us immediately if they find someone who has returned from other cities to their villages. We are also enlisting the names of all the migrant workers who returned from other states in the recent past.”The barricades at the entry points will not only help prevent outsiders from entering the village, but also stop villagers from leaving. “We will allow some villagers to go to the nearby places to buy vegetables, fish and other essential commodities at best,” Kumar Swain, the sarapanch of Kurundi gram panchayat, said.When contacted, Narahari Sethi, the additional district magistrate (ADM) of Kendrapada said, “The arrival of a large numbers of migrant workers to their villages in Kendrapada district and its nearby areas from Kerala, Punjab , Delhi , Gujarat , Maharashtra and other states recently has exposed the locals to coronavirus as they returned without going through any screening. As a result, the local residents have put up barricades in their villages and are providing information to the district administration about the arrival of migrant workers in their villages”.Mirza Babbar Beig, the additional district medical officer of Kendrapada said, “We are monitoring and screening the health of the migrant workers who arrived in the district. Health officials are preparing a database of the migrant workers with the help of the district administration. They will remain in home quarantine for the next 14 days. Authorities will take legal action against the workers under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by the public servant) and 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life ) and 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code and under the provisions of the Epidemic Disease Act, 1897 if they violate the lockdown order.”

Title: Nashik: 31 schools in rural areas to be used as quarantine facilities
Content: NASHIK: The district administration has identified 31 schools in rural areas that will be converted into isolation wards for suspect patients.While Covid-19 positive patients will be put up in isolation wards in hospitals across Nashik city, those requiring institutional quarantine will be sent to these facilities spread across 15 talukas of Nashik district.The health officials have already made arrangements for the quarantine process in which 45 ambulances, three each in every taluka, will be dedicated to transport patients.According to senior officials from the district administration and health departments, civil hospital has 66 beds and Zakir Hussain hospital has 100 beds for isolation purpose in the phase 1 of the treatment . For phase 2, Covid-19 patients would be rushed to SMBT Hospital in Igatpuri and Vasantrao Pawar Medical College in Adgaon.In phase 3 of the treatment, if cases rise, patients would be lodged in private and corporate hospitals that will be acquired by the government for the period during which the treatment has to be provided.“The institutionalized quarantine facility was required for people who have travel history and are violating home-quarantine guidelines or the ones from high risk groups, immediate relatives of Covid-19 patients, or the ones from low risk groups who have met Covid-19 patients,” an official said.The 31 government and government-aided schools across the district will serve as quarantine facilities for such group of citizens. “The administration will provide food, water, electricity and entertainment channels at these centres for the inmates,” the official said.Every room of the school will havee two beds required for the patients. Apart from this, a quarantine facility will be raised at Barnes School outside Nashik city. The need for institutional quarantine is felt for two reasons — first as precautionary measure and second for those who fail to remain indoors.District has a total of 517 passengers from with travel history of which 409 have been home quarantined and two are institutionally quarantined in Tapovan. Also 106 people are out of surveillance after having completed the 14-day observation period and failed to show any symptoms. So far, 65 samples were collected of which 60 have been found negative and the reports of five are still awaited.“Nashik has no positive patient at this point in time,” the official said.

Title: 11 truck drivers stranded in Andhra return home
Content:
Dharmapuri: The 11 truck drivers, who have been stuck in Andhra Pradesh without food and shelter since Tuesday, reached their homes on Friday.

MDMK MP Vaiko, meanwhile, urged the AIADMK government to help other stranded truck drivers from the state to return home. It is to be noted that at least 30 truck drivers from Salem and Dharmapuri districts are stuck in Jodpur in Rajasthan with loads.

M Chinnasamy, 29, of Thippireddihalli village near Bommidi in Dharmapuri, one of the 11 truck drivers returned home, said they had gone to Hyderabad to unload plywood sheets from Perumbavoor town near Cochin in Kerala. “Nine others are from my locality, while the remaining one is from Uthankarai in Krishnagiri district. We started from Kerala in six trucks on March 22,” he said.

When they reached Dharmapuri on Monday, they checked with the consignors, who asked them to proceed further without worrying about the lockdown. “We reached Andhra Pradesh at 2am on Friday, but police there denied permission to go further,” Chinnasamy said.

When the drivers attempted to buy vegetable, the local policemen chased them away. “One of the drivers, who was not part of our team, was injured in lathi-charge. We had nothing to eat until Wednesday night,” he said. Finally, the truck drivers posted a video mentioning their plight on social media. Following that, a few people from Dharmapuri contacted their friends in Hyderabad who arranged them food and shelter. They also took up the issue with officials in Hyderabad and arranged a vehicle for the drivers to return to their homes.

Similarly, another 30 drivers from Salem and Dharmapuri districts are stranded in Jodpur in Rajasthn with loads. They have urged the state government to take steps to bring them back at the earliest.

Vaiko said there are truck drivers who have been stuck in other states for more than 20 days. “They are struggling for food and water. The state government led by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami should take necessary steps to bring all the stranded truck drivers back to their native places at the earliest,” he said.

Title: No doc to keep tabs, norms flouted: Patient at JP Hosp
Content:
Bhopal: “I feared getting infected with COVID-19 while awaiting my test report in JP hospital for four days,” said a person with foreign travel history. The person had walked into the district hospital to get tested and was kept in the isolation ward, that flouts many COVID-19 guidelines, including that of infection control. Subsequently, the person has tested negative for COVID-19.

The patient, whose identity is not being disclosed, narrated the ordeal. “I informed authorities about my self-isolation on returning to Bhopal. No one from the health department checked my status at home. Around day 9, I reached out for help as I had mild fever and requested a test. I was told that the test sample would be collected from my home. But with no response for two days, I walked into JP hospital seeking a COVID-19 test,” the person said.

Surprisingly, Bhopal IDSP, Dr Rashmi Jain, the nodal person for all travellers’ seeking test and guidence, blocked the person’s number. Despite repeated efforst by TOI, Jain did not respond to this.

On the 11th day after the traveller returned to Bhopal, the person waited for a doctor from 5 pm till 9.30 pm. Finally, the doctor arrived at 10 pm. “I was told that since I have reported the case to the call centre, I will not be allowed to return home until the test for COVID-19 is negative. If I did, police would be informed,” the affected person told TOI.

The person was led to an eight-bed COVID-19 isolation ward. “It lacked bed spacing requirements for infection control purposes. Men and women are in the same ward and a dedicated toilet for females was used by all,” the person said.

After samples were taken, for the next two days, no doctor checked on the suspected patients. “On day 4 of my hospital stay, I received a message that my test is negative. However, I was not allowed to leave since the doctor on duty was not present,” the person alleged.

Government guidelines for COVID-19 isolation instructs ‘patient placement: keep a minimum of 1–2 metre inter-bed distance’.

The minimum bed space in both single and multi-bed rooms should not be less than 3.6m (width) x 3.7m (depth). 2 Four-bed rooms require a total area of 72.5m, as per EU norms.

Ahead of ‘Corona control vertical’, a top COVID-19 team that directly reports to the state government, JP hospital managed to increase the width of signage in the hospital. When contacted, health department and JP hospital superintendent did not respond.

Title: Collector says no to ‘traditional cure’
Content:
Coimbatore: Collector K Rajamani on Thursday rejected the offer of the zone in-charge of the Pradhan Mantri Jan Kalyankari Yojana (PMJKY) to distribute ayurvedic medicines to 3,000 people to fight Covid-19.

As many as six organisations had approached the district administration claiming to cure Covid-19 using ayurvedic and siddha combinations, Rajamani said. “We also had four people claiming they could track the cases and treatment using apps. I ignored the suggestions as no ayurveda or siddha medicine has been scientifically proven to be effective against the virus. We can’t be tracking people when we are dealing with such a crisis,” he said.

The PMJKY group claimed they could treat the condition with a combination of nochi leaves and turmeric.TNN

Title: Tamil Nadu govt asks grocers to shut by 2.30pm, food apps get nod
Content:
15,000 beds ready for Covid-19 patients

CHENNAI: The state government on Friday announced that Koyambedu wholesale vegetable market, vegetable shops and grocery outlets will remain open between 6am and 2.30pm to control movement of people on the roads. Vehicles carrying goods to Koyambedu market from other parts of the state and other states will be allowed to unload only between 6pm and 6am. “The announcements will come into effect from Sunday,” said an official release issued after CM Edappadi K Palaniswami held a review meeting with officials.Similarly, fuel pumps will remain open between 6am and 2.30pm. Exclusive pumps for government vehicles and 108 ambulance services will, however, be operated throughout the day. Pharmacies and restaurants, where only takeaway is allowed, can operate through the day.As elderly citizens and those who are unable to cook, book online for cooked food, the government has allowed aggregators Swiggy, Zomato and Uber Eats to supply between 7am and 9.30am, 12 noon to 2.30pm and 6pm to 9pm as a special case. The aggregators will have to get identity cards from police for the workforce and get them engaged only after a thorough health check-up. PM Modi on Friday asked the CM to strictly enforce prohibitory orders in TN to combat the virus spread.An official statement said the PM had telephoned in the morning and checked up with the chief minister the preventive measures taken against Covid-19 in the state, and the initiatives taken by the various state departments.“The chief minister apprised the PM of the measures being taken by the state. The PM requested strict enforcement of Section 144 for the well-being of the people, and the state to ensure that people isolate themselves. He requested the CM to ensure availability of essential commodities for the public,” the release said. Palaniswami had replied to the PM that the government was implementing all of them.The state administration swung into action to quarantine by Saturday all 96,063 persons with travel history from February 15 and those who arrived at state airports or other airports in the country and entered Tamil Nadu.About 15,000 beds are kept ready across the state to treat Covid-19 patients. Coimbatore ESI hospital with 350 beds has been converted into Covid-19 special hospital.

Title: Shoppers in Salcete rush to stock up
Content:
Margao/Colva: Panic-buying marked Day 3 of the lockdown in South Goa after chief minister Pramod Sawant allowed grocery shops , milk booths and vegetable stalls to remain operational.

By the time shops opened on Friday in Margao, people had already formed serpentine queues outside, spilling onto the streets. Though slots were marked for them to maintain social distancing, these were breached at several places. The Margao municipal market and SGPDA market remained shut.

Despite several people, including foreigners, making a beeline at major grocery stores in Salcete ’s coastal belt early Friday morning, none was open due to lack of stocks.

While smaller shops upped their shutters at around 8.30am, vegetable and fruit vendors began doing business from 7am. Many even made a quick buck by selling staples such as onions and tomatoes at Rs 80 per kg. Sources in the South Goa district administration said the police have been asked to advise people, through a public-address system, to maintain social distancing while shopping.

Meanwhile, beach shack operators in Salcete are already in the process of dismantling their temporary structures. The tourist season usually ends in May.

Title: 450 undertrial prisoners released on bail from jails across Maharashtra
Content:
The state department of prisons started releasing undertrial prisoners on bail granted by courts as per the re... Read More

PUNE: The state department of prisons on Friday released around 450 undertrial prisoners from jails across the state, including 18 from the Yerawada prison, on bail as per court orders in view of the Covid-19 spread.

All these prisoners are facing trial for property offences, among others, in which the punishment is not more than seven years.

Additional director general of police (prisons) Sunil Ramanand told TOI, “On the first day, we have released around 450 undertrial prisoners from various jails in the state after receiving bail orders from the courts. All jail superintendents are holding meeting with district-wise judicial officials and are giving them the list of the prisoners to be released on bail because of coronavirus.”

He said the courts were issuing bail orders as per a letter released by the high power committee (HPC) set up at the behest of the Supreme Court. “The process of releasing the undertrial prisoners on bail will continue till all those, who meet the criteria set by the committee, are released from the central and district jails in the next few days,” Ramanand said.

These prisoners will be released on regular bail. Those involved in serious offences will be released on interim bail.

“The process for the release of convicts on parole sentenced to seven years or lesser terms will begin next week. This is because the state government is in the process of amending rule 9 of the Bombay Parole and Furlough Act 1959 authorising jail superintendents to grant emergency parole to convicts for a specific period because of coronavirus,” Ramanand said.

UT Pawar, superintendent of the Yerawada prison, told TOI, “On the first day, we have released 18 undertrial prisoners on bail as per the courts order. We have received a list to release another 80 such prisoners from the judiciary through our legal department. Since the list was received after the office hours, a decision to release them will be taken on Saturday after verifying their criminal antecedents.”

Pawar said, “For instance, If an undertrial prisoner has been granted bail in one case but s/he is involved in two or more cases, then we will submit a report to the judiciary giving details of his criminal antecedents. If the judiciary takes a call in granting them bail in other cases, the prisoner will be released forthwith.”

“If an UTP is involved in one case, s/he will be instantly released on bail on completion of legal formalities like receiving certified copies of the bail order and executing the bond before the concerned courts,” he added.

Title: Essential item stores can remain open 24x7 in Rajasthan
Content: JAIPUR: The state government has issued directions to all collectors to ensure regular supply of food items to people during the lockdown period.Food and civil supplies secretary Siddharth Mahajan said shops selling groceries, essential commodities and medicines could remain open 24x7 in the state. But persons coming to grocery stores cannot come with vehicles.“People can go to grocery stores on foot or on bicycles,” the secretary said, adding door-to-door and online deliveries should be encouraged so that people need not go to the market for their daily needs during this period.Mahajan said proper distance between customers would have to be maintained at grocery stores and pharmacies by shopkeepers or through local bodies or police. During this period, more than five people cannot gather in one place.Mahajan said permission should be given for door-to-door sale of fruits and vegetables. “But only one family member will be allowed to purchase the items,” he added. He said cycle rickshaws and e-rickshaw will be allowed for home deliveries so that they can earn some money.He said the local district administration should coordinate with the local bodies and police and talk to trade associations and encourage them for maximum door-to-door delivery. He said there was no area where home delivery could not be arranged. Cooperative consumer stores should ensure that essential items are sold through mobile shops for adequate supply of daily use items.Mahajan informed that a committee had been constituted under the chairmanship of the district collector to streamline distribution of materials to the public in the state.He said the instructions had been issued by the medical and health department which have to be followed by the personnel and drivers employed for operating mobile shops. The list of wholesalers will be made available to all the retailers in the district so that they can get materials.

Title: Nine cops injured in attack by Baramati residents
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A police inspector, three officers and five constables were injured in an attack by a group of six to seven local residents in Baramati following an argument on Friday afternoon. At the time, the police team was on a drive to check persons ordered into home quarantined.

The group snatched sticks belonging to the police personnel and assaulted them with the sticks and stones. An officer from the Baramati city police told TOI that, as per government orders, persons in home quarantine must be checked to ensure they do not step out of their homes. The police team was walking on the public road, which leads to the residence a person in home quarantine.

According to the police, the group snatched the sticks and assaulted the team members. The police registered a case against the suspects late on Friday night and four suspects were detained. The injured police personnel were taken to a local hospital.

Woman assaults husband

The Baramati city police on Thursday booked a woman for assaulting her husband with a sharp weapon and beating her mother-in-law after she was asked to check if she was infected with the coronavirus.

Title: SCR sets up essential goods market at stn
Content:
Hyderabad: South Central Railway ( SCR ), in collaboration with the local municipal administration has set up a temporary market at the Guntakal railway station premises for the sale of vegetables, fruits and other essentials in light of the Covid-19 lockdown.

“The arrangement at the market in railway grounds includes numbered and demarcated spaces to set up stalls. Lines are drawn on the ground to maintain social distance among customers to ensure no possibility of physical contact,” read an official release from SCR.

Officials inform that they are aiming at overcoming the congestion at the existing markets while maintaining the requirements of social distancing. “The market was established in a day. We are also providing parking arrangements for the convenience of the customers,” chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh said.

“With the municipal administration handling the market which functions from 6 am till 9 am every day, possibilities of black marketing, quoting of exorbitant rates and sale of sub-standard products sold is eliminated,” he added.

Title: Uzhavar sandhais, major mkts to function as usual
Content:
Coimbatore: The district administration on Friday had a trial run of uzhavar sandhais in R S Puram and Singanallur for three hours from 6am to 9am. Following the successful run, it announced the plans to open around 10 major markets, which would function at their usual working hours , from Saturday. The move is expected to bring relief to many households that were struggling to procure their weekly supply of vegetables.

The district administration had on Thursday begun marking slots at a gap of every 1m in uzhavar sandhais and vegetable markets for people to stand and buy essentials, without compromising on social distancing.

While the slots were marked all the way from roads that lead up to the markets expecting a large turnout, uzhavar sandhais on Friday drew only a fraction of a crowd as the public were by and large not aware of their opening.

“In R S Puram, around 30 farmers from nearby locations had turned up, but it drew only around 100 customers over the three hours. They all stood in the slots and moved forward,” said a security officer at uzhavar sandhai. “Tomorrow, we expect more farmers and more customers.”

District collector K Rajamani also visited uzhavar sandhai and was satisfied with the progress.

After the successful trial run, the district administration said six uzhavar sandhai branches - four in the city and one each in Pollachi and Mettupalayam would start functioning from Saturday.

The collector also said the portion of Thiyagi Kumaran Market on Raja Street would function out of Gandhipuram city bus stand, while Ramar Temple Market in Ukkadam will function out of Ukkadam bus stand. Anna Market on Mettupalayam Road would, meanwhile, continue to function in the same area, but in shifts.

Officials said this decision was made as bus stands could offer more open space and flat ground, to ensure social distancing.

Farmers and wholesalers have been instructed to put up shops at a 1.5m distance from each other and ensure customers also maintain a 1m gap from each other and stand only in the slots marked for them.

Title: Gajapati panchayats to get temporary health centres, isolation wards
Content:
BERHAMPUR: In view of the coronavirus outbreak, the Gajapati district authorities will set up a temporary health centre along with an isolation ward in each panchayat.

School buildings with electricity, water supply and toilet facilities will be turned into such centres with at least 20 beds in each. Sources said health staffers from the nearby government-run hospitals will be deputed at the centres to look after patients.

“Of the 149 panchayats in the district, 83 of them already have temporary health centres,” district collector Anupam Saha said. “We will add more centres in the coming days,” he added.

“The temporary health centres will not only treat covid-19 suspects or patients, but those suffering from other ailments can visit them for checkup. We have taken all necessary precautions,” Saha said.

This apart, there are about 30 government-run health centres in the district. It includes the district headquarters hospital, eight community health centres and 21 primary health centres.

The move assumes significance as more than 4,128 people from outside the state and the country have returned to the district as the entire world went in a lockdown.

“We have asked every returnee to be in home isolation for at least two weeks,” Saha said. A dedicated health team in Paralakhemundi keeps track of their health status, he added.

“Of the 49 people who have returned from abroad, three have completed their 14-day quarantine order. They are in good health,” the collector said.

Saha further said the district administration has decided to send swab samples of the people who came from the foreign countries to the ICMR Bhubaneswar as a precautionary measure.

Title: Hyderabad man with withdrawal symptoms falls off building
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A painter who was allegedly exhibiting alcohol withdrawal symptoms fell from the third floor of a government quarters in Banjara Hills Road No 10 in the wee hours of Friday. The victim’s withdrawal symptoms are believed to have been caused by non-availability of alcohol due to the lockdown in the state. Police are trying to ascertain if the death was caused by an accidental fall or suicide.

Banjara Hills police said that the painter, who resides in Indira Nagar colony in Banjara Hills left his residence late on Thursday night. At around 4 am on Friday, he entered the government quarters’ premises, where government employees of various departments reside and went to the terrace on the third floor.

“On hearing someone on the terrace, the family which resides on the floor below went to the terrace and found someone slipping from top of the building. According to the family of the deceased, the painter was an alcoholic. They said that he had been behaving weirdly for the past few days as he was unable to purchase alcohol,’’ Banjara Hills Inspector Kalinga Rao said. Based on the complaint given by the family, a case was registered under Section 304-a(Negligence causing death) of IPC.

Title: Unseasonal rain flattens standing crops in Niphad
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The agriculture department has started a survey to ascertain the damage incurred to the crops in Nashik district following rainfall in the last few days.

Officials from the agriculture department said that standing crops and vineyards on over 1,000 hectare in Vinchur and Naitale villages in Niphad taluka was damaged. They are also seeking feedback from farmers in other talukas of the district about the damage to their crops.

Unseasonal rain lashed parts of Niphad taluka on late Thursday night and and early Friday.

An official from the state agriculture department said, “Rainfall, coupled with hail, damaged crops like wheat, onion and grapes.”

The standing crops in Malegoan, Igatpuri and Trimbakeshwar talukas have also incurred partial damage due to the rainfall. Crops like onions, wheat and gram have been damaged in these talukas.

Most of the farmers have already harvested wheat and gram. “The crops which were about to be harvested have been damaged,” said officials. Farmer Sanjay Sathe said, “Rainfall in Naitale village in Niphad taluka on Thursday night damaged most of the ready-to-harvest vineyards.”

The hails had crack open the ready-to-harvest grapes in most of the vineyards. This was a huge loss for farmers who had invested lakhs of rupees in the vineyards, added Sathe.

“The grape farmers in the district are passing through a very tough phase. Around 30% of the vineyards in the district are yet to be harvested. Farmers are unable to harvest vineyards as they are not getting labourers due to the lockdown imposed as a result of the coronavirus outbreak,” said Manik Patil, a senior member of Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh , an association of grape growers.

“The unseasonal rainfall, which lashed the ready-to-harvest vineyards, have added to the woes of the grape growers,” said Patil.

Title: CA exams between June 19 and July 4 in India
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Chartered Accountants examination scheduled to be held from May 2 to 18 has been rescheduled between June 19 and July 4 because of the Covid-19 infection in India.

A notification uploaded on The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India website on Friday stated that the foundation course examination would be held on June 27 and 29, and July 1 and 3. The intermediate (IPC) course examination (old syllabus) would be held for Group 1 on June 20, 22, 24 and 26, while for Group 2 it has been scheduled on June 28 and 30, and then July 2.

Intermediate course examination (new syllabus) would be held for Group 1 on June 20, 22, 24 and 26. For Group 2, it would be held on June 28 and 30, and then July 2 and 4.

Final course examinations for both old and new syllabus would be held for Group 1 on June 19, 21, 23 and 25, and for Group 2 on June 27 and 29, and then July 1 and 3.

International trade laws and World Trade Organisation part 1 examination would be held for Group A on June 20 and 22, while the same for Group B would be held on June 24 and 26. International law taxation-assessment test would be held on June 27 and 29.

“It may be emphasized that there would be no change in the examination schedule in the event of any day of the examination schedule being declared a public holiday by the Union or any state governments/local holiday. Candidates may note that two of the papers — paper (s) 3 and 4 of foundation examination — are of two-hour duration. Similarly, elective paper — 6 of final examination (under new scheme) is of four hours. All other examinations are of three-hour duration,” said S K Garg, the additional secretary (examinations), in the notification.

Title: PM calls Naidu hospital staffer, applauds role of nurses in fight against Covid-19
Content: PUNE: A senior nursing staffer at the civic-run Naidu Hosital was pleasantly surprised on Friday afternoon when Prime Minister Narendra Modi called her on her personal cellphone and extended his appreciation.“A total of 60 nurses are involved in the care of patients diagnosed with the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection at Naidu Hospital. When the PM’s office contacted us on Thursday for information on the nurses working at Naidu Hospital, we provided them with some names. On Friday, the PM called one of the nurses, Chaya Jagtap, working as a nurse at Naidu Hospital for 20 years now. He spoke to her and expressed his appreciation for her work and many other front-line nurses across the country who are so bravely dispensing their duties and boosting moral of patients undergoing treatment under their care,” said public health expert Sanjeev Wavare, the in-charge of Naidu Hospital, which is one of the designated isolation units for treatment of Covid-19 in Pune.

Title: Viral trail remains mystery in case of three Karnataka patients
Content:
Bengaluru: Of the 64 positive Covid-19 cases in Karnataka so far, 15, or 23%, have no history of travelling to any of the affected countries. These patients include a doctor and a security guard besides wives, daughters and domestic helps who had come in contact with persons who tested positive after having travelled to an affected country.

However, three cases have left doctors puzzled as they do not appear – at least from an initial tracing of their movements – to have had contact with a positive patient. They include a 10-month-old baby boy, a 60-year-old man from Tumakuru who died on Friday and a 35-year-old Mysurean.

The baby though had accompanied his parents to Kerala, while the Tumakuru man had been to Delhi. The Mysurean was employed in the quality assurance section of a pharmaceutical company in Nanjangud near Mysuru and was in contact with many healthcare professionals, health department officials said.

“We will have to trace the movements of all three patients,” said Jawaid Akhtar, additional chief secretary, health and family welfare department. “We are in the process of tracing their travel history. There is no evidence of community spread yet. They could have come in contact with a positive patient.”

Officials admit that the spread of the virus does raise questions as all the other infections have been intra-family affairs or limited to primary contacts of the positive patients.

Three girls are among the infected, having contracted the virus from their fathers who had a history of travel to affected countries. Two of the girls are siblings. The girls’ mothers too tested positive.

The siblings, aged seven and nine, tested positive on March 25. Their father had returned from the Netherlands and tested positive in Bengaluru on March 21. His wife tested positive on March 23. The wife and daughter of the state’s first Covid-19 patient, a techie, also tested positive. Incidentally, all three have been discharged.

A 45-year-old man working as a security guard in Bengaluru tested positive on Thursday, four days after his 51-year-old employer returned from London tested positive on March 22. Three women working as domestic helps in households of positive patients with travel history to affected countries are among the infected.

“When we say suspected cases should be in home isolation, we don’t mean their interaction is restricted only to the world outside. They should be careful at home too,” said a senior health officer, who has been involved in monitoring home quarantine cases.

“There are mandatory self-hygiene and cough-hygiene guidelines that they have got to follow and they need to maintain the social distance at home too. Going by these cases, there appears to be sheer lapses. It’s extremely important to ensure possible carriers of the virus behave responsibly.”

Title: Vote-on-account approved, cabinet to issue ordinance
Content: Amaravati: The state cabinet has approved the vote-on- account for the first quarter of the next fiscal.The cabinet has decided to bring in an ordinance to secure permission to withdraw funds from the consolidated fund as the government could not convene the budget session to take the legislature’s approval due to the spread of Covid-19. The ordinance would be sent to governor for approval. “We will give details of the vote-on-account after getting the governor’s clearance,” information and public relations minister Perni Nani told the media on Friday.Sources said that the state government would be issuing an ordinance seeking withdrawal of Rs 70,900 crore from the consolidated fund from April, 1, 2020. The government is seeking permission for the withdrawal of the huge amount to meet the proposed welfare schemes as well as the health emergency cost.The annual budget was expected to be around Rs 1.8-1.9 lakh crore for 2020-2021. The officials readied the draft budget proposals before the outbreak of coronavirus . The officials in the finance ministry are now worried about further dip in the revenue in the coming financial year under the impact of Covid-19.At such rate, it was thought that the government might be seeking permission for withdrawal of around Rs 50,000 crore during the first quarter of the upcoming fiscal.However, the government is likely to issue an ordinance for over Rs 70,000 crore without mentioning any timeframe such as first quarter. “Although, we are expecting to completely control the spread of coronavirus and overcome the crisis shortly, it is very difficult to predict as to when the next session of assembly could be convened as the present situation is completely fluid. So, we thought of securing permission for withdrawal of funds without mentioning the time frame to avoid issuance of another ordinance,” said a senior minister.Sources said that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had expressed anguish about the conditions prevailing after the outbreak of Covid-19 at the cabinet meeting.He said there would be a severe impact on overall economic activity in the state as well as the country during the coming financial year. “We might require to walk the extra mile to ramp up revenue as we have to implement all our promises,” the CM told the ministers.

Title: Five held for attempt to stage folk dance
Content:
BERHAMPUR: At least five danduas or main actors of Danda Nata — which is a seasonal and popular folk dance at Allapur under Ganjam district ’s Hinjili police station limits — were on Friday arrested for trying to stage a performance flouting the government order .

“A case has been registered against them following complaints from the tehasildar of Hinjili,” Abhimanyu Das, inspector-in charge, Hinjili police station, said. He added that they were trying to organize Danda Nata despite the government prohibiting all social functions and asking people to maintain social distancing in the wake of the outbreak of Covid-19,

Earlier, the Hinjili and Purushottampur police had arrested seven and 10 Danduas, respectively, for violating the government order and organising Danda Nata in their villages.

This seasonal folk dance continues in for 21 days in Ganjam. At other places, it’s a fortnightly affair and ends on Maha Visubha Shankranti on April 13.

Title: App to keep track of quarantined persons in Gujarat
Content: AHMEDABAD/GANDHINAGAR: A smartphone application, developed initially by the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) to track persons under quarantine , will be used across Gujarat from Saturday. The app was launched in four other major cities of Gujarat — Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Rajkot, and Gandhinagar — on Friday.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health & family welfare), said that the app uses Geographic Information System (GIS) to track the person’s device in real time. “The application has a ‘geo fencing’ feature, which alerts authorities if a home-quarantined person moves out of a specific area,” Ravi added.As on Friday evening, the state police have recorded 570 instances of violation of quarantine rules in Gujarat. The offenders have been sent to government-run quarantine facilities.Health department officials said that the app asks the users — persons under quarantine — details such as their travel history. The app detects location and records information on hourly basis. If the device is out of the house, stipulated by the distance specified in the app, health officials are alerted. The users also provide details such as symptoms of fever, cough, or difficulty in breathing twice a day.“As of now, Gujarat has 20,103 persons under quarantine including 19,377 in home quarantine and 575 at government-run facilities,” said Ravi. “Cumulatively, 236 complaints have been filed against persons for the violation of quarantine rules.”In another initiative, the ImTeCHO (Innovative Mobile-phone Technology for Community Health Operators) app will be extended to state-based doctors and health professionals. “The doctors are encouraged to report COVID-19 symptoms such as severe acute respiratory illness (SARI) to the state government for quicker identification of patients,” said the principal secretary. “So far, about 150 doctors have become part of the initiative.”For the four newly-constructed facilities for COVID-19, the state government is approaching ex-servicemen to manage and maintain discipline at the facilities, said officials.Ravi also appealed to the healthcare community to come forward to provide voluntary service for treatment or training. “While we are procuring ventilators, we will need about 3,000 experts for operating 1,000 ventilators,” she said. “Thus, we have appealed to doctors to train technicians. We will provide an email on our official Twitter handle soon for the purpose.”

Title: 40,000 enter Solapur borders to escape coronavirus outbreak
Content: KOLHAPUR: The Solapur district administration has launched a massive drive to educate the people on possible coronavirus threats in view of the large scale of people arriving from major cities.So far, the district has not reported any positive case except for few people, who have been directed to undergo home quarantine.Many people, who had shifted to major cities in Maharashtra and Karnataka for employment, returned after the fear of coronavirus gripped the people across the nation.Just before the nationwide shutdown, a large number of vehicles carrying commuters entered Solapur district. Officials from district collectorate said that they have recorded around 40,000 names of people entering the district in the last few days.According to the officials, around 20,000 people came from Pune followed by 12,000 from Mumbai. Only after the country-wide shutdown three-days back that the arrival of people has been reduced as the district borders have been sealed by the district administration.Officials said that people are returning to their villages, which fall under the drought-prone areas. Those areas don’t even have basic facilities along with a lack of employment.In Sangol taluka, which has perennial drought conditions, around 5,000 people have arrived in the past few days. As many as 1500 people in Sangola have been advised home quarantine.In rural parts, the village level committees have been formed to monitor the movement of the guests and to ensure whether people are following government guidelines. The committees are using public address systems or traditional ‘dawandi’ to alert the people about government decisions.In Solapur city, the municipal corporation has put temporary 130 washbasins where people can wash the hands. The civic body has made online submission of the registration, which is mandatory for the guests. Around 100 people have registered so far.

Title: Poor response to APMC’s demand to bring onions in sacks, only 230 quintal auctioned
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The directive from Lasalgaon APMC to the onion farmers for bringing their produce packed in sacks has evoked lukewarm response.

As workers involved in loading and unloading of onions are not available due to the lockdown, the AMPC on Thursday had decided to conduct onion auction in sacks after demands were made by the traders.

Accordingly, the APMC had appealed to the farmers to bring their produce in sacks so that it becomes convenient for the traders to load the materials in their trucks.

However, majority of farmers stayed away from taking part in the auction on Friday as they could not afford to buy sacks that cost Rs 30 per piece. Moreover, availability of sacks is also an issue as most of the outlets are closed due to the lockdown.

Usually, the arrival of onions at Lasalgaon is between 15,000 and 20,000 quintal per day. However, on Friday only 230 quintal of onions were auctioned.

“Availability of workers is a major issue. Traders are not getting workers for loading, unloading, weighing, grading and packaging of onions. Due to this, market had to cbe losed on Thursday,” an APMC official said.

“We had convinced traders to start onion auction in the interest of farmers. Following discussion with traders, it was decided to conduct onion auction in sacks,” the official added.

The average wholesale onion price at Lasalgaon on Friday was recorded at Rs 1,600 per quintal as against Rs 1,250 per quintal on Monday. The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices were recorded at Rs 700 and Rs 1,680 per quintal, respectively.

“This has caused another burden on farmers as they will have to bear expenses for buying sacks. Hence, only loose auction of onions should be held,” Prakash Magar , an onion farmer, said.

Title: Another tests positive without travel history in Bhopal
Content: BHOPAL: Third positive case of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) was confirmed in the state capital, here on Friday. The patient was admitted to AIIMS Bhopal after he tested positive, said health department officials.After the news spread, the person’s family and tenants have been placed under quarantine by the health department. The family resides in Chandbadh area of Bhopal near the railway station. The person who has tested positive does not have a foreign travel history. He is working with Indian Railways and arrived in Bhopal around March 22. A day later he went to AIIMS Bhopal for COVID screening centre. There after consultation the patient’s swab sample was taken. After second test report was diagnosed as positive, the patient was admitted to AIIMS Bhopal.First positive case from Bhopal was reported on Sunday. The same patient’s father, a journalist was diagnosed with COVID-19 three days later. All the three patients are being treated in AIIMS Bhopal. The condition of the new patient is said to be stable.After the new positive case was confirmed, around one dozen people, in four families have been placed under quarantine. A person who is a tenant of the patient, was located in Chanderi.
