After orders of the district administration the person’s swab samples have been taken and sent for testing to DRDO Gwalior, said health department officials. Four more swab samples from the immediate family of the affected will be taken on Saturday, said officials.Local police has been instructed to oversee the enforcement of the quarantine and self-isolation of the families in Chandbadh. On Friday, seven more swab samples were taken from other parts of the city.

Title: Ganjam ramps ups infra to deal with coronavirus fallout
Content: BERHAMPUR: As migrant labourers troop back home in Ganjam district from coronavirus-hit states following the nationwide lockdown, the state government has decided to temporally reserve around 300 to 500 beds with ICU facilities for those who might show symptoms of coronavirus The district administration has identified the Tata Memorial Hospital at Sitalapalli, a newly constructed hospital building at Hinjili, the Chhatrapur Science College and the Women’s College in Bhanjanagar to turn them into care units to accommodate patients in case of their numbers increase.“Besides, as many as 274 beds have been exclusively reserved for Covid-19 patients in the existing government-run hospitals,” chief district medical officer (CDMO) R Jagadeesh Patnaik said.He, however, said no positive case was found in the district so far. “At least 15 people, who have been admitted in the isolation ward at MKCG Medical College and Hospital , have tested negative for novel coronavirus,” MKCG superintendent S K Mishra said.On Friday, one person suspecting to be infected was admitted for treatment, he added.Mishra said following instructions from the government, a meeting was held with MKCG faculty members to prepare duty charts among the doctors, including post-graduate students to attend to virus suspect patients.

Title: Valpoi & Vathadev locals block roads
Content:
Valpoi/Bicholim: In a bid to keep visitors away, residents from different wards of the Valpoi Municipal Council ( VMC ) blocked the roads leading to their areas with bamboo sticks and coconut palms. A similar action was taken by the villagers of Vathadev in Bicholim, on Thursday, when they erected a gate across a road traversing their village to stave off two-wheeler riders who were defying the state’s lockdown orders.

VMC chairperson Akhtar Ali Shah, meanwhile, advised all citizens to stay indoors. He said the civic body and other volunteers were ensuring that essential commodities reached the villagers’ homes. However, several people flouted social distancing norms when they thronged Valpoi market early Friday morning, prompting the council to order stores to close.

In Vathadev, residents have requested the police to maintain vigil and keep violators of the lockdown at bay.

Title: Activist booked for spreading fake news
Content: Calangute: Calangute police registered an offence against social activist Ramakrishna Jalmi on Friday for allegedly spreading a message on social media that a person residing in a resort near Calangute church had tested positive for coronavirus.

Title: Pune health workers shunning duties to face severe action
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The district administration on Friday issued a notification warning health workers of severe punishment if found shunning their crucial duties at private or government-run hospital in Pune.

The notification has been issued in the wake of the fear among health workers about contracting the Covid-19 infection. This has prompted many to stay away from work, causing reduction in their numbers at hospitals treating Covid-19 patients and other small nursing homes and clinics .

Bharati hospital has reported about 60% reduction in their paramedic force after an admitted woman tested positive for Covid-19. “We will initiate action against the erring doctors eschewing duty for violations of the norms of Disaster Management Act 2005, Maharashtra Covid-19 Containment Rules 2020 and Epidemic Act, 1897 already effective in Pune and adjoining areas,” divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar stated in the notification issued on March 26.

Eye surgeon Sanjay Patil, the president of the Indian Medical Association (IMA), Pune branch, said, “For medical staffers not reporting to duty at private hospitals, there are certain issues that need to be sorted. First lockdown has made the commute difficult for the medical staffers mainly paramedics. Again, there is a severe shortage of personal protective equipment in terms of masks and other gears for health workers.”

A doctor from Bharati hospital said, “As soon as the news about our hospital treating Covid-19 positive patient came out, almost 40% of nursing staffers have stopped reporting to work at Bharati hospital. More than the staff, their families are refusing to send them to duties fearing they will contract the contagion. Many of them have left for their native places.”

“Adding to the woes, our hospital canteen workers have fled and many dubbawalas are unable to supply tiffins to resident doctors. With the help of catering firm, we have now started providing meals to around 250 residents doctors at our hospital. Besides, we are also regularly holding their counselling sessions,” the doctor said.

Title: Two more positive cases in Bihar, total rises to 9
Content:
Patna: Two more Covid-19 positive cases were reported in Bihar on Friday, taking the total number of such cases to nine across the state.

Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of medical sciences (RMRI) director Dr Pradeep Das confirmed the two positive cases. “One person is from Siwan and had returned from Dubai, another is a Nalanda native and is a staffer at a private hospital on Bypass Road where the Munger resident, who died last Saturday, had initially gone for treatment,” Dr Das said, adding, “He is the second staff from that hospital to be infected with coronavirus.”

Siwan DM Amit Pandey said, “A three kilometre radius around the residence of the Covid-19 positive person who had returned from Dubai on March 21 has been quarantined. His 13 immediate family members have been shifted to the isolation ward of Maharajganj sub-divisional hospital and their samples will be sent for the test.”

This man had reached Nautan block in Siwan on March 21 via roadways from Lucknow. “On March 23, our team had gone for random checking to collect details of all those who had come from outside Bihar. That day, we met him and got his details, however he was asymptomatic. On March 25 he himself reported to us after feeling uneasy and was referred to NMCH,” Pandey said.

He added that this Dubai-returned man had been following all quarantine protocols and had not met anyone outside his family.

The Nalanda resident who was also confirmed positive for Covid-19 virus on Friday has no travel history. However, he was working at a private hospital on Bypass Road, where a Covid-19 positive Munger native, who died on Saturday, had gone for treatment.

On Thursday, a ward boy of that hospital had tested positive, after which the district administration got it sealed. Patna DM Kumar Ravi said, “The hospital is now being disinfected and all staff have been quarantined. He said even family members of those staff who have been found Covid-19 positive will be tested.”

Apart from the two hospital employees, two other contacts of the Munger native have already tested positive, which includes his 12-year-old nephew and a 35-year-old neighbour. Their report had come on late Wednesday night.

Apart from them, a city woman whose son had travelled from Italy and another city man who had returned from Scotland had tested positive on Sunday. Another Patna resident who had returned from Gujarat had tested positive on late Tuesday evening.

As per the daily Covid-19 bulletin issued by state health society on Friday, total 544 samples had been collected till Friday evening, of which nine are positive and 487 are negative. Results of 45 are awaited, while three got rejected.

CHART

Total samples collected: 544

Negative: 487

Positive: 9

Results awaited: 45

Rejected: 3

Title: LPG agencies start supplying cylinders in tempos in Wanowrie
Content: PUNE: Many residents in the Wanowrie area had been out with LPG cylinders to justify their movement on roads.To resolve this problem, the Wanowrie police on Thursday held meetings with LPG gas agencies, instructing them to supply cylinders in small tempos in lanes and bylanes of the affected areas to dissuade people from coming out of their homes.The agencies started supplying cylinders from Friday. “We held meetings with gas agencies from HPCL, BPCL and Indane and requested them to supply cylinders in small tempos at places including Wanowrie Bazaar Sayyednagar , Handewadi and Kalepadal from Thursday,” inspector Salim Chaus from the Wanowrie police said.“Check posts were set up on March 25, to prevent people from travelling on roads, barring those in emergency cases. We have found that many people have been carrying empty cylinders on the pretext of refilling it,” he said.He said, “As per the procedure, gas cylinders are required to be booked online. The people have been transporting empty cylinders and returning home without refilling it after travelling to various parts of the city.”He said they had sensitized people about the government directives issued because of the novel coronavirus outbreak. “We have appealed to them to maintain social distance and step out of the house in emergency situations, but most of them are not listening. We have filed cases against around 12 individuals under Section 188 of the IPC for violating orders issued under Section 144 of the CrPC,” he said.A resident from Sayyednagar said, “We have to travel for various reasons but the police are restricting our movement at check posts. We then started travelling with cylinders because there was no fear of police intercepting us. There is also no fear of cylinders being stolen because they are so heavy.”A resident from Wanowrie Bazaar said, “Citing emergency reasons such as refilling cylinder or showing old medical prescriptions helped us cross the check posts. Otherwise, it is not possible because the police has been strictly monitoring movement on the roads.”

Title: Villagers show Bhubaneswar the way in maintaining hygiene
Content:
BHUBANESWAR/ANGUL: While police have to be on their toes to ensure that lockdown is clamped in cities, villages have taken in up themselves to restrict the entry of outsiders into their areas, all in a bid to stop the unkown enemy — the novel coronavirus.

The educated and urban city dwellers may not always maintain the desired hygiene level in this hour of crisis, but the residents of remote villages in Balangir and Subarnapur districts are setting an example by ensuring the same without waiting for the police and district administration officials.

As one were to enter these villages, one will find check-gates like the ones set up in an army base. There are villagers manning these gates on shifts and they make sure that no outsider enters their area. Even the villagers who return from a vegetable market have to explain as to where they had gone and who all they met. After they are allowed in, they are offered soap and water that has been kept in a bucket for washing hands.

“Be it Jarasingha or Gaibahal villagees in Balangir district and Binka and Khaliapali villages in Subarnaapur district , the villagers have made it a point to screen people and then let them in. Initially, it was not easy to implement it. Many villagers would find it odd to get screened. For them, it was also odd to wash hands and enter the village. But the appeal of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister Naveeen Patnaik worked to a great extent,” said Jarasingha Sarpanch Kushadhwaja Meher

The villages, which now look deserted, inspired the neighbouring ones to implement similar restrictions. “The good thing is that the villagers have realized the magnitude of the problem and become self-motivated. We just had to make the logistics available for them so that they could implement the rules,” said Kanha Mishra, a resident of Binka.

Khaliapali village, which is known as the birthplace of saint poet Bhima Bhoi, now doesn’t allow any stranger to enter the village. The famous village usually witnesses tourists thronging to the religious site round the year. All the tourists coming in car or motorcycles are being asked to go back. The restriction will continue till middle of April. “If there is a need to extend it further, we will do so,” said Satyanarayna Pujhari, a villager. The villagers have collected money to buy soaps. At many places, the panchayats have taken initiative to provide the hand soap and bucket to store water.

Youths of Thakurgarh and Ranibandha villages in Angul district are allowing people into their villages only after proper investigation to prevent the spread of Covid-19. They have also put up a board, “Covid-19 Awareness. Entry restricted” at the entry to the villages.

“A person is allowed into the village only after sanitizing his hands at the check gate built on the outskirts of the village,” said Anin Charan Swain, president of Trinath Youth Union.

Title: Odisha: Youths guard entry to villages
Content: ANGUL: Youths of Thakurgarh and Ranibandha villages in Angul district are allowing people into their villages only after proper investigation to prevent the spread of Covid-19. They have also put up a board, “Covid-19 Awareness. Entry restricted” at the entry to the villages.“A person is allowed into the village only after sanitizing his hands at the check gate built on the outskirts of the village,” said Anin Charan Swain , president of Trinath Youth Union. The youths are also maintaining a register of those who either want to go out of the village on some urgent work or want to enter the village. Those suspected of violating government guidelines are barred from entering the village.Pradeep Sahu, member of the association, said this campaign would continue till the end of the lockdown. But people in urban areas continue to be reckless and can be seen moving around in motorcycles.Angul police have so far registered cases against 36 people and seized 21 motorcycles for violating rules in connection with the lockdown. Collector (Angul) Manoj Kumar Mohanty told TOI, “We have taken steps to protect people and curb the spread of Covid-19. We have appealed to people to stays indoors and come out only for basic necessities.” Currently, 56 people are on home quarantine.

Title: Testing times ahead with stores fast running out of provisions in Pune
Content:
Shelves lie bare, grocery crunch felt

PUNE: Shelves and aisles across multiple grocery stores and super markets in the city have run dry amid lack of fresh supply in the wake of the 21-day nationwide lockdown triggered by the Covid-19 spread.

Wanowrie resident Sakshi Jain said, “I had stepped out to buy some groceries on Friday. The fruit section of the grocery shop I visited was shut. Vegetables were available but were of poor quality. Coffee powder wasn’t available either. I tried to visit other stores as well but the entire market, including grocery stores, is shut at Jagtap Chowk.”

Similar was the case on Satara Road. “Several food products are not available in the Satara Road area. Even to get milk, one needs to step out either very early in the morning or late in the evening,” Purva Sankhla, a resident of Satara Road, rued.

NIBM Road, Kondhwa and their surrounding areas are among the worst affected, with shelves at most shops almost bare. Residents from the area said there was a shortage of milk powder, butter, cooking oil, biscuits, pulses and grains.

According to the owner of Chandradeep Stores, Ramesh Rathod , noodles, tetrapak milk, packaged frozen chicken, dry snacks, flour, honey, disinfectants and other cleaning agents have almost disappeared from shop shelves in several parts of the city. “Many brands selling these products have warehouses in Pune, but the stock is not reaching shops due to logistical issues and staff crunch,” he said.

Distributor of FMCG products Sham Mundada said, “Stocks of several items across the city have started depleting. We are still trying to figure a way to resume operations.”

Title: Close watch on home-quarantined people who returned from Mumbai, Pune
Content: KOLHAPUR: District guardian minister Satej Patil on Friday said that they are keeping a close eye on 41,000 odd people who returned to their native places in the district from Mumbai and Pune.“We are keeping a close eye on them as it has been almost a week now since their return, and, if anyone carries any kind of symptoms, it will start to develop now. We will heave a sigh of relief only when they are told to be safe and safely pass the quarantine period of 14-days,” he told TOI.He said that the administration is on high alert after two positive patients from the district were identified on Thursday night.According to Patil, they are planning to shift all the existing patients admitted to the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Rugnalaya (CPR) to private hospitals so that CPR could be entirely used for Covid-19 patients.Patil told the citizens not to panic. “We can get over with this as long as everybody gives extends their support to the administration.”“Many private hospitals and staff members are helping us along with the government staff members. I can assure you that we are fully prepared to tackle this virus,” he said.Minakshi Gajbhiye, dean of Rajarshi Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj Government Medical College and CPR, said that a male patient who has tested positive for Covid-19 had a travel history from Pune.“We had sent his swab sample to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune on March 25, the results of which were received on March 26, confirming the infection. We have immediately put all his close contacts under institutional quarantine. We have also sent around 30 swab samples to NIV for testing,” she said.According to Gajbhiye, in view of current situation, the administration is working on increasing the number of isolation beds and the quarantine facilities in the city.She said that the TB ward in CPR, which was lying unused, has been renovated and a 25-bed isolation facility will be made available in the ward soon.“With this, we will have the institutional quarantine facility as well as a ward for Covid-19 positive patients,” she said.State minister of health Rajendra Patil-Yadravkar said that the administration is trying hard for setting up of a testing lab in Miraj so that it can help in detetcting positive cases in Sangli and Kolhapur regions.Meanwhile, Kolhapur Municipal Corporation commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti said that disinfection activity was organised in the morning and residents in the said area were asked to strictly adhere to home quarantine.

Title: Kolhapur administration approaches private hospitals for making infrastructure available
Content: KOLHAPUR: As the number of coronavirus suspects is increasing, the district administration has approached private hospitals for making available necessary infrastructure for institutional quarantine of the suspects.Currently, two people in the district have been infected with the virus and many who came in their contact are being screened. There is a possibility of increase in the number of infected patients that have been compulsorily sent to institutional quarantine.The administration has made available 112 beds in various facilities and screening of people with travel history is being carried out. Over 1,000 people have been found and asked to stay home quarantined for 14 days.District collector Daulat Desai said, “We are going to bring the suspects, who are developing symptoms, to the quarantine facility. We have approached private hospitals and aim to create around 900 isolation beds with ventilator facilities. Private doctors have also assured help in case emergency occurs.”Meanwhile, the district administration has assured the general practitioners to start the out-patient departments as complaints are coming from patients for opening the clinics. Doctors too have shut their clinics in fear of infection of coronavirus.A senior district official said, “We have spoken to the doctors. They can take necessary precautions such as social distancing and ask patients to wear masks. The home quarantined people have mark on their hand and such patients can be asked to refer to the public hospitals.”The doctors have claimed there is shortage of masks and disinfectants in the market and suggested the administration to provide personal protective equipment (PPE). The district authorities maintained that the PPE will be provided to the doctors in the quarantine wards and screening centresThe doctors also maintained that they are refraining from going out to their clinics due to lockdown. They have been assured by the district authorities a travel-pass for the 21-day lockdown period.Patients in the rural areas are queuing up to the primary health centres that are short of doctors and nursing staff.

Title: Cong: CM inept, guv should dismiss him
Content: Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant has proved to be inept in handling the lockdown necessitated by coronavirus and should step down, Congress said on Friday.Sawant, said the party, ignored the Union home ministry’s guidelines and also failed to provide safety equipment for doctors and nurses.In a press statement, state Congress president Girish Chodankar said if Sawant did not resign, governor Satya Pal Malik should dismiss the chief minister and take over administration of the state.“The chief minister who calls himself a doctor has no right to continue in his chair as he has completely failed to provide health care to the people and has pushed the entire state into a probable ‘ corona destination’. He should apologise to the people of Goa for calling them anti-social elements,” Chodankar said.Congress said despite the Union home ministry issuing clear guidelines to keep the essential commodities shops open, Sawant ordered the closure of grocery stores.

Title: DGP: Police to allow free movement of goods vehicle
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Amid reports of police high-handedness during the lockdown, the Odisha police headquarters on Friday guaranteed free movement of inter and intra-state goods vehicles. “We welcome all trucks and other goods vehicles from other states to Odisha. There is no restriction on the movement of goods vehicles in the state,” director general of police Abhay said. “If a transporter or driver faces difficulty, they can contact on our helpline number - 0674-2620200 for immediate assistance,” he added.

The state has so far reported three coronavirus positive cases. To prevent shortage of essential commodities, the transport department too shared a similar statement. “Goods vehicles, including essential, non-essential and loaded or empty, can move freely throughout the state, including Bhubaneswar and Cuttack. The drivers do not need to show vehicles passes,” state transport commissioner Sanjeeb Panda said. On Thursday, the state government directed the district collectors and SPs to ensure that the goods vehicles are not stopped anywhere in the state and drivers not harassed. “We have asked collectors, SPs and regional transport officers to ensure that the drivers and helpers get access to the basic facilities on highways,” an official of the regional transport office said.

Title: 34,000 messages in four days & counting, SEVA cell operates round-the-clock in Pune
Content:
SEVA cell personnel of the city police address queries of people and issue digital permits to commute in case ... Read More

PUNE: In the four days since the Pune police released four WhatsApp numbers for citizens’ enquiries, the SEVA cell has fielded more than 34,000 requests.

The four numbers are being operated by 12 police officers and constables round the clock, who deal with various requests for permission to commute in case of an exigency, or various enquiries related to the Covid-19 lockdown.

Deputy commissioner of police (crime) Bachchan Singh said they were issuing permissions only for valid requests from the jurisdiction of the Pune police. “We are issuing digital permissions to those who need to visit hospitals, etc. Some people message for trivial things, which are being denied categorically. Similarly, people from areas outside Pune police jurisdiction, like Pimpri Chinchwad and rural Pune, also send messages, but we don’t respond to those,” Singh said.

“Each WhatsApp number is monitored by a group of four constables,” inspector Shilpa Chavan of the SEVA cell told TOI. “This allows them some respite, as messages pour in every minute. We have responded to 80% of the messages by granting or denying permission on a case-by-case basis. We don’t respond to trivial requests,” Chavan added.

She said most of the requests are for those seeking to go to the hospital or buy medication. “People suffering from cancer, heart ailments or other serious problems get permission in a minute,” she said.

Chavan said special attention is given to elderly couples or senior citizens live alone. “In such cases, We have asked the local police stations to help them out by fetching essentials or medicines. We have also issued permissions for the movement of elderly citizens’ home nursing attendants,” she said.

The WhatsApp numbers have also received requests from students staying in hostels, seeking help to get food, permission to go to the mess or any place they can get food.

“However, there are also annoying messages, such as where one can find vegetables, groceries and other items, or seeking permission to go to petrol pumps. We ignore all such messages,” Chavan said.

Initially, the constables had used response templates to reply to the requests. But soon, it took too much time and the volume of messages pouring in just increased. So they resorted to replying with just “yes” or “no”, as the case may be. One constable said messages arrive in such large numbers that it sometimes becomes difficult to respond to them all quickly. “We use the laid-down norms and our reasoning to permit people to venture out onto the streets,” he said.

Where, necessary, some requests not covered by the norms are also granted on humanitarian grounds.

A woman constable said, “There was no provision in the earlier rules for animal-feeding. And we received many messages from people from across the city, seeking permission to go out and feed stray cats or dogs. We gave them permission.”

The flow of messages never lets up, the constables said. “If we take even a little time off to drink water or use the washroom, about 500-1,000 messages pile up,” a constable said.

Title: Grocery prices to normalise next week
Content: Jaipur: Due to crunched and delayed supply, the prices of flour, edible oil, ghee and other items, were increased in retail stores across the city.The retailers complained that they are neither getting timely supply nor the quantity of items they are asking their wholesalers to send. Since panic buying has been stopped, retailers are expecting the prices to be normal from next week onwards.TOI on Friday visited many areas in the city and found that there has been a rise in the prices of food items and also variations in the prices in various stores.A good brand of flour which was available at Rs 310 per 10 kg to Rs 325 per kg was being sold in Rs 350 to Rs 400 at many stores across the city. Likewise, a known brand of desi ghee, which was sold at Rs 510 to Rs 550, was being sold at Rs 580 to Rs 600 per kg, refined oil prices which were around Rs 80 to Rs 100 per kg is been sold at Rs 90 to Rs 100 per kg.At many places, retailers who were giving 10 to 20% discounts on Fast Moving Consumer Goods are now selling at maximum retail price printed on it. “The dealers are not sending us the goods and while we insist they are overcharging. Earlier, their salesmen used to come. But post lockdown we are visiting them, paying them in cash and still they are overcharging,” said Manohar Lal, who has a grocery store at Vaishali Nagar.Many stores are out of stock with things like disinfectants, potato chips, tomato sauce, pulses, biscuits and other things like noodles. “Day-by-day the supply is improving. We hope to get our store re-filled by the first week of April. Also, the authorities should intervene to check the over-pricing by wholesale dealers,” said Sarvesh Goyal, a retail grocery store owner at Khatipura Road said.

Title: Ambulance driver blames Pimpri Chinchwad police for father’s death
Content:
A policeman raises his lathi at two scooter- borne men carrying a cylinder

PUNE: The Pimpri Chinchwad police on Friday decided to conduct an inquiry into the allegations levelled by an ambulance driver about police high-handedness at the Urse toll post while carrying a patient and his relatives from Mumbai to Ahmednagar, leading to his father’s death.

The inquiry would be conducted based on a video showing the driver narrating the alleged police excesses that has been brought to the notice of the police higher-ups and the fact that a case of accidental death was registered by the Shikrapur police.

Pimpri Chinchwad’s additional commissioner of police Ramnath Pokale said, “We have received information about the matter. We shall inquire into the allegations. To ascertain the exact cause of death, we are waiting for the post-mortem report.”

As of now, apart from the accidental death, no FIR has been registered. Nor the ambulance driver has lodged a written complaint. The post-mortem was to be conducted at the Sassoon General Hospital on Friday night.

In the video, the ambulance driver, Nilesh Shinde, claimed that the police stopped his vehicle at the Urse toll post around 12.30pm on the suspicion that he was ferrying passengers. Shinde claimed that he and his father Naresh Shinde (49), sitting in the passenger’s seat next to him, told the police that they were carrying a patient and his relatives from Mumbai to Ahmednagar, but the policemen did not listen to them.

Shinde claimed that while he and his father were pleading the policemen to let them go, one of the policemen abused him, while another hit his father with a stick. He claimed in the video that the police asked him to pay Rs5,000 but later allowed them to go after taking Rs 3,000.

“After driving about 15km from Urse, my father suddenly fell unconscious. I took him to few hospitals nearby. But no one admitted him. At last, a private hospital in Shikrapur allowed us in. But doctors declared my father dead on arrival,” Shinde said.

He claimed that had hospitals near Chakan treated his father, the latter could have been saved.

Shikrapur police inspector Sadashiv Shelar said, “We have registered a case of accidental death and sent it to the Shirgaon police under the Pimpri Chinchwad commissionerate for further probe. It was not clear if there were patients in the ambulance.”

Title: Man arrested for attacking fuel station contractor in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A fuel station contractor (38) suffered a serious head injury after a motorcycle-borne man (27) hit him with a stone following a dispute over refusal to refuel the bike at a petrol pump near RTO Chowk around 9.30am on Thursday.

The Bund Garden police arrested the customer, Dawood Guddu Nadaf from Tadiwala Road, on the charge of causing grievous hurt. He was released on bail on Friday.

The complainant, Pramod Kadam from Mangalwar Peth, is a cleanliness and maintenance contractor at the fuel station. “Nadaf arrived at the fuel station on a bike and picked up an argument with the staffers after they refused to dispense fuel,” investigating officer Naushad Momin from the Bund Garden police said.

“Kadam intervened and tried to pacify Nadaf by saying that as per the state’s directives, fuel would be supplied to only government vehicles and those on emergency duty,” Momin said. As the argument continued, Nadaf picked up a stone and hit Kadam on his head.

“Nadaf was arrested soon after the incident,” the officer said.

Title: Lapse in communication spread the infection in Sangli family
Content: KOLHAPUR: The total number of people infected with coronavirus from a single family in Islampur , near Sangli, went up to 24 with another 12 members testing positive on Friday.District collector Abhijeet Chaudhary told TOI how the lapse in communication led to 23 positive cases in a single-family and and one positive case in Kolhapur “Four members of a family, originally from Islampur, returned from Saudi Arabia and landed at the Chhatrapati Shivaji International airport on March 14. On landing at the Mumbai airport, they were neither given stamps for home-quarantine, nor was the information passed on to the Sangli district administration,” said Chaudhary.He added, “Had the authorities been informed, we could have averted the infection from spreading by issuing the necessary guidelines to the family, which now has unintentionaly infected the members living in close contact.”The four people, who were living with their joint family, started showing symptoms on March 18. They were admitted to the isolation ward at Miraj Government Medical College on March 19. On March 23, their swab samples tested positive for the contagion.Chaudhary said that the family members, who came in close contact with the four infected patients, were strictly advised home-quarantine. “However, they did not follow the guidelines of social distancing and inadvertently, the infection was passed on,” he said.After March 23’s revelation, as many as seven samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune. Five of the sample confirmed positive to the infection on March 25. At this point, the district administration put as many as 27 family members under institutional quarantine at Islampur. On Thursday, three more positive cases were reported from the same family two of which were from Islampur and one was a woman relative from Pethwadgaon in Kolhapur district. As on Thursday, 12 people from the same family had tested positive for the contagion.Chaudhary said that the 12 patients who tested positive on Friday would be transferred to Miraj civil hospital, where the previous 12 cases were being treatedNow, Islampur remains under the close watch of the district administration with the area which the positive patients being heavily cordoned with six entry and exit points. As many as 500 homes nearby ave been strictly asked to observe home quarantine. The health department is surveying the area to curb the spread of the infection.

Title: Health emergency declared in Bhatkal
Content: KARWAR: Bhatkal on Friday became the first town in Karnataka where health emergency was declared in view of the Covid-19 crisis Uttara Kannada deputy commissioner Harish Kumar K issued the order till further notice in the areas under Bhatkal Town Municipality Council , Jali taluk panchayat, Shirali, Hebale, Shirali, Mavinkurve, Mundalli, Yalvadikavoor and Muttalli gram panchayats.Kumar said the district is threatened by Covid-19 and it is necessary to take effective measures to prevent its spread. “There is a need for consistency in the application and implementation of various measures across the district while ensuring maintenance of essential services and supplies, including health infrastructure,” he said.A small town, Bhatkal has one of the highest numbers of Covid-19 suspect cases in the state. It has a large number of people returning from Gulf countries.Bhatkal has recorded three Covid-19 positive cases. While two patients are undergoing treatment in Bhatkal, and one in Mangaluru . Kumar said the two patients in Bhatkal will be shifted to the INS Patanjali Hospital in Karwar.Meanwhile, the navy has made arrangements for some beds for Covid-19 cases at INS Vajrakosh, the facility it uses to store armament and an isolated area SP Shivaprakash Devaraju said police are acting with utmost restraint in the district, violators of lockdown rules will not be spared. “From Friday onwards, cases will be filed against violators, he said.

Title: Many states, many kinds of passes. What works?
Content:
People queue up to take the curfew passes at DCP office amid the lockdown due to coronavirus, in New Delhi on ... Read More

With only those employed in essential services or facing emergencies allowed to commute on city roads and highways during the lockdown, state governments are struggling to find the best mechanism to ensure this. From the experience so far, it looks like issuing and using e-passes are simpler than physical passes. Also, decentralising the issuing process as much as possible appears to be the way forward. Another simple way is to focus on ID cards issued by respective organisations.

E-passes

Delhi has introduced e-passes for those involved in the manufacture, transport, and storage of essential items. Requests can also be made on phone. Though 10,000 e-passes have been issued in the last two days, 50,000 are still pending, so huge is the demand. Karnataka has decided to go for e-passes after first introducing physical passes that clogged the system. Haryana has an online application process for emergency passes during the lockdown.

Coronavirus lockdown: Latest updates

Company ID cards/uniforms

In Kerala and West Bengal , ID cards issued by respective organisations are accepted from those who are part of essential services. In Hyderabad, delivery boys need only to wear their uniforms. Other than them, those in essential services need to mail their names after which authorities examine and issue physical passes.

Kerala also has self-declaration forms for emergencies like hospital visits, but they were initially misused.

Physical passes

Almost all other states and UTs use this. Punjab , Haryana (those who cannot use an e-pass) and Karnataka gave the responsibility of issuing passes to deputy commissioners. It proved chaotic everywhere. In Mohali, the authorities ran out of printed slips in a day. Across Punjab, different DCs are handling it in different ways, leading to further chaos.

In Mumbai, the system of physical passes is working well. In Nagpur, as of Thursday, 13,500 passes were issued from different police stations.

In Tamil Nadu , ID cards will be issued to those moving essential commodities and to farmers by district collectors. The process has just begun. Vehicles will also need a self-declaration sticker. In UP, district administration officials are issuing passes to essential staff and farmers.

In MP, passes are being issued by local police stations. In Jabalpur, passes were initially issued through the district collectorate, but the rush was such that it was handed down to the local police stations.

More on Covid-19

Coronavirus pandemic: Complete Coverage

21-day lockdown: What will stay open and what won't

How to quarantine yourself at home

Trust the newspaper for your daily verified news

Title: Citizens across Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad take the lead, help police with food and water
Content:
Residents of a society near Sinhagad Road visit Haveli police station with packets of food

PUNE: A number of citizens across Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad are providing food, water and other essentials to policemen manning the roads. Food packets, dry snacks and water are being distributed among on-duty policemen at checkpoints, chowkies and police stations.

Jai Ganesh Group from Kachi Ali in Guruwar Peth has been serving breakfast to policemen in and around Swargate for the last 4-5 days. “Our wives cook the food at home and we go out to deliver. Six of us go to deliver on different days in rotation. So far, we have prepared and served poha, idli sambar, upma, and other snacks. We have sought permission from the police to distribute food between 8.30am and 12.30pm,” said Chetan Lodha .

Lodha added that the initiative took root because the group wanted to do something for the police. “After serving the police, if we have any food leftover, we serve it with tea to employees of petrol pumps and street dwellers,” he added.

Apulki Group from Sinhagad Road has also been engaged in delivering snacks and water to the police personnel on duty. “The police personnel are standing at assigned checkpoints for a long duration. They hardly go home. While they do carry tiffin, if they get hungry again, they may have nothing to eat. We are distributing dry snacks like chakli, chivda, shankarpali, biscuits, wafers, pedha, barfi, chikki, and many other items, among the personnel,” explained Sameer Rupade , coordinator of Apulki Group.

The group delivers the eatables to 12 checkpoints, three police chowkies and one police station along Sinhagad Road. “We have been distributing the snacks for three days. On Friday, we distributed 700-800 water bottles. We are also providing garbage bags to the personnel to dispose the waste,” said Rupade.

A policeman on duty at Dange Chowk in Chinchwad said, “Several people give us tea, biscuits and snacks on a daily basis. They also feed the municipal workers if there are any in the area. We are thankful to such persons and organisations, who are providing for us.”

Title: Procure chilli, maize from farmers: Cong
Content:
Hyderabad: Congress on Friday demanded that the government immediately make arrangements to procure thousands of tonnes of chilli , maize and other agricultural produce from the farmers.

“The procurement of a large number of agricultural products mainly the chilli, maize needs to be commenced urgently. Farmers are waiting to sell their produce. “Unseasonal rain at this juncture before the government procures it, will damage chilli and maize, causing huge loss to the farmers,” Sampath Kumar said in an e-mail to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao.

Though the farmers want to sell their agriculture produce, they are not able to do it due to the lockdown. There are no goods and transport vehicles also and market yards in towns have been closed, Kumar said.

While welcoming the decision of the government to offer Rs 1,500 each to white rationcard holders for purchase of essential commodities, he urged the CM to enhance the grant.

Title: Police foil woman’s suicide bid
Content:
Vijayawada: Police prevented a 32-year-old divorcee’s suicide bid at Prakasam Barrage in the city on Friday.

The woman was identified as A Ramadevi from Vizianagaram district.

According to One-Town police, the incident happened at 10 am when the woman stood near the railing of the bridge. Upon observing her suspicious behavior through CCTV footage, the cops rushed to the spot and realised that she was trying to commit suicide.

The cops said she had divorced her husband and was living alone in Vijayawada. Recently, she had lodged a harassment complaint against a youth identified as Badri.

Relentless in his pursuit, once out on bail, he threatened to kill her.

The cops said that the woman decided to take the extreme step fearing for her life. The police took her to One-Town police station to let her lodge a fresh complaint against him. The woman has two children and is working in a private company.

Title: Pimpri Chinchwad: Three from PCMC areas return home after full recovery
Content:
Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Applause rang out on Friday morning for the first three Covid-19 patients from Pimpri Chinchwad who left for their homes after they were discharged from Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial Hospital in Pimpri.

Doctors, nurses and the staff cheered as the ambulance ferrying them left the hospital’s premises.

The three patients are among a batch of 40 people who had returned from Dubai around March 1. Earlier, another couple was discharged in the Pune Municipal Corporation limits.

“The three patients were undergoing treatment in the isolation ward of the YCM hospital. Their first and the second swab reports were negative enabling their discharge. They will be in home quarantine for the next 14 days,” Namdev Dhake , BJP leader in Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation , said.

So far, 12 Covid-19 patients were reported from Pimpri Chinchwad till Thursday. Nine patients are in isolation. No new cases were added on Friday, making it the seventh such day without a fresh Covid-19 case.

The civic body on Friday said 1,342 people in Pimpri Chinchwad are in 14-day home quarantine after they returned from abroad or came in contact with the 12 positive cases.

The throat swabs of 157 persons of the 183 who were tested are negative and the results of the others were awaited.

Over 4.78 lakh people have been surveyed by a team of 244 civic and health officials for their age, current health condition and travel history across Pimpri Chinchwad.

Title: These women cops in Bhopal take coronavirus challenge in their stride
Content:
DSP Richa Jain

BHOPAL: Three probationer women DSPs, recently posted as SHOs at three city police station, are working shoulder-to-shoulder with their male peers for 15-16 hours daily ever since the lockdown came into force.

Speaking to TOI, DSP Richa Jain, posted at Chunabhatti police station, said, “I reach police station by 7 am and work late till midnight. In the morning, we focus basically on ensuring milk and vegetable supply. The grocery shops and medical shops open around 10 am and we focus on maintaining social distancing among customers. We ensure that not more than three people gather outside a shop. We got white circles drawn outside shops for social distancing. We help grocery traders when they go out to purchase items from wholesale traders. I personally go to various areas and appeal them to stay at home.. I and other police staff distribute food packets in the area to needy people.”

On challenges being faced in personal life after lockdown, DSP Richa said, “I got married a year back and my husband DSP Akshay Choudhary is posted in Raisen. We have not got time to talk to each other properly ever since the lockdown has been enforced.”

DSP Shivali Chaturvedi, posted as SHO Sukhi Sewania, said, “I have been working for around 16-17 hours. I have to remain active so as not to miss any instructions of senior officers being broadcast on wireless set. It takes around an hour for me to reach police station so I leave for work around 6 am. Before leaving I have to prepare my food as I have sent my brother and sister, who resided with me to Chhatarpur, my native town. I leave for work around 6 am after preparing my own lunch. We have contacted companies located in the area and asked them to distribute food packets to many needy people from villages including daily wage workers, under their CSR activity. My day goes in patrolling the jurisdiction area and I work late till 12.30 to 1 am. We spread awareness among people that lockdown is for their own safety and appeal them to remain at home.”

DSP Antima Samadhia, posted as SHO Eintkheri said, “I reside in a room above the police station itself so I start my day early at 6 am with patrolling in the area. Around 9 am I brief the police station staff on their duty and after attending the radio talk with senior officers I go out on patrol in the area. My family resides in my native town Shivpuri and my younger brother and sister reside in Bhopal. Earlier I used to visit them daily, but now I just talk to them over phone. The villagers in my jurisdiction area are worried for their cropsas it is raining so enforcing lockdown has become a challenge. Many daily wage workers,approach Eintheri police station seeking help. I contacted the village Sarpanch and arranged for their food under the mid-day meal scheme.”

Title: Finland return man, 14-month-old toddler test negative in Kolhapur
Content: KOLHAPUR: A 32-year-old man, who recently returned from Finland, and a 14-month-old toddler — admitted to the isolation ward on Thursday — have tested negative for Covid-19 Amod Gadikar, district civil surgeon (Satara), said the man was admitted to the isolation ward as precautionary measure owing to his travel history. “However, the toddler and his family member did not come in contact with any Covid-19 infected people nor do they have any travel history,” he said.Earlier, Satara had registered its first Covid-19 positive case on March 23, the same day when four positive cases came to light from Sangli district The first patient from Satara was a 45-year-old woman who had returned from Dubai on March 22. The second patient, a 63-year-old man, was identified on March 24. He had come back from California. His wife was also tested for Covid-19 but the result came negative.Meanwhile, Shekhar Singh , Satara district collector, in his recent order instructed all sugar mills to arrange basic needs of their employees along with those involved in cane crushing.He has asked the mills to provide them with masks, sanitizers, soaps, along with provision for their meals and transportation and accommodation facility.In his other order, he has asked private hospitals, pharmacies, and other medical establishments to function as usual. He said it is mandatory for these individuals and establishments to function normally or they can face action under the Disaster Management Act, 2005.

Title: Locality cordoned off, Kolhapur residents fear water supply, essentials will be cut
Content: KOLHAPUR: The police have cordoned off the locality in Mangalwar Peth where the first Covid-19 case was reported in the city.More restrictions are being placed in the area and the movement of people has been regulated. The police have sought details of each family and will only allow one person per family to go out to buy essentials. A senior policeman said that guidelines from the state government regarding the procedure to be followed have been received.Fearing the spread of infection, areas have closed the roads leading to Mangalwar Peth.The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation KMC ) has begun disinfection of the locality and nearby areas. Earlier, disinfection was only carried out in public spaces.Local residents are worried that essential supplies to their societies will stop.One society has written to the civic administration asking for assurance of adequate water supply. The residents say they depend on water tankers as the KMC’s water supply is poor and now they fear that water tanker suppliers will not send tankers to the locality.“We have old people and more than 30 children in the society,” said a resident requesting anonymity. “The water supply by the KMC is not regular. The issue has been pending with the water supply department for several years. Now, with the Covid-19 positive case being reported, many people are being screened and we are likely to face inconvenience. We also fear the supply of milk will stop. We can get out to buy milk pouches but water tankers may not arrive,” he said.

Title: Sanskruti Foundation dreams of beggar and ‘beghar’ free Nagpur
Content:
Nagpur: ‘Let’s go home, this is not where you belong.’ These words, uttered each time by Sakshi Kshirsagar, a criminal lawyer, whenever she finds a beggar or homeless person on the streets of city spell hope. In the shelter home run by her ‘Sanskruti Foundation’, these homeless people not only get a roof, food and water, but also love, care and humanity.

A dream come true, is what Kshirsagar says of her work as she recalls how she began her journey. She used to see beggars, especially the elderly ones, begging in the scorching heat of Nagpur and her heart would break. She eventually decided to invest all her hard work and passion in creating ‘Sanskruti Foundation’.

“Whenever I saw beggars on road, I would feel guilty at not being able to help them. While I was completing my law studies, I promised myself I will make a home for them with the little resources that I have,” said Kshirsagar.

It started in 2012. She had a small place where they used to run the ‘Home’ as she calls it, in Sitabuldi for five years. Her vision has always been clear, ‘End homelessness’. This foundation is transforming the life of homeless by resolving problems in their life and bring them into mainstream of society.

After endless struggle of finding a proper place that will feel like home, in 2017, the Foundation got a closed NMC school and Urban Homeless Shelter Home at Hansapuri Primary School for Nagpur City Homeless and Distressed People was born.

Nitesh Nagdeve joined hands with Kshirsagar as manager of the Foundation and has been its pillar since then. He has contributed in searching, convincing, and bringing these beggars to the foundation for over three years now. “It was never easy. Talking to beggars and helping them has always given me a sense of satisfaction. We strive hard to get their identity, hunt jobs for them and take care of their basic needs,” said Nagdeve.

The foundation has benefited over 347 homeless people. Also employment was provided to 48. They were also enrolled in social benefit schemes, given de-addiction treatment, education, skills and medical treatment. Kshirsagar aims to make Nagpur a “Beghar Free” city.

“As our city is developing each day, the homeless, distressed and beggar population needs attention. No homeless should ever be found in a developed city,” she said.

Kshirsagar’s study and knowledge of law helped her. She said it is very difficult to convince the homeless that they have come to help. “We have to show them pictures and proof that we can help them live a better life. Recently, we rescued an old man and gave him a haircut and a bath. He looked so happy. That’s my reward,” said Kshirsagar.

“Most homeless have skin allergies and live in poor condition. It is a very sorry sight. We do our best with them,” Nagdeve said.

The Foundation also provides free food for senior citizens and children above 14. It has TV, lockers, 100-bed facility . They take the inmates for movies and also try to find their families and identity, which is a tough job. “A study says more than 80% are addicted to alcohol, ganja, bidi , and tobacco chewing etc. So, we tied up with a de-addiction centre and are treating them,” said Kshirsagar.

Asked where she wants to see this foundation in future, she said, “I want my city to be beggar free. I will always work for these people, who have no family. I want to become their family and one day surely there will be no beggars and homeless people on our streets.”

Title: Odisha government asks officers not to hold Census meetings
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Days after the Centre postponed the Census and NPR updation process in view of the coronavirus outbreak, the state government on Friday asked all district collectors, who were designated as principal census officers to not hold any preparatory arrangement such as training and awareness activities in the state for the Census.

State revenue and disaster management secretary Pradipta Kumar Mohapatra has issued a direction to the district collectors in this regard.

Earlier, the state government had planned to conduct the house listing (first phase of Census) and updation of the National Population Register (NPR) from April 15 to May 31. The revenue department, which is the nodal department for the Census-related works, had already designated officers at the district, sub-division, tehsil and block-level to carry out the activities.

“The Centre has asked all the states to carry out the house listing and NPR updation in 45 days anytime between April to September. We had accordingly decided to carry out the process from April 15 to May 31. At the moment, it is not possible to conduct the training programme for the officials. Instructions have been given accordingly,” said a senior revenue department official.

As the entire state machinery has been directed towards the containment of Covid-19, chief minister Naveen Patnaik had on March 20 requested Prime Minister Narendra Modi to postpone the Census and NPR updation activities. tnn

Title: BMC asks food apps to deliver groceries in Mumbai
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

The BMC asked food delivery apps such as Zomato and Swiggy on Friday to tie up with local grocery stores and deliver items that Mumbaikars may require in wake of the lockdown.

Civic officials said the idea is to ensure that people do not step out. Besides, online grocery stores would be provided with essential services cards from police authorities so they face no hassles during delivery. The BMC also plans to develop a software to ascertain the ration demand for every area.

Title: Legislators chip in to ease burden
Content: Bengaluru: Bengaluru Central MP PC Mohan has released Rs 2 crore from his Member of Parliament Local Area Development (MPLAD) fund for purchase of emergency equipment for treatment of Covid-19 patients at Victoria Hospital.He also handed over a letter in this regard to chief minister BS Yediyurappa. The state government is preparing Victoria hospital complex with 1,700 beds for treating Covid-19 patients."Mohan has mentioned in his letter that the amount be utilised for emergency purchase of personal protection equipment kits, ventilators, N-95 respirators, surgical masks and other protective equipment required in ICUs," said a release from his office.Meanwhile, Bengaluru South MP Tejasvi Surya launched a Bengaluru South Coronavirus Task Force, in association with Bengaluru South and Bengaluru South East Division Police, to attend to the needs of senior citizens and vulnerable sections of the constituency."As part of the task force, Surya launched a helpline — 99464 99464 for citizens to avail assistance. The helpline will be able to assist senior citizens and the economically weaker sections procure food, groceries and medicines. It will also provide emergency non-Covid-19 medical assistance to citizens, especially pregnant women," a spokesperson from Surya’s office said.

Title: Pune: 50% dip in supply triggers sky-high vegetable prices, tomatoes at Rs 80/kg
Content:
Many vendors quoted abnormal prices

PUNE: Cashing in on 50% short supply, some unscrupulous elements are selling vegetables in the city at sky-high prices.

A resident tweeted on Friday, “A shop in Magarpatta City Pune is charging Rs300 for chilli. The vegetables are being sold at whatever the amount they (traders) want.”

The vegetable market in Gultekdi and the Shivaji market in Camp are shut at present. Retailers claimed that the supply of a bulk of vegetables like tomatoes, cauliflower and okra, which come from outside, were restricted because drivers transporting them did not have identity cards (ID) proving that they were a part of essential services. Against this backdrop, unauthorized sellers are thriving and selling vegetables at whatever price they wish.

A resident tweeted, “I have no fuel left in my scooter and so can’t even go to buy groceries and essentials. My local area shop is empty of rations and vegetables. Can I please get some fuel pass or grocery/veggies to my home in Gujarwadi?”

On Friday, some retail vegetable shops in Shivajingar sold onions at Rs70 per kg as against the price of Rs30 per kg three days ago. Tomatoes were sold at Rs80 per kg as against the price of Rs40 per kg three days ago.

Shankar Surve, a retailer in Shivaji market, Camp, said, “Vegetables are in short supply as a lot of transporters and sellers have not been able to procure the ‘essential services’ sticker for vehicles. The number of farmers getting the produce to the Gultekdi market is low because of police checks and lack of stickers or tags to move about unhindered for supplying essential goods like vegetables.”

Surve said the unwillingness of traders and sellers of Market Yard to resume operations before the month-end was worsening the situation. “Vegetables are only coming into the market from nearby places. Vegetables like tomatoes, cauliflower (comes from as far as Satara) okra and cabbage are thus in short supply. Shivaji market is closed right now but illegal sellers have started selling vegetables at a high price outside the market,” he said.

“Some vendors were selling chillies at Rs250 per kg outside Shivaji market on Friday morning,” he said.

Vitthal Hanamgar, another retailer on NIBM Road, said vegetables were over 80% short and the prices in the past few days had gone up by 25-30%. “My shop was closed last two days but on Friday, we managed to get some supplies from farmers directly,” he said.

Sunil Kumbharkar, the owner of a vegetable wholesale firm in Market Yard, said, “Truck loaders who get the produce from farmers to retail markets in Pune also need to get essential services tag from the police. Unless they get these tags, their movement will be restricted, and the supplies will remain low,” he said.

An official from Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) Pune said despite the Gultekdi Market being closed, a total of 120 trucks of vegetables (brought by farmers directly) came on Friday. “More supplies will come to Gultekdi from farmers on Sunday, as per our appeal to them. The traders and sellers of the market will resume operations from April 1,” he said.

Title: Two railway staffers felicitated
Content:
Rafiq Jusab making masks

Rajkot: The Bhavnagar division of the Western Railway (WR) on Friday awarded two of its employees for exceptionally good services in the times of coronavirus outbreak.

According to a release issued by the WR, Rafiq Jusab, who serves as a track maintainer, made 141 masks out of extra clothes from turbans and distributed them among the railway staff on Thursday.

WR also awarded trolly man Champak Heera who distributed sanitizers, masks and thermal guns among the railway staff on Wednesday and Thursday. TNN

Title: Corona on mind, India warns on bio weapons
Content:
NEW DELHI: The global economic and social implications of the pandemic, caused by Covid-19, have underlined the need for international cooperation, including institutional strengthening of WHO, said the government Friday. The assertion came in the context of India's reiteration of support to the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BWC) on the 45th anniversary of its coming into force.

"India reiterates the high importance that it has always attached to the BWC as the first global and non- discriminatory disarmament Convention, prohibiting an entire category of weapons of mass destruction. We give a high priority to its universalisation and full and effective implementation by all States Parties to it," said the government in a statement.

On the economic implications of Covid-19, the government said these had highlighted the need for strengthening cooperation amongst the "States Parties" to the BWC aimed at full and effective implementation of the Convention in all its aspects.

"India has been working with fellow ‘States Parties’ to establish an Article VII database which can play an important role in dealing with bio-threats and bio-emergencies," it said.

"As we approach the 9th Review Conference of the Convention in 2021, we reiterate our call for institutional strengthening of the Convention, including negotiation of a comprehensive and legally binding Protocol, providing for an effective, universal and non-discriminatory verification mechanism to strengthen the implementation of the Convention by ‘States Parties’, ensuring full compliance and deterring non-compliance with it," said the government.

India strongly believes, said the government, that the BWC must respond effectively to the challenges posed by the new and emerging scientific and technological developments of relevance to the Convention. India has been submitting an annual Resolution at the UN General Assembly on the "Role of science and technology in the context of international security and disarmament”, which has been adopted by consensus.

"India has also been highlighting the dangers from the possible use, in future, of micro-organisms as biological weapons by terrorists through its annual Resolution at the UN General Assembly, titled ‘Measures to prevent terrorists from acquiring the weapons of mass destruction’, which has been adopted, annually since 2002, by consensus," it said.

Title: Cops promote indoor competition to help people beat boredom
Content:
Rajkot: Surendranagar police have come out with an innovative way to encourage people to stay at home and beat their boredom at the same time.

Accoring to a statement issued by the Surendranagar district police, an array of activities have been organized as part of the indoor competitions which include drawing, decorative arts, wooden craft, embroidery, floral decoration, pottery, stone art, jewellery art, textile handicraft, origami, poetry, essay, short story etc.

These competitions will be open for those under 30 years of age. It will also be open for the prisoners who will have to write essays of their experiences in jail.

The contestants will have to submit their work on Surendranagar police control room’s WhatsApp number 9687690100 or via email to control-sp-srn@gujarat.gov.in. The contestants will have to give their names, address and their respective areas’ police stations, said the release.

The first, second and third prizes will be adjudged on the basis of best out of waste concept, added the release.

Title: Essentials on track: Another milk train leaves for Haryana
Content:
A goods train loaded with 6.90 lakh litres of milk has left for Palwel in Haryana on Friday.

AHMEDABAD: A goods train loaded with 6.90 lakh litres of milk has left for Palwel in Haryana on Friday. The railways have so far sent trains carrying 448 lakh litres of milk from Gujarat to Delhi and Haryana.

Officials said that the Indian Railways has stopped running passenger trains due to the national lockdown. The railways, however, has kept the supply of essential commodities running. On Friday, 6.90 lakh litres of milk in 16 RMT tank wagons were loaded from Palanpur and sent to Haryana.

Divisional railway manager (DRM) Deepak Kumar Jha said that the division was monitoring the situation and was ready to ensure that there was no shortage of transport for essential commodities.

Officials said two trains were sent earlier to other states loaded with Amul products. One went from Kankaria to Jhansi, and the other from Palanpur to Palwel. Western Railway officials said that 1,200 locomotive pilots and assistant locomotive pilots worked in goods trains on Monday across various divisions namely Ahmedabad, Vadodara, Rajkot, Bhavnagar, Mumbai and Ratlam.

Title: States step in to help lakhs of stranded
Content: MUMBAI: Three days after Prime Minister Narendra Modi declared a 21-day lockdown to halt the spread of coronavirus , the Maha Vikas Aghadi government led by Uddhav Thackeray has provided food and shelter to an estimated one lakh people stranded across the state.The lockdown announcement brought buses, trains and flights to a halt, leaving many stranded in the state, far away from home.Thousands of poor migrant workers who could not get a toehold in the last jam-packed train home found themselves staring at starvation. Many of them had worked construction or laboured at industries for daily wages. They were left with little money and no shelter.Konkan divisional commissioner Shivajirao Daund said preliminary reports indicated about 11,000 people were stranded at 67 locations in the seven districts of the coastal region of the state.Palghar had 1,700 stranded people, Thane 2,000, Mumbai district 3,000, Mumbai suburban district 2,000, and Raigad 2,000. Ratnagiri and Sindhudurg had the remaining few hundred. “We will provide them dry ration or cooked food and temporary shelter. We will ensure every stranded person gets food and shelter. Officials of the revenue department are working at the grass-root level to locate stranded people,” Daund said.Jalgaon collector Avinash Dhakne said besides employees of the revenue and other departments, he has roped in NGOs to provide food and shelter. “As of now, we have made arrangements for 5,000 stranded persons. Their arrangement has been made at mangal karyalayas (marriage halls) in the district. We are following social distancing norms. If more persons are located, we can make arrangements for them too,” Dhakne said.Akola collector Jeetendra Papalkar said the district administration had made arrangements for 500 persons. “We have made arrangements in municipal schools. Cooked food is from local NGOs. All officials have been asked to ensure no stranded person remains without food and shelter,” Papalkar said.A bureaucrat said the Centre had directed the state to make arrangements for the estimated one lakh stranded people. He said it would have been a difficult task if not for the response from NGOs. “All district collectors have been asked to find out the exact number of stranded persons, with their complete details, particularly the medical history,” he said.

Title: Chiranjeevi shares a picture of his 'morning duty' during the Coronavirus lockdown!
Content: Celebs around the world have been sharing pictures and videos of how they are spending their quarantine period at their homes through social media posts and South superstar Chiranjeevi is no different!The actor recently took to his Instagram to share a picture of himself watering the plants in his garden. In the photo, he can be seen wearing a brown t-shirt teamed with denim and shoes. He captioned the post, "my duty every morning #21daylockdown #StayHomeStaySafe"Check out the post here:Meanwhile, COVID-19 has brought the world to a standstill. As there is no cure for the disease, staying at home is the only way left to combat it and avoid the infection.On the work front, the shooting of Chiranjeevi's upcoming film has been put on hold due to lockdown. The film is helmed by Koratala Siva and backed by Ram Charan who also plays a crucial role in it.

Title: Builders, bizmen told to stop fleeing labourers
Content:
Labourers preparing to leave Rajkot city

Rajkot: Rajkot police commissioner Manoj Agrawal on Friday issued an order to all builders and factory owners to prevent migrant labourers working in their units from leaving the city.

The order was issued after thousands of labourers were seen returning to their natives on foot, leaving the city. “If a labourer is COVID-19 positive, he is likely to infect many others in his village when he reaches there. Keeping this in mind, the commissioner has issued the order,” said Agrawal.

Most of the migrant labourers working in Rajkot city and district are from Dahod, Godhra, Chhota Udepur and Jhabua and Alirajpur of Madhya Pradesh.

Agrawal told reporters: “The builders and factory owners have been asked to provide their labourers free food, boarding and lodging. If any builder or a factory owner is unable to do so, he may contact NGOs to provide the facilities. There are several NGOs in the city providing free food and other essential. If it is found that any builder or factory owner has asked his labourers to leave the city, he will be booked for the violation of the government’s lockdown order.”

For the citizens of Rajkot, the commissioner said that arrangements had been made to provide all essential commodities including vegetables, milk and grocery items at their doorsteps. “We have made public the list of medical store owners with their cellphone numbers who can provide medicines at the doorsteps of the citizens when called up,” said Agrawal.

“Apart from the vehicles of the government officials and the members of NGOs providing relief materials to the citizens, no vehicle will be permitted to ply on the roads,” the commissioner added.

Balram Meena, superintendent of police, Rajkot rural, has also issued a similar order to all the builders and factory owners of Rajkot district.

On Friday, thousands of migrant labourers were stopped leaving the city by the police at Greenland Chowkdi, Madhapar Chowkdi, Raiya Chowkdi, Gondal Road Chowkdi and Maliyasan. They were provided with meals and made to return to their sites and factories.

On Thursday, 1,000-odd labourers were seen on the roads in the city. They were caught and made to return to their respective sites and factories.

Title: Three migrants returning to native die in accident
Content:
Representative Image

PALANPUR: Three of the six labourers , who had hitch-hiked from Kamrej in Surat to go to their native in Rajasthan, were killed and two others injured when the truck in which they were travelling overturned near Mehsana town on Friday morning.

The accident took place about 4 km from Mehsana town near Mau toll plaza. The truck was loaded with sugar bags.

According to police, the labourers were leaving for their native in a truck as no other means of public transport was available due to the lockdown. The deceased were identified as Tararam Meghwal, Ramesh Meghwal, native of Danhrdi village in Rajasthan. The third deceased was from Palanpur, but is yet to be identified, said police.

In another accident, an SRP jawan Mukesh Rawal and his relative Kanti Rawal were killed after a speeding truck hit their motorcycle from behind near Deesa. Both died on the spot. They were coming from Dhanera and going towards Deesa. Mukesh was posted in Gundri village of Dhanera in Banaskantha district.

Kanti is resident of Bejwada village of Deesa. Both died on the spot

Title: West Bengal Corona news: 9-month-old tests positive in Bengal, could be country’s youngest patient
Content: Five members of an extended family — a nine-month-old girl, her six-year-old sister, their 27-year-old mother, and an 11-year-old boy and his 45-year-old mother — tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday, pushing up the total number of cases in Bengal from 10 to 15. Currently in an isolation facility in Nadia, all the patients are being brought to ID Hospital in Beliaghata The five returned to Tehatta on March 20 from Delhi. There, a group of 30 relatives, including the five, had met another relative who had returned from the UK on March 16. A local source said the group reached Sealdah station on March 20, from where they boarded another passenger train to Bethuadahari . From there, they reportedly took an auto home. “The five, who have tested positive, had all been in contact with a Covid-19 patient. So, the source is known,” said a health department official.

Title: Ambaji trust donates Rs 1.1cr to CM Relief Fund
Content:
Palanpur: To help strengthen the government’s plan to fight the deadly Covid-19, the Aarasuri Ambaji Mata Devasthan Trust (SAAMDT) Ambji donated a check of Rs 1.1 crore to the CM Relief Fund on Friday.

Talking to TOI, Banaskantha collector Sandip Sagle, who is also the chairman of the trust, said, “Our aim is to strengthen the government’s plan to fight the fatal disease and also provide food to the poor people.”

He further said that the Ambaji temple trust has always been on the forefront during such times of crisis and also expressed his hopes that more such donations will pour in to help the government defeat the fatal disease that has almost crippled the world.

Title: 11 desi firms rolling out body suits, masks for medics, public
Content: NEW DELHI: Eleven Indian firms, including garment manufacturers and healthcare companies, are now producing protective suits to be worn by healthcare workers at the frontline of Covid-19 fight while two others are churning out masks for public.To plug the gap in demand and supply of protective gear for coronavirus, the government has roped in small- and medium-scale manufacturers in the country. A senior official in the textile ministry told TOI that 11 firms are producing personal protective equipment (PPE) suits while two are providing masks, including N-95. The firms include Gujarat-based denim maker Arvind Mills, three from the garment hub of Tirupur in Tamil Nadu , and others from Ghaziabad , Gurugram, Bengaluru, Chennai and Kolkata.“Around five more firms will start manufacturing these items,” the official said. So far,10 lakh masks have been supplied since February second week. The firms have also produced 5,000 protective suits in two days. Officials said they are hoping to raise the supply of suits to 8,000 per day by March 30.The products are being procured by HLL, a government of India undertaking in Thiruvanthapuram , and are being distributed for free in government hospitals for staff and for public purchase in in government-run healthcare centres.

Title: Relief for farmers
Content:
Easing movement of farmers and those involved in harvest and procurement operations, the Centre on Friday granted them regulated exemption during the lockdown . It will be a huge relief to farmers who have to harvest their crops and sell it in ‘mandis’ (agri markets) and begin preparations for the next crop cycle.

The home ministry issued the order in the wake of demands from farmers as they could not afford to leave their Rabi (winter sown) crops in the field during the lockdown.

Title: US-returned quarantined woman booked
Content:
Rajkot: A woman who was home quarantined after returning from Chicago in the USA was booked on Friday after she went missing from her home in Kings Heights Apartments on Amin Marg Road in Rajkot since Thursday morning.

Police said the accused, identified as Eva Khanpara (20), had been put under home quarantine since March 17.

“We spoke to Eva’s father Sanjay Khanpara who said that Eva was with her family members in his village,” said J S Champavat, sub-inspector with Malaviyanagar police station.

“I forgot to ask the name of the village. However, once we find the location, we will go there and detain Eva and transfer her to the government quarantine,” said Champavat, adding that Eva had been booked for the violation of the government’s Epidemic Diseases Act of 1897.

Title: Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh acquire private hospitals to combat coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

INDORE/RAIPUR: With the Covid-19 outbreak showing no sign of abating, the Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh governments have invoked a British-era law to acquire private hospitals to battle the pandemic. The Indore administration took over two such hospitals on Friday. The commercial hub accounts for nearly half of the state’s 29 cases and one of two deaths.

“On the orders of collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav, Gokuldas Hospital and Vishesh Hospital have been acquired for treatment of Covid-19 infected patients,” said Indore chief medical officer Dr Pravin Jadia, adding that this was done under Epidemic Diseases Act 1897. The law was enacted on February 4, 1897, to battle a bubonic plague outbreak in Mumbai.

“We have a 60-bed treatment facility in state-run MRTB Hospital and a 150-bed quarantine in Jagadguru Dattatreya Hospital. The 450-bed MTH Hospital is being used as an isolation facility,” said the CMHO, adding that 18 private hospitals have been authorised to treat the disease.

“There is a difference between ‘authorising’ and ‘acquiring’ a private hospital for treatment of a disease. Private hospitals acquired by the administration will be dedicated only for treatment of a particular disease while authorised hospitals can treat other patients along with those of Covid-19,” explained Dr Jadia. Medical and other staff of private hospitals will be roped in. Neighbouring Chhattisgarh has acquired the privately owned Raipur Institute of Medical College.

Representative image

INDORE/RAIPUR: With the Covid-19 outbreak showing no sign of abating, the Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh governments have invoked a British-era law to acquire private hospitals to battle the pandemic.
